summary: "Amazing company and the most driven and smartest of the people"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
- You can learn a lot very quickly in a very short time
- Surrounded with nothing but incredibly smart and driven individuals.
- Compensation is well beyond my expectations, and more than suitable.
- Exciting projects all across the company that keep you interested and focused.
- Amazon is changing the world
cons:
- Can be overwhelming, very steep learning curve
- Can be difficult to keep up if you are not self motivated

main_text: I have been working at Amazon
pros: Amazon provides a tons of learning opportunities
cons: Work pressure in few teams

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros: Really smart people, a lot of opportunity for growth, always encouraged to be innovative, think big, and create something new. Competitive salary and benefits with other major tech companies. 100% self motivating work environment. No dress code and 4 legged friends are welcome.
cons: You have to be self motivated. NO ONE will hold your hand and tell you that you're doing a great job. If you need constant affirmations from management, this company isn't for you.
advice_management: More on-boarding training before new employees are thrown in the fire. The first couple of weeks can be very confusing on where to find the information you need that pertains to your job.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Jeff Bezos and his "S-Team" are brilliant and continue to make great decisions for long-term growth.  

You work with smart people, you work on exciting projects, you are pushed to your limits...which can be rewarding when you accomplish great things.  The diversity of the potential work and innovation can be very alluring.  I've often called Amazon my "Sexy Mistress...she's emotionally abusive, but she's so sexy that I go back for more punishment."
cons: The management process is abusive, and I'm currently a manager.  I've seen too much "behind the wall" and hate how our individual performers can be treated.  You are forced to ride people and stack rank employees...I've been forced to give good employees bad overall ratings because of politics and stack ranking.
advice_management: Don't pretend that the recent NY Times article was all about "isolated incidents".  The culture IS abusive and it WILL backfire once stock value starts to drop.  I'm an 8 year veteran and I no longer recommend former peers to interview with Amazon.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
I've been at Amazon for a month now, and I've seen none of the horror stories being communicated to the public, although Amazon is a large enough company that I'm sure there are good pockets and bad pockets. Everyone here is really smart, and wants to succeed both personally, and as a company. People collaborate and help each other, focus on data, and truly focus on the customer. Every company I've ever worked for talks about how important the customer is, but on day 2, they're forgotten. Amazon seems to genuinely focus on what's best for the customer, and it's awesome to be in meetings where people actually bring that up, and make decisions focused on long-term customer satisfaction.

The opportunities to learn here are literally unlimited, and the opportunity to take on new responsibility is as well. I honestly believe you can be as awesome as you want here.
cons:
No cons, so far - seriously. Like I said, I'm sure Amazon has some bad pockets in it here and there, but this is an amazing job, an amazing opportunity, and the biggest thing I have to complain about is that it's a little chilly in our building. I can live with that.

Does Amazon demand high quality, measurable results? Yes! Is it hard work? Yes! Is it rewarding? Yes! So I'm not calling that a 'con'. Work/life balance seems comparable to other places I've worked - not worse.

summary: "Can be amazing for some people, horrible for others"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Amazon is doing lot's of cool stuff...but lots of boring stuff too.  There are really well run teams...and very badly run teams.  The experience for software managers and engineers is all over the board, from really run low operational load teams to teams where people burn out after a year.

 - Amazon is built, quite deliberately, to be Darwinian.  You can generally expect that anyone who's been here for more than 2 years is competent and motivated or they wouldn't have survived.  You can count on them as long as your priorities are aligned.  There aren't many slackers here, and they don't survive long.
  - We work on so much stuff that there's always an opportunity to find amazing cool stuff to work on (note that it's an 'opportunity', one that you have to pursue)
  - A chance to make a huge difference
  - A place where you can learn a lot about all kinds of things, both technical and about yourself
  - Amazon encourages high mobility - even your manager can't prevent you from moving to another team within 6 weeks (normally, more than a few months under unusual conditions).
  - Your friends and family have actually heard of the place you work and have at least a vague notion of what Amazon does without you having to explain
cons:
- You're responsible for your own career progression and finding the places and teams that are doing the stuff you want to do. No one is going to take you by the hand and help you with that.
- Amazon is built, quite deliberately, to be Darwinian. The strong survive and the weak perish (metaphorically speaking) and the 'bar' is constantly increasing. The level of performance that would have been acceptable five years ago will get you canned today.  It's a kind of crucible that'll help you develop a harder edge, if you can survive, that can serve you well in your career and in life, but it's often not a pleasant experience.

I wouldn't recommend it as a place to work for just anyone.
advice_management: Stack ranking is a horrible practice since it's rife with favoritism.  It's also not Amazonian in that it's not data based (arbitrarily designating a certain percentage of employees that must be put on performance management isn't a data driven criterion) and it's not frugal (effectively forcing an individual out of the company in one division who would make the grade in another is either retaining someone who doesn't meet the bar or a waste of talent). The goal is to force managers to actually make the hard decisions about how their team members compare with each other (not everyone can be exceptional), but it has more defects than virtues.  Replace it with a common comparison of each person against the bar for their position, based on data.  The percentages that are assigned to each performance category will turn out how they turn out, but there will be an evaluation mechanism that's fair and frugal.

summary: "We are now in a world where we are condescended to by our inferiors"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: This company gets A list performance from C list employees.  The culture is quick and hard charging.  You are always working in relevant and meaningful projects.
cons:
Maybe because the company recruits C listers who have neither merit (intelligence, strategic vision) nor pedigree (academic or professional accomplishments), most of those who become successful do so in treacherous, low cunning ways.

Imagine the Lannisters in Game of Thrones attacking the Starks in Game of Thrones; or Rawls and Burrell attacking McNulty and Daniels in The Wire; or Barrow and O'Brien attacking Mr Bates in Downton Abbey.  This is every day leadership behavior at Amazon.  The culture at Amazon is so infested with these middling talent weasels who have juked the stats and schemed their way to positions of power that new employees coming in actually start thinking that this behavior is normal and expected if you want to "manage people."

The work itself was stimulating and fulfilling, but the sneering condescension of the d bags that cheated and skated their way through high school and party colleges, then just converted their winky nod nod good 'ol boy shenanigans into a "ask no questions, have no introspection" company culture have made manifest some of the worst criticisms of capitalism.  Any left leaning political aspirant would look at this business organism and immediately have content to lash out against the corruption that can come in free enterprise where hard work is not rewarded, and the connected, incestuous, privileged class lounge their way to wealth while treating their employees and customers like some kind of filth their shoe picked up on the street.
advice_management:
Bezos you bought the Washington Post and hired Jay Carney to be your PR head.  There is nothing I can write here that you would deign listen to, because you are a hack.  You must be mad that Expedia beat you to the punch and hired Chelsea Clinton to serve on their board of directors.

For those grasping Weasels that have squirmed and back stabbed your way to success, you know who you are.  You won't care what is written here because "You got yours, Eff them."

For those truly diligent and hard working employees that don't want to believe the story from NY times that called Amazon a "Snake Pit" because you don't want to think you actually are involved in such a dystopian landscape of anti-business ethics: "Always yell with the crowd.  It is the only means to be safe."

summary: "Good place to work but no benefits"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Work is pretty reasonable for a warehouse job
Free coffee and occasionally free food
Some of the managers are proactive and friendly
There appear to be many opportunities to move up
cons:
Some coworkers don't want to do the work 
Very little guidance on how to do your job, which makes work more difficult than it needs to be and requires you to ask questions to the manager on how to do a task after hours.
There are quite a few managers that make you feel uncomfortable about asking questions in doing a task. This seems normal for any workplace, however.
No one really has a clear idea of what is going on in the warehouse as a whole, not even the managers.
No benefits and they cap your hours to that end. This is a job with no resume required to apply, so you really can't complain too much...
advice_management:
Please have a formalized training process of some sort on how to do work. That would great.
It would also be nice if you  Amazon can give benefits.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 10 years
pros: You can make your career at Amazon whatever you want it to be. I started in Finance and although I was good at it, I did not enjoy it as much as I believed I should. I then pursued Program Management and later Product Management, where I found my passion. The great thing about Amazon is that internal transfers are not only expected, but encouraged. I personally move about every 3 years, but the duration one stays in a role greatly varies across the company. It's all about continuing to learn, feeling there is meaning in what you are doing, and finding things you are passionate about.  Your time at Amazon will be what you make of it.  I enjoy working with extremely intelligent people on a daily basis and the ability to take full ownership of my work. I should mention that I am a mother of two children and have great work-life balance.
cons: The Day 1 culture at Amazon means many things, but one of them is solving new industry problems. If you are not comfortable with ambiguity and solving  problems that have never been encountered before (to your knowledge), you may not enjoy working at Amazon.  Depending on your role, I have heard that work-life balance can be more challenging for those starting early in their careers and looking to move up the ladder quickly. However, if you set expectations with your manager with open conversations about your desired flexibility, you will likely find an arrangement that works for you. Work-life balance is something you create for yourself as a priority, it is not automatically handed to you.
advice_management: I've been fortunate to always have a great manager at Amazon, but I've seen others that do not. Your relationship with your manager will be a major factor in your enjoyment at work. IE: micro-managing vs empowerment, etc. For this reason, I'd encourage management to be open to feedback and reflect on your management style. Sometimes what you mistake for a weakness in your team's ability to deliver results could actually reflect a weakness in your management style. If you see high turnover in your team, perhaps take some time to reflect on your own actions rather than assuming they were 'not a good fit for the role.'

summary: "Fast paced learning for those that want to learn"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: If you excel at the tasks given to you, you’re given a good shot at learning new things and advancing in the company. You are given ample time to do the work so long as you focus on the task.
cons: In order to get a pay raise for a job you’re already doing, you still have to interview for it...you get taught new skills, and get licensed to operate different machines, but you still get entry level pay. Rather than get moved up based on your work ethic and knowledge of the position, you have to wait for a certain position to open and apply...even though you’ve been doing the job already without the pay. It’s frustrating.
advice_management: I know the process for advancement is network wide at Amazon, but there are circumstances where an individual is trained and excels at certain tasks and is just overlooked because of the internal interview process. Promotions from within should be given to those that know the job and are already preforming the job.

summary: "Amazing place to learn for several years, hard to stay long-term"
job_title: Former Employee - Senior Software Development Manager
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Working at Amazon is like attending the most cutting-edge technology and business school you can imagine.  The hiring bar is extremely high, so everyone is extremely talented.  Amazon VP's are some of the smartest people you will ever meet.  The whole company moves so quickly that every day you are working on a new major initiative.  The leadership principles are literally used everyday - people quote them in meetings, and the company only focuses on customers, never on competitors.  It's quite remarkable.  If you get an offer to work at Amazon, take it.
cons: I stayed for over 6 years which put me above 98% of other Amazonians (there's a tool called "oldfart" that compares your tenure to other employees).  Most people only last 2-3 years for several reasons.  First, the pace is relentless which at first is exhilarating but becomes downright fatiguing.  Second, Amazon doesn't really care about you as a person - only as a productive cog in the machine.  Third, the RSU award program is ok, but total comp is really only great if the stock is climbing 30% a year.  Finally, everyone wants to hire an ex-Amazonian right now.   When you combine these, Amazon becomes an amazing training ground, but not a great place to stay long-term.
advice_management: Amazon comp is decent, but many other top tier companies can match it with better benefits. PTO is weak and employee perks like discounts are non-existent.  The 401(k) is limited and many other companies offer better stock vesting plans. Despite attempted reforms, end-of-year ratings are problematic and promotions are far too bureaucratic.

advice_management: What’s the incentive to work for Pillpack when the other mail-order/closed-door pharmacies in town all pay OT to their salaried pharmacists and Pillpack/Amazon doesn’t?  There is frustrated and low morale in the pharmacy team because of this and grumbling of looking for job elsewhere from quite a few people if this doesn’t change.  Pay your pharmacists the OT like everyone else does so you can develop a good team that wants to work hard for you.

summary: "Fine place to work if you like being physical and are looking for a part time job."
main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Easy (but physical) work and nice co-workers. $15 minimum wage was nice. There is a lot of room for moving up into management if the shift assistants/managers like you (or if you work there long enough).
cons: Management does not notice when people work hard; such a lack of appreciation. There were people who would stand around talking all day but management liked them more than hard workers (so much favoritism). Impossible to be full-time if you’re a level 1 associate. 90+ degrees in the summer and fall and not enough fans inside the warehouse. No communication between management of the front and back half of the week. Popularity contest when picking ambassadors.
advice_management: Give credit to people who actually work hard.

summary: "A lot to learn, a challenging environment"
job_title: Former Employee - Senior Technical Program Manager
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: You have the opportunity to work on a scale that is only found in a handful of companies. Generally, the team has the flexibility to determine how they work as long as they get the job done. Amazon encourages mobility, giving you the ability to work in multiple teams, with different technical and/or business challenges.
cons: A culture that wants you to eat/drink and sleep Amazon in order to succeed. Your role becomes more and more political and there are more and more bureaucratic challenges as your scope grows.  It is too easy to burn yourself out, from the TPM role it is too to be responsible for others burning themselves out - you need to own and drive what your healthy balance of ownership, energy is and need to know that yours may not always match what is expected from you to do your job.

cons: This is by far the most frustrating place I have worked. Employees are pitted against each other. Every conversation is contentious and results in an argument, most of the time the loudest or most persistent employee wins without regard to the validity of their argument. You must learn how to navigate corporate politics well or you will not move up the ladder.
advice_management: In my particular department, they need to more clearly communicate vision. It mostly feels like Amazon is a machine and it's hard to say if anybody has any real control over it.

summary: "AWS - Fast Paced, Great Place to Work"
job_title: Current Employee - Senior Software Development Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The company will give you opportunities to do meaningful things every day. It's run like 1000s of little startup companies, with each two-pizza team owning a significant chunk of work. Decision making is pushed down to the lowest levels, and teams have a lot of autonomy to decide on what tools and technologies to use to get the job done.
cons: Staff turnover and rotation seems to be a constant, but I think that's pretty norm for our industry.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Amazon base pay is $15 the hour with a .60 shift differential for working at night. That is for all workers regardless if seasonal or full time associate. However, once you are a full time associate, after 6 months you get an additional .25 and continues after 6 more months and so on until about $18.xx and I believe if you work the weekends you get an additional dollar. So if you work there for 3 years night time and weekends, you can potentially earn about $19.
cons: I dislike working at night but there is a lot more pros than cons.
advice_management: Train many people in other areas than normal because gives a sense of value to workers.

summary: "Job Flexibility and easy-going job with fair pay"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros: I choose my own shifts, may can cancel any shift outside of a 24 hour window and only need to work one shift a month if I so desire.  Once the responsibilities are job expectations are learned, the job is fun and easy.  Pay is fair @ $15 an hour.
cons: Shifts are grabbed quickly (within a 1 minute window) as they ‘drop’ each evening.  I have a second part-time job to help with some financial obligations, but because I enjoy my job and the flexibility I’m given, I’ve remained after being employed with Amazon after one year.   Training is just one day and a bit dismantled seeming; one trainer for 10 new employees with little time to train efficiently.  Just when you think you’re getting the hang of taking hours quickly, they’re hiring 10 new employees for your home-site.
advice_management: Hire more Prime Now Managers; provide at least two training days; provide a bigger stagging area at the BDN store; hire managers with years of leadership experience or ‘life’ experience.

summary: "Good company but you won't get promoted."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: My team is wonderful. There is a great work/life balance. Everyone is professional and smart. I feel constantly challenged by my managers and encouraged to explore all kinds of new ways to do our work more efficiently and to innovate.
cons: I am underemployed. I have a license in my profession that requires 7 years of advanced schooling before sitting for that license. In contrast, MBAs are hired at a higher level than me. The promotional process has looked for a "unicorn," which is a fantastic beast that does not exist. It was great to learn here, but there is no upwards trajectory. This has a disproportionate impact on women and people of color, who are consistently hired with the same credentials as people in a traditionally higher level role than the rest of us.
advice_management:
Hire for the right level. Do not hire high functioning, licensed professionals for work that does not require that license, and then use the fact that the job description does not technically require said license as a reason for slower promotions. Do a deep dive on the numbers and how this breaks down by underrepresented minorities. Consider tailoring base compensation to the amount of time and education represented in those numbers. Presumably licensed professionals in non-license required jobs nevertheless have the same bills as other people with those licenses (e.g., student loans.)

I really like this company and want to help it succeed, but I also need to be mindful of my own career trajectory and right now this company = status quo for the foreseeable future.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: They pay top dollar and the benefits in terms of healthcare are excellent.
cons: The game studios division is a giant mess and over time it is getting worse not better.  I moved my entire family more than once to work on projects. There was always a big rush to get me in position. Only when I got there I find that the project has no proper production discipline, blind management, and a firm belief that if you just put a plan to paper it will happen. We went through an exhaustive effort to create a better publishing structure with milestones and gates, only to have it ignored 2 months after we started. After a few years here I felt drained of energy. The organization is so complex, getting anything approved or let alone finding who is in charge of a certain project is a tremendous task. And then when it all went south they hit the LAYOFF button. Laid off 200+ people...everyone except the management who actual made the awful decisions. We let go of some amazing talent that had long advocated against the decisions management was making.  To add insult to injury I had to try and go around a beg for another job in the company - re-interviewing just like a new employee. Only thing is the terrible reputation of the games division inside the company is like the kiss of death with other teams.
advice_management:
Re-think how you approach the "Hire and develop the best" leadership principle.
Take a deep dive into how other game devs and their use of Associate Producers and EPs to keep a dev team on task. 
Don't just hire older game devs because of what they did in the past. Look for new talent dying to prove themselves. 
Actually trust the market research you are collecting instead of your own gut. Doing the latter has gotten you nowhere.
Someone needs to put the big boy pants on and combine Amazon and Twitch orgs so that they are on the same page. Both are going to lose out on the gaming opportunity if they stay divided.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: I can't think of anything positive to say about my employment there.
cons: They are strictly numbers based.  They will work you extremely hard without caring about their employees.  They also didn't seem to care too much about advancing your career.
advice_management: Listen to your employees more and maybe actually just try caring about them.

main_text: I worked at Amazon

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Amazon has a lot of interesting projects and is very product focused as a company. Amazon likes engineer to have ownership, meaning that a developer takes responsibility and has freedom to design and implement his/her product features. It's easy to transfer to another projects to gain different domain of knowledge. Because of the ownership mentality, the company also has many hands-on volunteer programs for career development, i.e. interview bar raiser, security certifier, SDE bootcamp trainer, API reviewer, etc. Even though ambiguity exists in every projects, the product goal is clearly guided by the company leadership principles. The company is very good at commercializing technology for its customers so the chance of SDE's contribution making to the end user stage is very high. As in the tech industry, there are some crunch time when major holiday season approaches, but the company as a whole cares about work-life balance. Flexible hour and working from home are commonly seen among teams.
cons:
For external hire, Amazon has higher bar in terms of experience. i.e. x number of years in y company is not equivalent to x number of years in Amazon.

The research effort is proportionally small comparing to other mega tech companies. Research projects have limited resource and can be cancelled quickly if not meeting deadline. 

Contribution to engineering community is relatively small comparing to other tech companies.
advice_management:
Contribute more back to the engineering community. 

Employee benefit is above average, but still not as good as other big tech companies. Considering increasing the benefit to retain talents.

- Your day-to-day satisfaction will mostly be dependent on your manager and team. In my case I enjoyed my team and manager - work-life balance was decent, can't complain.
- Industry standard compensation and benefits (although not the most in tech)
cons: - Reputation for poor work-life balance is definitely warranted from stories coming from other teams
advice_management: Be a leader in responding to workers' demands and taking on social issues as other tech giants have done. Issues like climate change, workers' rights, housing affordability matter to a significant number of young tech workers and it certainly makes Amazon less attractive as an employer when other tech companies can offer the same pay and benefits without the bad reputation Amazon has gained in recent years

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
- great for introverts
- 3 day weekend, work 4 ten hour shifts. More time for yourself!
- easy but just a lot of work to do, BUT that makes the day go by faster 
- the higher up’s are always so friendly and helpful. Loved every one of my AM’s and PA’s. OP’s were wonderful too
- For your first four weeks, you attend a class once a week hosted by HR where you can ask and talk about pretty much anything. This is awesome for newcomers
- HR also throws you “birthday parties.” 
- learned how to properly lift and use box cutter, which is extremely useful in real life
- you can use your time off anytime you want and they won’t question you about it.
- You have sick time, unpaid time, paid time off, and vacation time 
- set schedule
- benefits are great 
- perks are great! I got free tickets to a local water park and I believe you get discount for Verizon or some phone company too. They have discounts for pretty much everything. You just have to look it up. 
- they accept pretty much anyone. Didn’t go through an interview. 
- pay is good. $15 all around the nation is not bad. If you live near a big city, you get paid more. Got paid $15.70 since Seattle was next to us. 
- great career opportunities. Within working for a few months, they asked me if I wanted to be a learning ambassador, which is great start if you want to work your way up. Know a guy who became PA within just a few months as well

Honestly not a bad company. Worked here for a year. Left because my husband got stationed in Hawaii and there’s no amazon here unfortunately. That would’ve been awesome though
cons:
- long hours of heavy lifting back to back
- super sore coming home from every shift. Would not recover until two days into my weekend
- long hours. Show up to work when it’s still dark outside. By the end of your shift, it’s still dark. Come home, can’t really eat a big dinner or spend time with family because you need to go to bed right when you get home. Feels like your day is already wasted. 
- you gain 10 hours of paid time off once you work 350 hours. That’s very little for all that time you worked

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great hiring bonuses, and second year retention bonus. Amazing ability to build your own career, if you are lucky enough to have Amazonian leadership.
cons: New management is far from Amazonian, and those who have been at the company longer are underpaid and under valued. Bad leadership is tolerated, if not rewarded, while being Amazonian gets you labeled at a “trouble maker”.
advice_management: Review your teams, look at those who have been at the company 5+ years, and ask “why haven’t they been promoted, and why are they paid less than my new hires”, and then fix it.  You are going to loose a lot of awesome experience to the big competition in the area. It’s already happening.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Best-in-class benefits, good co-workers, competitive pay for unskilled labor.
cons: You'll be in Pick or Stow until you quit or are fired, with almost zero opportunities to move to any other departments. GMs last only a year before moving on, & morale at RIC2 is accordingly low.  A level of micro-management heretofore unheard of in the history of civilization eventually renders reporting to work onerous.
advice_management: Face facts: your productivity demands necessitate unethical behavior in the Stow department at RIC2. The fundamentals  that brought Amazon to it's current prevalence are no longer maintained; the resulting shaky foundation plagues this  facility. No amount of micro-managing will fix the underlying problems, so put down your laptops, roll up your sleeves, & "dig deep" to repair the issues that create those conditions. Keep turning a blind eye, & everyone there will end up unemployed when Jeff shuts it down.

summary: "Great place to develop and influence the future of computing in a sustainable way"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
I love the fact that customer obsession drives how the company makes progress, innovate. This is much better way to drive business than being competitor obsessed. 

- Leadership principles drive how we do business and shape the culture. It simplifies the expectations from each employee and from each other.
- Very supportive system to make you successful at your future job. 
- I get upto 90 days to train and get my certifications before doing any externally facing work. 
- Lots of investment on my development which will pay off for the company in the long term as I will be an effective employee that can represent company, culture and its services 

With the recent announcement of Amazon commitment to reach zero-carbon by 2040, 10 years ahead of Paris agreement  shows why Amazon is the right place if you care about climate and sustainable future for everybody.  Amazon will drive our carbon from every part of its business and cause ripple effects across many industries as a result. I love being part of this change.
cons: If you are not mostly in agreement with the leadership principles, it may be hard for some people to succeed.
advice_management: Please continue to keep climate crisis in mind at everything that we do to drive carbon out of our business processes and products. In the near future, that is what our customers will demand from us.

advice_management: Continue to put efforts into Green sustainability. It's the way of the future.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Decent pay, benefits, emphasis on safety, decent training.
cons: Managers talked down to you and essentially treated you like an asset instead of an actual person. Experience started out great but quickly soured literally only due to the toxic and paranoid people I had to work with. The attendance system and LOA policy needs reworked entirely. People are getting fired over things that are not their fault because the company is not admitting and correcting their mistakes. A total and complete joke, honestly. You're told one thing by one person, and a completely different thing by the next. And let's not forget them changing policy and schedules with no notice or communication then having the gall to tell YOU to get YOUR priorities straight. And the end of shift meeting that keep you over an hour after you're due to leave, that are utterly pointless because none of your insight is actually acknowledged or put to use.
advice_management: Get over yourselves.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Definitely a place that challenges you while maintaining good work life balance. Lots of great mentorship opportunities and access to talented co-workers to help implement innovative ideas. It’s a 9-5 job most of the time (except special weeks). Lots of niche teams to help find you the right fit. Amazon even has its own “Machine Learning University”!
cons: Tools change rapidly. If you learn a new software tool to get your task done or have automated something using it, expect to learn a new one in a few months. Teams can also be very niche and specialized, which might not be tricky for generalists. However, that is to be expected of most large companies. While most weeks are 9-5, workload can be a little high during on-call rotations. This is especially true when you end up with a high severity ticket. While Applied Scientists generally don’t need to be on-call to answer tickets every week, expect it about once a month.
advice_management: It’s a great place and hence don’t have much to add.

cons: Mandatory overtime for days at a time. And you can't pick your schedule

job_title: Current Employee - In-store Shopper - Whole Foods
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Flexible job and decent pay.  I work at the Ashburn, VA Whole Foods as an Amazon Prime Shopper.   I enjoy it.  It's an active, busy job
cons: They hire too many shoppers.  It's very hard to get shifts.  Very little communication from manager.  When an ordered item is out of stock, it takes a lot of time locating a store employee for assistance.  We can't offer a substitution to the customer without a Whole Food employees' assistance.    This wastes a lot of time.    We are judged solely on our pick rate (number of items we pack per hour) and substitution rate.
advice_management: Rethink your scheduling practices.   As it is now, you have huge turnover which means you spend a lot of time hiring and training new employees.   This creates a whole group of employees who are learning the job and will not work as efficiently.    I would love to have the option to have  a set shift.  Even if it's just once a week, Monday evening, for instance.  This option would be great for college students or retirees.    The Amazon moment (the employee shift scheduling system) could be used to fill sub requests, additional demand and empty shifts.

summary: "Amazon could be greater than it is there is a disconnect between corporate training and what goes on in the field."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Brand Name, Fortune 50 company, 4 day work weeks, smart talented managers to work with.
cons: Senior Leaders show little respect not much room for growth without relocating, little to no appreciation with high expectation. Time off is often an issue and the senior leaders do not follow the company core values. Worst treatment in my entire professional career.
advice_management: mix up your senior leaders to get a more up to date way of thinking to motivate other leaders. Respect and appreciation goes a long way, please put site leadership through ethics training and have site leaders do 360 evals by all managers they work with or work for them so they can get anonymous feedback that can be impactful. Corporate HR needs to visit sites to get real honest feedback local HR is contaminated by bad habits and Leadership. HR should report to Corporate and only relay changes needed to be made and roll up findings to HQ not be an extension of the culture or a former team member of the site they currently serve as HR. It is a conflict of interest and feeds into the issues plaguing some sites.

summary: "Learn a lot, opportunity for burnout is high"

cons: It breeds a really unhealthy culture where you're not looking to help any co-workers unless it's in a self serving manner.

summary: "Good experience, not good work life balance"

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Great brand name that will open doors for you later
cons:
Your project/life balance really depends on where/what team you end up in. Was part of the MBA hire process and you basically have no influence on what team you end up on...

Career progression/compensation is also not set in stone. Part of the MBA hire process includes guaranteed bonus for the first two years, which when you get to year 3 disappears... so if you don't get promoted to L7 by year 3 - your comp actually goes down considerably...
advice_management: Yes compensation isn't everything, but if your comp goes down after each year... you're not really saying you value your employees... "Oh your compensation will increase due to stock increase" isn't a good way to justify not keeping up with comp...

summary: "Lots of Potential, but Employees are Commodoties"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
- Huge growth potential
- Emerging technology
- Easy to make internal transfers
- Lots of opportunity for individuals of all levels to carve out areas of expertise and programs to own
- Fantastic mechanisms in place for vision setting, delivery, etc.
- Amazon is typically "great" at everything they offer to customers--developing their own tools/technology,  solving problems quickly, the quality of delivered products, etc. If you like working for the best, Amazon is it.
- People here are brilliant. You get a PhD level education quickly.
- If you're great at ownership and delivery, you can experience fantastic work flexibility and balance (see cons for flip side). I've worked here for years in multiple orgs and have never downloaded email on my phone or worked a weekend.
cons:
- Ownership is used as an excuse to not provide direction or support
- Managers are rarely allowed to truly manage - must also deliver as individuals
- Very difficult to be promoted
- Leadership is overwhelmed by scale and out of touch with employees
- Few benefits
- Average compensation
- Frequent management changes and reorganizations mean that employee expectations and growth plans are often changed
- Easy to get lost in huge company. Hard to get visibility.
- HR protects the company, NOT the employees.
- Little to no accountability for managers who make decisions that negatively affect those that work for them
 - If you are NOT naturally inclined to ownership and have trouble quickly delivering expectations,  you will quickly be overwhelmed and will have no work life balance.
advice_management: Develop clear training requirements for managers. Make promotions an expectation and benchmark for manager success. Hold managers accountable for negative decisions.  Commit to employee growth. Introduce compelling benefits for employees to stay beyond RSUs to reduce churn. Commit multiple HR business partners to organizations instead of just one. Hold managers accountable for delivering on employee growth plans.

pros: Benefits are decent, hours can be flexible, oversight is minimal, independence is high, casual atmosphere, pretty good pay, mostly great people, work's not that hard but there's a lot of it, generous education allowance, generous transportation stipend
cons: Fringe perks are minimal (free food is rare, gym membership discount is really small, health insurance mostly covers just the basics, etc), promotions are few and infrequent, pay system is really opaque and inconsistent, the corporate structures are really rigid, dogmatic and annoying, weasely career climbing behavior is often rewarded/encouraged, upper management are often biggest blockers of productivity, the dementors
advice_management: A lot of jobs are best helmed by high functioning underachievers with mid to low ambition but the Amazon hiring method really only targets low functioning overachievers so there are a lot of people who can't do the work well but were really good at pretending like they could. It really cripples progress.

summary: "Great learning opportunities but can destroy you."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
- You can learn so much from Amazon as a software developer. Since you get to own a lot of responsibilities.
- A great place to set the rock solid foundation of your career.
- There's so many technologies you can experiment with.
- You get to see true high-class engineering, and work with talented folks.
- Free bananas, and coffee. Some teams cater food weekly, or have snacks on the floor.
- Leadership principles are something you can carry into your life outside of work or future work.
cons:
- 24/7 Oncall duty can be very stressful and eat your health and life up.
- Unrealistic deadlines towards certain events such as re:invent.
- Toxic Management is quite common here. That includes bullying and micromanagement
- PIP is also common, if you are underperforming compared to your peers, expect it.
- Office politics play a huge part in promotions. Because of this some smart people are unfairly treated in their career growth here.
- Compensation decays rapidly over the years compared to your newly hired peers.
- Too much responsibility on developers.
advice_management:
- Properly compensate the tenured folks in the company, recognize their value by assisting in their promotion.
- Prioritize the tasks that make dev life better, we are also customers.
- Separate DevOps from Software Development. So more time and care can be put into each.

And they also have free pads and tampons in all of the girl bathroom's
cons: It's so hard to stay motivated when you are standing for 10 plus hours and are all by yourself with no one to talk to and you have to walk so much because everything is so far the bathroom is literally a 3-5 min walk and that's walking at good speed and remember that's only the bathroom 😂 going to the main break room is like a 7-9 min walk depending on how close you are and I'm not over exaggerating either lol the first 4 hours of my shift I've usually already completed roughly more than 8,000 steps and I'm just a stower so imagine a different position that includes constantly walking. We should also have longer breaks and a longer lunch.

summary: "If you don’t wanna be worked to the bone for 10 -12 hours straight, this job is not for you."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great benefits and pay. They pay for school after a year of unemployment.
cons: They work you to death. Do not care whether you are sick or not. They’ll fire you for the smallest things because to them you are disposable. Injure yourself? you be back on the floor working in 5 minutes. You don’t matter, as long as they hit their numbers, that’s all they care about.
advice_management: Treat your employees better and not like they are some type of work slave.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The pay, that is about it. Stay the hell away from this place.
cons: Too many to list, their "candidate help" is outsourced so you don't get ANYONE in the United States to help you. You select a shift, then when you go to confirm the shift, they tell you it is not longer available, and force you to select a new shift that is NOTHING like the shift you selected at the hiring event.
advice_management: Hire competent people in the United States to help with candidates who you screw over. It's highly unethical to hire someone on one shift, and tell them they have to select another shift. That is using false information to lure someone in.

summary: "You are a tiny cog in a juggernaut"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Benefits for health and dental are immediate.
cons: Try getting a bathroom break. Too busy to learn anyone's name. Human resources are not real HR staff that went to school for it...they are people who used to work on the floor pulling boxes and they never have answers. HR will ignore voice mails, emails and actually hang up on you. It could be weeks before you actually meet your "supervisor". You need internet to find notices about your job because a real human will never be asigned to tell you. The most impersonal management I have encountered. A friend got hurt on the job and he says the HR dept admits they don't know who to contact for what information. Says HR repeats "call your case manager" but HR doesn't even know if the case they speak of is through the state, the company handling it for Amazon, or elsewhere.  Says he has spent hours on the phone trying get answers any to get transferred to various companies.  An extremely "pass the buck" attitude when management is faced with a problem partially because they don't care and partially because management doesn't know what to do. It's like Walmart workers who will act within certain parameters but have difficulty with independent thought. They are gammas.
advice_management: Give people real training in the jobs they occupy. Have answers for employees and recognize that it isn't good to have no answer.

summary: "If you like a challenge, this is the place to be."

Don't expect freebies like free lunch or gym membership benefits but you will earn a lot of other aspects of professional career for free in this amazing place.
cons: Can sometimes do a better job at being employee friendly as well.  It is not to say Amazon does not provide any benefits or Employees expect freebies but the motivation levels need to be boosted from time to time so that obsession on customers stays alive !
advice_management: Once in a while it is good to Indulge on Employees as you do on Customers.

Everything is said to be a fantastic opportunity but it isn't. It is stuff they want you to do without having to pay you more. There are multiple people here who have innovated and worked on countless projects that still receive no monetary or professional benefit from doing so.
Culture - Everyone does there own thing with their own teams. Not much opportunity to interact.
advice_management: Make growth a realistic possibility. There are multiple talented people who can work far beyond rudimentary mind-numbing tasks in this role. If you support those who can and are willing to grow, they will only add value to the goals of the company.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros:
- The culture is amazing. One of the ONLY companies I have worked for that live and breathe their leadership principles every single day. 
- Expect the unexpected. The business continuously grows or might change direction. Being able to adapt to it is such a fun and amazing challenge. 
- Everyone here is brilliant! Although they may not be great everything, the intelligence in this company is insane!
cons:
- Change management is always hard, especially with such a large company. Sometimes you might miss communication, or you might receive too many emails that it's hard to sort which ones are important or not.
- There may be some ends where we take out principles too far. Being a large tech company frugality is normally not a common term, but here it is. Many people misinterpret it for only monetarily being frugal (which sucks when you are traveling or booking team events).

job_title: Current Employee - Sortation Associate/FC Associate I
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Amazon is a wonderful place to work, and I enjoy my job, and Supervisors. They work with you to find areas you're good at, and are always willing to help. They also assert strict safety guidelines. I like the schedule I currently have which is 9:15p.m. to 5:45a.m. :C1.
cons: I've been here almost a year, and my schedule is about to change for the third time.  As I said I am currently on the 9:15p.m.-5:45am : C1 schedule. The most recent schedule change will make it difficult if not impossible for me to get to work on time. It's also changing to a 10 hour shift, instead of the 8 hour shift I've had the last 2 schedule changes. My only other option is to switch to a flex schedule, which will take me back to a white badge, losing all the progress I've made to become a permanent employee, which took me almost 9 months to achieve. Also, I'm not clear on the requirements of being on a flex schedule.
advice_management:
Please keep the schedules as they are at the DPX5 Sortation Warehouse before the upcoming change.  Meaning to keep the following schedules:
·6:15a.m.-10:15a.m. : Pick/Stage
·7:30a.m.-12:00p.m. : C2
·10:30a.m.-3:00p.m. : FLEX
·12:15p.m.-6:15p.m. : PFSD
·5:00p.m.-10:00p.m. : RTS
·9:15p.m.-5:45a.m. : C1
The current schedule I have is the most convenient schedule that has been offered to me, and I would love to stay on with Amazon, as long as I can, because I really enjoy my job. It can be really difficult to constantly worry about your shift changing, and how that will affect your life.

job_title: Former Employee - Senior User Experience Designer
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: stock and some smart people
cons:
everything other than stock...

Managers and VP's do not care about you or your career. Everywhere else you get a promotion or raise for doing a good job. At Amazon you have to do a good job then ask for a promo and then they tell you  to work harder for 2 more years and then you might get it. If you are making too much money in their opinion or they can hire someone for cheaper because your stock has gained too much then you will become part of the 6-8% layoff group. What they do is make up something they are unhappy with. You can have 5 star performance and evidence of that but that doesn't matter. They want you gone and they will do anything to make that happen including making up things. If you are lucky you will get a manager who is generally nice but they are not on your side, they are pounded just as hard. When it comes down to it they will not risk their job to stand up to their manager. Everyone generally is not happy, there is ZERO culture and no one cares for very long. If you come in bright and full of positivity you will get worn down and melted into a ball of stress and frustration. The base pay is low for the industry and they expect you to rely on the stock to makeup for that. The stock can go up but it can also go down. You do not get bonuses or pay raises.
advice_management: Dev plans are crappy and if you want to continue to carry out your upper managements bidding I hope you go to church every day and get baptised. I seriously don't know how you can live with yourselves treating employees like that.  Your answer is probably "money" and if that is your answer I feel bad for your sad life.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: I was excited upon being hired and loved the Fact of being employed with them.loved what they presented  benefits, culture, just UPWARD MOBILITY..iAmazon.talked a Good one, All Smoke and Mirrors
cons: Bait and Switch..when we did Onboarding written copy of Job Outlook at Orientation they Switch up required days to VET, just any and everything you could imagine..it was a train wreck..New employees started leaving the first night..due to the cinfusuon and tbe obvious lies, first night in this Rockville, MD location was like being in an Oven in the Middle of August..Hot , Stank workers deordorant had gone Left b4 they started ..not a nice atmosphere..AMAZON you all shocked me i thought highly of the Company Now I see it is a  SweatShop..NoBueno
advice_management: Stop printing out on Amazon Letterhead And having Onboardings that descrine one thing , Yet when on the first day of employment,  not a One of management could begin to answer questions it makes you all look Incompetent..Instead New hires are directed to CALL ERC, who  are and outsourced Call Center in Another country..and can't answer your questions properly so Frustrating and UNPROFESSIONAL.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Fast Pace and Large Scope
Constantly Evolving Business
Open Door Policy
Endless resources, tools and training materials to assist
Non Union
If you want something and chase it while working well with others, it is likely within reach
cons:
Absolutely Survival of the fittest, don't expect hand holding
You will have to earn your keep on a less than desirable shift, but your time will eventually come if you perform consistently
Depending on the location, internal politics that protect the "fake it to make it crew". Eventually it comes out in the wash and performance is the only indicator of success
Performance review process is very deliberate, and you can expect at least 1 manager at every level to receive additional scrutiny to work on identified opportunities. Failure to improve will likely lead to them being shown the door. This is where first time managers or those with a slower learning curve can fall behind early.
advice_management: There should be more deep dive into the ability to develop new managers, as manager development is an afterthought if the business is performing. This is Absolutely a company that requires you to be a self starter, but at the current rate of growth we need to be willing to invest more in newer managers to ensure business continuity long term before determining they are not meeting the bar and starting to force them out.

pros: Friendly people for the most part. Dont have to worry about someone taking your lunch at amazon. Time goes by fast cause you're constantly doing something, hard work is shown since you're rated per hours worth of work, its recognized. Good pay if you work overtime, up to 6 days a week if you wanted to. Good workout. I really like fast paced jobs and staying active, although that may not be everyone's cup of tea.
cons: Sore muscles forever, fast pace work environment means you're walking and lifting stuff all day, if you're not willing to sweat, this isnt the job for you

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: -Great company name on your resume
cons:
-All managers are over worked, specifically Area Managers 50-60/hrs/wk, but zero overtime. 
-Continuous revolving door of managers because of the work/life balance. 
-Complete political process to get promoted, and promotions are not equitable across the different functions of the company. So someone at an FC will get promoted 2x as fast as someone at a Sort Center of AMZL.  
-Promotions do not offer even close to the compensation if you came in from the outside - 49% less as a matter of fact.  
-Only prople that stay are those who started as temps and are managers now (don’t know any better) or senior managers that got stock years ago (500+ shares) and now are g - golden handcuffs. However, because the company isn’t pying as much anymore, people are leaving for quality of life.
advice_management: Your hiring and promotion practices are horrible and when you finally realize the true cost of your actions, you will find it hard to hire more and more qualified people. Don’t wait until it is too late - change how you do business now.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year

advice_management: Make a policy and/or regulation pamphlet for new employees so they don't get terminated.

advice_management: Train for a different position!! focus on moving up so that you wont be slaving as a regular! & to the Managers maybe, just maybe act like associates mean something to you... that would better productivity & build trust & respect.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Flexible hours are a great. It's a good position to have while conducting a job search.  Most company information, about extra shifts or opportunities for other positions, are posted on the internal company site which is easy to navigate with a smart phone or from laptop. They also have computers at work, if you do not have access to one at home. Get compression socks and shoes for made for standing as your legs and feet will be tired.
cons: Communication can be a bit confusing about shift changes while at work.

summary: "Great if you like being treated like a tool"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Nice breakroom, set hours, great benefits and perks. Lots of opportunity for promotion (if you're the right person).
cons: The pay sucks for what's expected. This job can break your back. Your time is micromanaged, minute to minute. If you're not working, you need to scan in and out or report your time off task to a manager. Managers talk to you like you're an idiot. You get coached on the same things over and over again even if it's not your fault. Hard to get trained on other things. Managers give BS reasons when you ask about advancement opportunities. HR is very slow with orientation. I don't like discussing HR issues in public. They don't have an office. They're just behind a desk out in the open. Mandatory overtime. Long days make for difficult work-life balance. Too hurt or tired to do anything afterwards or on days off.
advice_management: Learn how to talk to people.

summary: "Keep in mind- it is a HUGE company"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: I can't just say one way or the other if Amazon is a good place to work as a whole, because there are hundreds of expanding departments and LOBs. I will say that my department, AVS/SAS, is awesome.  Love my manager, love their open mindedness, love that they recognize hard work and improvement, love that career dev is a topic they are passionate for. Coworkers are great. Just remember, your attitude and gratefulness will reflect in your position. Put in what you want to get out of your job. Also benefits are sweet.
cons:
Your work experience may depend on the efficacy of your manager.
Amazon will work you. Most positions are way over 40hrs a week at least for the first year while you adjust.
A software dev in AWS will have a 100% different experience at Amazon than a VM in Amazon Business or Retail. The company is huge. Try to find reviews and comments from people in your preferred org to get a better idea of the QOL.
advice_management: Work on the SOP overlaps and current project teams' overlaps. We only need one SOP for one thing! Keep them updated.  Follow the steps of managers who are well liked and the org will improve as a whole with job satisfaction increasing.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Amazon is a place you always feel is growing, with all the pains involved. You'll be able to affect change from day one on a potential global scale just by bringing in a new perspective.
cons: Amazon is not afraid to fail, they will fail fast and often on their path, which will rain down on the tech work and policies.

summary: "Join if you have been offered a position at the appropriate level or you will be stuck."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros: Great to have a large company name on your resume. You can work on as many services/projects your want and interact with all sorts of folks. If you want to work 24x7 you can surely find work to do and even do work not related to your primary job to help develop new skills, If in a pre sales role, you literally can travel anywhere and travel very comfortably.
cons: Golden handcuffs for RSU's and 401k match, each time you change roles you "reset" the clock to be eligible for a leveling promotion, not everyone at AWS is actually smart as there are a few deadweight folks who for some reason are still around and they literally don't do the work that is expected at their level, lots of politics between service teams, public sector teams don't get the same attention as commercial teams, level process in general is odd, especially if you have a manager who is an amateur, and doesn't understand the promo cycle process, they can't appropriately advocate for you. New folks get hired in with hardly any relevant experience to the role they are hired for, but will be hired a level higher than most tenured folks, your future lies in the hands of your manager, if they suck, you are screwed. Management will play games to keep you from leaving, but won't do their part. Easy to get caught up in working 24x7 while sacrificing family life or work life balance.
advice_management: Reward those who deserve to be rewarded. Especially those who have have given their job a priority where it greatly impacts the bottomline business and revenue when compared to others in the organization.

Also ince blue badge/conversion from "temporary " to Part time regular associate. You have to wait another 90 days for benefits. Yes,they okayed us for a year to get benefits.
advice_management: Work with your team instead of dictating and when someone shows they can work. Do not put the stress if no help n.v on waterspiders. Not far how you work them.

summary: "Working at amazon, was a good experience. Everyone worked as a team to quickly get things done."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon
pros: The best reason would be the pay, they did pay me 16 an hour which was more than any job as ever paid me.  The managers would always help me and make sure i’m okay with the task i’m doing.
cons: For me personally was the location. It took me almost 2 hours to get to work on 2 buses and 1 train. The locations just made the trip to work harder, especially on weekends. They don’t give you free food only water. We work for 8 hours and all they give us is water, but it’s not too much of a big deal because from my experience most jobs are like that.
advice_management: My advice to management would be to take it a little easier on your workers. It’s not easy scanning at the rate of 400 per hour. It’s going to take some time to get at that scanning rate. Also be a little more open minded with injuries or health issues. If a person is getting an allergic reaction then please don’t tell them there’s nothing you can do and tell them to get back to work.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Access to a slew of educational resources, more money than they know what to do with, higher pay
cons: The company culture is a real-life social network so if you think you want to work here, really think about whether you want your success to be derived from how socially adept you are at playing games and drinking beer.  I worked in a 50 person group, mostly engineering, and witnessed very little getting done.  I was reorg'd twice in the first few months and ended up working for a manager who really wasn't prepared to manage people.  This place will eat itself from the inside over the next several years.
advice_management: There is no advice for management, as it's a culture derived from the mind of Bezos, and his giant ego.  Want real evidence?  Go look at his giant glass balls downtown Seattle.

advice_management: Offering shorter shifts or even part-time positions would help you retain a tremendous amount of good employees who otherwise become frustrated and completely burned out, physically and psychologically.

summary: "Not the job you WANT, only the job you NEED."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Benefits. That is all. Benefits are great and management likes to remind you of just how lucky you are to have them. It's like "hush money", but not.
cons: Carpal tunnel, tendonitis, back and neck aches... you name it. That coupled with being penalized for restroom breaks, only having the ability to choose a 10 or 12 hour work day ( with two 30min breaks that really only equate to about 25 mins each), and knowing just how expendable you are? Truly troubling.
advice_management: Perhaps actually have experience managing others before trying to manage well over 50 people. Warehouse employees are people, not cattle. Act like it.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: A lot of material to learn. 10 min break, 30 min break, plus another 10 min break.
cons: 150 scanning per hour? Sometimes can be stressful a lot if you have two lines and a lot of packages coming to your way. Plus I’m short I can’t get to put the packages in the third row. Plus the scanner sometimes get stuck, and it takes 2-3 min to set up it again. Plus if you get to scan the wrong package, the device won’t allow you to keep scanning until you solve the issue. I regret the day I apply for this job lol no worth my backache to bend and push those heavy boxes.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Somewhat of a decent pay. $15 an hour is good for people who’s pretty new to the work life.
cons: Very inconsiderate company. It’s all about taking and wanting from their employees but could never give anything in return.  They want you to be productive every day but never have their equipment functioning well enough to produce, or they always short of equipment. They try and mandate some overtime to stay when they need you but god forbid you want to pick up extra hours for a certain week, you will be kicked out for the day if it shows you’re over the 28hrs max they give. They randomly change the schedule not considering that people have lives before the job and probably made their schedule to work around the schedule. And when you tell them about how inconvenient it is for you even though you initially signed up for a specific shift they basically tell you, take it or leave it. Just don’t do it. They are unorganized, and half of the management sometimes seem like they don’t even know what they doing. The stress from this job and the physical demand is definitely not worth it. A four and a half hour job feels like you’ve been doing a whole 8hr shift. I wouldn’t recommend working here. I always heard how amazon don’t care about their employees and treat them like crap and didn’t believe it until I experienced it.
advice_management: Stop talking down to people and thinking because you have on a blue vest that you’re above someone and actually make sure y’all have what’s needed on a daily basis for y’all employees to perform as how y’all need them to perform.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The leadership principles, discussion with recruiters and the hiring manager were all very honest, and with a few months under my belt, I can see that what I was sold on proved to be true. I have great leaders and am treated with respect. I love the writing culture, ideas win when they are thought out and written clearly, not when they are spoken to eloquently, forcefully addressed, or politically established at a social event.
cons: read the leadership principles and if some of them rub you the wrong way, you will feel it when you work here. Frugal is there, it gets annoying if you're used to a nice lunch at your work training, but it is a principle, so it wins. Customer obsession is real. The writing is real. It can be hard to be vocally self critical, but you must do it to succeed

summary: "Come for the dream, stay for the reality"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Coworkers. Rare opportunity for OT and...oh yes the stretching area.
cons: Passive aggressive Management. average pay for always increasing volume your expected to finish.  Senior management is more interested in its/their image. expectations have no flexibility.  Even robots have to stop for periodic maintenance. Why expect more from a human?  It would have been nice to see one of the bosses or senior bosses do anything other than stare fixedly into a laptop attempting to appear busy. An algorithm can tell you when work flow is decreasing. why not have them actually pitch in and do REAL work. Must be nice to stare at a screen and lead a morning stretch for $75,000 a year...
advice_management: Dig deeper. Way deeper. $30,000 ?  Why is a tech side of Amazon or logistics management paid 5 or ten times more. I realize supply and demand of low skill workers is a reality in our day and age but you know what else is a reality? When a company starts seeing profit margins in the BILLIONS. its time to ask is $15 really the best you can do? Maybe if you payed management less just to manage expectations and labor an honest wage you wouldn't have one of the highest employee turnover rates in the nation.

summary: "Invest in your people and equipment at older buildings"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Comradery, capable of scaling your pay if you wanted to by moving up the ladder, able to move around the world, compensation, 4 day work weeks, 3 day off, benefits
cons: Only cares about numbers at the fulfillment center levels, less on the people that product those numbers and always increasing the rates, the lack of investment into CAPEX projects
advice_management:
Appreciate your area managers at the fulfillment centers on a higher level such as taking them out for a thank you every month or give them a break by taking them out for lunch! Not hard to ask for working 70 hour work weeks for 6+ weeks during Christmas.. Not even a bonus or presents given. 
INVEST in your older generation buildings, they are causing productivity levels to decrease due to machines and increase the stress levels of managers and associate's.

summary: "Get paid, but prepare to be miserable"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Pay is the best around; stock options are a nice perk

Your coworkers are some of the smartest and most talented people in the industry; you will learn quite a bit from smart people
cons:
Senior management (particularly in Minneapolis) is awful. They will pit you against your coworkers. Prepare to be in a continual depressive state after your third month of working there.

Nobody cares about you or your personal growth there. You have to be the person in charge. Any "trainings" or "conferences" are done on your own dime and managers will see all personal growth as time you could have spent doing work for them.

Work life balance is poor if your manager decides they don't like you; it's always arbitrary. Amazon pretends to be a "data driven" company, but it's all political and managers *will* manipulate data however they see fit. I know some people whose managers like them that do little to no work and have found the gravy train. Good luck if that's you!

They are having attrition problems because they are driving many people out. Presumably because Amazon is cutting a significant part of its workforce! Sooner or later that will hit you.
advice_management: Mandatory attrition rates to continually cut engineers while managers continue to get paid is dehumanizing. You are throwing away talent continually for no other reason that to make Lord Bezos happy.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 8 years
pros: I worked in AWS sales and business development roles in a leadership capacity for almost 8 years. I loved the culture - work hard, play hard, change the world. Great opportunity to build a great business and express your talent in creative and imaginative ways.  Your enjoyment and happiness depends a lot on your attitude. If you can work hard and keep your spirits high, you can have a blast. Do not get into a negative mindset or you will be unhappy with the fast pace and growing pains.
cons: Great company and fast growth.  Many new managers that do not understand the AWS culture. It can cause disappointment among staff when the bar is lowered in hiring.
advice_management: Work on maintaining the culture throughout the organization before it gets lost from the influences new hires bring from previous company cultures. Hold everyone accountable to the guiding light of the LPs. Keep reinforcing beyond new hire orientation.

summary: "Overall an amazing place to forge your career."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Huge company with huge opportunities in a wide variety of career paths.  Compensation can amount to "golden handcuffs".
cons: It's a big company that internally wants to pretend its a startup.  This creates a decentralized workplace where centralization would be WAY more efficient.  Depending on your line of work, this could be good or bad.  For innovators and creators, it's great... for operations minded folks, it's not.
advice_management: The Day 1 philosophy is a great rallying cry but is impractical in a company of this size.  Big companies, like Amazon, require process and procedures to find efficiencies of scale.  Actual Day 1 companies do not hold internal conferences with 1000's of employees in attendance or have today's biggest rock stars at an employee-only concert.  It's great to think like a startup, but Amazon is far from being one.

summary: "Do not I repeat Do NOT accept this job if you aren't coming from a Support position"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
Free certification test
Free learning options (linux academy, lynda, a cloudguru)
AWS account where you can practice anything.
cons:
This job is a glorified call center complete with metrics that make no sense.
Customers can rate you from 1-5 based on your interaction and you have to have a 4.69 average rating every month or you did not hit metrics.
You do not have actual time to learn on the job all you do is google answers, and essentially do customers who are too lazy to troubleshoot their issues jobs for them.
No time to work on projects during your "40 hour work week" because you're too focused on meeting metrics.
Not meeting metrics for consecutive months will get you fired.
Metrics don't make sense.
This position will be a waste of time in your career if you are not going down a support path. If you have come from project work and deliverables thinking that working at AWS you will get a chance to learn the technology in-depth this is the WRONG role.
advice_management:
Actually LISTEN to your employees and heed their advice
Do the training, work a week or so in the employees shoes and understand what you are asking for is unrealistic.
Employees are either not hitting metrics globally or they are working overtime stressing themselves to hit metrics which majority of employees are indian on L1 and H1B visa so they NEED this job and will work 50+ hours a week to hit their metrics effectively skewing the results and giving management justification that if they guys can do it why can't everyone.

Associates are expected to perform in undesirable conditions, lacking in materials and supplies in which they need to be successful.  Those issues neglected causes great people to leave Amazon daily.   Way too much mandatory overtime.  If time was management more effectively, less mandatory overtime is needed.
advice_management: More management roles, a training program for management and allow substantial amount of time to be effective in a department before rotating your management.

Management literally said during meetings that they don’t give a crap about us and not to small talk with them 
Building relationships was discouraged 
Talking was very rare
Every man for themselves
They eager to replace the weakest link quickly from day one 
Numbers are valued higher than their employees 
Very uncomfortable!
advice_management: Be less...mean. Be more...compassionate. Stop trying to intimidate as a means for control.
