main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Starting at $15 an hour for an entry-level job is not half bad.
The company is pretty hands-off about letting you handle your own time off. You can report your time through an app, which means there are no confrontations with managers. They treat you like an adult who can monitor your own schedule.
Sometimes there are free t-shirts and water bottles and stuff.
A good job for people who like to keep moving. There's not usually a lot of time for standing around.
cons:
You can get lost in the shuffle and get stuck doing the same thing everyday all day if you don't volunteer for things occasionally.
Sometimes you have to advocate for your own break.
Working under several managers can make things complicated when they are all saying different things. You have to really learn what each manager expects from you and be flexible about that. Kind of like bouncing between divorced parents :-P
advice_management: Management really should spend more time talking to each other and getting on the same page.

summary: "Positive experience overall but dislike the company"
main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Straightforward with set hours and interaction with management is minimal if you go in and do your job.
cons: Warehouse conditions were not clean and it hurt my lungs.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
Relevance - Customers care about the cloud, and executives are always willing to meet. 

The Technology - Customers can execute end-to-end digital transformations with AWS technology.
cons:
The Culture - Working in sales at AWS is a nightmare. I'm shocked by how normalized the toxicity is here. People crying at their desks and working 60 hour workweeks out of pure fear of not "raising the bar". No one is ever recognized for their work unless they shamelessly self promote themselves. 

Leadership - Front line sales managers at AWS are notoriously bad. These are typically newly promoted, former individual contributors who have ZERO leadership skills whatsoever. They almost universally have very low EQ, are extremely Type A, chronically micromanage, and very rarely agree to promote anyone on their team. 

Pay - Pay is very low compared to competitors. 

Hiring process - I was misled by recruiters during the interview process. I was told that my desired salary was "well within the range" for my job, but when I was sent my offer after interviewing, it was more than $100K short. 

Career development - Amazon has "levels". Most AWS territory sales reps are hired as an L5 or L6, but some are hired as L4. If you are hired as an L4, you will have no opportunities beyond your current job, you will earn upwards of $100K less than your peers who do the exact same work, and it will be almost impossible to get promoted.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros: Benefits were wonderful and work was fulfillling
cons: The management was sometimes not the best

summary: "Great job but the hours are long"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: The pay and ability to work hours around your schedule or a definite pro.
cons: Well the company itself treats their employees really great. Some of the managers seem to have and these are my slave attitude. Or a drill sergeant attitude.
advice_management: On the shift I work the manager never threatens our jobs. He encourages us to do better through games and other fun activities. He always recognizes those who are doing great. When I have worked VET I hear the managers tell the workers they don't work good enough if they don't get their time or speed up they will half to be wrote up. I see a lot of workers of the hair not called back. You're more likely to get that a production rates if you treat their workers with respect. Also the drivers are mean to the workers during the morning shift. They expect perfection from workers that aren't even the responsibility.  They should not be yelling at the workers/pickers.

summary: "Opportunities are limitless, if you have the desire to reach for them."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
- Lots of complex challenges 
- Fluid working environment 
- Everyone's opinion is valuable and desired
- Small teams with lots of ownership
cons:
- Cross organizational communication 
- Conflicting team goals
- High demand
- Promotion philosophy is rigorous
advice_management: Create more incremental success metrics for employees, smaller and more regular wins will keep employees happier. Keep evolving the benefit offerings -- Amazon is not leading the pack on this front. Make environmental issues more top of mind, and create more opportunities for employees to feel like they have a way to give back in a meaningful way.

summary: "If you're lazy and unmotivated to work apply elsewhere!"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Benefits on the very first day
cons: MET (Mandatory Extra Time) Sometimes you literally learn after your second break that you are scheduled to come in for MET (depending on when your overtime day is). Another con are the break times.  You get two 30 minute breaks, problem is that it may take you a good 3-4 minutes just to even make it to the front entrance. Your feet will definitely be barking by the end of your shift, trust me!!  If you're more than 3 minutes late then they will deduct an hour of UPT (Unpaid Time) from you. Each associate receives 20 hours of UPT every quarter for a maximum of 80 per year. To move up to tier 3 positions within the company they also look at the number of hours you have left of UPT.
advice_management: None, they're pretty open to everyones ideas.

summary: "Employing a contractor who cares more about going out partying than they do about employees with families"
main_text: I worked at Amazon
pros: Great company to buy things from and work for
cons: Hires a contractor like Northern builders that fires someone because they wouldn’t go out socializing with other employees on lunch or after work or on the weekends. She wouldn’t go out with them on lunch because she wanted to go see her kids for 30 minutes she wouldn’t go out after work because she wanted to be with her kids wouldn’t go out on the weekends because she loves being a mom. But according to Northern Builders “she doesn’t for it because her life is too busy. Maybe it would be better if she just stays home” so according to Northern Builders family isn’t important so if they fee that way Amazon must feel the same way if they hired them.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: They do their best to make it a diverse & friendly work environment with occasional events and contests. The salary is relatively good, as they try to stay competitive. Base rate PLUS Additional +3.50/hr for part-timer's here in Houston. (20-29hrs/wk)
cons:
- VERY VERY hard labor - An intense workout from start to finish (even for a fit & active person.) You are expected to meet unreasonable rates and stand 10hrs + daily. By the end of the shift you will have ZERO energy for anything.
- Low job security - You can get fired for: not meeting the ridiculously high rates, using up the very little "unpaid time" you are given, or even picking up a fallen item from certain parts of the floor.
- Ultra-Micro Managing: You are clocked to the minute for everything you do (including going to the bathroom) You have to speed-walk from your area to get to break and back in time.
- Attendance penalties: You have very little "time" to use in case of call out/sick days/etc. 1 Hour of this time bank gets used if you are more than 5min late (dumb)
- Weak benefits (Part-time): Part-timers get wayyyy less call-out time and less medical benefits. Full-Timers get much more time to use and better medical benefits.
advice_management: Remember, you are dealing with PEOPLE. Treat them like gold and you will be rewarded handsomely. Most people are afraid to leave HONEST feedback on the questionnaires for fear of termination.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Everyone is super helpful and friendly.

The job is very straight forward and easy to pick up.

 Organized hiring process.

Great job if you like working night shift.
cons:
Extremely boring and repetitive work.

Only mangers and corporate get full time and benefits.

Seasonal/part-time have Limited working hours, No benefits.

Each shift has strange and sometimes overlapping hours.
advice_management: Need Full time and benefits to all employees not just managers and up.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Plenty of training and opportunities for advancement.
Part-time hours are very do-able.
The work pace is not too hard.
Meet plenty of people.
Pay is well above minimum.
cons:
Many of the Area Managers and Process Assistants seem imcompetent,   like they are only there to collect a pay check instead of investing their efforts to  LOGICALLY make their employees' work more efficient. 
They react to productivity problems with the same method, like a habit and as if it solves everything.
advice_management:
Stop relying on habit to fix productivity issues. 
Ask your employees what the problem and what reasonable resources they are lacking before reacting on your judgment...aka, get a fuller picture from people actually doing the work instead of first impressions.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
- Gain experience extremely fast
- Extremely hype name at the moment, easy to get employed after working at Amazon
- Get to live in downtown Seattle with comfortable salary
- Quality of coworkers is almost always great
cons:
- Almost no company perks
- Overly competitive culture
- Leadership principles are subjective rather than objective
advice_management: Take advice from companies like Google and Microsoft on how to sustain engineers rather than having a bad turnover rate; a lot has to do with company culture, but even increasing the benefits could make people stay longer.

summary: "AWS - great hiring experience and exciting company to work for"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Like the best medical benefits I've see in an entry level position. While I was there, they offered to purchase all diabetic supplies for while I was employed - that's a big deal. After a year employed, they'll pay 95% for certain courses in college.
cons:
Though air-conditioned, it really only dries out the air (I was hot without sweating and I stayed thirsty - a bathroom visit was a detriment to my rate especially with the distance involved). Like a carrot held out of reach in front of a mule pulling a plow, my rate I was guilted to keep felt similar.
I asked manager what percentage socializing got him into his position, and he said 90%. Being less social kept me as entry level for more years then he's been with the company.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Pretty easy to do

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: EVERYTHING is provided: training, equipment, etc... You are given every tool to be successful, it's just up to you to make it happen. The benefits are great, potential for growth is unlimited and it doesn't hurt that we work from home, often in pjs. :)
cons: It's sometimes frustrating difficult to work with customers who are upset about things we have no control over and can't fix, but that's not specific to Amazon. Personally, the biggest "con" in my book is regular shift bids and team changes. I have other obligations and really NEED my schedule to be set, but Amazon is much more focused on the needs of the customer.
advice_management: It would be great to have a more control over which departments we were assigned to work in. It's always easier to love a job when you love what you're doing. It would be great if there was a way to allow us to realign to skills that brought us joy.

advice_management: Culture eats strategy for breakfast, let's keep this our motto as we grow and expand.  Client first and the rest will follow.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon
pros:
•Paid Weekly
•Everyone Is Paid Equally
•Friendly Community 
•Great Benefits 
•Great Discounts 
•401K Instantly
cons:
•Short Breaks (10 min / 30 min / 10 min) 
•Long shifts are usually 3rd 
•Must be able to lift around 50lbs consistently 
•Fast-Paced
advice_management: I believe that with the new systems, the production rate will improve, but will need some getting used to.  However, I wish that they include either a)more breaks, or b)have the current breaks extended, because during our low months of the year we're quite slow at the end and they don't often offer VTO's.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
At AWS we help our customers fundamentally transform their business. It's incredible. It's not just a company line. It's true.

Surrounded by very smart and accomplished people. 

The Leadership Principles you read about are real and this IS a customer obsessed culture.  My team has a goal to help customers reduce their monthly bill. Would Microsoft, IBM or Oracle do that?

A tremendous amount of time and energy ( i.e. money) is invested in growing  employees. Compensation is heavily weighted to stock so quite a bit of luck is involved both in the stock price on award date and vesting dates.  

Also, don't come here looking for a big title. I think that helps keep egos in check a bit.
cons:
A tremendous amount of time and energy ( i.e. money) is invested in growing employees. This is great unless you prefer to focus yourself on doing a great job in your current role, getting paid and being happy with that. 

 Compensation is heavily weighted to stock so quite a bit of luck is involved both in the stock price on award date and vesting dates.  

For all the benefits of the Amazonian culture (Whoops, not allowed to call it culture. Better call it "way.") it can be unnecessarily tedious. I actually sat in a presentation and listened to someone tell me how many spaces to put between sentences and that I should use the Oxford comma. 

I sort of feel like I signed a four year NFL contract with a company option at year two and four to extend. I guess that's a good strategy to get people to walk away when it's clear their RSUs are not reloading and their income will plummet. 

Also, don't come here looking for a big title. May be tough to convince future recruiters that yes, you are bigger than your current title.
advice_management:
For all the weirdness (we like the term peculiar) you can't argue with success! 

401k matching and vesting is weak. I can't retire off my RSUs since my issue price is   ~$1900. I need a fat 401k too.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Benefits are great and the people are fun to work with.
cons: LONG hours on feet, quotas, short break time remaining after walking to break room.
advice_management: To avoid the very high turnover rate in positions that require high hourly quotas (stow, pick, pack ect.)  lower the required rates by 10% - 20% and higher just enough employees to make up the difference.  That will cause less errors that because employees won't have to rush as much which causes errors and the overall employee moral would be much higher.

It may cause you to believe that society has become increasingly lazy . Temperatures can get into the high 90's and above depending on where you work in the building.
advice_management: Never bite the hand that feeds you. Try using the Golden Rule. Favoritism runs ramp id . Management on all levels needs to learn the processes in which they over see and please learn business math!

pros: They give free tampons and maxi pads but you can’t go to the bathroom but during your break or lunch so yeah, that’s a perk 🙄
cons: Pay is horrible. Can’t go to the bathroom but on your break or lunch or you will get “talked too”. There is absolutely no place to sit if your having a problem during your shift and need to sit for a minute. The so called “breaks” are like a cattle call and it takes so long to get to the break rooms that when you get there you’re break is almost gone.  The amount of work they expect done per hour without mistakes is absolutely ridiculous and impossible. The benefits are good if you want to spend a lot of your paycheck on them.  Long story short, if you want to work in a sweatshop then this is the place for you. They have a revolving door and now I know why.
advice_management: Oh I’d love to sit down with management and let them know how I feel

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year

advice_management: We know that managers have their own daily tasks that need to be accomplished and are important for the success of their station. I believe it is still vital for them to make their presence known and show all associates that they are apart of the whole team.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: They make it easy to go big and really try to accomplish something big for customers and your personal interest. If you can get stakeholders on board, the sky is the limit.
cons: Constant sprinting, I am amazed by those who have made it past 5 years in a leadership role. It is a grind. Getting people to buy-in is challenging due to differing goals and how accountable everyone is to their personal goals instead of company wide goals. Visibility is super important. It can be extremely frustrating to be passed over based on visibility instead of merit, which unfortunately happens somewhat often.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: You will always be challenged with the work you do at Amazon and the scale you work with will prepare you for anything. Furthermore, you work with some of the best and brightest in your field which is very refreshing. Finally, the pay is very fair and I'm able to achieve pretty good work life balance
cons: The culture here is pretty mediocre as there isn't really a sense of community if your direct team doesn't make it. Your time at Amazon really does depend on how good your manager is, if you have a good manager, its awesome, if not, you are kind of at their mercy.  If you are big into the big tech amenities then Amazon is not as good as the others, but personally, I'd rather get paid more so I'm fine with it.
advice_management: I think management is doing a pretty good job with the lack of management resources they have available and the scale of employees they have to deal with.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: The most amazing, smart people I've ever worked with in my life.  You get to work on cool projects, lots of opportunities to do all kinds of things.  You almost never hear "No" as an employee you always have the opportunity to contribute and grow the business
cons: I've been here five years as a manager and individual contributor.  The rumors you hear about abuse are completely true.  Yes people cry at their desks on a regular basis. Yes managers are given unlimited power to browbeat and abuse employees.  If you are lucky to be on a team with a mentally healthy manager you will be fine.  But upper management has no system to change the culture.
advice_management: Get honest about treating your employees with respect.  Create and execute a plan to train managers and weed out the bad ones. Incentives are all wrong.  You incent managers to fire 6% of their workforce every year and managers abuse the system.  I would never ever recommend anyone work for this company until they clean up their management.

cons: Compensation strategy is not friendly, HR and immigration is slow and not as helpful

summary: "Shiny title on your resume after you leave. That's about it."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
- Job search is made easy after leaving Amazon due to brand recognition by recruiters worldwide
- It is repetitively simple to apply for a new internal role within Amazon if you want to switch teams/position, given your manager supports you. 
- Pay and benefits were OK.
cons:
- Management with no management skills. 
- No compete agreements - and Amazon keeps donating to WA state politicians to enforce them.
- It is official Amazon policy not to invest in development of their employees, because infinite queue of replacements  is ready to jump onboard  at low cost.
- Long hours - work until you drop approach
- Demands to  report for work to  the office , hence making traffic congestion at South Lake Union insane, this policy alone ( yeah you go it right -  "work from home" is strongly discouraged) 
- For a US Citizen it is hard to compete with H1B visa workers  - they keep working  12-14 hours a day for their immigration benefits and will tolerate all management misconduct without raising a concern, because they can't change their jobs easily, neither they will risk their immigration status by challenging immoral/unethical/unprofessional conduct of their bosses. This is how all management misconduct remains unreported at Amazon. 
- Leadership principles are used as either as religious artifacts (in best case), or as tools  of management power and control ( in the worst case).
advice_management: Reconsider the risks you are taking by  treating your employees badly: your ability to print H1B visas and replace high skilled workers at low cost may come to an end. It may do more harm than good.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Good pay and benefits
cons: Hard on the feet and hands. Boring.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Good starting pay decent benefits
cons: Hard to advance don’t tell you if you don’t know certain positions you won’t even be considered.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great benefits and perks. Beautiful campus and facilities. Smart and motivated people. Opportunities to take risks and do things that change the world.
cons: Sometimes coworkers can get a little intense.  It's up to you to set your own boundaries. Anyone who doesn't will burn out. It can be a bit of a boys club and there is a lot of unconscious bias at the upper levels of management.
advice_management: When I joined I was told that our HR partner would give us career guidance and coaching. That never happened. Managers are too busy doing actual work to have time to nurture a career path for their teams. All of my peers at L6 are giving up on any hopes of being promoted.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Good health benefits and work environment
cons: Not a good place for iOS or Android developers.  All engineering practices are based on web services.
advice_management: Figure out how to make Agile work at Amazon.  Real agile.

summary: "If you enjoyed elementary school... work here."
main_text: I worked at Amazon
pros:
Flexible hours...
Easy to get hired only requires being a human who has no felonies and no illegal drug use...
Great benefits.
cons:
Treated like you are a child. 
Ridiculous learning curve. Unrealistic expectations. You should be up to speed first time out on the floor training.
Lack of support. If you have an issue while training there is rarely anyone to answer questions or assist in a timely manner. 
Not worth the crap you have to put up with even for $15 an hour in my opinion.
Lack of communication.
advice_management:
Treat the people you hire with respect.  Be kind and supportive instead of condescending with new employees.
If you say they have two weeks to get up to speed, give them two weeks to get up to speed.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Good hourly wage. Hours are set when you're hired so no surprises. The shift can be anywhere from 3-5 hours. 
Cool managers (aka process assistant.)
Reasonable system for missing shifts/being late (point based)
Very willing to work with you on HR stuff
cons:
They'll hire anyone who passed a drug test, but many are weeded out along the way, so there's high turnover. 
Training could be improved.
Cliques among employees.
It's hard work so if you're not up for heavy lifting, don't bother
advice_management:
Hmm. Well, more communication, would be the one thing. Though it can't be easy with the amount of seasonal employees and turnover. 
Train employees on all aspects of the warehouse operations at the beginning!

summary: "Great Place to Work; Not for Everyone"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
- Empowered to drive projects you care about if you have the right data.
- Learn an incredible amount working at an impressive scale.
- Lots of opportunities to work on a variety of subjects if you want to try something new. Very easy to change teams.
cons:
- Not for everyone; need to be driven and self-motivated to thrive.
- You're responsible for your own work/life balance.
- It's a big company and if you don't know what you want in a team, it can take a while to find the right fit.
- 401K not competitive with similar companies.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Pros: great pay, intelligent colleagues, challenging work
cons:
Cons: toxic management!!! Constant meetings about risk for union strikes at this location with pressure to mitigate all HR and operations demands on your own. The AM role here is total BS. You're more or less there to fire bottom performing associates and do dirty work. They will work you for every penny, especially if you are a college hire demanding you work 5 sometimes 6 days.

At JFK8 you'll be getting intense demands because of geographical location. Most orders will come from the northeast region but this location particularly (compared to NJ, Boston, Maryland) is highly more stressful because of poor management and setup from launch.
advice_management: Stop trying to turn your workers against each other by making up lies. They need the social support from each other to deal with your narcissistic toxicity. Trust in them and cutback on the micromanagement.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Choosing Amazon as my first job was the best choice I've made so far! Grunts make $15/hr and are treated with respect by the manager. Although an associate is the lowest tier at amazon, it's far from powerless: write-up misbehaving drivers, report to manager, etc.

It's not labor intense at all! The place I work at has free water bottles, sometimes drinks, coffee, apple cider, hot coca, and even tea if anyone is feeling dehydrated! Often, associates get free food! Pizza!!

I also love my co-workers. They're all friendly and patient!
cons:
As a physical labor job, you're gonna sweat a lot (there's AC luckily). There hasn't been a single day I was sticky from all the sweat after work. You also gotta stand up your entire shift (excluding break times). Your feet are gonna hurt for a bit because the floor is made of concrete (at my place).

The instructions while working may not always be clear, depending on the manager in charge. Different managers like to organize the warehouse differently, this results in conflicting instructions, so always stay up-to-date with your manager!

Instructions aren't always clear when told to do the job; I wasn't told that cars had to take certain hour routes, I had no idea of confirming on their phone during checkout, I did not know how to stow packages immediately or shown how to use the phone, was not informed how to deal with drivers that did not show on the computer (discovered to write with paper and pen), did not completely understand unacceptable behaviors of flex drivers, etc..
advice_management: Try giving employees someone experienced to assist them with their job. There can be quite a bit of information that takes a while to absorb.

summary: "If you like learning situations that are like drinking from a firehose like I do, this is the place for you!"

summary: "Good starter job. Not worth staying at though."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Good for first time work experience and extra income. Lots of different shifts to choose from. Working 4 days and off 3 is nice.
cons:
Management is awful, they have no clue what they're doing. Everything is disorganized and hectic. There's a lot of simple changes the company and management could make so things run smooth and simple. No one thinks downstream though and managers don't really care to listen. It all makes things harder for employees in the warehouse and the flex driver employees.

They also put a lot of pressure on employees. Getting one person to try to keep up with a two person job is not a smart idea. It just slows everything down and stresses the employees.

Also the ambassadors are lazy and the training is terrible. There's no feedback for when you are doing something incorrectly. The management and ambassadors just don't pay attention to employees and it's hurting the warehouse.
advice_management:
Listen to the suggestions of the employees that have to actually do the work. 
Pay attention to your employees and notice who actually works hard and who doesn't. 
Giving feedback for mistakes or for doing well would help out a lot for the growth of the employees. It'll also show management pays attention and cares.
Train train train! Get a better training system.

summary: "As advertised - customer obsessed and bias(ed) for action"
job_title: Current Employee - Senior Leader, AWS Enterprise Sales
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The Amazon Leadership Principles tell the story of working here. If you're aligned with and agree with those principles and want to work in that manner, you'll like the environment. It moves fast, the principles are real and show up in situations each day and people are comfortable to (respectfully) challenge others when they think the principles are not being lived up to. And AWS is definitely the most customer-focused enterprise technology company in today's market.
cons: Depending on your group, the social aspects of the culture may be limited. People are pretty busy and committed to their work, but may not make time for social events and priorities. For those coming from other large companies, it's a significant cultural adjustment that takes a while.
advice_management: Stay focused on the customer and keep making long-term bets. Evolve comp to keep attracting/retaining top talent.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Good pay, easy work, self-management. Coworkers are great, very relaxed work environment.
cons: Very hard to get shifts sometimes, Amazon keeps hiring more and more people causing competition to seemingly constantly increase. I would work 40 hours if I could but sometimes I can barely get 10. There's also absolutely no challenge, it's mindless work which can get very repetitive and boring. Other than that, great job.
advice_management: Share more results of people's progress and good efforts, no reward/encouragement for working harder to meet company demands. Also would be great help to share opportunities for different positions to make up for lack of hours. Don't hire so many people when there's enough people trying hard to get shifts.

job_title: Former Employee - Virtual Customer Service Representative
main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Working from home
Tons of overtime
cons:
The performance metrics are tough. You are graded on whether the customer feels you helped them or not. Sometimes there just isnt anything you can do. Sometimes you have to enter a ticket for the issue. Sometimes the customer just doesn't know how to use a computer and you are limited with what you can do. 

 The supervisors are hit or miss. They take a long time to respond sometimes. In the meantime you are getting graded on your handle time. If you need to escalate a customer to them they will sometimes fight you to take over the call. The reps are very limited on what they can do so you have to call the escalation line until you get a helpful supervisor. 

The training was too short. There was not a lot of practice time or real life example calls. You basically get thrown in and you either sink or swim. They just tell you to sound confident even though you have no idea what you are doing.

The shifts are so scattered throughout the day. Sometimes you end up with just a half hour or hour shift at a time. You basically log in and out all day. It makes for an exhausting day.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Keep in mind that these pros are for a part-time sortation building, not a full-time picking-and-packing building.
 
-Great pay at $15 an hour
-Soft quotas (enforced, not too difficult to meet)
-Freedom to take bathroom breaks on most jobs in the building when you need to
cons:
Keep in mind that these cons are for a part-time sortation building, not a full-time picking-and-packing building.

-Management moves you around where you are needed, mostly regardless of your preferences
advice_management:
Implement a system on the app for blue badge associates to set a preference as to which role they want to fill most of the time. This would assist with job enthusiasm and make rostering easier.

i.e. an associate can put inbound and small sort on their preferences, and management can roster them there first if they need people in those areas.

summary: "Amazing People, Culture, and Great Opportunity to Power Tech!"

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Great culture of intelligent, smart people who really live the leadership principles and walk the talk.  The commitment to innovation, inclusion and diversity, support of the community and local organizations, and STEM programs really makes this an exciting place to be!  The standards bar is high, but there are many resources and tools available to help those who put in the work be successful!
cons: N/A - Just must be self-motivated and a self-starter

summary: "What's it like to be a stower at Amazon Fulfillment Center"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: I was lucky enough to start with Amazon at a new fulfillment center despite some initial anxiety, everything went well, they have training ambassadors whom work with you very closely to learn your job, walked in first day with full benefits and time off... $15 per hour, the work can be tedious and it's ten hour shifts you are on your feet all day, basically the product comes to you in bins where I am at in North Haven CT (someone brings it to you  the product varies from tiny merchandise  to to packages no bigger than 18.5 inches x 12-14 inches, , anything you can imagine comes in the bins t-shirts, earrings, books,water bottles, dog food, nothing heavier than around 20 lbs..it's all mixed up in the bins and your job is to sort it out, scan them and put the product in the appropriate sized pods... you dont have to walk anywhere the pods come to you.... I get a 30 minute lunch break (paid and another 30 minute break later in the day.... once you are trained after about 10 weeks they said, you are expected to stow away about 250 pieces of merchandise per hour... it's not that hard, at a steady pace after 3 days of work I was doing 300, I don't know if it's because it's a new warehouse or what but everyone is real nice and the manager's as well, maybe it's luck but I like to think this is just how amazon does business, kudos to Amazon. 15 per hour to start on day shift... not bad for this type of work...
cons:
the application process is long and arduous, come to think though, there was no real interview, if you go through the hiring process, have all your documents pass a drug screening and a background... you should be good to go...

the only other con I can think of is that the fulfillment center is like crazy huge! going on breaks and lunch, to get anywhere you have to walk 5-10 minutes... which makes me feel a bit rushed on breaks and during lunch.. wear comfortable shoes! I swear the place is four flours and about 10 football fields long... ugh!
advice_management: Keep up the good work!

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
Great Benefits 
Room for Growth 
Diversity
cons:
Work life balance was horrible. I worked 70 hours weekly. They tell you that you will work 4 days a week but in reality you will be called into work every week at last minute. You’ll always work 12+ hour days and forget about getting a break. 

It is an extremely toxic work environment. Area managers will step on you to get ahead and look good to the Ops and the Ops turn a blind eye to all of it. 

There is absolutely no training for you the position. You are given a tour of the FC and a vest on day one and then left to figure out  everything on your own.

advice_management: You can’t dictate someone’s bladder and if they gotta go they gotta go

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
-Company has strong financial performance
-Lots of learning opportunity, especially about working at scale
-Some extremely smart people
-Work/life balance is not as bad as people claim
cons:
-Worst stock vesting schedule of any tech company
-Particularly low 401k matching
-Worst perks of any major tech company
-What you work on and what direction the company is moving in is entirely decided by people you will never see
-Compensation is on the low end
-Management can be a mixed bag
-Forced to use tools not because they are the best, or even particularly good, but because they were developed in-house

Even SDE2 total compensation can be exceeded by new grad offers to Google, Facebook, Uber, etc. During my tenure, I noticed that the best and the most creative people (engineers, managers, PMs, etc) were being quite easily poached by other companies. Amazon performs well financially because they hire cheap engineers and take advantage of H1B visas, not because they hire the best engineers. I've had to deal with entire teams in Seattle where the entire team spoke Chinese, including the manager. Even though there are extremely smart people, they are scattered widely within Amazon, so talent is extremely inconsistent.
advice_management: Review the leadership principles. Focus on customer obsession and remove the ones that don't matter. 11 leadership principles with so many of them conflicting with each other that most people don't take any of them seriously.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
The people! I’ve been at my building since it’s launch. People come and go, you’ll meet a ton of character.
The benefits! The pay.......
cons:
.... on the pay is the 15$ raise was nice. But it was better with the bonuses previously offered monthly. 
They are ruthless when it comes to injury’s! At the end of the day you are a number. I was out a few months on injury and i was treated horribly the whole process. 
You don’t have a HR. 
Your work way to many hours with 2 breaks. 
Lots of standing! Lots of repetitive movements.
Unless your a favorite you’ll never move up. And even in that case the manger will only be there for a month then leave you’ll have 1000 a year come and go. So nobody is treated like they mean anything. We have no emotion with management.
advice_management: Stop being so tough. We get there are numbers to be made. But actually get to know the AA’s or just being more mindful of where they are coming from. Personality’s and motivation differ from person to person.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year

Unless you have accumulated paid time off for unpaid time off to cover it you will be fired. So as long as you live close by and you never get sick and you don't have kids and you leave with enough time to cover an emergency like a car accident or a flat tire or anything else that could go wrong during your 1 hour commute you should be fine

summary: "Does Amazon know how to hire managers?"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
-You get to listen to Alexa while working
-getting 6 day's a year that are paid without work
-one on one's are really helpful where you meet with your manager to talk about your employment there or talk about anything on your mind even if its not job related
cons:
-the company say's they hold themselves to a higher standard than everyone else, truthfully the managers at GO and HR department do not do so. They would rather break laws than to explain to their higher ups why the company broke several laws in someone being fired
-write ups are not taken seriously by management, meaning you can have a write up that is not based on truth or based on events beyond your means like the Tool not working properly in how much the recipe should be that day and they will still write you up for it even though you are not the person that weighed it (I still have my notebook that I repeatedly went over the math to make sure I followed the recipe as I should have in making it ready for the customer)
-the managers listen to themselves rather than they listen to their Associates when it comes to improving production, saving money, and saving time. However they will say otherwise but in reality the ideas you tell them to implement are not taken seriously even though they could do just that
-there are really two teams in GO: Managers and Associates working against each other as the managers won't take the time to help allow the Associates to feel like the managers are about one team working to accomplish the goal and are rarely seen .
-Conflict is not something the managers know how to do in resolving, it gets to the point that you wonder if they can handle conflict in their own lives and when you tell them what would help improve the situation comments like "that doesn't work for me" are often said.
-management is often seeing yelling even several times a day every single work day yet is allowed to happen. Along with things like theft from managers and badgering. 
-the ERC Team (Employee Resource Center) or the HR 1800 number, you often have to be patient with that several have asked if they are actually contractors and more than once I have had to explain something five times just to be able to answer their question the first time. As they will ask you a question like "who do you need to talk to?" and when you tell them they will ask four more times before they take that as a legitimate answer almost as if your answer has changed since the first time they asked, second time they asked, or the third time. 
-while the benefits are great and exceptional the stress from the managers don't help with releasing the stress from them. To where the managers often cause more stress than what should be necessary and have said several promises to fellow coworkers that were not seriously kept.
advice_management: learn how to resolve conflict to begin with.......if you can honestly have your Associates back they will have your back including but not limited to production will increase, your job will get easier, and more problems that you are seeing will easily be worked out and resolved alot easier.

summary: "Amazing place to grow, learn, and develop new skills, but the pace was not sustainable"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: If you are fortunate enough to be given an opportunity to join the ranks of the management team with Amazon, you will soon find yourself surrounded with some of the best and brightest around.
cons: The hours are brutal.  Plenty of other things that one can complain about, but they aren't really unique to Amazon.  Its a tough job.  Its not for most people.  You probably aren't tough enough to do it, and if you are, I'll double-down that you can't do it without complaining.  If you are one of the few who are tough enough and can keep your criticism constructive, then go for it.
advice_management: Get out of your office / conference room and get on the floor with  your people.  They will tell you what is going on, but you have to get out there and listen to them

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The benefits you pay into from the day of hire as well as the immediate 10 hours paid time you get.
cons: It's like doing 10 hours of cardio nonstop. Both of my legs/feet swelled so bad and I was in constant pain from the massive walking/standing you must do. You have very little time to breathe for they constantly advise you of your quality as well as productivity in which 99% of people won't hit the target. I was extremely jumpy for at any given time a unknown person can walk up to you and start asking you questions about the job or go through your area zone to pick up a item which fell. You also get 2 days of training and by the 3rd day be written up based on quality errors. The place has windows that you can't see out of. It's like a prison. Management walks around all day with labtops watching your productivity and you receive messages on your machine how fast or slow your going. There is a extreme high turnover of people for the conditions simply isn't realistic. Employees are told at orientation that their bodies will ache, but I was one who was simply naive to the harsh realities of feeling I've been hit by a train. I quit! This labor work is for people who doesn't have any other options. Stay away!! The (4) 10 hours days seems nice but management knows you need the 3 days off to recover.
advice_management: Management become realistic with human beings can do. Give at least 1 hour for lunch plus a 30 min break. The constant man on the microphone calling out names and productivity please stop for that isn't impressive but annoying when most people want to put in their hours of work and go home. What one human being is capable of doesn't mean everyone else can do the same. Plus create a Amazon store for employees that holds leg, feet, hands, arms, back compressions for most people can't produce in severe pain. Have shoes and insoles that will help alleviate all that concrete floor/10 hours of standing/walking.

summary: "Hard work, fast paced, , long hours, good pay, good benefits."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
- Employees and managers are kinder than they are given credit for
- Free hot coco and coffee.
- First week(s) are painfully sore, but new  employees on their 3rd and 4th day have the opportunity to leave at any time with VTO (voluntary time off), and it's helpful to just take some ibuprofen when you're sore.
-  I'm 19 and 160 , i'm not conditioned, but i was one of the fastest people in the warehouse on my third day,  to me stowing can be pretty easy.
- To some the minimal standards for units put away per hour when stowing can be un-achievable. Thankfully the first 4 weeks you work at amazon they give you a "learning curve" so you only have to manage 70% of what they ask the first week for instance.
- Very good benefits, highest coverage for one person i think is 39$ a month, lowest being 15$ a month.
- No education needed.
- Management promotions i have seen within 6 months for T1 employees.
- Holiday pay is time and a half plus 8 hours. so if you work the 10 hour shift on a holiday that's 345$ instead of the usual 150$.
- TONS of opportunities for overtime, which is 22.50$ an hour.
- You start with 10 hours of PTO (paid time off) and 10  hours of UPT (unpaid time off). 
- 40 hours of vacation accrues over a year, and rolls over the next.
- After one year you get 80 hours of vacation a year.
cons:
- Insane amount of speed walking from stations to lockers to make sure you clock in/out on time and not use any UPT (unpaid time off).
- UPT is taken out by the hour, so if your 6 minutes late to work, they take 1 hour of UPT.
- only lockers are in the front.
- working and walking can be unbearable if you aren't conditioned, i'm surprised i see people working here over 40.  
- You need to eat pretty fast. 
- when stowing sometimes you only get large boxes and not enough pods come by to put them in. This decreases your "takt time" and units you put away. 
- it can get pretty hot on some floors, i'd always recommend wearing shorts, and carrying a water bottle to your station.
- Mandatory overtime. 
- I wear my fitbit to Amazon, according to the fitbit, i usually walk 4-6 miles per 10 hour shift at Amazon, which is roughly 13k-17k steps.
- The statistics your managers base you on can be pretty brutal. If you need to go the bathroom  before a break happens, your takt time will be almost un-fixable.
advice_management: Increase breaks or lunch by 5 minutes, if you get stationed in the back of the building you have to run/walk to get to the lockers in time to clock out and to have enough time to eat.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Product Manager Technical Products
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
(This review applies specifically to Amazon Web Services, although much of it is likely true for other organizations within Amazon)

Amazon is a great place to learn because the work moves quickly, at big scale, and with a great emphasis placed on customer obsession/working backwards from customer needs. 

All of these are critical to succeeding within product management, and as such you'd be hard-pressed to find a better place to start or continue building a career in product management.
cons: The pace of the work is fast, and if you're not comfortable within that kind of environment, then you may be better off steering clear.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Everyone really lives the Leadership Principles. Customer obsession is not just a saying, it is a way of life. Amazonian leaders give you room to innovate, drive, and grow.
cons: Unique - or as we say, peculiar - culture that takes some getting used to ... you may wonder several times in your first year or so if you made the right choice. If you hang tough, you'll realize you did.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: I work 9:15pm -.5:45 am, these hours are great for me personally.  It was nice how they worked with me to find a work schedule that fit me best.  From day one the associates were awesome. Management and the training staff always had a How can I help you attitude. I love the crazy fast pace of the overnight shift. I've trained in different positions and I'm never bored. When an issue comes up I'm listened to, and given a solution.
cons: I wish they offered full time hours.
advice_management: Replace the associates that are slackers, or have them go to an easier shift that isn't as labor oriented.

Generally unpleasant work environment.
Poor employee evaluation system.
Young and inexperienced Area Managers.
Fans don't work most of the time.
No music, no headphones, etc.
Bathrooms not cleaned frequently enough.
advice_management:
Improve employee evaluation.
Make it easy for employees to monitor their performance, view errors, view rates, etc via the employee AtoZ App.
Allow employees to explain the reason for infraction before write-ups are issued.
Allow FC staff to be able to freeze rates whenever work is interrupted by other staff or when there is a need to use the bathroom.

summary: "Interesting To become a amazon delivery driver"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time
pros: Amazon is a really good place to work. It’s a very easy job. Great management. Good pay.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Easy job, not much thought required.
cons:
Yes, on paper you'll earn $15 an hour but if you only work your shifts, you're actually earning less than that.  Let me break it down.

Say you're scheduled to work 4, 4 hour shifts a week most times they flex down unless it peak season.  So in essence, you're working maybe 12 or 13 hours of them time you're scheduled to work.  You only get paid for that time that you work so you have to pick up extra hours to earn close to what you're supposed to be earning a week.   Well, although it may seem great to only work 3 hours when you're working, when you think about it you have to plan to work 4 'just in case' so you have to dedicate (in your mind at least 4) per shift of your time.  

$15 x 12 = $180  That $180/16 hours that you're scheduled to work and can't do anything else during that time is $11.25/ hour.  Do the math, it's not what it seems.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 8 years
pros: The experience you can gain at such a company is second to none. There are so many opportunities to learn and move around. It's very easy to contribute meaningfully
cons: The environment is so fast paced that you can easily get swallowed up in the competitiveness. It's not uncommon for teams to "race" for claims on projects and being able to navigate the political waters is a must. One wrong interaction, and it can throw off the course of your entire career.
advice_management: Focus on making an environment where people can understand the group success mentality. It's important to identify your personal contribution to the win without negating from the win of a peer.

cons: They barely give you time for breaks. Even a water break is rushed. They don't let you have water on the floor. The management team is rude and don't treat employees with respect or care about them. It might be in the best interest of this location to review management here.
advice_management: I would not advertise that you're willing to pay $15-$17 online. I have years of previous experience and when I told them I was looking for $17, the manager laughed in my face and said that they didn't start anyone above $15. Overall, very unprofessional and rude management.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon

Congratulations on another note on being #5 in Fortune 500’s best places to work.  Keep up the great work on that.

summary: "Good compensation, mundane work, and bad politics."
main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: $15 an hour, if I remember correcly you get an additional .50 or a dollar if your schedule is outside of normal work hours. It's easy work if you're not in a full-fledged facility. The little events were nice for employee morale, food, giveaways, etc. Benefits are also good. They're open to hearing ideas to improve technical things on how the facility is run (not behavioral)
cons: My location ONLY had part time for non-management, ambassadors were in ugly competition with one another, mangers gossiped with associates, and the work is so mindless. Only two managers ever attempted to train me to do things beyond what I was already doing because they could tell I have bigger potential. Then circling back to the ambassador competition some were hesitant to fully teach what they know because that's seems like more competition for them.
advice_management:
Stop engaging in petty gossip.

Do not encourage the idea that ambassadorship is the road to promotions knowing good and well opportunities are far and few between and letting these people rip each other apart to be the favorite.

When choosing promotions, chose the hardest working, most knowledgable, and consistent worker, not the one that was pretty high up on the list, but they brought you lunch, came around a lot, and was chummy. Not only that, you told that one you hand-picked about the opening to apply, and stayed hush with the other top employees. That was ugly. I'd be surprised if your clear-cut best associate is still working there after that stunt.

Give leniency to your top employees.

Do not overextend ambassadors, you know they are eager to please and it was sick to watch you overwork and underappreciate those people. A different-color vest can only keep an employee happy so long.

Do not unnecesarily micromanage good employees.

The "local" HR there is slow and useless. I believe this is a 100% remote job, and if it's not, let that be a caution of how absentee they are. Let them have office space where people can be in contact with their concerns more immediately.

Although the drivers are contracted, if you're working as a unit their issues matter too. At one point some drivers went weeks, if not months unpaid because management wouldn't get off their butts to correct the issue with the lead.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Category Merchant Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Amazon is filled with intelligent, motivated, passionate people.  People are interested in their work and focused on moving their career forward.  There isn’t much slacking on the job that happens, so you rarely have to pick up someone else’s work for them.  There are so many interesting projects happening that you can choose something that aligns with your interests and have a direct impact on the business.  Amazon has a high tolerance for experimentation and failure.
cons: The Amazon culture rewards people who are opinionated, vocal and critical.  People will challenge others in meetings, rarely in a way that is negative or condescending, but to many can feel aggressive and exhausting.  There are so many projects going on that it’s easy to get overloaded and overworked if you are not vigilant and have hard prioritization discussions with your manager.

job_title: Former Employee - Senior Human Resources Manager
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
AMZN is led by the most brilliant CEO imaginable. 
Compensation is above market.
Opportunity to work with smart, hardworking professionals. 
High bar was used to make hiring decisions in year's past.
cons:
HR for HR is non-existent and extremely political.
An employee's success (or failure) is dictated solely upon the manager's subjective opinion vs. deliverables. 
Unfair employment practices do exist in pockets of the company.
advice_management:
Adhere to company's written policies each and every time. 
Treat hourly and salaried employee's with a modicum of respect if/when a complaint is raised against a leader, even if s/he is a VP or senior leader. Customer Obsession should extend to your workforce vs. being detrimental to the health and welfare of your employee's.

summary: "Pay could be way more for the amount of work and hard labor"

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros: Initially pay was really good and seemed like a good opportunity
cons:
- Cut new managers pay by 25k and put in a serious effort to get rid off managers that made more than that even if they were top performers.
-Poor senior leaders in location - they could not do the job that they were managing
-Serious age discrimination - if you are over 30 - no change of getting promoted
-They expect you to work 60 to 80 hours per week
advice_management:
Clean house of L6's - most of them were pretty useless. Get leaders that actually understand the logistics business. They are over paid.
L7s, depending on location, werent worth anything. They add less and less value and don't truly understand the business. They are extremely overpaid and do not bring the value needed for six figure salaries. 

Lastly, honor hard work and not just political connections within the organization.
New grads, dont believe half of the things they tell you. Look on LinkedIn, there is a reason that people don't stay for more than 2 years. 

Pay was ranked 3 stars based on original pay, new pay, they expect you to work 60 to 80 hours per week for 60k.

job_title: Former Employee - Senior Human Resources Assistant
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: You build a lot of character. You do learn how to handle situations that entry level HR would not deal with at other companies (sexual harassment, workplace violence, suicidal ideations, etc). You can really bond with your team members about how much you hate working at Amazon (but most likely aren't able to hang out with them outside of work because schedules are horrible)
cons:
Where do I begin? 
-Business Partners are not transparent, you can tell there is a lot of shady stuff going on that if you ask about they'll get defensive.
-Little room for growth/no clear path to promotion. There was no guidance on what to do to get promoted and when someone does get promoted, there is no acknowledgement of what they did to get promoted (favoritism is definitely a great way to get promoted, that's the only thing I can say for sure)
-Your site could pick and choose which policies it does and does not want to follow. Towards the end I was terrified I would get in trouble for following policy because it wasn't "in the best interest of the associate"
-The associates are frustrating. Some can be very combative. I've gotten yelled and cursed at several times. There is little disciplinary action for the people doing the yelling because "they're frustrated and we're here to help them."
-Initiatives would start and fall away within 2 weeks, so if you don't like something, you're in luck because it probably won't stick
-I don't know how anyone could survive being in this role for more than a year and a half. Everything is extremely repetitive and after a while the tint on your rose colored glasses fades hard
advice_management: Be transparent with your team. Create development plans with your directs.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year

cons: Short breaks supposed to be 30 minutes but you have to walk 10 minutes back to stations or be written up, management can’t tell you anything cause they don’t know anything, also mandatory OT is trash just because others don’t make numbers you have to use your off days to come in and make up what they didn’t do.
advice_management: Stop Nanking anyone a manager

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year

great pay
room to advance
its a very simple job. it doesnt require a lot of thought but it is pretty much like playing tetris and requires common sense...which most of your coworkers wont have
cons: working in a warehouse is taxing but thats to be expected. Coworkers were terrible  they would stack boxes any type of way which would make all of the boxes fall because they would stack heavy boxes on top. then i would have to rebuild entire pallets. the worst part was i was younger than all of them but had way more sense. it is also extremely boring and repetitive.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Interaction with multiple teams where you’re able to learn from different stakeholders

Work on projects in and out the US and meet more stakeholders and learn from other processes
cons:
Micro management 

Quick changes organizationally without clear direction of the vision 

No clear communication within team and others

Being that it’s a large company and it’s always changing it takes managers and theirs as well months to be clear on what the team goals are and there’s no good communication from them to stakeholders.
advice_management: Be clear when bringing in new people this a fast changing environment with very high demands of your personal time.  People should know they are joining a culture that is flexible in some ways but not when it comes to how many hours you put in and how many hats you were in the team.  If you double and then triple the workload from when employees were hired be prepared to give raises unless you want to keep the high turn over.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Being physically active all day and free coffee ( if you could make it to the break room & back)
cons: During orientation and beginning of training the warehouse has loud music playing, that only plays in the entrance. No music is allowed - itd really make the day go faster if it were. Small bin count for 10 hours with no noise except yourself counting is horribly boring. Amazon jobs are only for people with very little intellect.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Non-union, health insurance from day 1, some of the managers are really great, goal oriented company.
cons: You are not judged on your performance like amazon claims, that’s a filthy lie.  Your preference is dependent on others getting you product, that product being correct, and the equipment working as expected, all of which never happens.  You are penalized for others mistakes.  In CT we are required a certain amount of sick time, but amazon sent us an email “you get vacation, so you can use that for sick”.  As a 4 day 40 hour employee, we get 3.5 days of vacation a year,  not even a full 4 day work weeks worth.
advice_management: Don’t penalize employees when you can’t keep your own conveyor belts running. 1/4 of the day with broken equipment, now 3 days in a row is unacceptable.  I shouldn’t be penalized if another employee gives me the wrong items to box, puts the items I’m supposed to box in the wrong spot, and/or gives me broken items.  Yes, I said that correctly, if you are given an item to box and it’s broken, your numbers are penalized for not boxing that item as you have waisted the time to get to the point of pulling the item and then have to damage it out.  As a packer, every second counts.  My numbers should not be effected by me having to sit and wait for the pickers to put items in a cubby hole.  Let me say that again, they base your stats on hourly work, but if the person who is supposed to give you an item to pack doesn’t work fast enough, YOU are penalized.  This is garbage.  If the equipment breaks, you are still expected to make numbers, even if it’s their fault they can’t keep a proper work environment functional.  The numbers for packers should be based on how quickly and properly you pack an item from start to finish, and if the item has an issue it should not count against your stats.  Plain and simple.  This is a garbage union job without the actual union.  This is socialism.  This is a job where your fellow employees can screw you over by not doing their jobs, just like a garbage union job.  Stop lying, Amazon employees a rated based on how well other employees work, and how well the equipment works.  Oh and tell the CEO to pay his taxes you socialist scumbags.  As a single employee I pay more taxes than my entire company.

job_title: Former Employee - Seasonal Associate - Delivery Station Picker
main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Uhh.  I'm drawing a blank.
cons: No A/C.  Aisles too narrow and they send us all to the same aisles at the same time.  You do the same monotonous job every day.   A very physical job; lifting heavy, cumbersome bags filled with boxes.  Poorly set up floor space.  You have to pick a bag on one side of the warehouse and stage it on a completely different side of the building.  Wildly inefficient.  A serious lack of "u-boat" carts.  No enough space.  Everyone on top of each other like sardines.  Scanner only works about 60% of the time.   Several unprofessional blue-shirts and shift managers on power trips.   I can see why people only work here a few weeks and then quit.   For the heat and physical-nature of the job, you really should get paid more than $15.
advice_management: Stop laughing and yucking it up with other managers while you are sitting down and we're doing all the work.  Show more courtesy to workers.

Try it for 2 full weeks straight and be treated the way we all do. I guarantee you that you will have a different outlook

summary: "Good place to start a career, not very tolerable otherwise"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Generally it is awe inspiring to watch Amazon brute force their way into huge markets from the inside.  Improbable number of smart, driven people in the company who push big ideas.  Lots of strong leadership at high levels.  Proximity to cool tech and get to test new hardware / services.  Easy to create good statistical models due to the amount of data available.  Sense of accomplishment from lasting for more than a couple years here.  It can be a good place to learn if you are early in your career.  Easy to change teams.
cons: Everyone is everyone else's customer which in non-Amazonian terms means someone you're accountable to.  It's both over and under staffed.  Tons of redundancy and a Darwinian race to complete projects that other teams are also working on.  It takes forever to accomplish anything because every org is strung together with half broken services, bottlenecks, permissions, re-orgs, planning docs and churn.  It's hard to be "smart" at your job, because all of the low-hanging fruit is already picked and you must use weird, poorly documented, often throttled internal services instead of industry standards.  Constant parroting of leadership principles (Amazon's sanctioned term for corporate jargon).  Suffocating amount of mediocre middle management and extreme deference to hierarchy.  Individual contributors are generally not involved with any kind of planning or strategy but there to execute on what gets passed down from above.  Even non-managers can spend most of their working hours randomized in meetings, meaning the best opportunities to get work done are on your own time, which you may find you have very little of.
advice_management: The internet game is winner-take-all and Amazon is a winner.  They will win whether you work there or not; Amazon knows this.  You can take it or leave it.  Advice to management is moot as long as there is an inexhaustible supply of candidates.

summary: "Put a lot of thought into this career choice"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
- Working for a renowned company

- Worked with some very talented people
cons:
- Peak was a mess at the delivery station I was in. The stations Sr. Ops doubled volume and we literally drowned in boxes. Zero order and the number of safety near misses I witnessed was insane.
- No training or guidance, it was sink or swim and people would let you know you were sinking. No upper management had any guidance or insight.
- Favoritism, definitely was a political environment. If you weren't working Front Half, you were written off.
- Terrible hours. I came in around noon and would leave around 1-2 am. Wednesday through Saturday. Amazon loves their salaried workers. 
- Keep in mind this was a delivery station management position - which is COMPLETELY different from the corporate environment.
advice_management: Burn out rate is fast due to zero work-life balance and lack of training.

summary: "They will have a class action lawsuit against them if one or two people PICK ALL THE SHIFTS using tech software"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Class action lawsuit payout soon to happen. The only reason to stick around.
cons: C'mon amazon....we all know that at the whole foods shopper position, there is one or two people who greedily gobble up all the shifts and then release them days later to  people who actually PAY these bot shift pickers. It's one giant scam and they are going to get caught soon!!! I heard there are covert investigators from the FTC and the EEOC that are getting hired to see for themselves. I was only able to get 4 hours for the entire week. After that particular day when we picked the shifts (gone in less than 3 seconds thanks to greedy employees that probably have backdoor arrangements with the greedy managers) many days were released (not wanted anymore) by the ones that hogged up all the shifts to begin with. I know in my heart that someone is using bot software to get all the shifts and then is getting paid to release the days to the employee who pays. Almost like insider trading (well, sort of)
advice_management: Hurry up and stop slacking and get your MANAGERS to actually manage. When I told them what stops someone from hogging up all the shifts and then releasing them to certain people that pay or their friends, he was shocked. I came from an industry where this was common. They paid heavily for their mistake and are now using TELESTAFF as a system to give out days. Amazon needs to totally revamp their system. It's false advertising (up to 20 hours a week) and a waste of a person's time using such a manipulated, corrupt and archaic system. They will soon get caught with their pants down and will have to settle a class action lawsuit that is organizing. Pay attention to your employees AMAZON!!

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: The management team meh, $15 an hour,
cons: Water bottles all over the floor hazard, wanting you to be Speedy Gonzales, with picking and staging in the midst of all of this, You get a 15 minute break, bottle warm water, no PTO  only VTO, yet during prime they VTO you to death, after prime day now you have to use unpaid time  if you have emergency  because they aren’t offering VTO and deal with points that won’t come off until 90 days the maximum is 12.5 points and your fired. No medical benefits for seasonal sortation, you paid $40 to talk to a doctor so he can diagnose you over the phone what’s wrong with you, The 7:30 am to 12noon shift shuttle bus is cancel and not enough parking available at the site. During your shift when you pick off the line the jiffies and the boxes, they don’t have enough sorters to remove items to place in the bags, so it’s hard on the pickers, because we have nowhere to put the items, three hours your picking and then we usually take a break, but their are times that they will ask you to get a scanner and help knowing that pickers get their breaks first, no regard for your breaks whatsoever, for the pickers or sorters, The sorters are the last to get a break. You have to scan out for your 15 minute break and after your 15 minute break you start to pick and stage, when you get the bags ready for the prime trucks the majority of the bags are on the floor not on the racks nothing is really organize, so you waste time looking for bags that on your scanner playing the hunting game, yet they wants you to do three pick and stage before clocking out, at 12 noon,  but sometime you end up with a huge pick and stage where their three racks that you have to push by yourself from one side of the warehouse to wherever you have to stage your items, one rack at a time, by the time your finish it’s time to clock out.
advice_management: This is a billion dollar company get some 32 oz Gatorade in these warehouses people sweat and bust their behind working hard and limping getting packages ready for the customers, the least you can do is make sure folks thirst is quench with something other than warm bottle water and unfrozen popsicles, Gatorade is $1 for a 32 oz at Kroger’s. Make sure you have enough sorters because it’s hard on the pickers to have to figure out where to put the jiffies and the boxes when their is no room to put anything on those racks, clean your warehouse of the numerous water bottles laying on the floor so no one will break their neck in the process of moving their racks, to the prime delivery areas, give us PTO and medical like you do the full time people at the fulfillment center, and stop timing us on what we do when you know their are older people on the job that aren’t as fast at picking and staging, their are people that aren’t physically able to move as fast as younger people.  The job isn’t difficult so stop making it difficult, just so you can write people up, Amazon change people like clothing, instead of retaining your employees and training in other areas, you hire new people. I never met anyone working five years here, three years top that as far as it goes, when you can cross train folks and let them grow with the company, instead some are fired for attendance and if they had PTO every pay week during their pay period they would be covered. Full time workers get 10 hour PTO every pay period that they can use, for emergencies but seasonal and part time people don’t, get PTO. It’s seems to me that amazon sets you up to fail, use you for the season and that’s it.

summary: "Your experience depends entirely on your team"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Amazon can be a great place to work. Employees are generally empowered to take full ownership of problems and drive solutions entirely. This means that you can have an outsized impact relatively early on. If senior management is on your side you'll be able to push your vision forward and change the world in a meaningful way.
cons: The primary drawbacks are that the hours are long and if you have a bad manager your life will be miserable. In many respects this isn't all that different to most companies, but you'll feel it more acutely at Amazon. Also, if you work on an unsexy, unglamorous team, your best bet is to switch teams.
advice_management: Hiring for SDEs is getting worse, not better. Raising the bar is only meaningful if the best people stick around, and that no longer seems to be the case.

summary: "Where builders can build and take risks, learn and improve"

cons: When your business gets big you spend a lot more time on upward reviews and less on innovation. Easier to get hired in at a senior level than to get promoted from within at all levels.
advice_management: Appreciate what you have in talent and provide them career mobility instead of losing them

job_title: Current Employee - CSA - Customer Service Associate
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Work From Home
Pay, benefits,
cons: They lie about schedules, they promise they will work with you, but then they do not. They pick their favorites and then everyone else is treated like crud. They insist that if you do a good job you will be promoted and rewarded, not true. Management is a joke. They need to fire most of the Team Managers they have and get ones who actually engage with the employees and care.
advice_management: Get your act together, treat your employees like they are humans and not numbers. Be there for your teams, it should not take you hours to respond to messages, makes us think you are not doing your job and not watching your computer as you should be
