summary: "Great Place to Start a Sales Career"
job_title: Current Employee - Demand Generation Representative - Inbound
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
Wonderful co-workers.
Inbound direct managers are great.
Free Bananas and Starbucks drip coffee.
Goals are very well-defined.
cons:
High metrics. Possible, but if you take more than a couple days off you're going to have a hard time hitting them.

Little communication from leadership on organization goals and progress.

Working overtime will not help you catch up if you fall behind.
advice_management:
Regularly propagate top-down communications of goals and progress for the organization. Share the org's vision and progress regularly.

Lower the metrics and keep them the same for everyone regardless of tenure, people are hitting them because they are afraid to take time off and working outside of working hours to make career progress.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Amazon offers amazing benefits -- health, dental, vision, etc. In addition, they provide you with a free Orca card for transportation at no extra cost to you. They offer amazing training that is very engaged and catered. HR rep for Seattle location was great. She always checked in to receive feedback from employees and address concerns and issues.
cons: The compensation at a retail level was minimum wage. I understand it is retail, but paying minimum wage is just bottom of the barrel -- shows how much you value these employees who are on the frontline with Amazon customers. Amazon speaks of customer obsession, excitement around products, but offer a compensation that is considered poverty level in Seattle.
advice_management: Be up front with candidates applying for particular roles. Don't tell interviewees that the role doesn't entail "x", then they begin the job and its based entirely around "x".

advice_management: Share the wealth

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros: NONE. Terrible company!!! Evil! Don’t take a job here!
cons: Abusive  managers. Evil. Greedy. Don’t work for corporate! Their jobs are a joke! Low and terrible pay. They keep all the money for the top executives. Awful, sneaky, lying and manipulative coworkers and managers! Run! They will set you up for FAILURE on purpose! Then they will FIRE you! They don’t want to pay a living wage in major cities when doing a white collar job! Also, if you are an American citizen, don’t bother applying because they only hire non-citizen foreigners for cheap labor (at the white collar level)! They also hire a bunch of temps on a contract so that they don’t have to pay them benefits. Weird, evil, immoral, conniving, lying people work here! RUN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

cons:

advice_management: * We move fast, making downstream internal communication uneven - Provide a monthly one-page snapshot indicating recent wins, how the group is executing against our goals, where we can improve, and what's coming next

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: I applied online and choose night shift which is from 6pm to 4:30am wed-sat then was given an option to choose what day I wanted to go in for a hire event (no interview) 4 days later at 4pm. I went to the hire event and just had to fill out personal paperwork , took a drug test and got my picture taken. 5days later I got a email saying I passed the drug test and background check and was now hired. I’ve been working for 3 days so far it’s easy but your body gets super sore. I can barely walk my feet hurt so bad . My upper back and shoulders hurt they burn and feel like needles. I can’t bend over cause my lower back also hurts but it’s only my 3rd day so I’ll see how it goes. Pay is $15.45 $0.60 extra for night shift. Benefits since day one. Everyone is always so positive. There’s no uniform. Free coffee and gatorade in cafeteria.
cons: Long hours of constantly going up and down a ladder to stow items. You need to move fast they track your time and how much you stow . No cellsphones allowed they must stay in your locker at all times. Once you enter the building there’s no signal.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year

summary: "This is not your parent's typical corporate gig"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Amazon looks for 'general athletes' that can pivot and address many different types of issues. This keeps my job interesting and self-directed. Amazon expects employees to look for and take novel approaches to problem solving. If you like to be told exactly what to do, this is not the place for you. Here you do your research, ask for advice, do tests, and decide on your own. You build your own projects and use metrics to explain impact. Amazon gives you tools, you build toward results.
cons: Onboarding is almost as self-directed as any other aspect of working here. Need help setting up your desk? Good luck buddy, you'll need it when finding IT help. Training in my area is basically about 2 week's worth of videos and quizzes teaching you the basics of  the app-like tools and the about the culture of Amazon. Ramping up is fast and hard but if you're a general athlete, you'll be fine.
advice_management: Run a skills assessment on new employees to understand functional areas that new hires might need to develop.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: I'm in a very diversity team and everyone in my team is willing to help me. Considering this is my first full-time job, I feel glad that I can work in Amazon.
cons: No free lunch and dinner :(

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: 3 days off and sometimes there's food.
cons: Possibly the worst job to do, especially right out of college. More of a people job than a technical job.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Pay, employee engagement events, snacks
cons:
The only employees they care about engaging are hourly associates. 

There is no checks and balances in place to ensure the site leader doesn't hire their friends from other stations.

Some leadership roles do not  have definition l so they literally sit around all day while others carry the bulk of the work 

If you have bad HR, they will target you to save their own hides. 

Harassment is allowed as long as it doesn't impact certain people. 

If you are a minority in salaried management, be prepared to answer questions about your race.
advice_management: Pay attention to who you put in stretch roles.

summary: "If you are lucky, good team. Otherwise, you are for some stressful times"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: The reputation that you get for being a Software Developer at Amazon, means you are above a certain bar.  If you work on backend services, you will be exposed to all things AWS.
cons: If you are lucky you get to work on a good team with good management, I know some people that are in that situation. However, my experience was on the other side of the coin, small team with tier 1 services and terrible manager and skip level.  There are some really bad managers that will make your time at Amazon a nightmare,  some are former developers that are new to management that will not stick for the team member, you will be overloaded and will work crazy hours and no matter whether you complain on the different survey mechanism these managers will just be shuffled.
advice_management: Get rid of bad managers, they destroy morale and eventually confirm all the bad things  that were once published in the New York Times article a few years back.

job_title: Former Employee - Digital Device Advanced Technician
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 8 years

advice_management: Give a pat on the back to problem solvers that go through the motions, but save real celebrations for real problem solving, and actually put some resources into it.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: The benefits are amazing, not just medical but they’ll pay for career path degrees in college. Scheduling is your choice and they do give you paid time off right from the start.
cons:
It’s a revolving door. It’s very difficult to move up in the warehouse positions, it’s very easy to get negative feedback and get fired. 
The amount of time off received is not enough to cover energencies and a vacation week if needed.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros: Very good pay, challenging, opportunity to lead large groups, growth opportunities to develop in the company.
cons: Work/life balance is non-existent, 16 hour days, shift work, could be working nights or bouncing back and forth from days to nights, on your feet the entire shift, not allowed to take time for lunch or to sit down, no breaks allowed for management because you are working through the Associates breaks doing their jobs.
advice_management: Treat your employees better, give them time to eat, take a break, and stay healthy. Get rid of the people are just numbers that are replaceable mentality.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: expected autonomy is great for developing a range of skills. Great pay. Flexibility to work from home, etc.
cons: The Leadership Principles look great on paper. But the combination of them and to the extent to which senior leadership pushes this culture down will ensure that anything resembling a work life balance is a pipe dream
advice_management: Treat your employees like people. Stretch goals only work if they are achievable. Otherwise they just cause turnover and employee resentment.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Orientation the stand out statement is : you are GIVEN 2 SHARES of Amazon! There is plenty of free coffee for those that drink coffee, and the break room is big and has a large big screen and you meet some genuinely good people.  I recommend this to individual with military backgrounds.
cons: There is no standing around at Amazon for the warehouse workers.  There is some favoritism and backstabbing. The mentality is usually tired and not shown enough appreciation. Not for civilian type personalities.
advice_management: Communicate with warehouse associates of all levels. Get to know  your team,  and there character.   If you are going to make a judgement call; then speak on it and be sincere.

summary: "if you don't suck up to them and drink  4 red bulls a day expect to get fired"
main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros: Amazon prime....-shrugs-....you get to wear almost whatever you want. If you like drama this is the place for you!

advice_management: Be managers....this isn't high school...and we are all professionals trying to get a check....be decent human beings if you are capable of it.....signs say no...

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Decent benefits, keeps the rent paid.
cons:
75% of your time is spent engaging in truly preposterous manual processes. Imagine moving a pile of salt with tweezers.

If a problem affects only one person, its not really a problem until the boss gets in trouble for it.

Sounds silly, but it's true; I worked for one year as the sole US representative of a team on the other side of the planet. I never met them, but about 30% of the other people in my office did.

One day the bubble gum and paperclips holding together this part of this business will come undone, but management will have escaped to another part of the business by then.
advice_management: Good luck, you're gonna do great.

summary: "Short term, no promise of long term."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Had a job that paid me
cons: Not enough work, no organizational skills, every one was fighting just to get routes.  And if they didn't have routes they told you to go to the warehouse where there wasn't anything to do.  Then they randomly laid off over 100 people, they said it was computer generated but oddly enough we were about to hit our 90 days.
advice_management: Be honest, stop keeping your employees in the dark and stop treating them like they are nothing, without them your company won't thrive the way it is.

summary: "Take heed this is a real assesment"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Four ten hour days, three days off per week
cons: They hire you for a specific position and then when you arrive they put you where they want. They are not truthful they tell you one thing and do another. They monitor you on every package you touch you are basically timed and expected to reach quota. You work on a conveyor line and have eight carts and or pallets to fill and then pull them out take it to a specific bay to load onto a trailer. While you are doing that your line is backing up and you have no help. They say if there is a box fifty pounds or over you need to get someone to help do not lift alone  There is no one to help everyone is too busy and no one is around to help. If you need to talk with HR or any other department you are expected to do that on your lunch break so ridiculous!  This is the truth per a Supervisor at Amazon "the average employment time for an Amazon employee  is three to four months" that is all you need to know

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Stock.  But unless you get a boatload, it isn’t worth it
cons: If you love being in a backstabbing cult - then AWS Public Sector is for you!  Worst culture.  EVER.
advice_management: Stop encouraging and promoting evil people.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Challenging physical work that will push you to do better, and multiple career options to branch out into
cons: Stack ranking that leads to favoritism and elitism, and god help you if you get injured. Between miscommunication and lack of communication between HR, Sedgwick, and AP3 the process of workers comp is like pulling teeth, and if you are not PERFECT in keeping on top of it you will end up getting punished for getting hurt in their warehouse.
advice_management: Lose the stack ranking, stop dealing with Sedgwick, and train your HR team to be able to better help people you're policies have gotten hurt, I'm not the only one that feels this way.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Fast-paced, high energy, smart people, willing to invent/try new things/processes.
cons: With an organization this large and fast-paced, it can be tough at times to find the right person to get to the right answer and understand who actually approves decisions.  The fast-paced nature of the company can make it challenging because people move so often that there is constantly loss of knowledge in processes and past-successes and failures if things are not documented properly.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Good pay, overnight positions available
cons: Hardly any training. No interview process- if you pass the background check and drug test you're hired. There's no rhyme or reason to their 2 day "training." High overturn in employment. No human interaction. Thought I was going for an interview, turns out to be a 3hr presentation and a drug test- no mention of that in the email I received. Never actually spoke to someone about the job and what was required of me. Thought I would be on the sorting line and turns out my shift was for pulling and staging pallets. No one mentioned that at my "orientation."
advice_management: HUMAN interaction. I find it ridiculous that "Alexa" called to remind me of my "upcoming orientation" and not a person from the location I applied for. Also, clearer job requirements and expectations. And better training before "throwing newbies into the fire."

job_title: Former Employee - Web Development Engineer II
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The salary is pretty high, all-in-all I was at about 160k/year.  Still not worth it.
cons:
The culture is awful, if you're a software engineer I highly suggest you find another job as there are many more.  I worked in downtown Seattle for an AWS team, and everyone in the building I worked in seemed perpetually depressed.  Hours were long (some team members worked 30+ hours straight), and almost all employees were foreigners on H1B visas who were more-or-less forced to put up with the conditions or leave the country.

In addition to this, the internal tooling is really old and outdated, leaving few opportunities to learn cutting edge technologies and the developer operations is an extremely mismanaged nightmare.

I've never seen people crying at their desk like some claim to have seen, but nonetheless, this is obviously not a healthy place to work.

cons: The culture is great but it's been an adjustment. The roles are very independent and although you work with your team, it's not the traditional style. As long as you have a good relationship with your team, there's always someone willing to help and answer questions

Theres an over flow of people being hired, no thought to who they are actually hiring. Not much direction on who you go to what for even for a simple call out. Your doing exactly what a other delivery persons are doing just for less.
advice_management: Get more organized, pay attention to who is being hired, Different start times for all drivers 1 time for all drivers is NOT efficient

summary: "Best place to work but have problemas as any other company"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: It's one of the few companies that you can create something new or fix something that is not working properly and be recognized by this. It's not the company that your manager just say: This is not your task, go talk with the owner to fix this or just route issues to someone else. We really feel that we are builders and we can work in a flexible and innovative environment
cons: As any company we have bad managers or those guys that are just smart enough to cheat the hiring process and get hired. As Amazon grows more and more people from other companies like Oracle, IBM, Microsoft try to get hired at Amazon and this brings the good people and the bad people. Sorry, we are not perfect and those bad people get hired too.
advice_management: The messaging from Jeff Bezos 20 years ago is still valid and the culture it not something that you can bend as adapt to your view. It's something to keep at the core and not be "interpreted". It's time to get back to the roots and review some people that got hired if they are really following the leadership principles and have the cultural behavior or if they are just bending the LP's to their own view.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Flexible at times. Pay is ok for the work.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
-benefits: almost every employee talks about the great benefits. medical, dental, retirement.
-very easy to apply
cons:
-Management can seem to be invisible, you may not even know who the manager is.
-You have a quota that you must meet. If you fail to meet the "numbers", you can be written up.
-Long days on a cement floor, and sometimes really heavy lifting with no assistance.
-People can be a little abrasive to work with and some employees learned English as a second language. Difficult to communicate over loud warehouse environment.
advice_management:
Managers and Supervisors need to be
Amazon Warehouse boasts an open door policy. This allows for employees to talk to both supervisors, managers, HR, etc.. without fear. This is a sound business practice, however, how can the individuals communicate with their chain of command if they have no idea who those individuals are.

Relax on the rating system
Many of the supervisors stress employees to reach a certain quota. If this quota is not reached, they will be reprimanded, retrained and eventually let off. This is understandable for a company to seek elevated productivity, however, many employees feel they are being abused. Quota over safety and health of the employees is the belief of much of the warehouse.  

Lack of trainers
Many employees have voiced their concern over training in collateral duties in each respective area of the warehouse. It is difficult to understand why certain duties are not being fulfilled, however, no employees are being trained to complete those duties. Those that perform highly in their respective field are not rewarded with more job training, but instead granted more work. 

Work Hard, Have Fun, Make History
Morale is quite low in the warehouse. (Just an observation).  With "Have Fun" as a motto at the warehouse, one would assume you would actually be having fun. Many say "Have Fun" sarcastically before returning to their shift.

summary: "Great experience for a first job out of college"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Bonuses, promote quickly, team based environment
cons: Poor work life balance, long hours

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: interesting problems, complex designs, exposure to new technologies - but highly dependent on team.
cons: Promotions are very political (even though they claim merit based) and highly dependent on your manager and how he/she will present your projects (even though they claim it's more on you).   Then it is determined by how much you've won over the x number of engineers you've worked with.  If your manager changes (my team has had 4 managers over the past 2 years) it effectively resets your promotion process which is not ideal.
advice_management: Give interesting + high visibility projects to devs earlier / also start promotion talk/steps earlier.  Don't wait until your team members are pissed and leave right after promotion because they've felt underappreciated & underpaid for a long time.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Great Company, Good Schedule, Great Pay, Room for Growth, Overtime if you want it!!! Its a good part time job for certain people..
cons:
Back breaking work. 
Stowing and pretty much every job there is for the younger generation.. I consider myself an average middle age woman in good shape. You have to be in REALLY good physical shape to throw those packages all night, up and down, right AND left at the rate they want you to go,  Up to 70 pounds and yes it's production!!! @50 years old, my back just can't take it. It day 5 and I'm in pain.
advice_management: Consider the older skilled workers, Hire men to do the heavy stuff and let the women do the latter.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Your coworkers are great people.
cons: The building I was at, was very poorly managed. They hire people to be supervisors and have tier one associates teach them their jobs. Training was pretty much non existent. They really don't care about the employees. But I managed to hang on for 5 yrs
advice_management: Bring in all new management.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Fascinating company and very innovative. Everyone really gets to take ownership of their work.  It is a very autonomous environment. You manage your own time and create your own prescreen templates.
cons:
Their processes are severely flawed.  It was like working in an agency, but without the commissions.  Super heavy workload of reqs, agency metrics, recruiters who were extremely aggressive and cut-throat.   If you love agency recruiting, you might like it, but you won't get the payoff of commissions and if you like corporate recruiting, you probably won't like it at all.   You have to be prepared to play the political game and win the popularity contest to get promoted.

It is the most subjective hiring I have ever experienced in recruiting.  The recruiters and even client leads are treated like administrative assistants and have zero buy-in from hiring managers.  They are not even allowed to speak during debriefs, where group think and subjective reasoning run rampant.  It is grossly flawed every step of the process.  You  are treated like anything BUT a trusted adviser.  They only use behavior based interviewing based on their 14 leadership principles so they miss key points of making effective hiring decisions.  STAR based interviewing a an effective "piece" for making decisions, but it should be combined with hypothetical questioning  and an actual assessment of technical and soft skills to make a truly informed and objective hiring decision.  The number of exceptionally talented candidates who are turned away  is unacceptable.
advice_management: Start over.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years

cons: Work is hard on your body, too much change in process, not enough positive engagement.

summary: "Challenging, rewarding, and wary of burn out"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon
pros: You will learn a lot, and get paid well.  Leadership generally adheres to Leadership principles.  You will receive helpful feedback on your performance. Defined culture and “way of doing things”.  The people are generally decent, and really smart.  Good resume builder, as you can shape the future of many industry leading businesses.  If you have the strength, grit, and tenacity, you can produce some really great achievements.  You will have to work through the more of tedious and manual work for a long time, but if you can invest the extra time, you will come out on the other side as a self-sufficient expert who is highly effective.
cons: Amazon is not designed for long term careers; I’ve been on 6 different teams and very high turnover is the norm.  Your work load never stops increasing.   Amazon wants you to work overtime everyday to keep up.  Hard to have a life outside of work.  If something should be done then you will own doing it indefinitely (a lot of times), no matter if your plate is already full.  This is especially true if you are on the critical path of delivering a customer experience (I.e. any unit of supply).  Systems are all in infancy stage, and automation path is slow (+years), so you bear the burden of the automation gaps - which can be high amounts of manual work (>50-75% of your normal work hours).  Multiple kinds of business reviews going on all the time: WBR, MBR, QBR, OBR, Topical Reviews etc... multiplied by every country!  These sap the life out of you, because your sole focus is preparing Call Outs (interesting changes in metrics) for the next Business Review - each having Sr VP scrutiny, driving follow up work as well... it can feel like a full-time job in itself.  The tedious work is piled really high, and doing something creative or strategic generally happens on your own time.
advice_management: You need to give people more space and time to be creative, and respect the burden of the work they already carry before you keep adding to it.  Burn out is happening all the time as a result.  People do not feel respected in this area.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
1. Amazon has amazing and high-efficient management strategy. Here, I understood why this company continues growing rapidly given that the turnover rate is bigger than companies like Google and a lot of people have short tenure. Amazon is my first job, and I changed from a student to an industry leader after staying at Amazon for 3 years.
2. Amazon has a lot of smart and passionate people. They are role models for my career and technical growth. I benefited from working here with them.
3. Amazon functions like a startup, and I was impressed by a lot of new and great ideas popped up from people's brains every day.
4.  My projects at Amazon are always challenging and I can always learn new things from them.
5. Maybe only specific to my org (Amazon Advertising) - promotion in my org is very frequent. Every quarter, I saw a lot of people getting promoted.
cons:
1. Since everyone is working hard, sometimes work will be stressful, and I had to escape from work sometimes to relax myself.
2. Benefits at Amazon are worse than companies like Google, e.g. no free lunch/dinner at Amazon, 401 match is smaller, etc.
3. There are indeed a few teams that are not good, where I saw people getting fired frequently. But that really depends on teams. For my team where I stayed for 3 years, I didn't see anyone being fired.
4. Amazon has oncall culture, which may be bad in some teams. But in my team, our oncall load is reasonable.
advice_management: Benefits can be better

summary: "Whether or not it's worth working here depends on who you are working with"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I have met some truly beautiful people at Amazon, people who are concerned and thoughtful and dedicated to others. The company's focus on the customer has garnered well-earned praise.
cons: Very often cliques emerge, and when these cliques start to move up the ladder, they take their friends, and push everyone else down. Also, everybody makes a big deal about metrics, but the metrics don't matter. The metrics can be made to say anything.
advice_management: Upper management should start paying attention to the whole person. Right now, only the opinion of the current manager matters, even if their opinion is at odds with every manager who has come before.

summary: ""It is a job without any support from the company""
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: The benefits and freedom to work from home
cons:
There are many cons in this work from home, the first against is that you do not receive enough support to solve customer problems, the change of schedule in less than 6 months, and the change of skills without sufficient knowledge, it is not enough a training of a couple of hours to be able to assist the customers in the indicated way, and above all to be able to fulfill the goals.
They do not give the necessary time to be able to have at least the basic knowledge of each market, and if you do not meet the metrics of the new market, your manager puts you in a counsel.
advice_management:
Give a better training, and above all give more support to the agents who work from home, the chat that is there to help is not the necessary support, since all those who are in the chat are agents too and cannot always help Those who ask for it.

My suggestion is that there should be a chat that is only support for agents.

summary: "Fast Pace. Self-motivated. Huge Impact. Self-satisfaction. Flexible location"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: This is my 4th companies to work for in  my career and Amazon has been the best one yet. This is NOT a place for a slow learner / dependent. You are expected to understand the team goals and define your best contribution to get the team there quickly. You will spend a lot of time self-learn Amazon ways. You are expected to escalate the roadblock immediately and identify correct support to keep hitting milestones. You will learn and grow a ton here with many other great Amazonians. Failure is expected but you are also expected to never make same failure again. For 1 year working at Amazon, I have learned more than I know the past 7 years. However, if you are not self-motivated / dependent on someone's guidance, this is not a place for you. Plus, Amazon practically has a building in every big city in the world now so you can go on vacations and work at Amazon building in your travel city without the need of using vacation time or combine them together.
cons: No great benefit (free lunch /snack) like Google / FB. Only banana is free. 401k is weaker than Google / FB. Senior manager is sometimes busy so lost track of priorities so if you do not help bring them back to realities, prioritization can be a struggle.
advice_management: Keep up the good hiring process. It is working. Amazonians are the best co-workers I have ever been working with. Prioritization can be improved.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
• Starting Wage of $15.85 for Nights and 14.85 for Days
• A very busy job that will have little down time.
• Lots of Overtime possibilities that you can get paid time and a half.
• Very great staff that are friendly and will listen to your concerns.
• Has plenty of A/C in the Warehouse
• Not doing the same job over and over again and allows promotion and multiple different training options.
• Integrity Staffing Solutions is a great way and easy way to get into Amazon as long as they are hiring.
cons:
• There are many different positions in the Warehouse that require rate to be met. Being vocal is a necessity which if you are not, you are going to have a bad time. (This is more of a con towards non-vocal people)
• Mandatory Overtime can be flung at you with little notice which can catch you off guard if you expect to only work 40 Hours. Expect to take 50hrs and 60hrs shifts at Amazon from time to time. (This is more of a con towards people who want a more stable schedule)
• If you got hired through Integrity Staffing Soulutions, you are hired as an contractor so you lose some of the benefits that Full Time Amazon Employees have aka. Blue Badges. Also getting a Blue Badge is very competitive so make sure to stand out.

job_title: Former Employee - Seasonal SDS Logistics and Customer Care
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Good starting wage, thorough training, caring leaders, fulfilling for those who like to help people.
cons:
For seasonal employees right out of training we were thrown into calls quickly and it was mandatory for us to work a certain amount of overtime per week. With the schedule I had, I worked 10 hrs a day and adding extra hours was such a task. I suffered from fatigue and it was no way around it. 

Crazy resource center, its hard to find anything without specific keywords. 

Hard to find help when needed.
advice_management: You have such a good thing going. The company is set up to win, don't overwork your employees, just hire enough.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: You get paid okay, if they let you stay all day.
cons: You are treated like a robot and told to work harder/faster by higher ups who do little to no physical labor. Breaks are very limited, you actually don’t get to use the full duration of your break due to the “scan to scan” policy. The work load can be unbearable and is constantly raised to meet demands. I understand I didn’t sign up for an easy job, but this is by far the hardest jobs I have ever done.
advice_management: Please listen to employee complaints. Please give us space to breath.

summary: "It is a great place to work"

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: It's a big company doing a lot of different types of development work, so there is a lot of opportunity to learn and grow in different directions. The base pay and stock options are pretty high, and the other benefits are okay.
cons:
1. Many teams prioritize velocity and new feature development over code quality or operational excellence, leading to excruciating on calls. By the time teams realize they do need to do major refactors, the code base is complete spaghetti that no one on the team fully understands.
2. The public statements made by the company about AWS Rekognition are incredibly concerning and frankly unethical. Management has not listened to the large numbers of employees who have expressed concerns, and has been vague and hand-wavey about the company's moral responsibilities regarding facial recognition technology.
advice_management:
1. You might have better velocity and more innovation if you prioritize removing legacy systems more often and slow down a little less in the short term.
2. Recognize your moral obligations as technologists to not build questionable tech, and to use tech responsibly. Don't wait for the government to tell you it's illegal before deciding it's immoral.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros: All Tier 1 associates get paid the same, and those that show interest in learning are often given chances to learn new roles, and earn a few more hours each week.
cons: All Tier 1 associates are paid the same at Delivery stations. Regardless of if the pull 4 routes in 4 hours or 6 routes in 4 hours.  And the laziest person that kisses the right butt usually gets promoted before the hard working, proactive person.  Management yells are you, even if they are completely wrong.  They will also throw you under the bus for telling you the wrong information.
advice_management: Not hire an HR person that has worked in that warehouse in a prior role, and is friends with some of the associates.  Because sometimes things that are suppose to only be known in the walls of the office, ends out on the floor.

summary: "UNORGANIZED. They’re still trying to figure it out"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The job can be easy depending on location
cons:
-  SAFETY. The didn’t have first aid kits in the facility my first couple of months. They still don’t have first aid kits in our vans!
- Untrained managers
- network has terrible connection
- managers will say different thing about policies. One time the boss over our facility said something about what we do while deliberating and the next day a manager said the total opposite .
- support isn’t great. They will be mad about you not helping others (rescuing), but won’t send them when you need help. They only send recuses to people who usually are not doing anything.
- The system have connectivity issues, but they’ll still write you up for having unproductive time. I don’t know how people can get wrote up or warnings for unproductive time if there’s not a connection to track someone.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year

cons: Work life. Although salary, it’s based on 40 hour ls but in reality averages 50-60

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Experience many different services and technologies.
cons: Being forced to meet arbitrary goals that change often.  No time to dive deep into a customers issue because we must take as many cases as possible. High Stress environment. Unreliable management. Rare career growth within Amazon. No leadership from Management.
advice_management: AWS Support was good years ago, but recently in the past 1-2 years there has been a dramatic shift in management. AWS Support does not currently care about its employees and only cares about metrics, when the metrics don't line up they find a way to mark an employee as under-performing and put them through the Amazon Pivot process. Management is also guided to lie to you about performance and it benefits the manager to terminate you as soon as possible. This culture currently in place in AWS Support is toxic. It is supported by current VP leadership in support and I would encourage management take a step back and look at what they are doing to the role.

summary: "Don’t fall for the bogus positive reviews"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: I can’t think of any. I mean Insurance is decent but not that great, pay is livable.the only positive thing I can say is I liked the people I worked with.
cons:
Amazon is hands down THE WORST company Ive ever worked for. If you hear or read any different they’re probably managers or on boarding personnel and technically HAVE to say it’s an amazing company to work for and it’s all sunshine and roses with opportunities to grow and be a part of something big. THEY ARE FLAT OUT LIES

I’ve worked at amazon twice now and both times were absolute HELL.

-They give you a brief 15 minute safety walk through with all the do’s and dont’s and a 20 minute video your first day then send you to work
-Unrealistic expectation of how fast and item needs to be picked, packed or stowed. 
-they have to know what you’re doing every millisecond of everyday you’re on the clock. If it’s not related to work it’s a write up. (I had a manager come after me for taking too long to use the restroom)
-you never get to see family and friends and miss out on a lot. 
-forget about having time to go back to school.
-if you get hurt your SOL, their onsite medical staff doesn’t care and you’re considered replaceable.
-you apply and apply and apply for opportunities for advancement but unless you know someone or have seniority you’ll be stuck in one station by yourself during your entire employment.
-you’ll get hurt...a lot. save your back and knees cause you’ll never be the same. 
-Severe micromanagement 
-you get in trouble for things that aren’t your fault and are out of your control. 

Bottom line is, the pay and benefits aren’t worth the physical, mental and emotional stress.
advice_management: Jeff needs to do undercover boss and work a day in an FC and figure out a better model.

pros: Pay is decent. Lots of chances for overtime
cons: Favoritism is rampant here. Very poor management.  They don’t want to be bothered with you, unless you’re a favorite.  If you’re not a favorite expect to be badgered about time off task and your rate constantly. If you’re a favorite you can expect to stand around the managers desk and do nothing all day. Don’t worry about time of task because you will be keyed in for a “ special project” I’ve worked for Amazon for 5 years and have had 18 different managers. Preach safety and rules constantly but there’s really no consequences for breaking them, for some people, so people just basically do what they want.  Come here if you don’t mind working with lazy people who stand around and do nothing all day while you bust your butt and management looks the other way.
advice_management: stop the favoritism, same rules should apply to everyone. Listen.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
*truly an inspiring place to work - so many cool projects and super smart people
* ability to make an impact
*amazing opportunity to try a variety of different roles
*organized and process oriented
*data based decision making
*fast-paced/decisions made quickly
*autonomy and ownership
*high level of accountability across the company
*FUN
cons:
*Amazon has a significant negative impact on the environment, and they really need to step up the efforts toward carbon neutrality before it's too late. 
*individual experiences can be  quite different based on the team you're on
advice_management: As a global leader, Amazon has a responsibility to project our communities and the environment. Leadership decisions don't reflect this. The only reason I could foresee myself quitting my job is if this doesn't change, and it's not only me; over 8K Amazon corporate employees signed the climate plan resolution letter calling for change, and this is only the beginning - the movement will grow and there will be increasing pressure until Amazon takes action.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Some of the best people I have ever met - while they last. Fitness initially improves, pace is exciting.
cons: Fitness and focus increase over first 1,5 years but then declines as performance deteriorates due to injuries caused by doing the work without regard to proper posture and form (specifically, it comes in improperly stowed so it is hazardous to pull and unhealthy to perform for any period of time. The absence of a pre-employment physical means that any injury that occurs over time can be denied as prexisting. I loved the company and people and did not understand the need to operate this way - when you are the industry leader.
advice_management: Lead by walking around - not by staring at Tablets. Be positive. Stop being afraid to challenge something that is broken. Stop eating your own.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The job itself is engaging because you are constantly moving around and interacting with your associates and fellow managers. You will be assigned to manage a team of 40-80 employees and expected to drive their rates ane keep them motivated.
cons: Working with upper management and co-managers can be stressful and straining. If you are straight out of college or new to operations, people from inside the company may not have your best interest in mind. Managers are constantly under-appreciated and driven to find new ways to motivate associates; There is very few positive feedback or incentive, if any, given to managers. Expect to work an average of 50 hours a week and be loaded with administrative work.
advice_management: Pay your employees more; Your salaries for operations supervisors/managers are not competitive with industry standard. Find more ways to appreciate not only the associates but also the managers within the fulfillment center.

job_title: Current Employee - Manager - Customer Solutions Management (AWS)
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
If you're just starting out, arguably there is no better place to learn how to function in a highly competitive and rapidly changing market such as Cloud Computing. Amazon (AWS in my case) teaches you (you mostly teach yourself) how to approach almost any business/technical situation using their Leadership Principles (LPs). The Amazonian way is highly structured in many regards, in that the LPs are something you must embrace and embody if you want to succeed here. On the other hand, Amazon has structured their organization and their culture a lot like a startup. The basis for this is the Two Pizza Team (TPT) construct. TPTs aren't successful merely because the small team size. The effectiveness of the TPT is more about the autonomy these teams are given to solve virtually any problem they encounter, so long as it ties back to the customer. This leads me to an important point: Of all the LPs at Amazon, Customer Obsession is the one that rules them all. Everything we do connects back to solving problems for our customers. In fact we "work backwards" from the customer on just about everything we do. It is truly obsessive. 

Our motto is: Work Hard. Have Fun. Make History.  And this is exactly what we are doing.
cons:
What I am listing here are not "cons" per se for me. I just know that many folks might see them this way. 

Amazon is not for everyone. If you are looking for lavish perks, you won't find them here. One of our LPs is Frugality. Like most everything we do, this ties back to the customer. If we are spending tons of cash on employee perks, we are reducing our ability to offer the best prices on our goods and services. I personally don't see this as a "con," but I know that many folks might, so I placed it here. 

If I had to describe my experience here thus far using only one word, that word would be "athletic." You are constantly challenged here, and while most folks think they want to be constantly challenged, far fewer actually do in reality. This is my experience. So before coming to work here, spend some time with any Amazonians you know. Ask them what it's like. and listen carefully.
advice_management: Athletes (see my comment above) need top quality fuel. The cafeterias here are serving up low quality, nutrient poor foods like hamburgers, pizza, and french fries. Please consider bringing in some new vendors that can offer fresh, organic foods that are delicious and healthy. A good example is Sweet Greens here in NY. As we employees pay for these meals, and there are no subsidies, there is little or no cost for Amazon to do this. Other ideas: A daily sushi station. Organic juice and smoothy station. Organic salad bar (fresh, locally sourced).

cons: On the retail side at least, things can become a bit routine so you need to really take initiative to keep making the job interesting.. Opportunities for advancement exist, but there is a lot of competition. It's a large organization so it can be hard to figure out how to reach out to people in other areas of the company.
advice_management: Good job on communication and being responsive to any staff concerns when they are identified. Try to find out how there can be more cross-pollination between departments.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I enjoy working at Amazon because of the fast paced, driven culture. I consider my coworkers the cream of the crop, and I am inspired daily by the diverse talent. Amazon's culture around mistakes is very forgiving. I have benefited from the ability to make mistakes and learn from them without repercussion. The environment is incredibly fast-paced, which has helped learn to prioritize, speak up when something isn't right, and flex my ability to work autonomously.
cons: Amazon is a large organization, so this sometimes results in duplicate work, organizational politics, and extreme competition. This is sometimes a challenge to moving forward, but as with any con, can be turned into a growth opportunity if you're willing to flex your muscles and dig in to tough situations.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: The company is sanely run and tries to improve itself constantly.
cons:
Within retail, at least, there can be a little too much churn of trying to coordinate between large organizations.

Some say that you have to work crazy hours. Personally, it was less than at any other job I have held - far better than most startups - but I presume that it depends on where you end up in the company. It's a big place, I expect that you can find almost any working environment, somewhere.
advice_management: You should create a tool that tracks projects and estimates, company wide, with the connected dependencies across teams as part of the declaration, so that it creates a dependency chain between all teams and organizations. When things change, it would notify everyone affected and update estimates across the company. It would also allow hotspots to be identified where, because of demand and necessity, some teams end up with a backlog of years worth of requests, but insufficient manpower to deal with it, becoming a bottleneck for others and leading to the creation of competing products within the company.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Paid weekly. Easy to be hired on.
cons:
The hiring process was horrendous. I had done everything online prior to my first appointment. When you go in, they treat you like cattle. They want to get you in and get you out and there is no time for questions.

I applied for the shift that I wanted and after going through the drug test and screening, my shift, the hours and my start date was CHANGED 4 TIMES IN 5 DAYS. I even called to make sure they had secured my schedule and start date, the amazon employee in Seattle assured me they had, then a few hours later I would get an email saying that I needed to pick a new schedule and then given a new start date. 

I was supposed to receive the orientation link to do online. After calling 3 separate days, I still did not get the Orientation Email - 2 days before start date and still have not received it.

They hire everyone on as Seasonal. I had no idea because I applied for Part Time. No where on my paperwork did it say Seasonal. I found this out at my appointment. Amazon cuts costs this way because they don't have to pay tuition reimbursement or health benefits. 

They literally hire anyone that can pass a drug test and criminal background. This means you can work with the laziest or unprofessional employees and have to pick up their slack.

Very impersonable. Honestly, this experience has made me severely rethink purchasing through them online knowing what the person goes through who's putting my box together. 

My Husband also had an interview for a management position as he has a Business Degree. The guy that did his interview was literally on his phone the entire time and was like "Don't worry, I'm listening to you." as he continued to scroll through his phone. 

***If you're looking for a good paying warehouse job in the area, check out QT, FedEx and Walmart Warehouse in Harrisonville or Ottawa Kansas.***
advice_management: We're human beings, not numbers.

main_text: I worked at Amazon
pros: The only thing I good I can say about working here is that you get paid weekely
cons:
Don’t even know where to start. Definitely one of the worst jobs I’ve ever had. 
Expect pain in your legs, feet, ankles EVERYDAY. You’re so tired after (1) shift you don’t have time for anything but to eat and sleep. I don’t have kids but if you do, don’t expect to have much energy to bop around with them. I can barely come home and run my shower. 
Look I know you want to make some money and $15/hr looks appealing. But TRUST ME this isn’t it. You’re working for every minute of that $15. 30 minutes of backbreaking work for $15/hr is equivalent to $7.50. 
Try it if you must, but my advice... don’t even waste your time
advice_management: Allow music, offer more opportunities to move up. It’s people in there that know the job better than the people that are “upper management”. Have rubber mats around to alleviate the pain on the joints.

summary: "See something, say something. An Amazonian Fulfillment Associate "Behind the Smile" review"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Benefits on Day 1.  Start dosing on ibuprofen beforehand as a countermeasure for the Amazonian experience that commences shortly thereafter.
cons:
I got my first look inside an Amazon Fulfillment Center as a Fulfillment Associate. My perspective on Amazon has changed as a result. This isn't some Amazon bashing missive, but more of a bare bones raw analysis of a middle-aged man's experience inside Jeff's castle. 

It's a grueling job and isn't for the meek or timid. Your body will hurt after 9 hours of manual labor with 2- 1/2 hour breaks. I never complained about the work; I knew going into the position almost every muscle fiber in my body would plead for mercy and relief. If you've ever watched the Spartan events on TV or YouTube, be prepared to face similar challenges at Amazon's FC's if you're not used to physical labor. I'm a very fit individual; my tolerance may be higher than yours. Most Fulfillment Associates throw in the towel at the 4 month mark per my Area Manager; many don't make it that far (either due to exhaustion or they are fired for performance). They have their own in-house clinic to keep aches, pains, moans, and groans "in-house." In addition, it's no surprise during training, the Learning Ambassadors were quick to point out the PPE (Personal Protective Equipment) vending machine always freshly stocked with OTC painkillers, antacids, eye drops, etc. to combat the sheer bruteness of the $15 hr. job. By the way, you need to scan your badge for those ibuprofen; your dosing is monitored. 

Nonetheless, I put the pain aside in an attempt to climb the promotion ladder and kept up the pace. You will be evaluated for Time On Task (or TOT for short) and quality & quantity of your scans. Mr. Bezos expects 9 full hours of work for every calorie consumed by a Fulfillment Associate. I never once had a performance issue although I was coached for a safety issue. 

Eventually, my "fight or flight" response set in. My body was being used as a vessel; there is a consequence for taking this position. It's not all smiles on the inside of an Amazon FC, but cries of pain concealed by OTC painkillers and a false sense of security. There is this "robotic culture" within an Amazon FC that simply replaces your devoid flesh like a Amazon drone picking up an empty plastic water bottle left in the grass. As soon as the Amazon drone lifts off and discards your body, you're replaced with a fresh set of legs until that water source runs dry. It's a vicious cycle repeated week after week. It's what makes Amazon so successful. 

I have no ill-will towards my former employer. I still shop on Amazon, but my check-out experience is a little more painful for internal reasons
advice_management: The robot culture at Amazon needs to be reintroduced to a human strain.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year

summary: "Great money for students and young adults looking for work!"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
My time at Amazon has been really great so far. I'm currently in college and wanted a way to make some money before school started and the application process for Amazon is super easy and they update their job postings daily.

The work can be very physical depending on your individual role but such is life with a warehouse job. Comfy shoes are definitely a must because of how much you're standing and moving around. 

The managers I  work under are the two greatest guys and the other training associates are all super helpful and supportive.  They've been quick to compliment myself and others for doing a good job and are glad to give more direction if you have any questions.

For a college student like myself the pay is really nice considering I could be making far less as a cashier somewhere else. There are also a bunch of opportunities to pick up more hours or take some time off if need be.
cons:
The job can be physically demanding depending on your specific position. 

Not all co-workers give the same effort (can be for various reasons) which makes it harder to meet deadlines and can cause you to pick up their slack. 

I get a lot of questions about not being able to use the bathroom when working which is false. You're free to go whenever you like just not 10x in a shift and staying in their for a long time. During crunch time I'd say its frowned upon to go but it's no different than any retail job when you're busy. You go when you have time not when it's busy because then you leave more work for your coworkers.
advice_management: Place people in appropriate positions for their body types and personality traits.

advice_management: Create a conducive work environment. Stop the toxic culture; eliminate bureaucrats; build a performance management system that is credible.

summary: "Deceptive, Bureaucratic Cesspool Thriving From Slave Labor"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: healthcare benefits, stock purchase place and 401K
cons: During the recruitment process you're asked to answer a survey about your desired shift. If you select part-time they will hire you and won't inform you that you're full-time until the first day. They phrase it as "Reduced Time" because it's 36 hours,  (3-days, 12 hour shifts) instead of 40 (5-days, 8 hour shifts). But that doesn't  matter because you stated that you only wanted to work 24 hours maximum per week. Then they try to pressure you into staying. They don't care that you purposely wanted to be part-time because you're in school full-time, already have another full-time job, kids and a family. All they care about is themselves and keeping employment as a revolving door. You get lured in with wage differential shifts at rates of $17-18 overnights and weekends but what they don't tell you is that the intensity of the labor and the rate at which you're expected to perform said labor isn't worth it. Truly everyone in stowing should be making at least $25/hour its the toughest job in the warehouse. Also, when you're hired, they don't tell you which jobs are available and assess your skill level or experience, they just assign you to a post and you take it or quit. They say you can move around and try other positions later but there's a 30 day waiting period and you have to have a certain amount of UPT (unpaid time) in the bank to show that you're responsible. You can't have your phone with you on the warehouse floor for "safety" reasons. If you challenge the validity of that statement they say "It's also to protect proprietary information and the company." Mind you everything we perform and the machines and systems we use has been debuted on prime time  news outlets and on YouTube by Amazon for publicity. So it's not to protect proprietary stuff. It's so if conflict arises or you want to document working conditions you can't and then its just your work against theirs. They claim we also can't have phones on the warehouse floor because they fulfill cellphone orders. I seriously doubt that security wouldn't be able to tell the difference between a new phone and a newly stolen phone. First of all, one can't be activated and the other already has service, photos, phone numbers, etc in it. Bathrooms and water fountains are super far from work stations. You have less than 10 minutes to get to the bathroom and use it and return to your work station or your metrics drop. The metric system for time is so unfair. The 1/2 mile, 10 minute foot commute to and from the time clock and through security metal detector checkpoint is apart of the actual break period. So your 30 minute break could essentially become a 15 minute break. If you get to the time clock and punch back in 1 minute too late you're assessed 1 whole hour of UPT (unpaid time). You only get 20 hours every quarter (once every 4 months). If you're working only 12 hour shifts that's not even 2 days off if you have a family emergency or illness. PTO is is worse. Amazon outsources their leave requests to a third party -The Reed Group. Requirements to qualify for unpaid leaves are sketchy. God forbid you have an HR issue. Site HR persons will tell you to go online to the HR portal and will flat out refuse to help you. The automated response you get from some person or bot online directs you back to site HR. It's a big circle and vicious cycle of passing the buck. The performance metrics for stowing are unreasonable and cause fatigue. You have to move 300 units per hour at a rate of 10 seconds between each item you place on a shelf in a pod. Most of the pods are stuffed and overflowing so there's nowhere to stick the items or it takes longer for you to maneuver other items around that are already in the pod to make room for your items. You also have to place empty bins aside so that takes away from your Tackt time (10 second max) which might move you up to 30 seconds. The compliance metrics are even more insane because if decanters make a mistake on their counts it reflects poorly on you as an overage or shortage, because they don't do QA compliance or tracking  in decant. The Working Well program and stretches performed during  stand up before your shift are a joke and don't work. AmCare is to placate employees to return to work injured instead of seeking real medical care.
advice_management: The capitalist monster that is Amazon, which consumes employees and spits them out, cannot thrive if you don't conceded to their brainwashing, and bullying, harassment and micromanagement of lower lying employees. Stand up, and refuse to assimilate.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Coworkers make the job easier to endure.
cons: * Limited restroom breaks, and when you do leave your station for a break you only have a few minutes to get right back. * Heat is UNBEARABLE in the warehouse and not enough fans or water coolers throughout the warehouse to keep employees cool and hydrated. When workers feel sick from heat, supervisors will not allow them to go home without taking personal points against them which could lead to them being terminated. * Supervisors have different rules; there is no conformity from one day to another. * There are no scheduled breaks or lunch times. Supervisors decide when you can take breaks. EXTREMELY frustrating when you count on that set time to use the restroom or call your child to say goodnight. * Restrooms are ALWAYS extremely disgusting and dirty without toilet paper, soap to wash hands or paper towels. This is an every day issue. SOOO much more I could write......
advice_management: CEO Bezos needs to spend more time focusing on warehouse employee concerns re conditions at job sites.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Amazon has great outlook for the future and endless opportunity to promote from within with hard work. Overtime opportunities are very frequent.
cons: Odd hours including nights and weekends. There is a learning curve in regards to Amazon daily operations.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Tons of stuff to learn and easy mobility between teams.  The pace of work and life at Amazon is very fast and there's always something going on.
cons: Managers vary across internal divisions (AWS, dot com, etc), verticals, etc.  If you have a non-responsive or bad manager, you have to move teams, that's the only way things really work here.  Compensation is great, but the stock distribution in years 3 and 4 come at quite a shock to people (not in a great way).
advice_management: Be more up front about why compensation is the way it is with more insight into level bands.  Continue to empower teams to be autonomous and build, this is the heart of the business and AWS in particular.  Be sensitive to the world in which we live and try to work more with the US government and other governments to help make good decisions with the technology we produce.

summary: "Horrible Experience!!! Refuse to pay me, no credibility, liars!"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Easy to get hired if you can pass drug test and background check.
cons: Totally disorganized, poor leaderhip, unresponsive to complaints, refuse to pay me for training and work. Had to resign after four days on-the-road because of knee problems. Gave them a resignation letter, even though they claim to have fired me. Have gone to facility four times to resolve refusal to pay me, emailed at least four times, called five times, with promises it would be resolved within 48 hours - still no paycheck 6 weeks later. Haven't even recorded my hours on ADP portal. I believe they are stalling so that I will miss filing deadlines. I'VE HAD TO KEEP RECORDS OF EVERYTHING!! Have had to borrow money to pay my bills. Filed with L&I. Seeking advice from EEOC, talked to lawyer. I have multipe disabilities - has triggered my PTSD! During all this, also trying to find employment, which is always difficult because of my disabilities.  An absolute nightmare!!!
advice_management: Don't outsource to India. Unresponsive, liars, made simple resolvable problem into lawsuit. Shameful way of conducting business for a company that I had such faith in! I was really, really happy to have been hired by Amazon! Can't believe you won't pay me my pittance paycheck!

Rely heavily on call time for performance, penalized by getting weekends and evening hours when your call time is high... but your call time is high because you didn’t have proper training... Amazon is a joke.

summary: "RUN. THIS IS NOT THE AMAZON YOU EXPECT. NOT COLLABORATIVE NOR PROGRESSIVE. THIS PLACE IS TOXIC. RUN. DO NOT WALK"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: The ONLY pro are the benefits- benefits are unbeatable
cons: Many other reviews have summarized this place well so I will try to describe instances not listed on Glassdoor. TLDR; described by current employees as a "social experiment" "mind games" "toxic" "carrot and stick approach". This department is a “data warehouse” where you are expected to come in, sit down, shut up and hit your quota. They do not care about ANYTHING except SLAs. THIS IS NOT THE COLLABORATIVE, MODERN, PROGRESSIVE AMAZON YOU HAVE IN MIND; this is the Amazon they want to keep quiet. For over a year, I would wake up with extreme anxiety. There were mornings I would have panic attacks and start crying before 9 AM for no reason other than this job made me miserable beyond belief. This job DOES NOT translate well into other positions because there is so little required of you; there is little to no skill development nor career growth here. You are bound by a strict NDA, which further limits what you can disclose on your resume. In terms of growth, I had to BEG for stretch projects that I could work on to develop my skill set and to help me gain visibility within the organization. I was doing everything in my power to find a position internally/externally where I would actually be using my brain and contributing towards real progress. Luckily for me, my mentors at Amazon saw what a struggle it was to get promoted internally and encouraged me to look for positions outside of Amazon- even providing me references. BE AWARE that once you hit Level 3 you will hit a wall and you will be told that to level up any further it is in your hands. It will be up to you to "create a role" that "fills a business need" and then management ~MIGHT~ consider it if you are convincing enough.  Your extra efforts and strong skills don’t matter and will not be recognized unless YOU make a role for yourself.  Otherwise, if sitting at a computer pressing the same 5-10 keys sounds appealing to you then this is your place. Especially if you enjoy being micromanaged and having your every waking second time tracked. To add insult to injury, at managers DO NOT TRAIN OR WORK IN YOUR WORKFLOW; this means you can never go to your manager with a workflow specific question because THEY DON’T KNOW! Yet your manager will try to provide you with “tips” and “advice’ on how to “do better”- pretty hypocritical coming from someone who has NEVER worked in the workflow.  The most discouraging thing about this role is to see the rapid turnover throughout Senior Management and Operations; everyone above you transitions in and out of new projects, roles, and advances their career paths in a few months time, while the rest of the associate population withers away with no opportunity. You will also be expected to fill "stretch roles"- roles meant to be temporary or that seem like an opportunity of redemption before being promoted; it is neither of those things. These "stretch roles" are meant to seem enticing and appetizing as if they are there for vindication. They are actually a trap to get you to do way more for way less.  Otherwise, permitted you are hitting production goals you WILL sit idly by doing “queue work” for the rest of your days here

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Part of the Amazon culture is to develop their employees. We hold tight to our leadership principles, and support one another, to grow professionally. If your focus is on the customer this is the right company for you. Amazon is the most customer obsessed company that I have ever known. We have a diverse culture, and enjoy having fun.
cons: Amazon is growing rapidly. With this growth comes frequent change. It is necessary to be flexible and adaptable.
advice_management: Keep an open mind, and share your knowledge and ideas! Amazon appreciates diversity and creativity in all branches. And be prepared to have fun!

summary: "Best Company To Work for in the World"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Amazon genuinely cares about each and every associate.  They are geared twords helping you advance up the ranks within the company.  They thoroughly train you and give you the tools needed to succeed. I would reccomend anyone to work for this company.  They give you a good work/life balance unlike other warehouses you get 3 days off a week accept for busy seasons you will work occasional overtime.
cons: i don't have any cons as i have not had any negative encounters on the job at amazon.
advice_management: keep up the good work in helping employees succeed and grow within the company.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
You get to do things people talk about. I mean it - I remember the first time when I heard random people in a tour bus in a different country talking about something my team did at Amazon in the US. 

There are no textbooks that can teach you do things at Amazon's scale, you get to invent new solutions that never existed before. Sr. Leadership is typically OK with us choosing how we get things done. We get to deal with ambiguity a lot with little supervision.
cons: I am concerned that past Sr. Manager level in the company your growth opportunities are limited. While it is true that as a Sr. Manager you can do a lot of interesting things, based on my observations, the average time it takes to organically grow from Sr. Manager to Director are ranging from 5 to 10 years. All this time you will be just Sr. Manager.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I have worked at AWS for 3 years now, helping customers on their cloud adoption journey.  Things I like about AWS?  The fact that we actually live our leadership principals everyday.  The innovation and the freedom to take risks.  The quality of our people.  The freedom to really focus on my customers.  The strong support for employee development and training.  I came from Big 4 consulting and my experience here  at AWS is head and shoulders above.
cons: Downsides?  You have the potential to be overwhelmed by all of the new services we provide our customers so it is important to not only be a life long learner but to have the ability to focus on only what YOU need to dive deep on.  You can't know everything.
advice_management: Keep up the good work.  Keep on raising the bar on expectations and what we deliver to our customers.

summary: "An excellent place to work in high-tech."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Amazon's Leadership Principles are actually seen in practice every day in my division.   New hires are provided excellent training and made to feel included immediately.    Internal communication for such a large company is outstanding.  Heavy emphasis on learning and bringing your creativity to work.
cons: Haven't found any major cons after 6 months on the job.  Have been very happy here.

summary: "I can't imagine working at any other company after Amazon."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I love the amount of ownership that they give me over my career. They have great internal tools for tracking development and a network of wonderful mentors. We have a very diverse team with different backgrounds so I get access to viewpoints that I may have not considered. I love that you have the ability to switch teams if yours isn't a good fit without a tenure minimum in a role. I also love the trust that my manager has in me to get things done.
cons: I work with a lot of smart people and it is easy to get intimidated at times. I have a great work-life balance, but I do see others who do not put as many boundaries as I do to ensure they take time for self-care.
advice_management: Keep investing in employees and career development tools.  Keep the hiring bar high.

summary: "10 years of great people, experiences, and learning"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Opportunity to figure out what needs to be accomplished, make a plan, and go do it.
There is always someone who knows more.
Daily, automated, anonymous feedback mechanism that tracks your relationship with your manager so that their manager has insight into the relationship.
cons: Ambiguity.  Most of the time, the need to create something new requires operating without clear direction and I've seen it drive some folks nuts.  Being able to work without guidance, a path/process to follow, will be essential for any exempt employee.
advice_management: In my experience, senior leadership will respond to a direct email with at least a sentence or two, sometimes with an offer of an half-hour to discuss the topic.

summary: "Long hours and short breaks; but GREAT benefits"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Benefits are amazing; medical, dental, vision, 401(k), stocks (not awarded anymore); also raised pay to $15/hr minimum! EAP program and fantastic maternity leave
cons: Took away our annual stocks, took away attendance bonus,  long hours w few breaks, no loyalty to employees at all, productivity rates set high and difficult to meet (can get fired for not making rate), get in trouble for “time off task” (ie using the restroom, not moving fast enough, talking to coworkers at all)
advice_management: Treat your employees like people instead of just a number; reconsider how rates are calculated because they’ve become unrealistic goals unless you’re a robot

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: A lot of nice people working with you.
cons: 9+ hours on your feet constantly moving boxes was pretty exhausting.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for more than a year
