cons: hours vary so sometimes you'll be at 20 or less hours a week

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: You don't really need a gym membership for this type of job. You spend up to 10 hours a day lifting, squatting, moving up and down short stairs and walking long distances. I average 18-20K steps a day there. People are super friendly.
cons: The expectations of rates you have to meet per day. At times they are unrealistic due to factors that occur working there. Bins too full, wrong sized bins approaching, boxes aren't scanning properly, and "water spiders" not fully trained to know what you need (small and medium/large boxes) per day to satisfy the expectations of your rates. It will not matter if those factors affect your job as a stower, you WILL get punished no matter what. I have worked hard and constantly moving to at least try and still, I get worn out physically and punished. Unfair and unreasonable.
advice_management: Make sure the "water spiders" are trained properly before they help stowers, and to  REMOVE the punishment (write-ups) when the stowers are ENTIRELY not at fault. It will discourage them (myself included) and start to second-guess the potential we have to acheive making Amazon experience for customers a great success.

summary: "My feet hurt, and my mind is numb"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Benefits are not so bad
cons: Working conditions are tough. Amazombies are real.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros:
Benefit, Paid day off
401k, discount
cons: Long hours, hight rate and productivity

main_text: I have been working at Amazon
pros: Good pay and variety of shifts
cons: Management is terrible at communicating changes.

summary: "DUT1 - A good job to have for a short while"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros: It's honest, hard work, and good exercise. There are good managers, and good co-workers.
cons: Warehouse gets hot in the summer, despite efforts to keep it cool. Focus seems to be on getting work done as fast as possible rather than on maintaining high quality, though you'll constantly be reminded of your mistakes. Training on correct techniques to perform jobs at expected levels is minimal to non-existent. Equipment needed for jobs is poorly cared for, and in some cases inadequate to do the work required.
advice_management: Focus more on training employees to do the job correctly. Bringing in a group of 10-20 people, shouting out a few tips at stand up meeting, and then throwing them out to work while expecting them to keep pace leaves people lost, wastes time as more experienced workers have to go back and fix mistakes. Make sure that equipment (scanners, devices, label guns, etc) are getting regular maintenance and kept in proper working order. The dock team loses a lot of time dealing with issues in the induct process because they deal with substandard equipment. If you're going to claim quality matters, consider how much staffing you have and how much volume is legitimately feasible before pushing an insane flow rate of packages. The whole team struggles to keep up with what is asked, and we often end up doing things twice or three times. Let us do the job we are paid to do rather than rush us out early after stressing us out to push the volume through.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
The paycheck
The consistency in schedules
cons:
Told to pick schedule but didn't get the schedule.
The work was very tiring, the work there started affecting physical health. A month later and I am still recovering from the strain the job put on my body. A lot of heavy lifting. They want to stow 8 secs rates even when pods are 90% capacity.  15 mins break were really five mins
advice_management: Your workers are not robots, give worker actual breaks. Breaks should not be from stow to stow.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: The benefits are a big reason most people work at Amazon. Mulitple time off options from paid to unpaid plus vacation. Off for holidays such as christmas eve christmas and new years eve. Other holdiays we work are paid.
cons: Long hours doing repetive functions,mandatory overtime which can lost for weeks and months to prepare for increased demand,limited time off hours so if you have no time you cant miss work under no circumstances.
advice_management: Know your associates better and be more understanding

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros: great work culture and opportunity for advancement
cons: Figure it yourself environment

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Shift choice, work attire,
cons: pay rate should be more, working through holidays due to peak seasons
advice_management: n/a

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Good pay for entry level , overtime available, multiple schedule options

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 8 years
pros: it's a company with a lot of innovations
cons: the cultrure changed in the past few years with more and more office politics

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Allowed to pick your schedule.
cons: if I could give them less than one star, I would.  the initial orientation was led by a person who had ZERO enthusiasm for his 'job'.  Training consisted of watching a series of videos (which were prefaced by comments 'try not to fall asleep') followed by written tests.  Those who didn't pass the written portions were given the same test to take minutes after given the answers. The hands on portion of training on the stand up fork lifts lasted all of 15 minutes,  followed by a mind numbing overview of identification of bar codes and the order picking process.   Formal training lasts all of a day and a half before you are put out on the floor to figure much of it out for yourself.  Good luck finding your way around a 1 million sq. ft warehouse dodging several different types of power equipment while the machine you are operating is slowed to 3 mph due to the fact that you are in 'training' mode for the first 30 days.  Many of the aisles have debris, mainly dog food from bags that were broken open and not properly swept up, and just run over.  There are some decent people working there, but know going in that most are not. Many are only there because they could pass a drug screen and they didn't have to interview to get hired.  Of the 20 people that were in my orientation, 4 were still employed after 3 days.  There are many upper management positions that are unfilled, and the management staff that are there are no doubt looking for openings at other locations.  This is a miserable job coupled with mandatory overtime (so much for the Amazon promise of work-life balance), lousy training programs and supervisors who are in way over their heads.
advice_management: Work hard, have fun, make history.

summary: "Ask Plenty of Questions about Job Description in Interview"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The culture and the people. Great Insurance, 401K Plan Match and others! Lots of Swag and a small discount on Amazon yearly.
cons: Not a lot of work/life balance. It still has the atmosphere of a call center.
advice_management: Have the job descriptions not be so misleading in job postings and turn over rate wouldn't be so high. Management should be more approachable.

cons: Getting started and feeling comfortable in a new role takes time and it can be difficult to become confident in what you are doing. It helps to ask a lot of questions.

summary: "Jacksonville Jax2 - Not a good place to work!"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Best reasons - health insurance
cons: unsympathetic and don't care attitude from management and HR, Slave driven by kids that have no real management skills, common sense, or people skills! Statics driven only - move faster and work harder - meet those metrics is all you hear.  Its who you know, if you want to get ahead!  Overwhelming amount of favoritism within the company!
advice_management: Get a real clue about the real world!

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Fast paced environment.  Dedication to Leadership Principles.  Job growth (with geographic flexibility)  An education in lean business operations / continuous process improvements.
cons: Amazon recently cut Operations manager pay 30%.  Adversarial work environment - managers are given little support by senior leadership and most-days spend hours "bridging" aspects of the operation that fell short to goal.  Workforce is primarily transient creating a constant environment of hiring/training/mistakes.  They leave because Amazon treats them like "labor hours" and not people.   Our site went from 100% full time employees to 100% part-time after Amazon increased hourly wage to $15/hr (not having to provide benefits to the part-time employees).   They misled the public with their pay benevolence while hiding their wage suppression and lack of commitment to employees with basic job benefits.  This is deceitful and immoral.

summary: "More opportunities than you could pursue in 5 lifetimes"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Note: I can only speak to AWS and the Solutions Architect role.  Retail or what have you may be different.

1.  Mind-blowing number of cool projects/teams/initiatives/programs to investigate.  
2.  Access to information/tools/etc.  Everywhere else I worked was all about fiefdoms and repelling any outsiders that take an interest in what your team has going.  No one feels threatened by someone shining a flashlight down their dark alley.
3.  The machine is very well oiled.  Of course nothing is perfect, but it is difficult to find an internal system or process that is hopelessly broken and only alive because of politics. 
4.  95%+ of the people you’ll ever interact with are friendly, approachable, and super helpful.  Including (and maybe especially) established rockstars that would pee in your face for talking to them anywhere else.
5.  No dead weight helpdesk guy hired in 2003 who hid in a corner and rode the wave of company growth to a Sr. Director role.  Somehow with no one reporting to him and responsibilities that could be handed over to a gibbon.
6.  At the same time, you don’t feel that depressing Dell vibe where employees are openly regarded as more disposable than the styrofoam cups in the break room where even basic coffee isn’t free.
7.  No blame games.  If something goes wrong there isn’t a tribunal convened to identify the perpetrator and no public hearings held to ensure everyone understands who the butt-monkey is.  At previous vendors, due to this behavior, I saw orgs (especially service orgs dear God) with headcount inflated by 500% because 15 CYA steps have been introduced into every process.
8.  You don’t need to worry about getting assigned to a project with a bunch of people whose competence and drive are an open question.  Its ok to simply trust people to know what they’re doing or at least be capable of figuring it out.
cons:
If you are the kind of person who rises to a challenge, these aren't really "cons" per se.  More like a heads up that Amazon is not just another paycheck with a different logo printed on it.  There really is something different going on here.

1.  The firehose takes some getting used to.   It never stops so don't look for pauses to catch your breath.  Embrace it and adjust.
2.  You are going to wonder how you could ever do everything on time with enough quality.  If the only answer you can come up with is brute force 80 hour weeks, you are doing something wrong.  They'll take it if that's all you got, but honestly they don't want you to do that.  They want you to innovate and work smarter.  They trust you can do this.
3.  You may well doubt yourself at first.  This is the mediocrity of past employer's expectations talking.  After a while you'll be kind of insulted when you realize your previous leadership didn't believe you could be exceptional.

If this all sounds too exhausting or unreasonable, you may want to reconsider.  Its kinda like doing crossfit for 4 hours a day.  A certain type of person would consider that hell on earth and another would revel in it.
advice_management: Keep on keepin on.

cons: Amazon recently cut Operations manager pay 30%. I currently work in Fresno and the Front Half Night Team welcomed me with open arms!!! I am a former veteran, team work, communication, and cohesion are my pillars for a career..... Amazon has definitely fulfilled those pillars.

So many ways to advance in this company
cons: The only thing I can see...… you don't get the location you applied for
advice_management: Continue to Promote the Teamwork concept

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The people are the best. Always willing to help, no egos, very supportive, and extremely intelligent. Benefits start Day 1. Flexible Spending Account is funded on Day 1. Amazon has great compensation at every level. On-boarding is the best I have ever experienced in over 20 years with other top global organizations in their space. The culture is awesome. The Leadership Principles are lived on a daily basis, which is extremely rare in most companies. The Earth's most customer-centric company is, by far, the best place I have ever worked!
cons: No real negatives here. The environment can be intense and is very fast-paced, however, I find this to be a Pro.
advice_management: Keep giving great advice, supporting your team and stakeholders, and stay peculiar!

job_title: Current Employee - Amazon Prime Now Whole Foods Shopper
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: It’s a fun and easy job that makes a decent amount of money. “Flexible” schedule.
cons:
1. Disorganized management 
2. Very hard to schedule shifts
advice_management: Make getting shifts more streamlined and easier for workers on your website. Also don’t overhire the amount of shoppers you employ as that overpacks shift schedules and doesn’t give people the chance to work as much.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Great benefits that start the first day. You get good time off hours that can be used without your supervisors approval.
cons:
The work is very tedious and exhausting. No electronics are allowed on the floor there's also no music played. They expect you to be a human robot for 10 hours and only pay $15. Meanwhile this is a multi-billion dollar company. They dont want you to sit down in your station or rest even when the machine is down. My body aches so bad I dont feel like signing up for extra hours. 
Use your UPT first they try to take it for every little thing. If you're even one minute late they'll take a hour. Once you're UPT is in the negative you're fired. No bonuses for reaching or exceeding their expectations. I'm just doing this for the summer cant wait to quit!!!!!!

Simple
cons:

Not a job you stay at

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Amazing benefits, PTO, UPT, Vacation, LOA's
cons: Long hours, mandatory over time
advice_management: Please know your workers. Treat your workers with respect and don't write them up for nothing. Know your hard workers and your lazy ones. Learn how to communicate.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Decent pay and good benefits
cons: Managers watch your performance  like hawks if you do not produce you will be written up and eventually fired.  This is tremendously stressful to the employees people are angling and backstabbing to stay there, management forces associates to compete rather than cooperate  so there is always an undercurrent of resentment
advice_management: Treat employees like adults the warehouse is run like a big daycare  the activities games and contests are so juvenile and  a transparent way to inspire performance.  I believe if management showed more respect and confidence in the workers there wouldn’t be such a high turnover.Because of the  informality of the environment a lot of workers behave as if it’s a place to socialize and not a serious place of employment

summary: "Great Place to grow and work, Worst Place to find any balance"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: There aren't enough words to describe how awesome it is to work at Amazon. Great challenges, fair promotion process, non-bureaucratic (sometimes has politics), smartest people, incredible challenges, and if you perform well then amazing pay.
cons: Diversity is an issue...it is a harder place for women to work because it's a progressive company with non-progressive policies and very few women in leadership. By the way, I am not a woman, but worked in one of the most diverse group at Amazon and I speak for them. There is also absolutely zero effort to provide people balance in life. The words "go home and rest" is often used, but then there is still an expectation you deliver on things that are not possible to do by one person. I worked 80-100 hours a week and that's not humanly possible for long. I aged 10 years in my 3 years there. I ultimately left because I believed in life over career as I got older.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Enterprise Account Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Resume builder, with having the Amazon logo
cons: Long hours of work using legacy systems

main_text: I have been working at Amazon
pros:
Great people to work with
So far my hours are perfect
Easiest amazon position - so I’ve heard...
Good exercise
cons:
Point system for hourly employees needs to be re-evaluated and/or taken away. It’s ridiculous that I had to get a total of 3 points (you are only allowed 6 in a 90 day period before being terminated) over these last two days due to an emergency with my dog. I am very angry about this and can’t seem to find anyone anywhere to discuss this matter with. I apologize for having to be home due to a vet emergency that could have resulted in death to my poor pup but I shouldn’t be punished for something out of my control. Also people do get sick as well, and racking up points for missing a day because of such situations is terrible. REEVALUATE YOUR POINT SYSTEM OR TAKE IT AWAY!!! Ridiculous! 

Lots of walking, pushing of heavy carts up and down ramps. Can be painful for employees who are not active in daily life. 

The warehouse layout is terrible. I understand it’s a new place (opened in October) but there should be 2 bathrooms on either side and the way the drivers pick up packages is completely u organized on both sides, making it inefficient for the drivers and the inability for them to move quickly through the lines to pack their packages.
advice_management:
Reevaluate or get rid of the point system. Especially for us hourly employees who have kids, animals and daily life that could make us sick. 

Redesign the warehouse for delivery. More organization please and less people standing around “chatting” on the clock.

cons: Barely anything in terms of raise, locked into two year contract which isn't mentioned when accepting job, have to repay bonus and relocation if you leave. main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years

summary: "Good place to get your foot in the door"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Amazon moves very quickly, especially for such a large company. You are able to work on high-profile projects even in an entry-level design position. If you are starting out in design, I would recommend it since you learn a lot very quickly. 

Because Amazon is so large, every team is almost like a different company, so it really depends on your manager and the product owners you work with to have a healthy working environment. For instance, I don't work more than 9-5 except in very special occasions.

I've found designers have it much easier than developers. Many times as a designer, you are able to shape a product in its early stages. 

The commitment to customer translates to caring quite a bit about ux research, though far more in the quantitative than qualitative.
cons:
It's very much a sink or swim environment, nobody will hold your hand and you really have to figure things out for yourself. Amazon has all the negatives of startup culture and corporate culture with few of positives. Things are disorganized and messy and everything is on a tight budget. 

It's very rare to find healthy developer/designer relationships. They exist, but are few and far between. Front-end developers just started being hired but most developers working front-end are trained as back-end and are learning as they go.

Product managers are truly the product designers at Amazon, and many will use designers to literally translate what they have in their mind. Again, your relationship with your product manager and dev team will make your break your experience here.
advice_management:
Invest more heavily in design in a real and meaningful way. For being a "Big Four tech company" our design culture is sorely lacking compared to the other three.  

Invest more heavily in quality front-end devs as well. We are very far behind and need to catch up.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year

cons:
Work/life balance (enjoy working 50+!), salary, quality of work, career fulfillment, non-existent collaboration, V poorly organized, attitude, toxic culture, mismanagement

There's a lot more but I'm out of space.
advice_management: If you have an entire organization which incentivizes the absence of workload over the quality of work performed, you end up with an entire company filled with people adverse to actually lifting a finger.  Great minds leave and you're left with a facade built with lazy hands.

advice_management: Nothing for you to change.

summary: "Don't do it unless you REALLY love warehousing."

cons:
one misstep and you're not very upward mobile.
culture can be vicious.
Once you learn your area- that's it. 
you will have more things to do than you can accomplish in a week, so you can either "pencil whip" or choose what you want to get fussed at for.
Associates expect you to do everything for them, you will solve the same problems day after day
Associates that don't like you will sabotage your Connections scores on purpose.
You WILL give Amazon your time for free. I have yet to work a 40-hour week. 
You WILL be grossly underpaid. My next peer (same level with less experience) makes 10,000 more than me.
advice_management: Stop piling things on the AMs, give power to the PA's to help out, have Ops take an active role on the floor.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Had some memorable and wonderful managers throughout my years at Amazon. The atmosphere was fast paced and I was able to learn from the best of the best on designing and developing software.

Some of the best internal development tools ever.
cons:
One bad manager can destroy your career. Upper management will always side with fellow management before listening to an engineer's plight.

Frequent managerial churn and updates to the promotion process can leave you at SDE I for too long and you'll be put on a PIP or Pivot (performance improvement plan, something of the like) after three years.

The exhausting pace at which you're expected to churn out products can seriously damage your code base, leading to horrific on-call experiences.
advice_management: Listen to your engineers.

summary: "Can be an unkind place to work."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Very smart people, you will learn a lot. Strong leadership at VP and above levels. Stock is doing great and still has good upside potential
cons: Terrible work life balance in any of the real growth businesses. Treat employees in an expedient manner. Very little performance leverage in compensation (its all about the stock price movements since you started regardless of whether you are top or bottom performer. Stock vesting is very backloaded so you need to be confident you will be allowed to stay til years 3 and 4). Impossible to get promoted despite what the recruiters say.
advice_management: Work harder at building partnership with employees where information is shared and processes are clear. Try to be more incremental in changes to your performance management system. The impact on people is large so take care that new systems are properly thought through, tested and have employee buy-in.

advice_management:
When an employee is on medical leave, don’t make it so hard for them to get paid!
I’ve been off since 6/6/2019 and I’m writing this on 7/15/2019! I haven’t gotten paid anything and I call and they tell me it may be another 45 days before I get anything! I ask for financial help and all they say is use your vacation time! All because my doctor won’t fill out 1 piece of paper because she wants to make sure she knows exactly what is wrong before she puts pen to paper! Even though I’ve been to about 6 appointments already and have to keep seeing different doctors so my doctor can probably fill out the form! I have a back issue and it’s not your typical back soreness so they trying to figure it out! In meantime I can’t work and now I’m probably bout to be evicted out on street because they won’t pay me anything until they get this paper signed by doctor! All I’m saying is treat your employees on medical leave like you still care about their life!

summary: "Absolute lack of concern for workers and humans"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
Your experience at Amazon is largely team-dependent. I've been on teams where I've had a great experience, with a project that had considerable buy-in. Other teams end up having many issues, with projects being abandoned or redundant.

The people at Amazon are smart, and very hard working. The work culture I would say isn't as awful as you would have expected a few years ago, and there's been a lot of effort to improve that area. The people are not the problem, it's the corporate structure and the priorities higher-up.
cons:
Abysmal HR structure. I had to communicate some urgent matters a few months before my start-date, but it took several emails to multiple people. Turnover rate is also high-- in between my internship and my full time return offer, I had changed between five different recruiters.

Disturbing lack of concern for ethics. AWS powers ICE technology. If you try to speak out, they will put you on a dev plan-- a polite way to threaten you into quiet. Rekognition is a facial recognition technology which they're trying to implement for the government, which could be used to police immigrants and citizens. Ring is a home-security technology that has been discovered to have partnered with 200 law enforcement agencies (with racial profiling issues). There have been "business dinners" between Amazon execs and government officials. There is no sense of accountability when developing technology used by the government, not even a basic standard of ethical guidelines. Employees that bring up these issues in various letters, protests, and articles have been met with complete silence. Their approach is simply to ignore.

Manager-dependent career trajectory. There are some good managers, and some... not so great. Politics are huge, as in most large corporate tech companies. Stocks are on an awful vesting schedule, rewarding you for staying as long as possible instead of incentivizing you to stay of your own accord. People leave Amazon very quickly and within my team there's been at least three people who have left or switched teams within this year.

Please avoid working for Amazon if possible. It will wear down your soul.

The environment inspires creativity and invention through the level of talent and focus on the customer.  I am constantly in awe at the caliber of the people and culture here.
cons: Because there are so many things going on at Amazon and the growth and rate of development is so fast, things change fast and it is hard to keep track of what is going on across the company.  You have to be willing and able to quickly adapt to an ever changing environment to be successful here.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: The only pro is that you get paid every week, but for the amount of work that you do, those little 200-250 checks are nothing.
cons:
Amazon is a slave company. If you are thinking about working here, please change your mind. New people get hired everyday because the job id extremely rigorous. This is the kind of job where they work you to THEEE BONE. They say you’ll get a 15, but as long as the conveyor belt is going, You are forbidden to leave your row. They run out of water and you might be lucky if you find one, or one that’s even cold. They hover you and make sure that you meet their quotas. At the Amazon facility in Elizabeth , NJ, the goal for each person is to scan at least 180-200 packages an hour. If you are lower than the set standard, a manager will come to you and let you know your scanning rate, and that you need to work faster to meet the standard. They dont check on you, ask you if you’re okay, bring you water and YOU’ll be LUCKY if the fans and AC’s are working!!!!! This places is A CATASTROPHE. 

They are HIGHLY engaged in favoritism, if you are black, there will be little to no care for you, your body, or your health. 99% are the managers are white and they will yell and tell you that you need to work faster.


They literally think we’re robots. We are slaves.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
- The AWS Elemental office in Portland is awesome. I'm from Seattle and moved to Portland for this role and was totally surprised by how relaxed and nice the people/work environment was there. 
- AWS Elemental focuses solely on cloud solutions for video streaming technology so it has a focus or theme, unlike other Amazon offices, where everyone may be doing something totally different (ie: retail, Alexa, AWS, other, etc.)
- Free food in the kitchen! Snacks on snacks, and La Croix for days.
- Free Friday Lunch! Awesome local food card food delivered and a speaker comes in to talk to us for an hour. No cell phones of computers allowed, just a time to sit back and learn about something new.
cons:
- Limited career opportunities, within Portland, outside of AWS Elemental. 
- They just opened a new office across the street (PDX17) but they are slow to fill it with new teams and roles. Looking forward to that though!
advice_management:
- I have been super lucky so far with my management. I truly enjoy my manager, as well as his Manager. 
- The way they deliver performance related feedback is great. I had old bosses who were passive or overly negative.

pros: It's one big family of colorful personalities! There are multiple positions you can take on (and they do cross training), and the teamwork is awesome there. The Ambassadors are really human and approachable during my shift. You also get a good workout (but it's easy work), which is pretty much what I needed anyways (I have always had a sitting office job, and this was a nice change of pace). I enjoy sorting alot more than some people because it keeps me busy until each break, and before I know it, work is over. It beats always checking the time. I feel accomplished at the end of my shifts, usually. I really enjoyed how they give everyone a chance at employment here. You start off seasonal and then convert to permanent if you desire. There's just a lot of opportunities here to grow and advance. You really do challenge yourself to be at your best (meeting rates for sorters). They have been providing food for our hardwork and gift cards as well, which is a great way to keep up the positive morale. You WILL make mistakes, but you are allowed to correct them and learn from them- I really like that about this place. They dont expect you to be perfect right away. There are chances you are given  and you don't get ridicule right off the back. Everything is a learning process. The base pay is a good! You have the flexibility to choose your schedule at the start, to fit your needs and lifestyle. You can take up VETs when available, for extra income, and VTOs! Safety is huge here, which I admire greatly. Bottom line is, so far the leaders seem quite empathetic, which is always nice. People stay or leave because of management, and I have to say right now it feels like family to me. Oh, and ambassadors always go over anything important during standup, so yay! Also, their app is a life savor. Everything you need to call out, request is there.
cons: It really just depends on how you were trained and by who. When I started, there was a small detail no one taught me about. It was actually quite important to know, but I quickly realized it was because during training, there was no opportunity to share that info physically (it needed to be demonstrated), and it is something easy to forget for anyone.
advice_management: Leaders lead by example, keep it up! Never micromanage, and thank you for being transparent. Stay human.

summary: "Some positive aspects, but mostly negative ones"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
- Entry-level pay slightly higher than industry standard
- Low-cost health, dental, vision, and life insurance
- Long breaks in between workweeks; 3 on/4 off, or 4 on/3 off
cons:
- Incompetent lower- and middle-management
- Abysmal vacation & time-off structure
- Thuggish tactics employed to prevent union activity
- Training for some positions and activities is improper; associates will often only be made aware they were not trained properly when they have committed a violation and have already been terminated
- No advancement opportunity
- No sick time, only an unpaid hour system that doubles as an employee attendance behavior monitoring system
advice_management:
Lower- and middle-management - who interact directly with entry-level associates - are not experienced in the warehouse field; they are simply in possession of at least a 4-year college degree, and this is the only qualification. Amazon should institute a culture of hiring managers in charge of directly supervising the primary work staff that have industry experience.

Amazon has a very low rate of employee retention due to its lackluster working conditions. There is no logistically significant reason that associates in some positions cannot perform their function while seated. Many functions require only arm and shoulder movement, which would not be impeded by a seated position. Many associates sought employment with Amazon because they are elderly or otherwise health-impaired and were in need of low-cost health insurance... the company has taken great advantage of those in such situations.

Amazon does not lay-off according to business seasonality, however, they will do whatever they can to fire as many people as they can find an excuse to fire. Often, they will only enforce some safety or procedural standards when they are looking for people to violate such standards. Write-ups are frequent, but only for performance-based faults. Any "violation" - legitimately documented in some sort of body of policy or not - is grounds for termination. There is no form of employee representation in matters that may possibly lead to dismissal, and most any such violation leads to termination, followed by an appeal process with a sub-1% success rate.

This facility has dutifully dismissed employees for union activity. A notable case was covered by news outlets in early Spring 2019, though numerous other employees have been terminated for the same reason. It seems that every time someone mentions union organization, they commit a "safety violation" and are terminated.

Additionally, they are not very graceful when employees seek to leave the company. I left on my own accord in April 2019 after 6 months of employment. I spoke to my manager, who told me "you can just stop coming it's fine." Feeling as though that was unprofessional, I spoke with HR, who informed me that the only way to leave the company "voluntarily" is to accept a buyout at the end of peak season or after completion of a career advancement course offered by the company, and that the only way to leave the company otherwise is to run yourself out of Unpaid Time - an hour-based pseudo-system used to monitor employee behavior -  and accept "involuntary separation of employment." I complained after my leaving to the NYSDOL about this, and two weeks later I received a letter from Amazon that did not directly acknowledge my NYSDOL complaint, but frequently repeated "voluntary separation," perhaps an example of the company backing down to their own questionable behaviors in an attempt to mitigate chances of a lawsuit.

Those managers who stay are only there until they can cash out their stocks, not because of the way they are treated.

summary: "Worked ONT 8 for 6 months: here's the scoop"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
Hourly pay is higher than most other jobs in the area, and overtime is offered frequently (where you make 1.5 your hourly salary). Shift bonuses for working nights and/or weekends.
 
Training is extensive to cover many situations and expectations are made clear. Safety is emphasized! There are always risks in the warehouse industry, but Amazon has a very comprehensive and consistent safety training compared to other warehouses in the area.

There is a positive work culture where questions and concerns are encouraged, and teamwork is emphasized. Area Managers and assistant managers (“Process Assistants”) are available and work to make the job easier and more possible for the standard workers to accomplish. (It was actually my AM and PA’s that made me want to return to the job after a gap in my seasonal employment since I had built relationships with them and they made the work day better). HR is usually available for any concerns, and they plan fun monthly events if you want to participate and receive prizes (tee shirts, candy bars, raffles, etc).

If you are a full-time employee ‘blue badge’ (and not a seasonal ‘white badge’) you get options for time off, paid sick time, and vacation hours. Many ‘blue badge’ workers also utilize the tuition program for college students. If you are willing to stay long term (multiple years) and are a dedicated worker, there are opportunities for growth within the company. 

You are supplied with all the safety gear you need, even common OTC medications should you need them. The breakrooms and bathrooms are nice (at least, nicer than other places I’ve worked) which makes the job easier.
cons:
It is a physical job, the environment is noisy and can be dirty. There is a lot of walking, the shifts are long, you will sweat, and you will get exhausted easily if you are not careful to make sure you sleep and eat enough. Many people who were used to office or customer services settings had a hard time adjusting to the warehouse setting, but some people actually prefer the warehouse setting. Just know going in that is very much a warehouse job.

You could be monitored on a system to make sure you are on task (and not “time off task”), to make sure you are not making to many errors (“quality”), and also to make sure you are getting enough work done (”making rate”). This should not be a problem if you are working well and at the expected pace, but some employees had a hard time getting used to having their work being closely monitored.

Traffic and parking is a bit of a hassle, but if you allow yourself enough time to get parked and walk into the building you will be fine.

If you are a Seasonal “white badge”:
- attendance is stringent. You will be required to be on time and present for the whole shift every day you are scheduled, even on mandatory overtime days. There are a few days/hours (they use a point system to track attendance) but if you miss more than 3 full days or 6 half days or are excessively tardy, they will discontinue your contract. However, this is alike to the attendance policies of most surrounding warehouses.
- be aware that they can stop your employment at any time for any reason without providing an explanation. This was stated during hiring, but then during training, many of us were told that if we worked hard we would probably get “converted”, so this created some false hope and unrealistic expectations. They will let white badges go if they need to, no matter how good or hard you worked.
advice_management:
Con: Even though employees should be 'flexible' and open to new situations, one of the things I (and that many others I knew) liked the most about the job was the predictability. Keeping an open line of honest communication sets clear expectations. Not telling the standard workers what is happening/changing just frustrates most of us, because we aren't stupid and can usually figure it out anyways. Change is good, but having at least a little warning makes it easier to adjust and makes for more efficient workers. 

Pro: It was actually my AM and PA’s that made me want to return to the job after a gap in my seasonal employment (laid off after Peak, rehired in April) since I had built relationships with them and they made the work day better. The sense of community and teamwork at Amazon is better than any of my previous warehouse jobs and made the job more pleasant (much more bearable, as opposed to "man, I really hate my job"). This makes a huge difference and will motivate employees to stay longer and become more efficient in their process.

summary: "Discontinuity and Lack or Resources Torpedoed My Morale"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: I loved this job initially.  It was a good environment and a good team.  I had the backing of my managers to succeed.
cons:
Constant reorgs: I had 4 different managers in under 2 years

Disruptive changes to mission come down from above with no input from the team and no warning, which didn't allow us to finish anything we started.

After these changes gut the team, when people get tired of it and go somewhere else in the company, back-filling takes forever.

As a front-line manager I am accountable to get work done regardless of how small the team gets, yet I have no direct control over hiring/recruiting.

My project was a multiyear waterfall project with firm dates and not enough people, and we were just expected to do whatever it took to hit the deadlines set years earlier.
advice_management:
Provide better training for managers, especially on the technology they are leading.
Don't chase off or fire good people simply because they are in the wrong role; give them a chance in a new role.

advice_management: For this position need more hands on training and job shadowing. Training Documentation for position. Longer lunches for positions that work 10.5 hour days...

job_title: Current Employee - Principal Technical Program Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
The work is exciting, fresh, innovative and creative. In my 17 year career I have never been in a company where I feel that my work matters and makes a difference, every day.

From your first day you I was given big problems to solve, and it has not slowed down. Amazonians want to get things done so delivering results is in everyone’s DNA. 

Decisions are data driven and I haven’t heard anyone say “my manager wants this so let’s do it”.

I should have joined sooner, so if you have an opportunity to work at Amazon, and if you liked the people you will be working with, do it! You won’t regret it.
cons: You need to pay attention and be very intentional about work-life balance.  Amazon gives you a lot of autonomy so you can end up owning more than you can handle.

summary: "A bunch of mid-Western MBA grads star-studded by the stock."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
- Smart people
- Good stock
- if you do not have a specific career path, lots of opporutnities to jump around within the company and keep making good money. If you know something you want to do (e.g. PM of Game Design), company is not useful on getting there in sooner than 6-7 years.
cons:
- 50% of pay is tied to stock (highly volatile for older employees planning family)
- No free meals/lunches
- Managers aren't really "people managers", they're high individual performers using management to get to the next stepping stone
- Everyone and I mean EVERYONE is doing 2 jobs, overworked. I know people who have almost divorced because of the jobs. 
- The company is held together by "duct tape" solutions, tech debt up to the eyeballs, bosses just trying to get to a career milestone then move on.

summary: "Good work life balance if you’re on the right team."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
I hear this is certainly not true for every team, but I think my team is great and I’m very happy at Amazon.

- My work life balance is great. I hardly ever have to work more than 40 hours/week. The few times that I do, I don’t particularly mind since I rarely have to. 

- My team and manager are really chill. Nobody cares when I get to the office, when I leave, or exactly how many hours I was there. I’m certainly expected to get my work done, but I feel like I have a lot of freedom to work on my projects however I’d like. I also work from home about once a week.

- This is especially true for Amazon Web Services (where I work) but I feel fortunate that I can learn how to use all the services on AWS for free. My field uses AWS pretty extensively, but it’s normally pretty expensive if you want to use it a lot. We get it all for free and we use it a lot in our everyday work, so I feel pretty lucky to be able to learn it.
cons:
- Compared to other tech companies Amazon is undoubtedly very cheap. We have to pay for all of our own food, the food is expensive, and it’s also mediocre. Parking isn’t even free. Our benefits are okay but not as good as other tech companies. Our office space looks fine but pretty minimalist. I find this to be minor in the grand scheme of things but it’s definitely noticeable.

- I dislike being on-call. I’m on call for a week at a time about once every two months. During that time you’re handed a pager and you have to be available 24/7 for issues. This could potentially be on a random weekend afternoon, 8 am in the morning, or worst of all, the dreaded 3 am pager ringing. Fortunately I’m not on-call all that often so I just suck it up and deal with it whenever it rolls around.
advice_management: I’m not entirely convinced that “frugality” is the greatest long term strategy.

summary: "Surviving the Amazon Box Jungle is Brutal."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Its easy to get a job without the dreaded interview process most employers insist on using resulting in a more diverse and interesting workforce.
cons:
Shifts can be up to 12HRS long with little to zero notice of mandatory overtime or hour extensions. 
Making friends is not prohibited as talking or socializing is detrimental to your RATE.
RATE is not an acurate indicator of your performance..you wont make it most days and will be eventually written up despite your best effort.
Computer system is slow and ruins your rate.
There arent any robots..you are the robot.
Managers agree with you on problems with rate ect but have no power to change anything.
They hire 30 new people every other week bc so many people quit 
You cant sit down ever, and you might pass out bc it gets so hot. 
The whole place reaks of body odor and a decent ventilation system is nonexistent. 
Plan on coming home covered in box dust and filth.
Attendance point system will terminate you. They have no interest in you making it 90 days so you can get your benifits (health insurance)
It takes 5 to 7 min of your break just to get to a break area.
Dont plan on having or using your cell phone for about 10 hours a day. 
Your monitored like a prisoner.
Its really too hard to work anywhere else or even look for another job due to exhaustion.
Your rate is shot if you need to use the restroom.
Your constantly taking tylenol bc your body is constantly sore.
Its very easy to injure yourself and if you dont have insurance your at the mercy of Amazons AmCare. 
A 15.00 an hour job that should be paying 18 to 20hr due to the overwhelmingly massive workload.
advice_management:
Rate is just another excuse to fire before paying out benifits.
Please install more ceiling fans..if planet fitness can afford it then Amazon can too.
Day one benifits is a lie. 
Shorter shifts (no longer then 8 hrs) with the option to work longer only if associate agrees to it due to physically demanding tasks.
Include extra 5min for employees to walk to break area. 
Make a way to stop being rated while using the bathroom.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years

cons:
- Individualistic and political culture, everyone is thinking about how they can get promoted vs. being a team player
- Lots of back-stabbing and relentless pace of re-orgs 
- Suggestions for moral improvement to  VP-level leadership and HR fall on death ears
advice_management: Measure employee churn and satisfaction to drive better culture and retention

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year

cons: Back breaking work with recognition being rewarded with in-house reward currency that builds up slow. Shifts can extend by an hour or two without any warning, and the forecasts for shift length are rarely accurate.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Technical Account Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Good flexibility in work/life.
Interesting technology to work with and build on.
Teams are motivated and customer obsessed.
Allowed to take ownership and see things to completion.
cons:
Work life balance can sometimes shift due to customer asks.
Enterprise Support is kind of a mess in terms of responsibilities, doing a lot of SA level work because the SA is busy.
Taking ownership often means maxing out your day to day; not a lot of support of actually doing the work.
Lots of "Give back to Amazon" through hiring, Area of Depth, training; have to juggle internal activities with customer ones.
Single point of failure in the TAM role; context switching is impossible some days; death of a thousand cuts.
advice_management: Keep working to improve the internal side of Enterprise Support. TAM's are supposed to be the voice of the customer, and we message that to great affect outside of AWS. Maybe push harder internally that TAM's aren't raising severity on cases and tasks because they enjoy filling out questionnaires for back end engineers.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Great work environment, good management, realistic job expectations, etc. It's actually pretty fun. Starting pay is $15. I recommend this job and workplace to pretty much everyone who asks me about it, despite my difficulties with the two cons listed below. (Unreliable hours and lack of benefits are are a pretty significant setback, but I stay because everything else is there).
cons:
Hours/schedule: You choose your own shifts in an app every week. This is great for flexibility, but it also means that yours hours and schedule is not guaranteed and that, sometimes, you may be fighting with other associates for those hours (They can fill up quickly, especially in times of low volume. I'm glad that I have a fast internet connection at home).

Benefits: Amazon is known having great benefits that start day 1 but, in this position, you get almost none of that.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Been working here a year now. during my 3rd month there was already opportunities to move up. If you're a hard worker you can ask to explore other areas in the warehouse to learn new skills.  In short, if you show up, don't take extra long breaks, and just communicate with your manger, its easy to move up and try new things.
cons:
They sometimes change your mandatory overtime day and there is nothing you can do about it.  
It is long hours (10hours to 12hours), it took a good 3months for my feet to get use to that.
advice_management: Bring back the monthly bonus check that we use to have, that was base on both the warehouse and the employees productivity and attendance. I believe it gave everyone a good push in the right direction and made it so people actually showed up to work  and stayed on tasked.  less overworking good employees and less mandatory overtime needed.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: I love that I get to work with many smart people.  Because of the size and growth of the organization there are variety of career growth opportunities. My team and manager work collaboratively and there is importance attached to work life balance.
cons:
Due to the complexity of the organization, knowing who to connect with plays a big part in your success. It is also a hierarchy driven organization with much importance attached to levels and titles. 

Compensation package was not appealing, especially the base pay.  The limits to base pay makes it difficult process to negotiate,
advice_management:
- Be open to chance policies related to compensation
- Increase efficiencies by removing bottlenecks created by levels
- Work on removing barriers to navigate the organization and access to data

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros: Good pay in the first four years. Most importantly Amazon is a global company so that you have a lot of opportunity to relocate or work for different business. It is a good place for you to challenge yourself and learn and grow.
cons: worked in the core supply chain department but not recommend. There are teams with good culture and better opportunities but not here. High bar for the PM but doing a lot of operational work. No life/work balance at all because you had to spend a lot additional time to do real PM job in additional to those operational work. Business flight had to be during the weekend and should not take the normal working hours; they didn't increase your salary as your overall income was above the bar just because the value of vested RSU they committed years ago increased a lot, which is ridiculous.
advice_management: Find an experienced managers to lead the team ; otherwise create a manager performance review system to rule those new managers.

summary: "Though the people and benefits at Amazon are great,  it is not a positive work environment."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon
pros: The thing I liked most was the people I worked with. You can meet a lot if cool people there. Though you don't have a lot of time to actually interact with them except for breaks. The pay and benefits are good as well.
cons:
Despite their insistence that they care about their associates, I find the overall structure of Amazon to be geared towards the opposite.  The pay and benefits are good enough that Amazon knows that either: you won't leave, even if they treat you poorly, or will leave, and they can very easily find a replacement.  They (high level management) do and say what they must to make their shareholders happy.  

In short, they wish we were robots, so standards are set at a corporate level so that they can treat us like one.
advice_management: We are people. Invest a little in treating us that way.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years

cons: You are underpaid for the amount of hours you work per week. Especially during busy season you are working almost 72 hours a week.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time

summary: "The culture is like your in high school"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: The benefits are what keep people there even when they don’t want to be. And the hire rate is $15/hr.
cons: You have an hour of Time off task, but they don’t take into consideration women, we have a lot going on (menstruation, some have bladder problems, bowel problems, etc), and of you’re gone too long your interrogated and treated like a child. The culture is very childish and messy. It’s like you’re in high school all over again. Unprofessional environment. Not very diverse. If you’re in management and you’re POC you have to be on your Ps and Qs, watch your back at all times. There are no friends in that environment. Sexual harassment is terrible in CLT2, HR is lazy doesn’t follow up with you even after writing statements. There is supposed to be no tolerance but the guy who did sexually harass me verbally was still employed. The Managers treat you like you’re a slave. And as if your health means nothing.
advice_management: Be more compassionate and more humane. You treat people like we’re robots

summary: "Work here if you want to be treated like a robot"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
SOME paid time off, unpaid time off, and vacation hours
health and school benefits (health benefits immediately, paid schooling after a year)
transfers available
cons: They stop giving PTO in May for the rest of the year so you can only use unpaid time and vacation hours after that. During peak season, you are required to work 11-12 hour shifts instead of 10, as well as a mandatory overtime day every week. I was a picker overnight and they NEVER accepted transfer requests for day shift or different jobs because they wanted to keep us where we were. Constantly raising the rates higher and working us harder. You get written up without warning for going slow. This is not a company where you can call out or use a doctor's note. If you can't make it to work, you have to have hours to cover it. If you go negative in your hours, you are immediately fired if you can't use PTO to cover them. There are leave of absences that you can take, but you cannot take a medical leave until you've been working there a year and a personal leave is limited days off with no pay. My body was constantly sore and tired and I never could take a minute to rest or my rate would go down. Very repetitive work that requires no skill or thought, just constant movements. Constant bending and lifting heavy items. You only can have gloves, your water bottle, and hard candy with you while you work. Your station is by itself and you are not close enough to anyone to talk, and if you are, it is too loud and your rate will probably decrease if you do. VERY isolated and secluded, which is what I hated most. I could go on and on..but I would not recommend this job to anyone who wants to keep their sanity.
advice_management: TREAT PEOPLE LIKE PEOPLE! NOT EVERYTHING IS ABOUT NUMBERS

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: You get the ability to work with amazing people with amazingly diverse backgrounds.  The work is in an extremely fast paced environment and gives one the ability to drive their own projects.
cons: If you cannot keep up you will get left behind.   However, since everyday is day one, no one effectively learns the intricate details of their job.  Amazon will increase the standard of the workers it has and highers which is great.  However,  Amazon continually increases the expectations of its workers while minimizing its return to the employees.  It is not a company that makes you feel wanted long term unless you on the corporate side of the business.  They are continually looking to "invent and simplify" as they say, which long term means reducing the pay and level of experience required for all positions throughout the company... Amazon will say their biggest principle is Customer Obsession but in reality it is just saving money by cutting corners, which they will call "frugality".

summary: "Great Place To Work If You Have Limited Options"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Minimum payment is $15 an hour. Depending on location, night shift gets roughly an additional $0.50-$2.40 an hour.  Day-1 benefits and they're actually quite good.
cons: Usually have to walk 5-7 minutes just to get to a break room while the break is just 30 minutes.  Virtually no chairs outside of break room areas.  Management is overly enthusiastic, to the point it's noticeably fake.  Information on work quota requirements is kept secretive to keep employees working as hard as they can at all times for fear of losing their jobs. Management will often play favorites when advancement positions open up.  Management will hound you for using the restroom outside of break time.
advice_management: We know you're not excited to be working 6pm to 6am on a Friday night, quit pretending to be.  Be more straightforward with what is expected.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: They pay at least $15/hour
cons: They have no respect for work/life balance. They expect workers to work overtime and through lunch breaks. They only care about delivering packages on time. Many of my coworkers have developed significant injuries while working. Yet our insurance doesnt kick in for 90 days, and it doesnt cover the first $1500 of costs. I honestly think they want robots, not humans. That is why they are working so hard on drone delivery. I cant wait till I find another company
advice_management: Respect work/life balance. Don't reprimand or punish workers for wanting to go home to their families when their scheduled shift ends.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: very relaxed environment, pleasant co-workers.  management has been helpful in all situations.....even though you may have to remind them a few times.  Growth has been rapid and managers appear to be stretched thin therefore some requests/needs can fall through the cracks.
cons:
They will tell you there will be no problem getting hours, and extra hours, but that just isn't the case.  Continued over-hiring of drivers has led to shorter routes and fewer hours.  Even if you have enough packages to deliver within your 10hr day, they will send one, sometimes more, drivers that are finished with their route to pick up some of your packages to deliver, in turn shortening your day/hours.  This will only increase turnover.

"seasonal" drivers are considered TEMPORARY positions currently and could be eliminated.....otherwise why wouldn't they make them full-time/perm positions.  As a seasonal driver associate you don't have the same access or perks as a full "blue-badged" Amazon employee.  For example, a full Amazon employee has an inside track to other positions within the company but despite a seasonal driver understanding the system by working there they don't get the benefit of that inside track.
advice_management: Allow the same access/benefits to "seasonal" drivers.  There are talented professionals that are driving currently in order to get their foot in the door, and we were all told that there is room for advancement in our interviews, but we have quickly found out that being labeled a "seasonal" driver also means "roadblock" and little opportunity for advancement.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Leadership cares about its employees!  Being part of the leadership team, I can see directly how this works, and I must say, I have never been at a company, large or small, that cares about its employees this much.  Plus, it does so as objectively as possible.  Most places I have been, I see promotions and annual reviews as highly subjective processes, but that is not the case here, we try to remove that subjectivity as much as possible.  
There is a high bar here, ensuring only top tier people.
If you want to try something new, the company is very supportive to move within the company, to try out a different business line or different technology stack.
cons: This is not the place for all people.  You need to be able to work well within an ambiguous problem space, own what you do, and care about the customers (internal and external) you support.  If you want a job where somebody else manages what you must do day in and day out, and you don't have to think about it yourself, you may want to find a different company.

summary: "Tremendous quality of work, opportunity and impact."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The opportunities for growth, technical and professional development are phenomenal. Amazon almost always tries to solve difficult problems which offers great opportunities to shape the technical and product vision. This is not a place for people who don't like ambiguity or dealing with competing priorities; those who can bring order to chaos will thrive, and not compromise great work life balance either. This is a company that invests in the future, sets challenging goals and empowers people.
cons: A lot of less than ideal aspects have been creeping in the past years. These need to be controlled and eliminated or the company will risk losing it's best people and the core of the culture that makes it great.  Unnecessary focus on process and documentation sometimes to the exclusion of good strategic and tactical thinking, counterproductive focus on hardware expense without clearly  considering business benefits, and tolerance of acerbic behavior all sometimes create an environment that detracts from the otherwise great work opportunities.
advice_management: There's a place for 6-pagers and other write ups-ensure these are not being over-used at every opportunity and detracting from brainstorming and solution building time.  Do not tolerate people who violate or abuse Leadership Principles, regardless of how senior. Ensure mechanisms are  put in place to maintain the core of what makes this company great-being data vs opinion driven, being lean and agile , and sustaining culture via the key leadership principles such as Earns Trust and Are right a lot, and promoting respect and good discussions. Keep up the Day 1 culture at all costs!

summary: "The Company has major room for improvement."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Excellent insurance and benefits, work at home, company purchased computer. Company Christmas gift at the end of the year.
cons:
So many changes are made and you are rarely made aware of them. You usually have to figure out the changes on your own. Most managers are new to the company so they don’t have a lot of knowledge but you still have to ask them for assistance since you’re restricted from
Being able to do certain things. Bachelor degree is required to move beyond a level 2. Since the pay increase no pay raises are coming and our stocks are gone. No reimbursement like many work at home companies—you’re responsible for your own internet and office set up. No company get togethers. Lack of “perks” compared to other work at home employers. No room for advancement without a degree.

Employee voice isn’t heard. You cannot tell customers about the survey that is included in all emails and that the survey directly impacts your metrics. Too much flexibility with policies and not all employees follow them.
advice_management:
Ask employee input. So many changes are made that we are never told about and they aren’t beneficial in any capacity...example, taking away the ability to access our time off portal, forcing desktops on those that are happy with the laptops, restricting email to only management (makes it hard to reset our Knet passwords since we can’t receive the email), stop mandatory overtime. People are more inclined to work it if they aren’t force to work it, understand employees would like major holidays off with family. The company isn’t going to go out of business if phone support isn’t available or consider it an open work day for those that want to work. Get rid of the shift bidding. Many of us have second jobs and the shift bids interferes with that. Promote from within first, consider letting employees do work explore to see if another area would be a good fit for them. 

Give us back our stocks. Don’t restrict us when using the career education. Many jobs at Amazon require a bachelors but the service will only cover up to an AAS, Audible employees are cover up to a masters. 

There’s so much room for improvement to make employees want to stay and do better you only need to listen to us.

Give customers upfront information return policy, state or country where the item is shipping from. Consider asking employees for suggestions on ways to improve customer and employee experience.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Lots of options for developers - you can usually choose what you want to work on and how you want to work. Everything varies team-to-team, but it's universally positive. Path to promotion is very clear and encouraged. Problems are challenging, if not always unique/interesting. Environment supports and encourages quick learning.
cons: Everything is built around isolated teams. The company essentially functions as 1000 start ups moving in similar (but not the same) direction. This can result in duplicated work and wasted time. To some extent, this is unavoidable at such a large company, it's very common here to implement a full platform that will be dropped within the year. There's also quite a cult-of-personality around the higher ups.
advice_management: Every is moving in a good direction. Just keep working to set clear goals and purposes for teams/orgs. Keep prioritizing ethics and sustainability.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Money until recently.  The last year and a half you've cut salaries and RSUs down so much everyone needs to stay away from Amazon.
cons: Cut throat down to the core.  If you are a manager expect to be stabbed in the back,  every day.  Trust no one.  L7 Leadership is so bad, you just bail.  The Senior talent has diminished so much, you can find better....anywhere!  They will cut you down, throw you under the bus, and protect themselves.  Amazon is pitiful and not the Amazon I was proud to work for.  I'm embarrassed the level they have fallen to.  Jeff if you are listening, I beg you to stop the insanity..
advice_management: Amazon 2019.  In the Fulfilment world you are cutting cost so much, you are killing morale.  College hires, you just abuse.  Rethink your compensation strategy because it is not working.  Your 2019 attrition rate is higher than ever.  If  you are going to subject new managers to so much stress, 60+ hour work weeks, and just beat everyone down it is not sustainable.   Cutting compensation of the hardest working people at Amazon to improve the bottom line  will last another year and then you will have to rethink the plan.  New talent brought to Amazon at a low $$$ doesn't cut it longterm.  The compensation director needs to rethink his or her strategy.  Stop the insanity.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior User Experience Designer
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
The pay is very good at low/mid-level positions. That's the main pro. However, the stock vesting timeline is very imbalanced, compared to similar companies.  Also, there's a base pay cap company-wide of like 160k, so if you get hired or promoted to higher-level positions that should pay more than that, you're just promised more future stock vesting on a very slow timeline.

Stock vesting schedule: Of the total number of shares promised to you in your job offer, you get 5% after your first year, 15% after 2nd, and then 20% every 6 months till you finish your 4th year. It seems like they're relying on people quitting within the first year or two, so they can save money.

The other pro is, since it's common knowledge that people don't like working at Amazon, it looks good as an accomplishment on your resume.

Oh, one more thing - since there are so many orgs and teams, if you get sick of yours in particular, there are always openings in completely different parts of the company, which you can apply for. You still need to go through the whole interview process for internal transfers, but if you don't want to leave before you've vested your stocks, it's a good way of changing the scenery without leaving.
cons:
If you have any morals, it's very difficult to deal with the conflicted feelings of working at a company that does so much unethical stuff. 

Besides that, A) workload can be unreasonable, B) you may find yourself working with proud Amazon super-soldiers who will get mad at you for not wanting to dedicate your entire life to make the company a few more million dollars, C) every org and team in the company operates differently, so it's very hard to know what working there will actually be like - it'll depend strongly on who your manager is, D) it's an extremely political environment (office politics, that is), with lots of bureaucracy, and everyone's really scared of people at higher levels than they are. Everyone turns into yes-men in front of their managers, and even more so for people above them. No one's capable of honestly disagreeing with dumb ideas, which leads to a lot of wasted time and effort.
advice_management: Have some backbone and actually be honest with your superiors when they have bad ideas about fields they don't understand, instead of just rolling over all the time.

advice_management: With growth comes responsibility, much is changing with centralized processes and control which is part of a company this size.  We need to balance the entrepreneurial spirit, two-way door decisions with the right controls.

Separately, the compensation philosophy is simply stupid: there is no real connection between performance and compensation (it's overwhelmed by the stock price fluctuations).
advice_management: Stop with the casino/game show-based comp philosophy. Pay people money.

summary: "State of the art, incredible pace and scale, but it can be a toxic culture."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Amazon leads the industry in many areas and you are afforded the opportunity to have an impact at every level through an initiatives program.  There are always growth and career opportunities.
cons: Toxic culture.  Stack ranking a highly functioning team for the sake of meeting a % goal of un-regretted attrition creates a very unhealthy environment.  Amazon talks a very good game about work life balance and how important family life is but for anyone seeking to embody that will likely face a bottom ranking and be "coached" out of the company entirely because of metrics and arguably nothing to do w/ performance.  Always have a plan B for employment because you are always looking over your shoulder.
advice_management:
- Keeping in line with our competition, completely dismantle the stack ranking and un-regretted attrition policies (unofficial or otherwise)
- Push decision making down as far as possible and when you think it's low enough, push it more.
- Listen to your ICs and encourage them to challenge the norm.

If you actually cared about safety-you would have already addressed these issues and you would NEVER have sent drivers out into a record setting storm.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I will say this about Amazon, the kind of job you have, and the team you work on, make all the difference.  I was lucky enough to be on a great team with great management.  Amazon is a little too far on the frugal side, but the work was engaging and the work environment fun and relaxed.  My coworkers were all very capable at their jobs which made each day much more enjoyable.  My manager(s) were flexible about the work hours and encouraged a healthy work/life balance.
cons:
Communication between the teams of various expertise, e.g. Mechanical, electrical, embedded, etc., was disjointed and clunky.  It was difficult to sync schedules and share work.
Additionally, as the project moved into the production phase, a lot of the exciting and innovative work was de-prioritized, which sucked some of the fun out of working on the Amzn Go team.
advice_management: Keep allocating resources to employee growth and allow them to pursue exciting new ideas and take risks.  Add some amenities to help people stay balanced in the workplace, such as having a room(s) to relax/meditate, and bring in some mindfulness training/awareness.  it was easy to get burnt out during the day causing me to cut my day short and go home when it would've been fairly easy to take some time to meditate or rest somewhere, and then get back to work.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
For people working software as developers, software managers, and program/project managers, this is a great company to work for. You are constantly getting to tackle unique and challenging problems to continue growing and improving the customer experience.

Ability to grow within the the company is very high, and if you're aiming for a high level role within Amazon in the long term it is better to work your way up from within. 

Compensation and benefits are good in general for a tech company, but on a lower than other large tech companies like Google or Facebook.  (pro and con).
cons:
Work/Life balance is heavily dependent on your team and manager. I have had no issues with it, but other teams have more pressure to deliver and skew work/life balance.

Tenure at amazon is often limited. Having a job at Amazon looks great on a resume (which is  pro) but as a result, many people will leave to join other companies who actively recruit Amazon employees. This can mean high turnover within teams, and that amazon benefits don't really kick in until year 2 or later.

I worked in Logistics for a long time, relative to the turnover rate, and they never really gave me better pay, time off, or promotions. I worked hard to get the FLEX representative role, and then they took it away and gave it to India just as quickly.
advice_management: Give your people some slack, because the job itself sucks. Most people take the job because it's the best they can do, but nobody wants to spend their time getting yelled at over a headset. Mgmt pushes their people too hard there, and few people are truly happy to be there.
