summary: "Please Read - Will save you a lot of time"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: -You’re challenged with incredibly complex problems, that look great on paper, but rarely come to fruition.
cons:
-TERRIBLE leadership
-Long working hours, zero disregard for work-life balance (Holidays are no exception).
-Meaningless projects, that deliver minimal results.
-Terrible data accuracy, with resource tools to benchmark 
-You’re very much a statistic 
-KPI driven culture, with Instock management receiving the brunt of most issues.
-Minimal compensation benefits, does not scale to the Seattle economy. 
-locked into a sign on bonus, which has been defined as “Golden Handcuffs.” 
-Extremely high turn over makes for a challenge when working on projects. 
-Leadership principles contradict each other
-Promotions are extremely rare, usually within 3-4 years of 60 hour work weeks, if you don’t burn out before then.
advice_management: Care more about your people and the engagement scores managers are receiving, and less about a KPI that doesn’t add value to driving your business.

summary: "Too boring and growth is too slow"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
1. Will learn some good values like customer focus.
2. Will work on some interesting problem spaces.
3. Aggressive goals help you focus on getting things done.
4. Team switching is quite easy so if you are unhappy with one team, can easily move to another.
cons:
1. Work can be too boring. Even on teams that are working on cutting edge things. Job postings heavily inflate the challenge faced by teams.
2. Technical debt, a lot of time will be spent cleaning up after bad/rushed decisions made before.
3. No real culture. In my team at least, we barely had any team building. People often ate their lunches at their desk.
4. Manager quality is a high variance and there are plenty of bad managers.
5. Virtually no perks and very high density seating.
6. Compensation is lower when compared to other similar companies. It has been higher in the last few years due to high growth, but now that the dust has settled, the compensation is not too good.
7. Oncall is the worst. Imagine being woken up at 3:00 AM in the morning to reboot a server. Automation isn't prioritized at all and often it takes months to fix/automate issues.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
- Super flexible scheduling and you can cancel a shift 24 hours in advance at the latest
- Remote manager so no one is breathing down your neck
- Some prime benefits
- Hourly wage means you get paid the same on the slow days as you would on the busy days
- Amazon is constantly hiring for this position and you don't even have to interview for it (just pass a competence test and a drug test)
cons:
- You can only work a max of 25 hours per week
- On busy days you are walking around non stop for a 4-5 hour shift (besides 15 min break); which doesn't sound bad, but you have to meet a 75 item pick rate per hour including packaging everything so you're always in a rush
- Amazon cares more about overall performance rather than on the individual level so a lot of coworkers will slack off and take advantage of the system
advice_management:
Please provide better support for people with disabilities. As much as I appreciate Amazon hiring all types of people, I am not trained to assist someone with a mental or physical disability. And I can't take the time to help them if it's going to hurt my job performance.
Also, it would be nice to have some benefits for people who perform well and haven't left the job after a few months. The turnover rate is ridiculous at this level and I feel one of the reasons that is the case is because the people who actually do good work are not recognized or appreciated.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
-It pays.
-Co-workers are the best I've ever worked with. No drama between employees!
-Good workout.
-Management acts nice.
cons:
-Management doesn't care about the pions.
-Human Resources is impossible to get ahold of. You can only go see them during your breaks and the office and help desk is on the opposite side of the building. Then you have to wait in line and hope you get your issue resolved and back to work on time.
-Employee Resource Center and any other employee hotlines numbers are outsourced to Bangladesh, India and don't speak English well.
-You are a cog in the machine. If you break you'll just be replaced and discarded. As a tiny piece, you don't matter.
-Empty promises. Seasonal employees are always told that conversion to full employment is "just around the corner."
-Rates. If Amazon doesn't think you're going fast enough, if you don't keep up with their absurd expectations, you're wasting their time and they will fire you.
advice_management:
Listen to your employees. Try to work on the communication between your departments. If you're going to outsource phone work to other countries, try one where English is a second language, not where English is barely spoken! Or give the work to people who speak it. Don't be cheap and use American employees.

If you're going to slap all positive reinforcement on the walls of your fulfillment centers about how much Amazon cares about all it's employees, follow through with it. Treat your employees equally. From the lowly warehouse worker, to the managers up top. From the white badges, to the blue badges. If you're going to give us anxiety attacks about keeping up with our rates, you could at least make us want the job you threaten taking from us.

summary: "This is a job, not a career"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Great Medical benefits
Good for students looking to make some cash while in school
Good for individuals looking for a second job
Good for seasonal work
cons:
Vacation accumulation is slow (until you have some respectable time invested)
Shift work is not for everyone
Strict attendance policies
Promotions from PA to AM are dependent on your AM selling you to other AMs when the rankings are done 2x per year. It's not about tenure o talent. It's about who likes you and wants you to be an AM.
VTO can be annoying when production is slow
The pay is low if you have your own bills and rent to pay.
This is an FC environment, it is an extension of retail.
advice_management:
Strongly consider ranking degreed PA's and non-degreed PA's separately when looking at promotions. College hires are recent grads with little to no experience, while you have PA's that finish off 4 year degrees while working at Amazon. It's backwards that a PA who finished a degree, has to go through a process and compete with other PA's who have tenure. It wouldn't be an issue, but when you rank them and they don't get selected to interview for AM it's a slap in the face when they end up with a new AM over them that just graduated college and never worked a job. Experienced PA's end up training them on how to do their job. Get with it Amazon. This is the 21st century and the reason myself and others have left the company.

There is better work out there for those who have degrees and prior management experience.

job_title: Former Employee - Pack Process Guide/Pack Ambassador
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Good benefits, lots of hours
cons: Revolving door of employees, the company is built around not keeping employees for longer then a year so don’t plan on staying long term unless you know people in upper management that can help you move up. The management system is very political and they make you feel like you’re a valued part of the team until they no longer need you and then they’ll drop you like it’s nothing. This company is built on the greed of its CEO and it can and will survive by any means necessary so they are very good at making people think they are good for communities and a good place to work but that’s all part of their trickery. They hire so much because they fire so much and they put all kinds of loopholes and clauses in their fine print in order to get rid of so many employees or just force employees to quit which keeps most of their employees earning the starting base rate instead of increased wages.
advice_management: I don’t think the management really have much power to do much, Amazon is the kind of company that is built on greed from the top down so the corporate structure is designed to take advantage of everything they can for their own benefit. The managers are giving only enough power to feel important but they are just as easily let go or fired as the regular employees so that nobody is there long enough to see all the negatives of the company.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
- Can work your way up to better positions pretty quickly, I got trained within a month and could have had any role I wanted.
- Worked in stow, easiest department by far. I'd say the other departments aren't worth it, mostly picking since it's just terrible.
- Competitive pay, was making $13.35-14/hr before the minimum wage change now it'd be $16.15/hr.
- Works 12 hours overnight 3 days a week, I liked having a 4 day weekend
- Some sites have a work shuttle, mine had one from train station
- You'll be given a target rate, but people confuse what they want you to hit ideally vs what will get you in trouble/fired. Just work consistently and well and you don't have to worry.
- Ton of benefits from pre-tax to medical, dental, 10% employee discount on Amazon sold items and etc.
- Varies, but plenty of potential optional overtime
- Overall I would have returned, but location wasn't hiring when I was still in the area
cons:
- Physically demanding, takes about a week to become conditioned, it's not for everyone.
- If you can't take feedback, this isn't the place for you. Managers and stuff will talk to you pretty much daily to talk about your rate.
- Sometimes you'll get a bunch of large packages like toys all day and it can be frustrating from a physical standpoint and from a stowing/picking standpoint since it's harder to get a good rate.
-Mandatory overtime can be rough if you're doing it with school. I ended up leaving since I couldn't do 36 hours a week + overtime since it conflicted with my school schedule no matter what.
advice_management:
Just remain consistent with asking associates about what they want to train in while communicating what they have to do to get there. Do surveys about what shuttles associates would be interested in since many people take public transportation.
- If you work in a role you train in, a lot of base associates can be annoying since they're trying so hard to hit rate and will blame you or make demands if they get a bad pallet.

advice_management: I worked for amazon for only a few months. I enjoyed working there but when the weather is hot, it is VERY hot and humid in the warehouse. There is no AC, they have a few big fans but they always point them towards supervisors and ambassadors not the employees who are actually moving around and doing all the hard labor.. the ones who need the fan the most.. I felt sluggish and drained due to how hot it was in the warehouse. I felt like i could go crazy. Then supervisors come up to you and pick on you because your rate is low. they tell you to work faster. I was one of the fastest stowers, my rate was always up but it fell drastically during the summer..  they need to stop picking on employees and put AC in the warehouse. other than that, i enjoyed working here during the winter, there are opportunities and you can transfer to any location in any state.

Training is horrible has no value towards the position you are doing, you will be written up within your first month if you do not meet THEIR expectations.  Takes a month for you to be transferred to a new position in the company.
advice_management: Work on your policies, I have a lot of cons towards you, your only pro's are very few.  Everything I have said is true based on what I have been told in the past.

main_text: I worked at Amazon
pros: Grocery shopping, I’m good at it and I love doing it.
cons: It’s almost impossible to get shifts.  Six days a week you have to be online and try to get a shift.  It’s almost like playing slot machines at a casino and you almost always lose.  It doesn’t cost anything to play, but between 6:15 and 6:25ish you hit refresh until the shifts show up.  They call it “tapping for shifts”.  First come, first served.  I got 8 hours last week and 4.45 hours this week.  I’m done.
advice_management: Your job posting claimed 20-30 hours per week.  Tell me when to come to work and I’ll be there.  Tapping for shifts and not getting any is too stressful.  I’m done.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Amazon is a great place to learn what you don’t know, and it’s a great place to hone data skills in an environment that is constantly expanding and growing. It’s easy to learn how to scale your work here and gives you a level of perspective on an enormous corporation that you simply can’t understand until you experience it.
cons:
I have never been as stressed in my life as I have been during the nearly four years of my tenure here. I have never felt secure in my job in spite of my tenure. True reflections of your performance from management are hard to come by, and the politics are real. Know that if you join Amazon, you have to play politics and learn to be friends with people you would otherwise hate.  As others have mentioned, this company stack ranks employees and politics plays a heavy hand in ranking - you can be great at your job and get a horrible ranking because someone with  a little power doesn’t particularly like you.  The level of fear and stress I have about my job performance at Amazon is shocking, and I suspect a therapist would tell me that I have PTSD. 

You can regularly expect to be working the jobs of 2 people because open positions sit for so long without getting filled. I don’t recommend applying to my friends because my own experience has been so negative.

I’m actively seeking new employment.
advice_management:
Lip service to good culture doesn’t cut the mustard. Expecting your employees to run full speed all the time is a fantastic way to lose great people and, when stocks begin to decline and antitrust regulation becomes real, it’s a great way to ensure that people won’t apply to your jobs. 

A dedication to work-life balance isn’t reflected in the actions of management. My SVP regularly says things like, “if you just stayed an hour or two later every single day, just think about all the things you could get done.” He either doesn’t understand or doesn’t care that our partners, children, and friends won’t always be waiting for us and this isn’t a healthy request. Job listings tout Amazon as the kind of place where you can work from home if you need to, and you can take care of your kids if you need to. The reality in my department is that working from home is strongly discouraged and telecommuting gets snide remarks from our SVP. So here’s the rundown: longer hours at salary, no telecommute option, unclear and arbitrary job rankings have made for an ultimately negative employment experience.

summary: "Unproductive chaos at all levels, non-transparent promotional process,"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Highly intelligent and engaged/sense of urgency in workforce, good pay and benefits package. Colleagues really try hard at their jobs and like to have fun. Progressive culture/attitudes among colleagues.
cons: Tout hiring people to have them develop strategy, but do not utilize the brains and talent of the people they have hired. Leadership states they want to be strategic but instead is overall panicky, volatile, and just reactive in their management of the business. Male-dominated culture with very little female presence which leads to a feeling of being on display quite often (in meetings, hallways, etc). Very few females in top leadership which is disheartening . Promotional process is totally lacking transparency. Performance review process lacks transparency and is done without taking into account formal customer and colleague feedback about employee (it's based off only what management's perspective is of you).
advice_management: Hire more women into top leadership positions. Make your promotional process and performance review process transparent. Be more proactive than reactive by placing more importance in process development since Amazon is no longer a small company.

summary: "Don't Work Here Unless You Want to Work to Death"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
-Benefits
-$15 an hour base pay
-Environment to work in is clean and decent
-Most people to work with are very nice and helpful
-LGBTQ+ friendly
cons:
-Managers pick favorites
-You do one minor thing managers don't like (Ex: leaving early without telling them) they punish you for it (Ex: putting you in an area they know you hate.)
-Physically demanding.
-Expectations are TOO high. Management does not consider the many boundaries you face throughout the day that can affect your rates, even if you tell them many times what they are. I have received countless bruises weekly from rushing just to make rate. 
-Management only looks at the numbers on their screens about you, they pay no attention to what you tell them.
-They make you feel like just a number. More new employees flood in, while others are being fired for minor things.
advice_management: Stop picking favorites. Actually listen to the boundaries that people experience through their day. Even something as minor as having trouble opening a box/carrying heavy items can delay time. Maybe train people more than 1-2 work days. I worked at Amazon almost 2 years and was STILL finding out new information I should have known in the beginning. Also let new employees get a feel longer than a month. Not even a month after I started I got a final written.

summary: "Not a bad job if you can keep up."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
I started off as a part time employee then transferred to a full time building after about 10 months.

+ Schedule
I work reduced time shift which is 12 hours per night and 3 nights a week. The other 4 nights I'm off so I can do whatever I want.

+ Benefits
Health insurance and Paid time off.

+ Overtime
A lot of overtime available.

+ Pay
 I get $17.40/hr on that shift
If I do overtime the pay is $24.9/hr
cons:
- Work
You have to work hard. Sometimes there's a lot of work but they'll give you time to get used to it.

-Health
 The first few weeks can be tough on your body. Especially the night shifts because you would've to adjust your schedule and maintain it even on your days off.

-Boring
It is boring doing one thing for hours can drive you nuts. But if you focus on your work not think about time it will pass by faster.

advice_management:
You guys are walking a thin line on a racial discrimination lawsuit. Most of your minority’s that try to advance within the company are stagnated due to favoritism and prejudice. There’s no way that a 22 year old Caucasian should have more experience and credentials than a 30 year with a college degree and 5+ years experience within a specific role. Your internal transfers are bogus. Someone needs to go back to the drawing board about your company culture and policies and start fresh before the UAW comes in. 10 hour shifts should have more than an hour break that is a labor violation. We shouldn’t be penalized for taking a bathroom break. 

For those looking for employment please do your research on the location you are applying for, Amazon is not as great as everyone is making it seem to be.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: It's always fun riding a company's wave when they're scaling and innovating.  Amazon is probably a few years away before they 're no longer the insurgent and at that time will begin to feel the effects of a stallout and overload.
cons: It sometimes feel like they bring you in, only to manage you out.  A number of colleagues were recruited for their expertise and knowledge but was out in over a year.  They also practice the GE reduction model where 5% MUST be submitted for under performance--irrespective of whether an entire group is performing well.  Amazon, consequently has begun shaving bone.; coupled with the fact that managers don't develop.  Many are too young to have developed that nuance and believe that PIP is how you develop under performing talent.
advice_management: Begin to hold leaders accountable for developing and promoting talent.  Several decades ago it was cool to be known as a leader/manager who had developed a line of folks who where promoted out.  It was fashionable to have that badge of honor vs. relying on PIP, to deal with underdeveloped talent.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: RSU offerings are good, but you need to stick around long enough for them to vest.
cons: Base salaries are low because of the comp strategy, which uses bonuses and RSUs to significantly boost your overall comp for the first four years. The culture and atmosphere is cutthroat and this comes from the top down. Lots of politics involving phony personalities, backstabbing, playing hot potato with responsibilities, throwing others under the bus, and nepotism. This culture tends to self-select for people who are entitled, self-important, pushy, and unpleasant. People here really drink the koolaid and believe they were hired for being THE BEST. Horrendous work-life balance - obsession with scaling, but without providing additional resources ("being scrappy"), so you end up working harder and longer until you eventually burn out. Constantly moving goalposts. Many of the people managers, even in HR, have no empathy and are socially inept. Benefits aren't great, pretty much the bare minimum you'd expect in a professional role with a large company.

summary: "Worst leadership of any company I've ever worked for."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Health benefits are good. Most co-workers are really great people, some of the best I've worked with at any company.
cons: So-called leadership is hired on the basis of "do you have a bachelor's degree?" It doesn't matter if the degree is in crayon making or basket weaving, as long as you'll drink the Amazon Koolaid and serve it to the masses!! Compensation for the actual amount of work performed is terrible ($15/hr is meaningless if they take away your bonuses and stock units). They keep reducing staff and pile extra work on already overburdened employees. Safety takes a backseat to productivity, although they claim different. If you get injured, their in-house mitigator "AmCare" will do everything in their power to blame the employee and nullify workman's comp. If that doesn't work mgmt will try and find any way to fire you. Finally, if that doesn't work they'll make your work life miserable and never let you move up or transfer out. All of this happens while employees see Amazon's Core Values painted on all the break room walls... sophistry like Hire and Develop the Best, Earn Trust of Others, Ownership, etc..  This facility is full of unscrupulous, dishonest, backstabbing management just like their adulterous weasel founder!
advice_management: There's no point, they hear but do not listen.. If all facilities are run this way Amazon is doomed to failure.

summary: "The best company I have ever worked for"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
- Extremely fast-paced, versatile and innovative.
- Highest caliber of colleagues I've ever come across. Smart, enthusiastic and helpful people everywhere.
- Truly living the 14 Principles - customer obsession is really the center of all decision-making.
- For technology geeks, there are few places like this - the internal tech and projects in flight are inspiring.
- Very practical management, very open to new ideas, and little sense of hierarchy.
- Every day I feel honored to work here.
- In AWS-land, the scale and speed of innovation is remarkable, so as a former customer it's amazing to see how AWS teams achieve their lead in the market.
- I learn something everyday (sometimes every hour).
- Many of the publicly-known work processes (Working Backwards, PR/FAQ, etc.) are extremely effective tools.
cons:
- With so much happening, this is not a place for people who like set processes or a quiet life.
- This company will not suit people who need constant management or direction - it's an environment for builders and self-motivators.
- You have to be willing to relearn many of the processes that made you successful in previous jobs. Amazon has its own culture and ways of doing things so don't expect to arrive and amaze everyone with what you've done before.
advice_management: Keep doing what you're doing - this is the first time in years I have total confidence in the people running the business.

cons: It's very easy to get burned out. Everyone will try to squeeze you to the max to reach goals sometimes ridiculous. If you're prepared and able to push back this might be more of an annoyance but if you can't say no, it can become a nightmare.

summary: "Fast-Paced environment, good for advancing your engineering skill set"
job_title: Current Employee - Software Development Engineer II
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Fast-paced: you don't often feel like you aren't doing anything

Customer-obsessed: most of the time you are delivering things that are valuable

Large scale: Mostly working on systems with large traffic, learn how to design with scalability in mind

Strong culture: Most employees are go-getters and trying to do the right thing. This creates a pretty open day-to-day environment.

Overall I have had a very positive experience at Amazon
cons:
First-To-Market: Amazon is successful because we launch fast, but this often means introducing tech debt and hacks. Tech debt reduction rarely gets prioritized, even if it has clear business value in launching features faster.

Tools?: we use a lot of internal tools, many of which don't have clear documentation. Error handling, measurement and root cause analysis are challenging as there is no standard across teams--this means you ssh into hosts a lot to diagnose issues

Business owners not technical: At least in my org, business leaders are not technical, and a lot of them aren't even very good at writing business proposals. This causes some frustration among the dev team that we aren't often pursuing best options. Also business owners are sometimes just yes-man to higher ups.

Mixed Quality of Team members: There is varied quality among all SDE levels. In some ways, SDE III still overrides SDE II decision even if other people don't agree.  Promotions are very political, and determined more by SDM/TPMs who don't even work with SDE on a day to day. 

Compensation: Amazon pays lower than certain other comparable employers. Also you don't really start getting paid real money until year 2. Compensation is also not very performance based.
advice_management: Learn how to valuate and prioritize Tech Debt to drive your business forward.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Technical Program Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
I was skeptical about the company culture having read so many articles about how Amazon squeezes every last drop from the employees.  Not true!

It is like any other competitive technology workplace where the number of hours is not the measure of performance.   As long as you are able to deliver your assignments/job responsibilities efficiently,  it is all good.  The one thing I am loving about Amazon is that they don't do the "artificial HR talk" about loyalty and "employees are family" type of words that many large corporations pretend to follow.  Managers do take good care of employees and offer flexibility as much as possible within their control. 

People who complain always find a way to complain. 

Seattle downtown is great and food options around are very cool.
cons: I was surprised to see chaos around some basic issues that exist in legacy companies but not expected in new-age companies like Amazon (e.g. two groups not talking to each other,  less documentation, immature processes).
advice_management:
1.  Time to spend some costs in operational efficiency!
2.   Up your strategy in AWS to combat the multi-cloud/hybrid cloud strategy from competitors.

summary: "Hard work, Fairly good pay, Awesome benefits"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
The pay while I was there was just okay, it was raised shortly after I left and is now pretty competitive. The benefits were fantastic, I was on the insurance plan and it covered EVERYTHING. Even chiropractic! The monthly pay for the insurance was not much, I've not had any other jobs were the insurance costs were this good. And they do a 401k match as well as offer stock options. 

The work required  at the large item warehouse I worked in had a lot of physical work, so if you like a workout, then this would be a good fit for you. Then mental processing required was not much, so if you get "mind numb" from repetitive tasks, it would not be ideal fit for you. 

Everyday you know what to expect and the regular team meetings are pretty nice. Goals are discussed often and supervisors frequently ask if anything can be done to help with those goals.
cons: If you don't like repetitiveness or physical labor, then the large item fulfillment center I worked at is not for you. (They do have many different fulfillment centers, so it could differ in your area). Also, numbers are VERY important, always make sure to get your numbers, and I am pretty sure the concern over numbers is throughout the whole company.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Amazing company. Great Benefits, Feels good to do a good deed
cons: I have non negative thing to say.
advice_management: none

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: There is a lot of people working on projects to better the customer experience. Everyone is willing to provide feedback or sometimes resources to help. Just be prepared for people to be pretty matter-of-fact in their feedback on your work. It really is in the interest of making it better.
cons: It’s entirely possible that you’re working on a fix to a problem that someone else is also working on. It can also be humbling to discover that your “unique” fix idea may not be all that unique. Only a con if you aren’t prepared to adjust on the fly.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Pay is nice considering they hire any and everybody I mean drug test was a mouth swab.  The "interview" was a direct hire event. 
Lots of cool people work here. 
Very generous time off plans including paid time, un paid time, and vacation which is accrued bi weekly.
Lots of overtime available. 
They have lots of little incentives and perks. Like paid bonus for adopting children  or lots of time off for the birth of a child and many other obscure perks that usually comes with time served there.
cons:
There is a major disconnect between management and employees, employees really feel like a second class citizen. Managers simply care about hitting the ever increasing rate they set to maximize there personal bonus. They walk around and talk to you like robots very impersonal. Most are early 20s fresh out of colleges with little to no work experience and just repeat there training.
11 to 12 hr shifts are tiring even though you get 3 days off they really work the snot off you your completely wasted at least a day. 
Work is super repetitive and  boring your repeating the same tasks which take about 5 to 10 seconds to complete over and over thousands of times a day and expected to stay at a certain minimal pace and they use computers and technology to hold you too it.
Little to no room for advancement only the ones on top move up or worse yet they dangle a carrot in front of you that gets you nothing in the end. 
The facility is huge literally my site they bragged about it being bigger then 28 football fields and there are only may be 10 bathrooms throughout the building so on your 15 min break your scrambling to a crowded bathroom and by the time your done you have to Sprint back to your work station but don't get caught running cuz it's a write up. 
Metal detectors take up even more time on breaks cell phones can only be had by management furthering the divide. 
Lots of oxy moronic rules and decision making such as they push us to stay hydrated but bathroom breaks are frowned upon unless it's your 15 min breaks or half hour lunch and any time off task counts against you and your daily rate. 
I could write here for an hour and still won't explain it all it's like they do there best to make the common employee to hate the place.
advice_management: needs a serious over haul on how they treat there employees. Be more compassionate and caring and the company could make even more money or save money buy not having new hire events every week because people would want to stay

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Easy repetitive work and laid back work environment
cons: Little to no training , the managers are inattentive to new hires and lack care and leave you to figure things out on your own while they sit in their corners without a care in the world
advice_management: Do your job and train new hires properly and actually check to make sure they are understanding it and be more attentive and don't sit in your corners and help.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros:
-Excellent pay for part time, Thye pay extra because its weekends. 
-401K plan
-Dental & Vision
-Sick time
-10% discount
-discounts at other retailers, other goods and services. 
-lots of resources available to employees 
- Many transfer opportunities
- lots of opportunity to advance 

My specific location has great managers, though i've heard of horror stories at other locations.
cons:
No medical benefits.

They aren't flexible AT ALL.  For part timers, you get no PTO and no Vacation time. All they give is sick pay which you accrue at a snails pace and something called "Unpaid time" which you get 20 hours every 3 months. Problem is, if you're more than 3 mins late to work, they take away AN HOUR of your unpaid time, and they rarely excuse you. Baptism? Kids Birthday? Vacation? Nope! must use your UPT, and if you've dipped into an hour of that time bc of lateness for say.... a freakish accident shutting down the highway, too bad!
Given this is a part time weekend job, they have zero empathy for people who have other jobs monday - friday. Personal leave is available for everyone else, but not part time, so if you burnout, too bad. 
They say HR will work with you, they dont.
Shifts are 10.5 hours long and you work... hard. Be prepared for a literal workout, though you do get used to it, nothing to be afraid of.
advice_management: Give Part time employees some flexibility!

advice_management: The stress just falls down the ranking. It’s like a Domino affect. Their 4 Managers are stressed to stress Tier 3’s to stress the Tier 1’s. If you don’t work very hard as a Tier 1 , you will be written up and stressed to get your numbers up. It is easy to get fired from amazon when you don’t meet the numbers. It is best to get out of Tier 1 ASAP. All of the pressure is put on Tier 1 for the packages to get out. Once you’re out of Tier 1 it’s GREAT!! It’s so unfair especially when Tier 1 is responsible for actually getting the packages out. It’s the reason the company exists!!

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: $18.25 per hour where I worked. Guaranteed work.
cons: Wow, the list of cons heavily outweighs the pros. Where do I begin. To start your shift, you walk about a mile to your truck, then wait in a jammed lot with 200 other trucks all trying to get into a warehouse, then you load your own truck with over 100+ packages, so you’re drained before you even deliver anything. Then you drive usually around 100 miles round trip all over highways, streets, dead ends, you name it, scrambling at every stop to find the package, up and down stairs, elevators, porches, in and out of the truck sometimes 150+ times a day. It wears you out. I dreaded work everyday. And if I finished early, they would make me go rescue another driver who didn’t know what he was doing. This was a horrible job.
advice_management: Stop overloading workers with packages to the ceiling of trucks. It’s not a fair way to treat your employee to get the maximum use out of them at the expense of their stress, physical and mental well being.

summary: "Decent Job if you can maintain their quota's"
job_title: Former Employee - KeyCore At Campus Pickup Point
main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros:
Area managers are very friendly, approachable and knowledgeable. 
Very flexible hours at CPP (campus pickup point)  Your opinion matters at the workplace.
cons:
Somewhat demanding on their metrics, everything is recorded. Sometimes the higher ups can be very demanding about maintaining or surpassing their quotas. Very difficult for job advancement.   
Little to none job benefits.
advice_management: Give us more opportunities for future job advancement, and less demanding on reaching specific quotas (demos)

The job has flexible work schedules, so it is good for students and housewives. 
 Moreover, it also offers some good benefits such as pay for part of your tuition ( specific amount depends on what you study and your position) and covers dental and vision expenses. The basic hourly wage is 15 USD per hour.  Generally,  managers and supervisors are friendly.
cons: It is more likely to encounter coworkers who like bossing and yelling at others than  at other workplaces.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Amazon is a large company with many distinct businesses. There are many opportunities to make an impact. Culture focused on leadership principles, data-driven decisions and mechanisms fosters getting things done and ability to scale organizations.
cons: Expectations and hiring bar differs across orgs, and not all leaders hold their teams accountable. Process to make decisions can be bureaucratic with multiple layers of management.
advice_management: Work on removing barriers to action and improving performance management practices.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: 3 days off, the work it self is a no brainer. The pay is not bad but it's very good pay for someone that is in their teens or in their 20s.
cons: My feet are killing me. Had to get a steroid shot in my heel. I cried many of times and had to stop in the middle of my work to rub my feet. I told HR that I was in pain and cried and ask if my shift hours can be reduced but she told me I would have to quit and reapply for part-time position. That don't make sense cuz then Amazon would lose money by doing the hiring process all over again. I also have a chronic autoimmune disease which I told late night HR but that didnt matter I need a medical doctors note to reduce hours.  I got my paperwork from the doctor but it's only for one month for reduce hours or my doctor will order me off my feet. Also to add insult to injury while you are in pain the kid managers on the first floor blast their music super loud as if it's a club in the warehouse so it hard for you to think. It's already loud with the conveyor belts now you add loud base music to that and you can spell delirious as you're trying to work and in pain. I don't people next to me playing  their music but on the first floor is they bring in special type of club equipment in to make it extra loud. It's very distracting when music is that type of loud. As I am in agony, rubbing my feet and hearing loud base in my head that won't stop I feel I hit a new low on life. The pay is not worth it all the hard work you do on your feet and all the crazy loud noise you have to hear. And it makes no sense that they have you take a drug test when you can clearly see who is dope up around you. I am currently looking to get out and I don't care about a pay cut I need to get off my feet and not be in a concert drugged up environment.
advice_management: Fight for your pickers to get normal working hours and a real lunch break for one hour so we can rest our feet. And tell them kids on the first floor to STOP BLASTING THEIR MUSIC as if we are in a concert because it's hard to concentrate while we work in pain. I hate that loud music it's makes the environment crazy!

job_title: Current Employee - Customer Service Agent, Technical Support
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great culture, lots of opportunities to move around, good benefits
cons: Within the AWS field, the specific department feels very terminal. If you're being hired as a level 3 or lower, be prepared to have a very difficult time getting out of the "level 3" squalor; most career starting points are Level 4 and above, so it's frustrating to be stuck at a bottom line/operations-driven role when you have the potential for more

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Did not have to redo i9 form.
cons: I worked for Amazon in a warehouse previously. I left on good terms. I apply for one of the new driving positions in a town I have lived in for the past 20 years. I am drug free. The position involved driving a van around and dropping of packages to their customers doorsteps.No special licenses are required  They send you some bulloni interview that you have to complete over the phone. I recieved this email an half hour before the event. It is mandatory that this thing gets completed before the hire event. I rush through it. Amazon didn't even show up to their own hire event. Some women came by that works for their hr team and handed out $50.00 giftcards for the inconvenience. She then said they need all the drivers they can get and that it you can pass a drug test you would have a job. At the next hire event the other were told they could take all the time they would want with this app interview at this hire event. My video interview looked rushed and crappy. They chose not to extend an offer because of the video. The only position they had left was a graveyard part time position in their warehouse located in Nashua NH.
advice_management: Stop using the app to determine if a prospective employee has people skills.  Especially if they worked very hard for the company in the past and the company already made a decision that they are eligible to rehire.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
- You will learn something new every single day.
- You will learn new skills that are outside of your comfort zone.
- You can make a big impact no matter what your strengths are.
- You get out, what you put in.
- Promotions are generally very clear, your performance, and ability to develop/influence others dictates promotion.
cons:
- Some managers are very lazy, and give no effort.
- Lack of accountability sometimes.  (Depends on your facility)
- Work Life balance is rough.  They are making efforts to improve this for L4 and L5 managers.  But since Ive been employeed for almost 4 years (now an L6), you will put in long hours, and pretty intense hours.
advice_management: Hold everyone equally accountable.  Dont allow lazy managers to coast, that increases the workload for higher performers.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Decent pay and benefits, paid time off.
cons:
My shift is S-W 6:30 pm to 5:00 am. Yesterday (5/20/2019), I took 2 hours of paid time off, so I clocked in at 8:25 pm. Then I clocked out for break at 9:31 pm and clocked back in at 10:01 pm. Finally I clocked out at 5:01 am for end of my shift.

Then I find out my punches were "corrected," so that I first "clocked in" at 8:07 pm then "clocked out" at 8:25 pm. Then "clocked back in" at 9:31 pm then "clocked out" at 10:01 am. Then "clocked back in" at 10:31 pm then finally clocked out at 5:01 am. This resulted me losing 8 hours of unpaid time.

Called support to fix this. If this doesn't get fixed, or if it does get fixed but I don't get my 8 hours of unpaid time back, I'm quitting immediately.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Decent compensation for an entry level part time job
cons: Lack of consideration for the health and welfare of associates. Company attendance policy has zero consideration for the welfare of employees. Being sick (even with a Dr's report) is not an acceptable excuse for not making it in to work even if you call ahead, and also complete the time-off request form on the employee portal. The Smyrna, Ga location management policy puts the health of employees at risk because sick associates come in to work for fear of loosing their job and expose other associates to the sickness they are dealing with.  This is an inhumane way to treat associates.
advice_management: The company has clear and well defined metrics to measure employee performance. However, it is only fair to take the well being, welfare, and health of employees into consideration. Granted the compensation is decent, employees should not have to choose between coming to work sick and keeping their job. You are putting the welfare of not just the sick employee but that of their coworkers at risk by forcing them (unspoken rule) to come to work with a 102 degree fever just to keep their job.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Opportunity to run massive businesses
The scale of customers you can impact with your decisions is incredible
Work with incredibly smart people 
Opportunity to work on projects that align with your interests
Exposure to many different business problems
cons:
Getting a good team or manager is very hit or miss 
Low levels of institutionalized development support
advice_management: There has to be more investment in your people - train managers, support ICs, and provide a clearer path for employees that want to stay in retail.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
1. As a scientist you get to work on the most challenging and ambiguous problems in Amazon.
2. If you enjoy making important decisions with data, and help the near and long term directions of the organization, then applied scientist is the best role to be in.
3. There are tons of data and state of the art technology to make the best of it
4. The co-workers are very competent and some of the best in their fields
5. Quick experiments are highly encouraged.
cons: 1. The expectation from scientists is very high. If you don't enjoy working in a challenging environment where you are constantly under pressure to deliver, then Amazon is not the right place.

summary: "Good Opportunity to get involved at Amazon"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
- Decent pay of $15/hr
- Flexible Schedule
- Office work environment can be relaxed and friendly for the most part (depending on what type of work you do specifically and opportunity to make friends there) 
- Not hard to learn and do the job (though people have different learning pace)
- Can get a 401k plan
- Potentially can be promoted from within to work full-time after being there for a certain amount of time (have to apply the full-time jobs online)
cons:
- Hours are not enough despite being a part-time job
- Unfortunate that the opportunity to get a stock plan for associates was removed when minimum wage increased to $15/hr
- Good amount of down times, so you may get bored when there is nothing to do
- Picking work shifts may be tough when the shifts are open to all associates to pick (though many associates tend to drop shifts during the week so you may pick up shifts during the same week or same day)
- Communication between associates and management/leadership is not exactly transparent
advice_management:
- Improve relations between associates and management 
- increase hours for associates who are willing to work (even though the current hour cap may be good for the business, there have been a shortage of associates filling up shifts) or create some incentives for associates to pick up unpopular shifts
- Keep up the good work!

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Amazon is always inventing and trying out new things - which creates a lot of opportunity and ways to contribute. It feels like a start up environment - even when we do in PR is always improving.
cons: You're in the spotlight. If you want a boring job, go elsewhere.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Software Engineering Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Smart, highly motivated people. Exceptional pay due to stock performance. Huge economic and societal impact. Company is still trusted by customers more than most other tech companies.
cons: Pressure-cooker environment. Highly process-based with little trust placed on individuals. No institutional emphasis on employee well-being built into leadership principles or manager reviews. High re-org churn and burnout rate means there's no point to develop interpersonal relationships with peers. Flat org structure and huge leaps in pay and responsibilities between levels makes promotions nearly impossible past a certain level, highly political, and competitive. A culture of "over-ownership" makes everyone appear to be working very hard and putting in long hours, but for questionable actual benefit.
advice_management: It's a goals-oriented culture, and there is nothing in the goals about creating healthy teams and ensuring employee well-being. Your burn rate among engineers in the US is exceptionally high, forcing you to increasingly rely on cheaper overseas engineers, which leads to even higher burnout as people routinely put in 14 hour days to make meetings with people halfway around the world.  Ownership is a good leadership principle in theory, but you have legions of people who's only job seems to be "owning" an issue and then immediately delegating every aspect of it while spawning redundant processes that then wasted and burn people out. Many of your highly-paid engineers are embarrassed of how badly we treat warehouse workers.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros:
Resume-padder.
Dedicated coworkers, some of whom are decent.
Decent pay.
Your friends and family delightfully saying "Oh, I love Amazon.com and the Echo!" once your line of work comes up.
cons:
Just about everything else. 
The benefits, culture, career opps, overall comp, systems, and management were truly appalling, and I've worked in big tech for several years now. Even in the moments where work was exciting and performance was high, it was extremely difficult to ignore the faces of depressed, angry, anxious, and freaked out people every single day. After I left, it took me a while to shake off the panic attacks and low stamina. Look, I get it - from the outside, things at Amazon look amazing. And some of it really is. Most of it really isn't. The anecdotes provided in the NYT article from years ago were the rule, not the exception. 

Build your resume and professional experiences elsewhere - there is a plethora of tech companies doing work that is just as, if not more, incredible. Don't do what I did.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: It's a unique opportunity to be a part of a company that continuously strives to foster a start-up environment at the scale Amazon does. Amazon does well with maintaining the hiring bar, and thus you are surrounded by people smarter than you in every team you'll work with. Innovation is encouraged at micro and macro levels and data-driven decisions are made rapidly to mitigate stagnation. Opportunities to identify and act upon think big ideas are omnipresent and those who bring cost-cutting or customer experience-improving mechanisms to life are recognized.
cons: The fast pace and need to maintain aggressive growth rates creates a challenging environment for employees to keep up in. Work-life balance can be difficult to maintain. I am lucky to be in a team with excellent leaders that strive to preserve work-life balance and who genuinely look to create a fun and rewarding culture for everyone. However, you must speak for your own development. Managers are more stretched than you are in terms of bandwidth, so if you aren't crystal clear with them on your plans for skill growth and career advancement and lay out a plan to achieve your goals, they don't have the time to focus on you. In terms of benefits, Amazon has excellent health insurance and compensation, however the perks you may see at other tech companies likely don't exist here. There isn't much of a wellness program (i.e. gyms on campus or gym membership reimbursement), no snack bars or free campus food, and they've ended the annual summer and winter employee parties.

summary: "Find what you love to do and dive in!"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Great team and leadership.  Flexible to home life needs.  RSUs are part of our compensation which really drives Amazonians to think and act like owners with a legitimate interest in how the company performs.  You truly own your development and are encouraged to try new things, take risks, and get creative with how you deliver your results.  Benefits kick in on day 1 (no waiting period for healthcare, etc.).  Leadership is invested in and supportive of inclusion and diversity in the workplace which is critical to the success of any company's inclusion and diversity initiatives.  If you've ever been in a meeting where you felt your voice wasn't heard, your opinion wasn't valued, or you were not kept informed, then you know how frustrating it can be wen leadership does not make inclusion a priority.  My peers and leadership value what I bring to the table and it motivates me to keep bringing more .
cons: Greater Seattle area traffic continues to grow.  Public transportation helps, but the housing market in the area leads many to buy or rent further from the city for more affordable cost of living.  There is no easy solution to this growing problem.  Working remotely when possible cuts out the commute but separates the team physically.  At that point, it becomes a team effort to ensure everyone is involved and included.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
- Certain teams work on newest tech stack which is awesome
- Very challenging tasks, building solutions from scratch
- Mostly pleasant and friendly coworkers, reasonable but busy managers
- Great offer (but no significant pay raise until you've been at your job for 2y)
- Tons of resources available for learning and self-development
- Pace is fast, but still people value their personal time, so nobody makes you work overtime
- Managers (at least some of them) learn from their mistakes and really try to establish great team culture.
cons:
- If it's a new team it can grow so fast it would become uncomfortable (literally people joining every month)
- People who come from other projects at Amazon can bring very toxic and nasty attitude poisoning the whole experience. A lot of long-tenured employees are after their next promotion, and it shows. Managers often don't have soundproof ways of fighting subtle toxicity, so you would be stuck with those delightful coworkers until your patience is up and you decide to leave the otherwise prominent team.
- Tons of ambiguity, and it's taking its toll on everyone.
advice_management: When the team is big enough, democracy doesn't work. Sometimes it's better to force a decision on the team than leave them with 10 unknown variables that are up to discussion. Ditto people management: a couple of bad seeds who are a source of rivalry and issues can still be managed out if that protects the majority of others, instead of making it "fair" for everybody, so each and every one member of the team has to just bear with it.

summary: "Great place to work for some types"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I love the space to innovate, have your ideas heard despite your level (so long as you're a strong writer), and the ability to define your career by voicing the products/projects/initiatives you want to work on. You have to be comfortable with ambiguity though. Often times your manager can't tell you what specifically you should be focusing on or what's the right next move - it's on you. People I've seen struggle at Amazon are the type of people who need a clear next step or path forward. With the rate of change and innovation, being able to create a plan and stick to that plan without being flexible is almost unheard of at Amazon. I also get to work alongside lots of smart people who are passionate  about the problems they are trying to solve. While I've been in the same role for 4+ years, it's continued to evolve and expand, keeping me interested. I've never stayed in a role longer than 2 years prior to Amazon.
cons: You need to be the type of person who owns your career to thrive here. Amazon isn't going to pull you along in career development, you need to network and create your own growth plan. You also need to draw your own lines in terms of work-life balance and set that expectation from the beginning with yourself and your team, only disrupting the balance occasionally as required.
advice_management: Bring in the SMEs to help make big decisions. There's a lot of expertise at some of the lower levels.

summary: "An awesome place to take ownership as a technology professional"
job_title: Current Employee - Senior Technical Program Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
* Strong product culture: one of the best in tech, actually.  If you've read Inspired by Marty Cagan, Amazon is a good representation.
* Great leadership: Amazons managers are great to work with and learn from.  As a whole, the company truly lives up to its principles at every level of the organization, every day. 
* Seattle is a central location for big tech - Amazon, Google, Microsoft, Facebook, Expedia, Zillow, Redfin, Tableau, and Nanostring to name the more notable.
* Opportunities abound: If you're a high performer, you'll never get bored here.  From robotics to fligh logistics to streaming media - there's always a new problem.  And leaders expect and encourage mobility.  My objective within the next two years is to take a position overseas.
cons: Work/life balance - this is not the place to work if you're expecting a strict 9-to-5 schedule.  True ownership of results comes at a price.  That said, I find it very easy to have work/life "harmony"

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
It completely depends what team you are on. Some teams you will receive brainless work, but luckily on my team we get some actual work. 
Casual environment
Flex hours and work from home
Not micro managed-- no one breathing down your neck
Get to do work in my field that I enjoy and find rewarding-- a lot of control over what I do day to day
Good stepping stone to have amazon on your resume and gain some skills
cons:
Amazon likes hiring "peculiar" people, so some of your coworkers will be quite odd/incompetent 
This is definitely a low tier job so you won't get much power and management won't always listen to your opinion
Can be difficult to advance depending on team
Low pay
Amazon likes to have everyone manage something/be in charge of an area even if they cannot do the job. A lot of incompetent managers, PMs, etc.
advice_management: Don't just hire someone because you like them, get actual skilled employees.

summary: "Great Company to work for: exciting career opportunities, smart and friendly colleagues, yet very demanding."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
People are required to be highly autonomous and are empowered to make decisions from day one.

There are several (horizontal) possibilities to develop and build a career (across functions and across geographies), seen the fast pace at which Amazon grows.

Colleagues are bright and normally fun to work with.
cons:
People should not expect to be coached daily by their managers, they need to be self-starter and learn via self-training and while performing the job.

Amazon systems evolve continuously: once you begin to master a specific tool it will be likely about to be replaced with a new one.

A typical work day is plenty of interesting challenges, yet very demanding.

advice_management: Instead of staffing anyone anywhere. Look to see what the associates strengths are and staff them accordingly.

job_title: Former Employee - Senior Software Development Engineer
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Brand recognition, opportunities to learn, ability to ship
cons:
AWS has mostly built its reputation on a few world class services (EC2, S3), but the vast majority are of mediocre quality and wouldn't stand on their own as products.  Most were designed poorly by amateurs and then scaled aggressively to keep up with the cloud computing hype.  As a result, there's some catastrophic operational nightmare occurring at any given time of day within AWS, and some poor souls are scrambling to apply more bubble gum and baling wire. 



The company, AWS specifically, operates on the lone, hollow vision of "make the customer happy".  With no vision comes constant re-prioritizing of work, bike shedding, and conflict, which only makes getting anything significant done in an under-resourced, massive, and operationally-intensive environment that much more impossible.  Vision and long term strategy aren't valued, which makes sense given that a lot of the leadership seems to be context switching between outages, people management, and 3-6 month out feature launches.  Odds are that your work will be largely limited to putting out interesting fires or making something terrible last a bit longer.  That and perpetuating the thin public veneer of elegant automation at scale, which in actuality are crude scripts (see any number of high visibility outages) at best and clumsy human driven deployments, changes, and operational responses at worst. 



Talent, overall, is not great because of the self-perpetuating cycle of under-investment in hiring and its second order consequences: poorly designed and maintained systems that drove high operational burden and ultimately attrition.  Intelligent and capable folks have mostly gotten the read that Amazon is a miserable place to be, which only makes this feedback loop worse.  To keep the lights on through the last few years of cloud computing hype, AWS has hired a horde of low-bar, Enterprise-type characters that seem endemic to corporations well past their high point.  A lot of AWS is well past day 2.  Turf wars, kingdom building, and subcultures imported from other companies were increasingly visible.  



There are bright spots within the company, but not many and they are certain not to last.  If you do end up joining, do your best to determine the trajectory of both your service and manager and adjust accordingly.  Moving between teams seems to be the only way to outmaneuver some of the miserable circumstances within the company and is available to those not under-performing.  Research as much as possible before signing your offer.  Ask your hiring manager about vision/priorities, attrition, and expectations out of different roles within the team.  Ask about what their biggest fears and goals are, and determine if they’re serious and/or capable of addressing either.  Take care to get a good read on the manager’s relationship with the team and their style of leadership as sociopathic managers seemed to thrive and escape accountability in the chaos of AWS.

summary: "Manage a department inside a fullfillment center"

cons:

advice_management: Treat your AMs how you would want your AMs to treat their AAs

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I work with a lot of talented people that are passionate about what they do. Everyone really puts the end customer first which makes decision making in meetings pretty easy to do. Work life balance is typically pretty good. There are always times, as with any job, where you need to buckle down and put in the extra work.
cons:
The "fail fast" mantra of Silicon Valley does not apply. I have found that those in leadership roles take Amazon's "Be Right, A Lot" Leadership Principle quite literally. Failure of experiments is seen as such, a failure. It is not seen as a good thing in the teams I have been on. It is seen as a failure of the individual or team that proposed and implemented. 

Compensation and benefits are very much lacking. The financial compensation model is a black box that individual contributors have very little insight into. There have been various attempts to explain the financial compensation model at a high level but they have been unsuccessful. Base salary raises are quite small as the company sees RSU's as a major portion of total compensation. When stock prices rise there is no guarantee that new  RSU's will be rewarded. With volatility in Wall St, this is not comforting. 

There are many who prefer to see their careers grow over the success of projects or teams. It is not common for managers to stick up for individual contributors while presenting work for review to Director or VP level leadership. The 'top-down' management style and rule by fear is very apparent in some of the more mature business units across Amazon. 

Because of the size of the company, there is not a sense of community within the design discipline. There are attempts to do so but they come across as stale and self-righteous.
advice_management: Push to understand the inputs into compensation and communicate these clearly with employees.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great benefits, different shift options, allows you to get personal accommodations. for school.  Opportunity to grow within the company, but they won't hold your hand either. You gotta have somewhat of ambition to seek the opportunities they offer.
cons: During the peak, there will be long hours 40 + hours
advice_management:
When hiring or promoting within make sure they indeed are capable of doing their job.  I like that Amazon hired  Area Managers right out of College, but they should make sure that they are able to do all the job positions within their department they got hired to do. I've seen a few that are have no clue how to do a certain job or how something works. 
Overall I had a great experience working at Amazon.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Business Development Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
-I get to work with some of the smartest, most curious people in the world.  The bar is very high to get into Amazon; this creates a sense of trust that each person you work with is more than capable of delivering results.
-We actually live and breath our leadership principles.  This is your north start.
-I get to work on very complex, challenging deals with full autonomy.  This work is extremely rewarding because of the scale and visibility -- this stuff makes headlines and news!
-Opportunity for promotions and more scope (I was promoted within first 12 months but you have to work for it)
cons:
-No on-site daycare or financial incentive to cover late pick ups, etc.
-A big part of your comp package is made up of RSU's which is amazing, however you can only sell these during limited trading windows.  Can be tricky to plan.
-Low 401K contribution
advice_management: -At least for the Seattle campus, please think about your employees with little children who require day care, etc.  I am constantly late for pick up and I'm charged a premium by the minute.  I would like to see Amazon either develop a childcare center for employees (a few of them around campus) that is offered at a discount (could be pulled right from pay check).  And/or help cost share in 3P daycare needs so I can continue delivering results.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
Decent pay for most positions.
My work as an ISS Rep was fun and interesting
I enjoyed a lot of my coworkers.
cons:
A lot of changes in policy in the 9 months I worked there
New things were getting added which wasn't communicated well
My department (ISS) was understaffed, and had necessary roles go unfulfilled
Many people were put into a role as problem solver that didn't deserve it.
Management wasn't putting a lot of effort in the wrong places to fix Problem Solving
If you took on the role as a problem solver, you got paid as much as a simple stower. Its even less worth it as an ISS rep.
advice_management: Keep consistent problem solvers. Identify who is the good ones and promote them to process assistants. Give them authority and let them lead problem solve. Don't be obsessed with labor tracking for problem solve, when we have backlogs of issues. ISS is supposed to be the place where only the best problem solvers go, don't treat it like a dumping ground.

summary: "Best Environment for Builder-Oriented Startup Mentality Big Thinkers!"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Working at Amazon / AWS is like working for an extremely well funded start-up.  You get the chance to insert yourself into transnational change with our customers and be a meaningful part of the future state of their organization.  Think Big is bigger here in reality than anyplace I've ever been.
cons: AWS's ability to drive small, innovative teams, that iterate new products rapidly drives tremendous value to our customers.  The growth is staggering.  You'll need to be ready to grow personally and professionally when jumping on this ride.  Given growth, there are not as many predefined processes or centralized reporting as one might hope for given the company changes at such a fast rate.  Overall, if you are fine with the "start-up" mentality you'll find this refreshing.  This said, the benefits to our customers far outweigh the pains of growth.
advice_management: Look for ways to automate out reporting an analytics where possible.  Consider ground-rules for new services and teams that help them integrate analogous to what we do with our services being API driven, but be careful not to sacrifice the agility that has led to the tremendous success.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
-Fast-paced shift-work that generally goes by fast. 
-Benefits are good and affordable 
-Salary is a step up from similar jobs at competitors 
-Opportunity for advancement (at least for now since the company is growing so fast)
-Occasional gratification that you're having a real impact on a company as large as Amazon
-Limited stock options 
-Military friendly (if you're a reservist or National Guard)
cons:
-Generally poor leadership at all levels; shift managers are under-trained and some are borderline incompetent; ops managers could generally care less about you. Anyone above this level doesn't even know you exist. 
-(Sometimes) very long hours. 80+ hour weeks during peak (busy season) are the norm but you are still only paid to work 40. (You will sleep in the office at least once during peak). 55-60 hours/week are standard outside of peak and you're only compensated for 40.
-Constant schedule changes are common. You'll frequently be thrust onto new schedules (days, nights, different parts of the week) due to managers coming in and quitting. 
-Manager turn-over is almost as high as associate turn over in some cases.
advice_management: Start caring about your people and do what you say you're going to. There are SO many "leaders" at this company that say they will do things and then simply don't. Don't be one of those people. DO your job. It is not just a title. Leaders actually lead.

summary: "Diffcult environment to thrive in - 70+ hour weeks"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Good compensation  package for the first 4 years.   After that comp drops off because the stock grants are cut back to prevent the employee from exceeding the target comp.   This effectively means the employee does not share in the success of the company. 
Very smart people with good ideas  Great place to learn and develop
cons: Very competitive, aggressive  and combative environment.  Leadership uses threats and intimidation to motivate productivity.   Not much team work.   Sr leadership  seems to be unable to prioritize.   Efforts are redirected weekly to new deliverables in a very reactive way.
advice_management: Amazon is customer obsessed but not employee oriented.  Need to learn to prioritize.  The 70 hr weeks drive high burn out.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Extensive opportunity for growth, both in scope of any individual role, as well as cross-functionally through lateral transfers.  Drive your own development and seek out mentors/high-impact projects.  There is a lot of autonomy to complete work however best you operate (i.e. work from home, nice office spaces, etc.)  Pay is competitive and benefits are great, particularly maternity and parental leave and certain commuter benefits.
cons: With any company, a bad manager can ruin an employment experience, but that is not unique to Amazon.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Good pay for this area
cons: The associates receive very little feedback or recognition. The Area Managers have very little experience. They are straight out of college. The process assistants are much worse, they have no experience or college and got the position because they were friends with the operations manager at the time
advice_management: I promise you the lower managment especially the process assistants are having a negative effect. The majority of the associates complain about this and many great workers have moved on to other jobs.

advice_management: Stop treating older people bad.  You will be older one day!  Karma!

I would rather take a pay cut and work alongside teams that have more EQ and recognize the importance of building POSITIVE relationships and establishing healthy team dynamics.

I would rate them 0 stars on culture and senior leadership if I could. Left within months.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Certified Pharmacy Technician
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
- Decent pay
 - People I work with
 - Dress code is lax
cons:
- Very cooperate. Severe separation between management and the rest of us.
 - People are often reminded they are NOT management (even when there is no reason to bring that up in the first place). 
 - They require you to display leadership abilities but do not allow you do do anything leadership. How does that work out?
 - Amazon removed our core values and replaced them with their own. 
 - Very hard to move up or ask for pay raises. No matter how hard you work you can always 'work harder'.
advice_management:
Listen when people give suggestions - and give them credit for it. Very often people will give suggestions and are told they are crap and then the next day/week they are implemented. 
We understand management and everyone else are on different levels - but we are all humans. Treat us like you would want to be treated. Turn over rate is growing because we are treated like ants. Again I strongly believe this is due to becoming more cooperate.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time

cons: work culture and its not good. on call every time

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Software Development Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Ensures there's no dead wood, and (perhaps) keeps the bar high..
cons: Once you've been pro-active in managing out low performers, you end up firing people who are doing a good job, which worries their colleagues, causes regretted attrition, gives Amazon a negative public image, and ties managers up in lengthy PIP processes, then rehiring and retraining with no guarantee of improved productivity
advice_management: It's dumb, and counter productive, if you're going to set an un-regretted attrition target,  set it at 3% not 6%
