summary: "Intense environment but is occasionally rewarding. Not a long term place to work."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
- the pay is solid for an entry-level job, you'll pull over 4k a month after taxes for your first year when signing and relo bonuses are factored in
- also stock, although most people don't stay long enough to see more than a couple shares vest
- amazing health benefits
- great leadership training during onboarding, and experience during day-to-day work will improve your ability to be a manager and leader
- get to have Amazon on your resume, recruiters will take more notice of you
-  you really do bond with your team and it can be rewarding to see your people improve and maybe even get promoted
- pretty standard promotions, around 1 year mark for the average manager
- 3 day weekends except in holiday season
- if you're a competitive person, you'll love Amazon, everyone is always trying to improve rate and outpace each other
- kind of cool to be part of the behind-the-scenes of when someone orders products off Amazon.com, a lot of people ask about it (including recruiters)
cons:
- there's a 50% chance you'll be working night shift, be prepared for it
- you get to submit location preferences but there are no guarantees
- you don't really learn many technical skills unless you go out of your way to do so, most analysis is done with Amazon's own tools so you aren't needing to mess around in Excel all the time
- long shifts, 12 hours most of the year and 14 hours during holiday season
- not many transferable skills unless you're looking to work in operations/logistics management long term
- generally hard to transfer to corporate until you get promoted
- upper management can  be unnecessarily critical and when you combine that with long hours and heavy workload, it can cause everyone to be miserable

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Flexible hours, ability to control your own projects, good benefits, living in Seattle
cons: Mainly FP&A roles with lots of iterative work, Finance has not been invested in properly to improve automation like the rest of the company, pay is not great, you will live in Excel if you don't learn other tools
advice_management: Invest in hiring more qualified FAs to automate iterative processes

advice_management: Decide what programs are value added, when you add more to an already overflowing plate, take something away. Allow Safety to actually be able to spend a decent amount of time on the floor, not wasting time on useless metrics.

summary: "Research your position and your Manager before Joining"
job_title: Former Employee - Senior Technical Program Manager
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
- fast paced
- interesting work
- always shipping is addictive
cons:
- no process (its day one every day and that is not a good thing)
- high level politics force astounding attrition
- limited growth
- 80 hour work weeks for L6 (Senior) staff

If you do not change teams every year, it is likely you will get managed out before you realize your RSUs, so don't bet the farm on any total comp offered.

There is little if any career development unless you luck out on a decent manager and skip manager, but even in those cases, there is no stability in reporting chains.
advice_management: Amazon is likely the most effective, least efficient organization on the planet. Its attrition for engineers and mid level managers is astounding. The premise that work life balance is not important and that fixing culture is not important because "there is a line up out the door of people to work here" is tremendously short sighted. The total lack of corporate maturity manifest in huge risk and tech debt.

summary: "Nice when you're lowest level, higher position people get worked to the bone"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros: Great coworkers, usually given all the resources we need to do our job well, lots of autonomy (no micromanaging, at least at my location). Definitely will learn how to be assertive (customers will walk all over you if you don't).  Really competitive pay for a college part time job,  in my opinion and experience with other offers.
cons: VERY unpredictable hours week to week. Hours can half or double week to week depending on lots of factors you can't control and how much the manager likes you. Customers are absolute jerks regularly but most are nice people. Customer service people will flat out lie to customers, then customer come in asking you for help with something that is impossible to do (poor communication between departments let's call it).  Very low likelihood of moving up management, if you want to do that.
advice_management: communicate what's happening in each department and various department's policies (that's to headquarters). Location managers are pretty great from what I've experienced.

summary: "What being a delivery driver for Amazon is like."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: People who have friendly pets and the scenery sometimes.
cons: What's it like to be a delivery driver for Amazon? I get that question a lot and I always tend to sugarcoat the answer, but not anymore. This is what it's like to deliver for Amazon.... you start the day by loading 250 to around 350 packages which is any where between 150 to more than 200 stop. A stop can be anywhere from 1 to 5 different houses. Packages can weigh up to 50 pounds and majority of the time packages are not labeled heavy so there goes your back when your day starts. Packages a majority of the time come to us drivers already damages. You have no time for a lunch break (but you have to write down that you took one) and if your lucky you might get 1 of your 15 minute breaks. You have to choose whether or not you want to stay hydrated and choose between going and finding the closest bathroom and being called by dispatch to see why you are leaving your area or do what the guys do and pee in a bottle in the van. When an area is not accessible due to remodeling or anything and you let Amazon know and they forget they blame you for their mistakes instead of owning up to it. You get in trouble if the business is closed when you get there, or if the customer needs to sign for the packages but they arent home. You get in trouble for every package you have to bring back even if it's not your fault. Amazon asks you to give your feed back on everything to how they handle things, the routes, and the navigation system. Beware of giving feed back, they don't fix anything, they take routes anyway, maKe the navigation worse, and will some how find something to blame you for to give you a tier 1 infraction which will cost you your job. So next time you want to blame the driver for an issue with your package not being on time or damages. Or that we are pissed off or cranky, please remember that we try our hardest to get it to you, we are hungry, have to pee, and out of the 200 plus people we deliver to no more then 5 have told us "Thank you".
advice_management: Fix they system.

summary: "Great place, but you get back what you put in"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Very competitive compensation packages, Excellent benefits from day 1, lots of opportunities for career advancement either at Amazon or through educational opportunities, the chance to work all over the world if you desire. You really do get back what you put in. Come to work happy and ready to do you best everyday and you will probably love it here, if you come in upset and always complaining and just do what it takes to get by and you will not like the environment. It is fast paced and high energy most of the time.
cons: It can be hard to get into some positions, sometimes growth and advancement can take time (you get back what you put in applies here too. If you are flexible you might move faster if you aren't it may take longer). Expect faced paced work, lots of standing and walking, a lot of lifting and moving items. Expect that if you are new to the environment the first several weeks WILL be hard physically as you condition your body but once you do you mostly don't even notice.
advice_management: Better prepare newcomers for the physical demands. Maybe a company sponsored video on work conditioning tips to get people ready and give them a chance to start getting more fit before Day 1. And a handout "tips from the pros" on ways to make Day 1 - 30 easier like best shoes for standing, insoles people have tried and love, before work at-home stretching and after work stretching to stay stretched out better and not tense up, most comfortable clothes (this may be different based on path and building due to climates), proper hydration vs high caffeine or energy drinks. Remember the 5 P's and if we did better at this with new hires we would have people happier and less stressed in those first 30 days.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great company that empowers individuals. Treats employees with respect.
cons:
Salary increases are very minimal and do not account for cost of living increase.
Recruiters should be very clear in explaining the Compensation Plan.
advice_management: Trust your employees and do not lose sight of the human factor that makes for a great company.  It's not only about the $$$.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Must enter five words, lol.
cons: So they keep pushing associates to do more because they want to increase volume all the time. But then they hire morons with bad attitudes and provide piss-poor training and then they wonder why people are walking out. What's more, just to get hired the process takes a month or longer, and prior to my getting hired the process used to be even worse. Before I was trying to get a warehouse job to escape retail and when I applied they gave me a position similar to an Instacart Shopper. WTF, I didn't ask for that. Screw this company. From what I hear, DMI3 used to be a chill warehouse but then due to the minimum wage increase they've become really anal and they only hire illegals. The warehouse is so hot that just standing perfectly still you'll have a pool of sweat forming.
advice_management: Rot.

summary: "Logistics for the Virtual customer service at Amazon"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Being paid to never work at this place or any of its sublets.
cons: It takes 10 minutes to walk to the designated break area and another 10 minutes to get through the security line, so employees are basically getting a few seconds of a break. If you leave to get water or take a bathroom break you're time off task. People contemplate suicide here because of the mandatory overtime, the fact that management is constantly belittling their employees during - standups, GEMBA walks, firing other employees in a public display on the floor to showcase their power that the employees have no other options but to stay at 100% or else they're fired. If hours reach 0 on PTO and UPT then you get fired automatically after clocking in. To those reviews that are actually positive is beyond me. Also with Amazon laying off over 1000 employees to open up an all machine facility, I'm surprised that there are no plans to unionize against this corporate greed. Also speaking of unionizing, if there are any plans to start a union management will try and break up the group and issue them suspensions and unpaid leave perhaps even firing the employees. They put fear into the employees to force them to pick up their numbers.
advice_management: Message to Bezos to be more precise. Actually care about the safety and health of your employees. Stop closing down mom and pop shops for your own selfish needs. $2B sounds like a lot to donate, but that's easily re-accumulated to a man who's dollar to a normal American is $88,000. I'm ashamed that the government failed to stop your monopoly of the world because you pay them off. But of course you will never care about anyone else's lives or welfare because it doesn't benefit you. You claim you care about customers, but by demoralizing and lowballing your employees this makes them give terrible customer service.

cons:
- sometimes there are inconsistencies in demonstration of core principles in different teams/under different managers
- culture favors long/hard work vs. smart work

- ensure risk taking across all teams/orgs (sometimes it seems more like lip service)

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: I suppose the only pro was learning more about the Logistics career field. Besides that leaving my previous employer might be the biggest mistake of my life.
cons:
Too many too list:
Work life balance- There are NOT 10hr days/4 days a week. They expect more like 12-14hrs 4 days a week.

Lack of advancement- Despite being over qualified for my current position (tier 1 manager) the additional responsibility I take on and training I cannot seem to advance.

Favoritism (and not to the best managers, only the used car salesman, sleezy type. Senior leadership (L7 and above) have NO IDEA what we do in operations. I have had 4 regionals and 5 ops managers in a year and a half. They will say you can't go from an L4 manager to an L6 and a bunch of other made up "rules" but it's all fake. I've seen people fail interviews and be offered positions anyways, I've seen people slide into positions where there was never a posting, and I've seen L5 managers get L4 positions but continue to be paid as an L5 manager. The whole process and all the rules is a total joke.

Pay- This may be the biggest one so listen up. There is NO signing bonus and NO RSUs given to you for accepting the job. What they are giving you is your raises for the next 4 years.

After my first year I was supposed to  receive my 12k bonus ($1,000 per month for 12 months). When it came time for my annual raise I didn't get one because they take into consideration the "bonus" they give you and all RTUs (stock) that vests. Upon my second year I again did not receive an annual increase and was told that I was hired in at more than most L4 managers so again I wasn't receiving an annual increase. The $1,000 a month  I was getting as my bonus ended and now I'm not getting an increase. Correct... The 1st year I didn't receive an increase because they considered my signing bonus as my salary and now that it's gone, they don't consider it part of my salary. In short after 2 years I am now making 12k less then i did last year. I do have 6 RSUs  that vest this year and one might say that's why I didn't get in increase.. well.. 1. I was given these shares as part of my "sign on" and 2. The shares don't vest until NOVEMBER and it's April. For 7 months I will be living on a salary 1k a month less then what I made before.

Please listen to the reviews!! It's cool to say you work for Amazon for about the first year. After that you'll be embarrassed, I promise. Move on to the next potential employer and hope you can do 10 years + with them. Amazon will totally ruin your life and not set you up for the next opportunity.
advice_management: I don't even know what to say. No one stays in their position long enough to make a difference. I've heard the term Churn and Burn in regards to our manager and it couldn't be true enough. I'm confident all L4 and L5 managers have a shelf life and I'm confident they expect you to quit before that. They will force you too so that they can get the next young dumb manager.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: I liked the atmosphere of being able to combat the Mgr verbally if you disagree with them (They promtoe that) and the benefits were awesome.  In addition, they offer tons of UPT (Unpaid time) and sometimes they're overstaffed and would ask if some ppl want to go home. They don't force you to go, but I loved going home almost every other day sometimes.
cons: This company have no problem working you like a machine.  Your body at some point will break down and be prepared to be replaced as if you were never an asset.  You'll stand all day for 10+ hour shifts and you only get 30 minutes for lunch.
advice_management: Nothing, Management is just as much a revolving door as the regular staff.

summary: "A fluke I made it into hell"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Never bored
Learn a lot
Quality engineers, especially backend
A million orgs mean a million cultures
cons:
Some orgs are stagnant and you will work on 10 year old code
Some orgs are so product driven that the engineers are never hear
The push for product erodes quality
The push for product comes from stack ranking an a constant need to deliver. this can create a lot of conflict.
advice_management: I'd honestly appreciate some blatant nepotism. Promo process is based on how much your manager likes you. Meritocracy is a lie. Also Jeff, you need some principals that understand Javascript.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Like everything in life, this depends on context; that is, where you are in life.  As a transitioning professional, this job will allow you the time to contemplate your life as long as you can meditate while  standing and moving constantly.  This job will replace any gym membership you may have had, although you will be focused on cardio exercise.  Moreover,  if you are in any way afflicted by analysis paralysis, this job will break your habit of overthinking things.   If you are just starting out, then this job will  provide an opportunity to learn what it is like to put in a  long, hard day of work and, for the observant, how  a complex system is  broken down into small units.
cons: If you are a transitioning professional, the  physical exertion will drain the energy from other activities.  If you are just starting out, then the path to advancement seems a bit vague.
advice_management: I have always felt that the best managers are always looking for ways to develop their employees.  This starts out with helping newer workers understand what employers are looking for with respect to work ethic.

summary: "Expectations can be unrealistic, the job exhausts you"

It's a demanding job, they want you to move non-stop, people don't seem happy and there aren't many advancement opportunities. I mean, where could you possibly find a job with a warehouse experience, another warehouse?
The pay is okay, but could have been higher considering the volume of the work.

 You get so tired sometimes that a 2nd job doesn't psychically make sense. Nothing attracts me in regards to benefits as well. It's not a career path.

summary: "Amazon is what you make it, and AWS is even better to work for!"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: I love the freedom to be myself at work, to be friendly and socialize with coworkers, to bring my dog with me and see how excited he gets to see all my coworkers. I love the level of intelligence and attention to detail my coworkers have, they really encourage me to grow and expand my skill set. I love the diversity of our hires. I work with people of all ethnicities from the entire globe and it makes work so much more interesting and rich. I love how laid back Amazonians are. There usually isn't a ton of ego or competitiveness between teams, people are very cooperative and open.  I love that Amazon encourages our employees to volunteer and contribute to our community, even if the media would have you believe otherwise. I love that I get to work from home in order to maintain my work life balance. I love the protection and support I feel from HR. I love traveling and meeting new people all over the world. I love working for Amazon Web Services.
cons: You get a lot of flack from the public working for Amazon. There are a lot of assumptions and misconceptions about our work environment or what our company values are. If you're brave enough to set an example and speak out about what working for Amazon is truly like, it is definitely worth it.
advice_management: Continue to prioritize work life balance and maintaining long term employees. Be mindful of stress levels and employees that tend to over-extend themselves. Continue to make diverse hires and support people of all genders, ethnicities, and sexual orientations. Always remember we are people first and employees second.

summary: "Great Company to Work For, SMART PEOPLE, makes you excited to go to work daily"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: all team member are SMART PEOPLE, gets you excited and not bored to work daily
cons: hard to compete with all these SMART PEOPLE, but to me, this what keeps me away from boredom
advice_management: keep raising the BAR!

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: You are given the ability to grow and/or get your CDL and move on.
cons: You'll work lots of hours on a small team, and you'll not be given much freedom.
advice_management: They are still figuring this team out.  It's not a great place to express yourself.  It has not reached the level of culture as inside of the buildings.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: When we did get vcp and stocks each year it was awesome. Pay upt pto and vacation time. Work events etc. It was enjoyable when there was music in the warehouse.
cons: Where to start? The constant reminder of time off task if you spend to long on an item u are unsure of, too many trips to the bathroom it becomes a problem. rate, hitting rate is ok unless you have a bad day and rate is low..  break times, two 15 minute breaks and 30 minute lunch. When you wait for the bell to dismiss you you end up spending about 2 1/2 minutes of your break walking to the break room and then 2 1/2  walking back. So you barely get 10 minutes of rest before you must return to the station. I was an employee at las2 for about 2 years and I just couldn’t take anymore. It’s mentally draining.

job_title: Former Employee - Virtual Customer Service Representative
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: There is always room for growth. Your company metrics are always available for you to review. Weekly meetings to discuss different situations and issues peers have come across. Warm Transfers. Wonderful team leads.
cons:
Minimum wage.
Prepare to be yelled at, then hung up on without getting a word in. 
Sometimes, fellow associates will COLD TRANSFER A SCREAMING CUSTOMER, which only upsets customers more (happened multiple times a day). Sometimes I was put into call teams that I was never trained in, which would tank my metrics until my team lead could figure out what happened.
advice_management: Report more cold transferring associates. It would help customers get issues solved quicker.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year

summary: "Liked it so much, I came back!"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I am a "boomerang" employee.  Had to leave for personal reasons but missed working at Amazon, so I finally go the opportunity to return and jumped at it.  Always something new going on.  The learning never stops. and the people are amazingly smart.  Customer obsession is the focus, but there seems to be more appreciation for employees since I left the first time.  Opportunities are everywhere at Amazon if you take initiative.
cons: You must be comfortable with constant change and ambiguity.  If you get frustrated with change and just wish that things would settle for a while, this will not be a good place to work.
advice_management: Some VPs get a God complex, so keep humble and live the core principles.  That's what makes Amazon great!

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros: A company that cares about your growth and happiness.  Fluid start/stop times.  Easy to transfer departments.  Employee events.  Cool work spaces.
cons: I have nothing to complain about.

job_title: Former Employee - Senior Product Authentication Specialist
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The company as a whole is amazing, great benefits, stock options, decent pay, and a very free and casual environment to work in.
cons: Some teams are great to work for, others have a reputation for a reason and should be avoided at all costs, do your research before joining and believe what you hear. Management is not always on your side and when they can lay blame on the low man on the totem pole they will. There is no guidance so it's easy to fail so watch out if you're not willing to take risks.
advice_management: Care more about your lower level employees success and look at the management structure of your teams, there should be no dotted line reporting and multiple managers within PQ teams tot he point that employees don't know who to report to or follow up with. PQ needs a serious overhaul in management and structure.

-cool workspaces in Seattle

-free snacks (team dependent)

-can work whenever (as long as you're pulling your weight)
cons:
-not as many perks as other tech companies (but aside from free food, I wonder how many you'd actually use) 
-"move fast" approach, which means things can sometimes be done hastily in the interest of delivering results quickly

cons: The policies fluctuate and you’ll find yourself getting written up. If cross trained you cannot go back to what you were doing before you were currently trained. You’re tracked for your entire shift and the #s dont get to you till the next day so you won’t know if you’re getting a writeup
advice_management: People work better when not feeling the anxiety of getting fired. Write people up for doing something wrong but small mistakes? Nobody’s a robot

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: People are nice and benefits are good.
cons: They set packing productivity rates that are nearly unachievable/Warehouse is HOT/The break time includes time to get to break and back - so it ain't a 15 minute break to me/Not a lot of screening to go into building but a whole bunch to get out, i.e. they don't trust us
advice_management: Re-think your packing rates. You say I am in control of hitting the mark, but the following  things slow me down and I can't control them : cages not delivered timely & I have to wait / slow taper - conveyor barely moves / no one brings me boxes but that's their position (water spider) / certain boxes not even available-they ran out!! / machinery breaks down. Wow! no wonder I can't do 62 pkgs. a minute.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Ownership: Despite being a huge company, it still feels like a startup - so you often feel like you're working on a project that 10 people should be working on,  with a due date that's 10x sooner than feels reasonable. If you're up for the challenge, that feeling breeds passion, excitement, ownership, and also career advancement. There is never a shortage of (actually pretty interesting) work to do, and never enough time to do it all, which actually seems to excite most Amazon employees (myself included).
cons: Some of the pros are also the cons. Things can feel scrappy in a bad way - where even though we're a mature company, we have "immature" processes, workflows, and systems in some areas of the business.
advice_management: The parts of the business where we're growing the fastest seem to be the ones that are losing the Amazon culture that we love the fastest. Do whatever you can to keep the Amazon we love alive, even as we grow.

cons: Bad operating I got hurt on the job & was fired. All after being threatened  to move from a 4 hour shift 5 days a week to a overnight 8 hour shift or the other option was to be fired. I switched over and ended up getting a hernia. I talked to several managers & the over the phone HR number to see what my options were because I physically couldn’t work the 8 hour shift but nobody could give me a straight answer. Managers told me to call the ERC (HR) number because they couldn’t do anything & the ERC was trying to force me to get workers comp & suggested I just go back & talk to the managers. Never once after a week and a half of putting in my medical wavier did any manager or HR person give me the advice that I needed to go about this situation. So I finally went in and told them I’d rather have accommodations to move to another shorter shift than to be put on workers comp. The next day after talking to manager I couldn’t  sign into my amazon A to Z To I called the HR number to see what happened they said they couldn’t find me so they transferred me to someone else & I was told that I was terminated. I didn’t receive a termination notice/call or email until over 24 hour later & their reason for firing me said it was a voluntary withdrawal & I abandoned my shift & failed to contact managers. After being terminated I contacted a manager & they gave me an HR email address that could help me. I emailed them & got no response. A week later I called again & got the REAL HR email so I emailed them & got no response for days until I threatened to take legal action. They HR lady said she would get back to me that Friday to investigate but didn’t get back to me with until two weeks later just to say my termination still stands. I would recommend amazon fulfillment center to anyone.
advice_management: Get a UNION & operate better & make it easier for people to contact you guys in the case of an injury.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: The pay was good, the head of the teams were great!
cons: There was no notice of cancelling the shifts when Hurricane Harvey was bearing down on us until two hours into the shift; workers are penalized for not coming in even if you call the worker hotline. The breaks are ONLY two 30 minute long breaks, but it takes up to FIVE minutes just to get to the breakroom. This, adding the wait time or any possible mandatory activities going on, leaves you with roughly 10 minutes to eat or relax, before you're forced to get back to your stations; on top of that, you get in trouble if you 1: do not clock out AT THE EXACT TIME OF THE START OF THE BREAK (thus shortening your breaks even further) and 2: are not clocked back in BEFORE YOUR BREAK IS UP. The bosses at Amazon want you back at your station and working BEFORE your break ends! Another problem is the fact that you are not treated as a person. You're penalized for talking to other people, not meeting the ridiculously high quota set, and even going to the bathroom!! They don't care if you're sick, they want you to show up. I got sick with a high fever, vomiting, and dizziness. I called in to tell them and they said that they wouldn't let me stay home because I hadn't given them a notice at least 24 hours in advance. FOR BEING SICK. I had to come to work, sick, almost passing out, at risk of passing my sickness to the other workers or even customers through the inventory, having to go to the bathroom to vomit every once in a while. My boss came and talked to me about my TOT (time off task) because it was pretty bad. One look at me and he sent me home. The lack of movement and repetitive motions for TEN CONSECUTIVE HOURS actually messed up my back and my legs. Not to mention the fact that the inventory isn't always safe: at least twice this box of Tide detergent powder wasn't closed and burst open right into my face. I couldn't breathe, couldn't see; I thought I was going to die from it. There was no concern shared for me over this. The eye-washing stations are so spread out, as are the water stations, I didn't even know where the closest one could've been. And no one saw me struggling to breathe or anything, because we are forced to KEEP WORKING NO MATTER WHAT.
advice_management: God, make it better. How can you stand to do this to the workers?! The HR people get chairs to sit on, but every other worker has to STAND for TEN HOURS A DAY.

job_title: Current Employee - Software Development Engineer II
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
The workplace is open and genuine.

Everyone's voice is heard in technical discussions and team meetings.

The technical challenges are very real and usually interesting.

The development and operations tools provided are powerful and easily available.

Talented colleagues that embody the Amazon leadership principles.
cons:
SDE on-call can be painful, but it's a great learning opportunity and motivator. Something to be aware of.

Systems and their interactions are very complex. There won't always be a happy path to find the answers needed to do your job. Expect to spend significant time diving into code and asking questions to learn about how things work. Also a good opportunity to learn and grow.

You will work with legacy technology. Amazon systems are powerful but they are not gold plated.

Work with other teams can be bureaucratic, slow, painful.

My current office building is old, awkward, and not the most comfortable working space. This is especially true when comparing to other Amazon office buildings.
advice_management:
Continue to treat your people with respect, thanks!

Let's work on having an Amazon-worthy physical workspace.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
We really do use the Leadership Principles in everyday tasks. We don't call them out by name, but they certainly resonate with current, future, and former employees alike.

I've seen an org change it's structure because of grassroots efforts.

I've felt like all my managers work for me, instead of the opposite. They're not blockers, but enablers.

I've always been able to find the best answer, even if not on the correct path. It's harder to find someone that won't help than will help (in my 2.5 year career thus far, it's happened 4 times).

Amazonians work here because we want to work hard (not kill ourselves, just do it right), have fun (we definitely have peculiar ways around this--broomball), and make history (by seeing our customers succeed far beyond our expectations).
cons: The problem with two-pizza teams is that we sometimes have more tools that do the same thing, which leads to a lack of governance. However, the culture of Amazon reinforces being flexible when choosing the tool(s) to perform your job.
advice_management: A little more governance/oversight would go a long way.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Software Development Engineer
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: I've been working for Amazon Web Services for over five years now and I have enjoyed the experience. I appreciate excellent work-life balance. It's extremely rare to work more than 40 hours/week or to work in the evening/weekend. I have lots of vacation and virtually no restriction when I can take it. On-call is unfortunately a thing but it's just one week every 2-3 months. Sometimes I won't get paged at all, sometimes a get woken up one or twice but again that's very rare and we definitely consider instances where people got paged to be Bad Things and try to remedy them. Comp seems solid but I have admittedly not done a whole lot of shopping around lately.
cons: Open space offices. I hate open space office and strongly believe it detracts from effective collaboration and productivity. But this is not unique to Amazon, you'll get this at most tech companies.

summary: "Find the right fit and you'll thrive here"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
As with any organization at Amazon's scope, you'll have to meet a high bar and contribute a significant amount of time and energy to succeed here. I've worked at several other organizations and I'd be suspicious of any recruiter trying to downplay that level of expectation and challenge. Take your time on the Amazon jobs site, read the descriptions carefully, talk with others in the company (ideally in the org you're applying for), and be upfront about any concerns when you're talking with recruiters and hiring managers. You'll find no shortage of candor. 

I admit that my first role at Amazon wasn't a perfect match, but thanks to the culture of creating your own path, I was able to evolve in my role and find the perfect team, all as a recognition of the effort, initiative, and value created for the company.
cons: I've talked to friends and colleagues across the company in several different countries, and experiences vary. While I'd still say on the whole it's a thrilling opportunity to work at Amazon, some leaders and managers still need to invest more in their own development to lead teams effectively. Stay vigilant when interviewing and make sure you align with the hiring manager's approach. Challenge them to share their own areas for development, how they've evolved, and what they expect from their direct reports. If what you hear doesn't sound like something you're willing to invest your career in, stay patient and keep exploring your options across the company.

summary: "The pay is wonderful, but it's not a good place to work."
main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: It is good pay ($15/hr). That's the only pro.
cons: There was absolutely no communication at our building. Managers didn't talk to each other and did their own thing, making it very difficult for associates to do their jobs. The HR "representative" refused to do her job. She constantly threatened to fire employees who complained about her. Management was difficult to work with. There was one particular manager there who was verbally abusive, disrespectful, threatening, and condescending to associates. He was put on probation, then they put him back as a manager, and he went right back to what he was doing. They would constantly change the process, causing our production to go down. Morale was very low and there was a lot of turnover. They fired hundreds of people in a "cost saving measure," but then they hired hundreds of more people at a higher rate. There was a manager and and a shift assistant who stole packages. They had been stealing packages for months before they were finally fired.
advice_management: A lot of work needs to be done to make Amazon a good place to work. I don't have enough time or space to write it all down.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year

cons: Stretched thin with extremely high expectations with little to no compensation to truly make it worth it

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Dynamic opportunities to make contributions or learn. 
Lots of respect in the industry. 
If you can make it after two years you can stay longterm.
Workers are very close to Unionizing through the Tech Workers Coalition. 
AWS and Retail will continue their growth for about 2-3 years. Prime and Ads are well-behind but might be able to continue the growth streak if they can find their footing in 3 years.
cons:
AWS scaled so quickly and did not solve inherent issues in their operations. There are EXTREME levels of inefficiency, but because the pressure to perform is so great people just put up with wasting 25% of their working hours on unnecessary activities. 
You don't have a personal life, you will be paged for any reason. 
Benefits are awful, many people have health issues after working here. There is no PPO and if you get very sick, your sign-on bonus, stock vesting, and moving costs vesting are completely frozen. 
Extremely levels of backstabbing and cross-team sabotage by managers. 
Cult-level belief in Leadership Principles, even when taking actions directly in contrast to those principles. 
Managers find ways to empire build to force themselves to get promoted by creating groups of people "under" them who are on their same level. 
No promotions or significant raises are part of annual review. You have to take part in an insane promotion process for a very long period of time. People with the right relationships do much better by having their promotion panel fixed in their favor. 
0 HR accountability. 
Amazon as an organization lies or misleads employees about its benefits and other factors like a politician might. You really have to investigate if a certain benefit is at the level of quality that they claim it is, or solves the problem they say it does. The majority of the time you discover there is a near-sociopathic decision that's been made in regard to how benefits are implemented or kept away from employees or customers. 
Managers' opinions are regarded as the word of god because Amazon believes they "hire and develop the best", it is impossible to succeed if you end up with one of the many many many many horrible managers. 
Payscale has been secretly increased throughout North America to levels of San Francisco and New York. Existing workers in SF and NY have not received a commensurate pay increase, nor have existing workers with more experience and contributions received an increase. Meanwhile, new employees with no experience or contributions are coming into non-SF and NY regions at $100k+ salaries to their peers. 
The majority of people do not stay long enough to get their stock equity. Amazon lies to employees about how your stock vests. If you get sick your stock will be delayed by the amount of time you got sick. When your stock vests enough taxes are not taken out and you will have to pay potentially 5 figures of back tax on your stock.
advice_management: Fire 75% of middle managers, consolidate Levels 7-8 down to Level 7; make Level 6 Level 5s, and make Level 5s Level 4. Compare ratio of resources and their experience level in technical vs. functional areas and compare their pay and contributions to their Level. You'll find that statistically, functional areas are expanding their footprint based off of "contributions" that don't actually accomplish anything.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
The jobs is challenging, but extremely rewarding. The Area Manager role is a very busy job, but with a lot of opportunity. 

You will always have a challenge ahead of you, and will never run out of work to complete. Due to the growth of the company, you will have unlimited growth potential, and Amazon is very open to moving you to any role as long as your talents match the position. The pay is very competitive, although it seems to be getting lower and lower every year. 

If you love work, and you love thinking about what is possible with any process or issue, this is absolutely the job for you. Look no further. If you can imagine it, and can provide the data to sell it, you can do it. 

I never imagined I would love operations and logistics, but I really enjoy my job. Those of us that are good enough to weed out all the things that aren't value added will have a great time here.
cons:
Work-life balance can often take a significant turn to the negative, specifically during holiday seasons. Operations seems to be the main place this occurs; yet, support program managers and other corporate entities are paid more than operations management, regardless of the extra work and direct-to-customer facing role. 

Even so, the biggest drawback of the job in the operations are all the petty, near-worthless duties you will have mostly due to HR policies. Let me be clear: an Area Manager is likely the busiest role in the company. You will have a lot to do, and not enough time to do it. Throughout this, you will receive a high amount of duties that I would consider short-term thinking, not matching the culture that Amazon has created; and most of it is due to HR policies. You will have to enter reports and checkmarks of things HR wants you to do that frankly make no difference in the long term at all. This wouldn't be an issue in itself, but an Area Manager has a significant amount of work to do, and these petty things add zero value to the work, and ZERO value to the associate experience. 

The company should really examine how much work the Area Manager role is being given, as it is always more and more, and a lot of it it useless. The role would be more useful if this was scrutinized.
advice_management: I would suggest to revise what you want an Area Manager to do. Every month there seems to be more added, with nothing being taken away. The workload isn't the problem here, but the amount of things that don't add value to the customer or the organization. The role is becoming more trivial than ever after 3 years of seeing it develop.

summary: "Finance is proud of the 2015 NYT article and hasn't changed much"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
The business teams you work with are talented, motivated, and accomplish amazing things.

You can rotate out of finance and onto a business team.
cons:
Finance consistently promotes managers with the lowers connections (employees satisfaction survey) scores.  It makes the "Making Finance Great" initiative and asking connections questions seem irrelevant.    

Process improvement and automation is discussed but not valued.  My team created some great automation which made planning easier.  I was told it didn't appear that my team suffered during planning, and people should be working until 7 or later during planning.   

Re-prioritization happens every couple of days.  It's really code for incremental work that must get done and deadlines on the original work don't move.  The attitude is to suck it up and work 12+ hours multiple times a week all while calling it work/life harmony.
advice_management: Stop promoting bad managers.  People will just leave the team or leave the company.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Technical Program Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
One thing to call out is that as Amazon is a large company, your experiences will vary based on your team. I have largely only had positive experiences and am very happy I made the transition to work at Amazon.  Some of the pros I've experiences:
- I am constantly challenged by incredibly smart and hard-working individuals, the culture embraces learning new things and stretching yourself
- I've been given significant responsibility and the ability to make meaningful impact almost immediately
- Compared to more traditional companies, there is no red tape. If you have a good idea, just make it happen. Individuals at all levels are empowered to do what they think is best. You don't have to have 5 managers approve something for you to get your work done.
- Work-life balance is incredibly important. Almost everyone on my team has kids and they all value your evenings and weekend time. Members of my team have gotten dinged for working on the weekend. And it's very understandable if you need to work from home (even suddenly if something comes up with your kids)
cons:
- There isn't much sharing across teams in the company.  I find out about what other teams are doing in the public news.
- While benefits are very good compared to most companies, we're behind other tech companies. Having some support for childcare would be appreciated and make a difference.
advice_management: Try to keep the culture consistently focused on the Leadership Principles, it's a great place to work.

We have like 5 holidays per year.
OK health plan
advice_management: Redo the terrible 401k plan.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
The culture - in my experience all of the people I worked with were great. Having been at Microsoft prior to Amazon, you don't get nearly as much of the contentious culture you see at Microsoft here at Amazon.  Team efforts are truly team efforts and everyone wants the company and their peers to succeed. 

Amazonians are smart people. You will not meet any incompetent people here. Unless you go to google or facebook, you'll realize just how high the Amazon caliber is as soon as you leave.
cons:
HR is shady - went to HR in confidence when I was having issues with my manager and she went directly to him. He confronted me the following day. 

Leadership/Management is shady -  there are several terrible managers here. Thankfully I only had to endure one during my time but one was too much. When I quit, he flagged me as ineligible for rehire even though I did not have any documented (or undocumented for that matter) performance issues. I heard from the team he was just furious when I left so this felt like retaliation. It took a lot of work but eventually after finding out about the flag, I had it removed. 

Work life balance is a joke - the rumors are true. While I was there, I interviewed for an internal role and the team I met with claimed they had great work life balance. When I asked what their typical office hours were they sad 8-630. In my book that's not great work life balance. That's normal Amazon hours.
advice_management:
Check your managers better. Check their firing history often. Too many managers there are determined to PIP folks out and saw this happen repeatedly during my years there. Keep an eye on this - if one manager is firing a lot of people, there's something to be said about that. 

HR practices need more integrity. I get they work for the company, not the employee but employees need a safe place to go to work through real issues. Amazon can burn you out easily. 

Keep an eye on managers better. They are not always right. Learn and be curious when it comes to a manager's negative review or evaluation of an employee. Check this opinion against previous managers. Do not just take the current manager's word for it. Get all the data including the insight from previous managers. There's too many bad/power hungry managers running around Amazon who should frankly be fired or who will cost you a law suit.

summary: "It's hard work, but it will eventually pay off!"
job_title: Former Employee - Senior Human Resources Assistant
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: You learn and experience a lot!
cons: There are a lot of abrupt changes that may cause stress and/or confusion in your standard work, but it all depends on your team and how effectively you all communicate with each other under pressure. Amazon Fulfilment can be a very stressful environment due to customer demand. During my experience working there many days were rough for me, but after leaving the company and working elsewhere I was able to identify the professional development I gained from  my trainings and experience. In the end, all that hard-work paid off!
advice_management: Managers are also in a very stressful position and have a large workload. My advice to both management and employees is to be mindful and compassionate with one another. Communication is key!

summary: "I don't feel like I am working"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
If you like making customers happy you will love this place.
If you like being on the cutting edge of technologies or technology movements you will love this place.
Very little politics and the leadership principles are reflected in everything we do, they are not an afterthought, but, what we rely on in order to make decisions.
All the resources you could ever need to do your job.
Everyone knows Amazon and folks are eager to work with you.
cons:
Too many tools, I like to joke that we have 3 tools for every problem you need solved.
It is very much a start up culture, so sometimes it feels like we are building the airliner mid flight.
The "firehose" refers to your first 6 months here, where you feel constantly overwhelmed and out of your depth.
The company turns on a dime, which can be overwhelming if you like comfort.
Yes, people will always have to tell you how much they love Prime when they meet you.
advice_management:
More documentation on pivots would be great.  It sometimes takes the ripple of decisions weeks before everyone is aware of what is happening and whether or not it was a good idea.
Tools that lots of people use, should have some sort of consensus from lots of people before they are rolled out.  Even a focus group review of new tools and processes would be welcome.
We understand that security is job zero, but, more thought needs to be put into changes to access to tools.

summary: "Amazon is all about Work hard, have fun and make history"

Smart workforce
cons:
Its a big ship (lots of opportunity), but you can get lost. 
Culture doesn't support inclusiveness, you have to be self motivated 
Be ready to push back. Whoever pushes back harder wins.
Team culture and leadership style varies significantly; from cut throat to setup for success.

summary: "Amazon Overworks Employees & Has Unhealthy Company Culture"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Working at "The world's largest internet company, by revenue."
cons:
-	Culture of overworking its employees, seen from every level. (I work in recruiting/HR) 
-	High attrition & turnover. Employees are constantly leaving teams within the company. After being here for almost half a year I’m starting to realize it’s not a “team” issue but a “company” issue. 
-	Not enough vacation or flex time. 
-	No focus on company culture or how to improve work/life balance. 
-	No focus on how to improve mental health for its employees as a result from being in an overworked environment. No mental health or public health initiatives coming from HR.  
-	Bloated with baby boomers in mid-management positions.
-	Amazon’s base salary + 1 yr commitment signing bonus is equivalent to regular base pay at other companies. Amazon entraps their employees through 1yr signing bonuses.
advice_management: Focus on company culture and mental health awareness from overworking employees.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year

cons: Managers are all over the place
advice_management: Get the managers on one accord

cons: You will be on your feet for 10 hours a day.
advice_management: Offer more opportunities to move up in the company.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: You can learn a lot in a short period of time. Competitive salary and benefits. Dynamic and exciting company.
cons: Those who get promoted do so in low and machiavellian ways. Leadership unable to retain quality employees and clings to toxic managers just to maintain continuity.
advice_management: Reward quality over loyalty. Listen to the canaries in the coal mine if you truly care  about building a quality work environment.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years

summary: "Good pay, Great stock and Bad Benefits"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
+ Great base pay.
+ Mostly nice and mostly very smart coworkers. This may vary depending on the org. In my experience high growth orgs like Alexa have top tier talent.
+ Dog friendly!
+ Leaders who genuinely believe in the company and have the Amazon customer centric culture embedded in them
+ High growth stock
+ Great relocation bonus
+ Easy, open internal transfer policy
cons:
- Sh*tty benefits. No meals/snacks nothing. Sub-par 401k match.
- Hiring bar is inconsistent. You might run into folks that are not technically competent
- Opinionated a-holes get promoted often. Difficult to work with.
- Compensation structure is troublesome. Backloaded stock vesting means you have to stay at the company for at least 3 years before you see some real RSUs
- Does not foster a friendly, tight knit work community. Everyone is in their own world. Work is just work.
- Promotion process sucks. Too much of hitting the checkbox. Promo doc feels unnatural and tedious. It's almost like have an additional FT job.
- Forced attrition puts added pressure on employees.
advice_management: Team building needs to be at the core of the Amazon culture. Benefits need to be more compelling. Attrition rate needs to be managed better.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Reasonable work shift flexibility.
Need to work minimum of 1 shift per month.
Great for a college student or those who need some extra cash.
Can participate in 401K with Amazon doing some matching. (See their info.)
Whole Foods employees are exceeding nice to Prime Now Shoppers.
No management breathing on your back although they do send electronic generated info when not meeting your quota.
cons:
Have to have really quick fingers to find and then accept work shifts that are displayed on your smart phone. (Competing with fellow employees)
This is not a job for those who have knee problems or can not stand or walk for long periods of time. 
Not too sure about promotions out of this job or pay raises which could mean it rarely happens.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Very smart and hard working colleagues. Great challenge, I love coming in to work every day.
cons: Many meetings can interrupt workflow, but they are always productive.  Have to be good at code switching.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Challenging work, define your own path, able to set boundaries on work/life balance, lots of talent, open to virtual/remote employees
cons: In a company this large it can feel overwhelming to choose one path when you look at all the things you could try to solve or improve

summary: "Gets a lot of hate, bet better than most."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Amazon is not as bad as people make it out to be. Sure some sites have had issues (as seen on the news) but the site I worked at was alright. I was given two 15 min breaks and a 30 min lunch for 10-hour shifts and three 15 min breaks and lunch for 12 hours.
I never had issues using the restroom or getting water either. Most sites are on 4 day-10 hours per day schedule

Some big Pros:
1. Full Benefits Day 1 
  1a. A total of 168 hours of time off options each year
   80 hours of unpaid time off, 20 hours each quarter
   48 hours of paid time off, earned based on hours worked
   40 hours of paid vacation, earned based on hours worked.
   Plus during non-busy times you can opt to go home without pay for no penalty 
   I feel this is a generous amount and the most I heard of for new employees.
2. $15 Per Hour (Recently Raised)
3. Daily food trucks arranged (This was at my site, others may vary)
4. Once a month or so they would buy lunch (pizza, Chik-fil-a, etc) for everyone
5. Peak Season (Nov-Dec) prizes, awards for attendance, and performance
6. Climate controlled 81 degrees max in the summer, 50-70 in the winter
7. Communicated overtime in advance of at least 24 hours
    7a. At most, you worked 5 days a week if needed.

Warehouse work is not for everyone, I have worked in several warehouses Amazon has some pretty easy positions. Most of the time boring, standing in one place but easy.
There are performance and quality rates to maintain, some people struggle, and some people excel. It is fairly easy to maintain these rates at a steady pace. This pretty much sums it all up.
cons:
Couple downsides, however, you will find this with most warehouses.
1. Despite the nationwide pay increase to $15 still low for how successful Amazon is.
2. Poor management, some better than others though.
3. Drama, even with some of the management. (This is typical with most companies)
4. Slow pay raise scale.
5. You are still a number.

pros: The salary was not great but fair, they send you the equipment you need
cons:
Unrealistic expectations and contradicting messages--given a 'talking to' for logging back from break 4 seconds late. then I was in trouble the next day for logging in a minute early. Got told to stop working ahead on my training then the next day, they awarded a team member for 'taking initiative and working ahead of every one in the group" You can't win.

Favoritism and racial bias--I wish this was not true but I am aware of it. Given the retaliatory nature of the business, I will leave it at that.

Aggressive managers- Very angry when asked questions or to explain anything. they were there to herd us through as cattle.

Encouraged  to get done before you were comfortable with material because it made the manager look good

Chaotic onboarding

Too much emphasis on metrics and not enough on employee wellness
advice_management: It's great that you emphasize the customer. You need to value and treat employees better.

The amount of hours are horrible and they don’t let you exceed 30hrs if they put out VET (voluntary extra time).

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years

- Teams actually have fun and enjoy working together
- Excellent place to learn a lot and grow as an engineer or in any role
cons:
- Backloaded stock vesting schedule
- Few holidays are given off automatically such as President's Day and Memorial Day
advice_management:
- Make stock vesting schedule more balanced (25% per year)
- Acknowledge more national holidays such as President's Day and Memorial Day
- More workplace perks in the office, snacks are good but more catered events, parties would be fun
- Bring back the summer picnic and holiday party

cons:
Frequent turnover of management

Massive lag time of implementation for solutions both on the work level and personnel level
Compensation underwhelming
Overt favoritism

Few roles of meaningful responsibility leads to growth by knocking one's peers down, usually by telling people they are wrong instead of helping them out

Value your employees

Empower, invest, and develop your employees so that they can grow rather than look for opportunities elsewhere

summary: "Job Habits/Preferences Questionnaire Misleading; Job Given Based On Seat at Random Table"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Decent starting salary, structured environment, great job for the right person.
cons:
Warehouse gets hot and the  water coolers not close enough to all stations; you'll need to stay hydrated, but time away from your station to get more water or use the restroom chips away at your production time. I hope you don't have a shy bladder.   
 Your time on the clock is completely micromanaged to the nanosecond; you'll not only be on your feet for ten hours a day, but when you get one of your two 15-minute breaks, you have to walk as fast as you know how to walk to get where you have to go; there's a three minute walk to break room, then you have to time the coffee machine to brew your cup while you run and get another cup full of ice so you can cool your coffee off enough to drink it since you can't bring it on the floor. You might shove a granola bar down your throat with the coffee, run to the restroom, and then back to your station so you can start picking again at exactly 15 minutes after your break began. 

Going to lunch involves waiting until exactly 12 to sign out of station, then walk three minutes to swipe out for lunch at 12:03. Upon return from lunch you'll need to attend the daily afternoon Stand-Up (required meeting) at 12:35, and since you can't sign in before you've been on lunch for 30 minutes, you'll have to wait until 12:33 to swipe back in and then run up the stairs to the third floor for the Stand-Up.  

RE the physicality of the job: Picking - which is what I was arbitrarily assigned despite all kinds of questions about my work habits asked of me in the online application process - is extremely physical work that is expected to take place at seemingly unrealistic speeds, so be prepared to hurt. If you're over 50, be prepared to hurt even more because you can't apply for another position for six months.
advice_management: Advice? They don't want my advice. They don't want yours, either.

summary: "Lived and learn of the Big Name Company"
main_text: I worked at Amazon
pros: Take advantage of everything amazon has to offer. The company will spoil you
cons: Know exactly what your position consists of when it comes to accepting the position. Because you are stuck with it until you pass the one year mark to do anything or go anywhere. Also you have to be seriously careful when reporting anything they will protect themselves before believing anything you have to say; if you get hurt their just know it’s not granted to get paid all of the time. I was getting bruises all on my thighs consistently and I told amcare the deal and it was ruled out to be non work related then I sprained my knee and I barely got paid for that after just getting hired in my first few months I got paid $35 for three weeks of workers compensation leave.
advice_management: Re-evaluations are a plus to all your management and learning ambassadors to keep the meal and job training in performance for employees to keep the task and job fun and always willing to grow with in. Also reach out as much as listen to you associate on how to make a better work place.

cons: Leadership has a huge bias for young inexperienced workers being promoted over seasoned workers.  Older workers are treated as inferior, second rate and expendable.  If you have grey hair just know going in that you will always be last in line for advancing.  Company boasts about so called (ownership) but took away stocks and attendance incentives in order appear generous with a supposedly higher wage.
advice_management: Realize the value of the people under you that in many cases know more than you do about work, management,  face to face interpersonal skills, professionalism, and exceptional  work ethics.   Don't treat someone generations older than you like they are kindergarten students.   A piece of candy reward and daily power hours are a  demotivating experience to people that give their best every hour of every day.

summary: "Easy Work + Good Pay but Management and Safety are Lacking"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Flexible Schedule

$15 an hour 

Clean and climate controlled environment

Wear whatever you want

Lots of access to water all over the building

Work is simple and easy, nothing is really over 40 pounds.
cons:
Management does not prepare for the day properly, often roles aren't assigned and things get backed up.

Human Resources messes up and takes forever to get things done pretty much all the time. They once lost my identification and I was suspended for the rest of the week and until I got them new identification. I watched as they scanned it in and said I was good to go, and the next day they said they have no identification.

They care far more about speed than quality work or safety. (If you are scanning packages, they do not like it if you are slower but are fixing pallets and picking things off the ground to help everyone else.) 

There is no way to know when the shift will end consistently, even 15 minutes 
before it's over. I have been lied to and told I can leave at 8:00 and then told I have to stay another hour, and then another 30 minutes after that.

Lately, they have been asking the hardest workers to do the work of 2-3 people at once, with no extra compensation, time, or benefit. You have no choice but to do what they say or risk termination. They do not care if you say you cannot handle the amount of work they are giving you.
advice_management: LISTEN TO YOUR EMPLOYEES. Many people who have worked here 6+ months know what needs to be done and what positions need to be prioritized better than operations. If someone says they need help at outbound, then send someone. Don't expect them to keep up with more work than one person can handle.

summary: "Working at Amazon is What You Make It"
job_title: Current Employee - Senior Software Development Engineer
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
* Amazon always focuses on the customer first, and in doing such, you feel connected with the people that use your products.  
* Many of the products we work on are at the forefront of the industry, whether it be cloud services, retail, physical shopping, devices, etc.  
* There's always something new to learn and there is a mixture of all kinds of roles from more scientific and research based to hard core system optimization as well as solving new and interesting business problems, so whatever problems you like to solve, Amazon likely has something in that realm.  
* You are allowed to move between teams pretty much as often as you like.  If you end up with a bad manager or unreasonable work pace, you can work with HR to find something more your speed.
* Amazon compensates employees in stock, and the stock has been doing amazing the past 5 years.  
* Amazon is very flexible with dedicated and long-time employees.  My wife got a job that required us to move across the country, and so I was able to start working from home (after 5 years at Amazon) while flying back to visit the main office in Seattle once a month or so.  
* The company operates as thousands of tiny little start ups.  Each team has it's own set of goals and goes through rapid iterative development cycles, which makes for a fun environment.  The advantage of being in a giant company like Amazon in this situation is that you can then leverage many of the tools and services that others have built and vend to you to make this even faster!
cons:
* Churn of people moving teams and in and out of company make it a little difficult to persist knowledge and keep full team momentum moving forward, but you can find teams that stick together for quite some time as well, it just depends.  
* Compensation is good compared to the software industry as a whole, but compared to other tech companies, it is slightly behind.  Compensation is definitely substantial and had me very quickly walk away from a different employer I was not planning on leaving and keep me hear for 6+ years, so it's definitely still pretty good.
advice_management: * Keep it up.  You have created a company that is not risk adverse and loves taking on a challenge.  In doing so, developers are encouraged to try things and it is okay to fail, because we learn from those things and move on.

job_title: Current Employee - User Experience Designer II
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: I was wary moving to a large corporation after working with a small design agency. But I have been pleasantly surprised that after a year working at Amazon, I have consistently had plenty of autonomy to drive my design projects, mentorship and support from the design community whenever needed, brilliant people working with me to problem solve and push the boundaries, and opportunities around every corner to grow my skills and expand my community. I'm lucky to work directly under a design manager on a creative team, and I am assigned out as the UX Lead and dedicated designer to an engineering team for a variety of products (small and large) that I can own myself. Therefore I have all the support and critique and benefits of working within a creative studio environment, and all the unique challenge and autonomy to drive my own projects and work directly with an engineering team and stakeholders. My manager is exceptionally transparent and encouraging, and has opened pathways for me to do my best work and be seen and acknowledged for my achievements. I take advantage of events and networking opportunities on campus, and a lot of my coworkers have become some of my closest friends. The compensation goes without saying, the health and wellness benefits are exactly what I need.
cons: The thing I struggle the most is Amazon's size and socio-economic impact on the city of Seattle and the world. That said, to me the positives out-weigh the negatives. With the current pace of technology, I am constantly questioning the problems we are solving with our inventions. For me, I make sure to align myself to projects I can stand behind. Furthermore, Amazon regularly encourages you to contribute tough questions, critical thinking and constructive criticism to weigh in on your organization or department decisions and direction.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: It's a dinamic environment and if you don't fit in the role you were hire for they move you around until they find the right one for you. Also there is opportunity to grow with the company.
