main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Great flexibility in terms of work hours 
High sense of ownership
Lot of interactions with the business/customer in diving deep to really understand what he/she is looking for. 
Opportunities to work in a large scale environment where needs and demands are extremely high. 
Have an idea ? you can always present it and no one is going to shoot it down.
cons:
Sometimes management can be ambiguous in what your responsibilities are as a recruiter. 
Recruiting systems are not the best and as recruiters we are aware of this and the recruiting head is working on making changes. 
Would be nice to see better benefits such as more Happy Hour, team lunches or dinners etc.
advice_management: No advice at the moment

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
You get to work on cool technology (and if you love linguistics, this could be a great fit if you find a role/team that’s a good match)
The team I was on had fun, quirky people
Extremely lgbtq friendly (in this one regard, it was a very safe space)
Dogs in office (it was somehow awful in spite of dogs everywhere)
Great location downtown
cons:
Management/Poor work distribution within teams creates incredibly toxic environment. 

You will be limited by your manager’s skills/experience. After being promoted, I was assigned to report to someone with no supervisory experience. I was given no core responsibilities, no recurring tasks, and a vague job description of about 250 words. My manager possessed little to no awareness of my day to day, my work output, or the hours that went into one-off projects I took on. When I asked for more structure/development, I was simply told it was on me to create my own opportunities and the level of structure I was seeking was beneath someone in my (almost entry level) role. My peers retained high levels of support under an actual people manager, while the momentum it took me almost 3 years to cultivate came to an abrupt halt and my career at Amazon nose dived. 

After many months of working up to 12 hours a day and on weekends (as a casual employee), trying to build a role from scratch and regain relevance to my team, my boss put me on a coaching plan for what was reluctantly alluded to as “difficulty handling role ambiguity.” Ambiguity was a strength of mine; what the plan implicitly addressed was my increasing frustration/pushback at working all hours and not receiving recognition on par with peers (I would have settled for a fraction of it).

At this point, the misery ramped up, as I was at my computer every waking moment, and there was very little left to give. My manager remained unaware of the volume or quality of the work, while continuing to assert I was underperforming (with no numbers or examples to support this). I got stress hives, migraines, panic attacks, and eventually broke down crying in-office when my boss formally documented an initiative of mine as insubordination, after he simply misremembered a conversation. My reaction to this, saying “what?!” on our internal chat, was characterized as overly aggressive. (He characterized other people as aggressive, too; it was not surprising he perceived people this way as his behavior tended to engender frustration.)

The inevitability I’d been fighting from day one came to fruition when almost everyone at my level was advanced in a sweep of restructuring, and I was informed my role “lacked scope for advancement” (an assessment made by someone who seemed to possess little knowledge of my role or how it compared to that of peers.) This all happened right after being promoted and specifically told I’d *finally* be getting the recognition and visibility I deserved. His only other direct report was similarly set up to fail. I do speculate management will decide to treat this as a coincidence and let him continue leading people’s careers down dead ends.

If you are indifferent to the work or advancing here, you may actually do great. If you are passionate about the work, it will be a struggle, as advancement, opportunity, challenges, etc., have more to do with luck than merit, and you will watch projects you are passionate about be allocated to people that don’t even want them (this pattern was by far the hardest aspect of the job).

Basically. if you don’t have an experienced manager loudly shouting about your achievements and how great you are from day one, save yourself time and pain and keep your resume up to date.
advice_management:
First of all, if the “exit interview” had been more than an e-survey with an extremely restrictive word count, I probably would not have posted this here.

Secondly, advancement at Amazon had little to do with given employees’ work or potential; it is almost entirely a reflection of a manager’s ability to manipulate a rigid, unintuitive system. It seems to take many managers over a year just to learn how the system works, as great employees are fed misleading expectations and their careers stalled. Please be more transparent and stop wasting years of people’s lives with false expectations set by inexperienced managers. Workers want to thrive; if you actually let them know how they can within your system, they will. Job responsibilities and expectations shouldn’t feel like an existential enigma.

Please provide more extensive training for new supervisors, perhaps making it clear that it is more than simply being an IC with mentees? My supervisor seemed to think his job exclusively entailed telling me to I had to create my own opportunities. He leaned heavily on the team’s people manager to execute tasks like delivering feedback (even to me), managing internal team politics, checking in on a regular basis (e.g., stopping by the room to say “hi”), driving team building, identifying professional development opportunities, etc. He seemed indignant at the notion these are things he should be involved in. There were times I literally sat in our workspace alone, while peers participated in professional development opportunities I was not looped in to because my boss didn’t seem to regard this as a piece of his role. (Sitting in that space alone,  wondering where everyone went felt just as pathetic as it sounds.)


Please make it more clear there are avenues for sending feedback for new managers that have very few direct reports. This would have been a much better experience if I hadn’t felt it was just me against a team of managers defending their own. Further, because this person was not a “full” manager, he seems to have faced no accountability for his actions with regard to this aspect of his position. During my final weeks, he was promoted as an IC in spite of his performance (or lack thereof) as a supervisor; meanwhile, his dabbling in management ended my future with the company.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Big data problems. Changes affect thousands to millions of customers. Empowers engineers to make decisions based on data and doesn't berate for the wrong decision; Allows them to correct and learn. You'll never feel stupid or unprepared. You are allowed to admit you don't know things and people will jump in to help you. They aren't a large company that "everyone is just a number". You are always treated respectfully and it's a work hard, play hard type of environment.
cons: Takes a while to onboard and learn their systems because it's a large tech landscape. It's all highly engineered and well thought out, but you'll feel stupid at first. They have lots of acronyms for everything that take a couple of months to get used to. But this isn't really a "con" because you'll be learning from the best. Check your ego at home when you start with Amazon because you're going to meet a lot of really smart people that are more than happy to help you step it up to the level of a trillion dollar company.
advice_management: I don't have any. This is a company with excellent management practices.

cons: Long hours and lazy people
advice_management: Let the PA's and the PG's a little more power, able to put associates on ToT anytime they see they are goofing around, chatting, and not working in general.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Currently ahead of the game and ahead of  many of its competitors. Wall street loves it, which makes it easier when it comes to taking risks.
cons: The company has a philosophy of treating its people as dispensable, and like stuff that rolls downhill, this goes across the board from the top all the way to the bottom. Amazon has in the past few years been making attempts to address some of its PR problems, however, the attempts are not sincere. This is not a company that realizes that its true worth comes from the people that work for them. This is a company that is obsessed about itself and its so called Leadership principles, however the company today is a faint image of its former self, given that most of the class A talent, those who joined the company when it was truly a Day One company, have left the company and moved on to better pastures. Many of the leaders that are left behind are Tier B or Tier C, especially VPs and Directors who have remained VPs and Directors 10-12 years since joining Amazon. Much of the success of the company is attributed to Jeff Bezos, however the fact remains that his wife, Mackenzie, has been very key and instrumental to making Amazon what it became, being that she paid close attention to the daily workings of the company and many of the Customer facing ideas came from her (many can and will attest to her involvement of the day to day). The current situation rips open the mystique of JeffB and lays bare the fact that he is no super human, and he owes his success to the efforts of many of those who worked for him, toiling many late hours, and didn't get to enjoy the benefits commensurate to their efforts.
advice_management:
Grow in your humility and integrity or face tough days ahead. 

Let go of the VPs who have not demonstrated value.

pros: Amazon is Customer and Associate Focused. They don't just talk the talk they walk the walk, and ask Associates their opinion. It is amazing here in Campbellsville, KY. It is a positive reflection on the personality and focus of our GM. I urge anyone who has ideas and wants to work hard to work for Amazon. There are so many learning moments here to grow from. I am an older new EHS Specialist with a recent Masters in Safety. They took me under their wing, and appreciate what I have to offer. I am honored to be a part of it. Also wonderful benefits and Management/Associate appreciation.
cons: Your experiences at Amazon are dependent on the management of the Amazon you are working at. I can only speak for SDF 1.
advice_management: Amazon across the board....continue listening to your people because we have helpful ideas. We are proud to work for Amazon.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Plenty of opportunity to fine tune your social/interpersonal skills. I have increased my knowledge substantially in using Excel and building Excel tools using macros, web scraping, etc. If you give this position all you have you can potentially change the way leaders outside of ICQA view quality inside the FC. Very big impact. Flexible schedule, great benefits.
cons: Moving up from an ICQA position is difficult. Must transfer into operations like RSP, or Outbound departments to get looked at for L4. This depends on the building you're at. You can move up from ICQA at newer buildings but for a building that's been through 3 peak season you will not be considered for any L4 roles other than support roles that are hard to come by. ICQA is no given much respect when compared to others outside the department. Rate is pushed over quality which is backwards. Understandable when meeting customer orders but quality should be taught first so the customer does not have a bad experience and to also reduce waste in the FC.
advice_management: Listen to your ICQA team, as well as give input to them. Work together with your support partners. They are here to help you.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros: Good interaction with customers and good way of learning about today’s technology incorporated with grocery stores.
cons: Fire really fast and staff is not as strong as they put out to be.
advice_management: Develop stronger values and a better team to create positivity in the work place.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: casual dress code, discounts, insurance
cons: on call 24/7, zero work life balance, managers who threaten, no Christmas vacation, situations you are not trained to deal with. As an LPM you will be on call 24/7 and expected to answer your phone and deal with endless suicidal threats you have no degree or training for, never asked your own mental status after dealing with suicidal threats for years, woken throughout the night by HR teams, maximum base salary of $69k, Amazon will include shares on your W2 even though you haven't sold them to give themselves the added advantage. No labor law training but expected to oversee protests and formed unions, associate employees are given free rain to write on a huge board at sites how they don't like certain managers and throw them under the bus, floor level employees threatening managers with violence, over 500 suicide cases inside 1 year in North America.
advice_management: Increase pay for support functions such as Loss Prevention, Loss Prevention Managers should be able to obtain L6, allow vacation at Christmas if you've worked 4 in a row.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Managers are friendly and supportive!
cons: It would be standing for so long
advice_management: Keep doing a great job

summary: "Two major pros and cons from my point of view"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Great culture, and leadership. Highest standards on future developments!
cons: Majority of teams has high operational loads!

summary: "Cross your fingers for a good manager"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Smart people. Good money. Fast paced. Many opportunities to learn.
cons: They will burn you out. If you are lucky enough to get a good manager, you will feel happy and excited while they burn you out. If you have a bad manager, you will resent it every step of the way. But burnout is a given.  A 50 hour work week is considered a minimum in many teams. And if you aren't checking your email first thing in the morning and throughout the evening, you won't be able to keep up.
advice_management: Take your diversity problem seriously. Stop blaming the "pipeline" --that is a copout. Take a look at the unconscious bias that is shot through the whole organization.

cons: The work is strenuous on the body and the management is very hounding.  They also often more than not forget to communicate with each other.
advice_management: Communicate with each other better. Often more than not request get repeated or undermined by others in charge. It becomes disjointed and it give the look of an un-unified front.

job_title: Former Employee - Virtual Customer Service Representative
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Seems like it would’ve been a fun job, decent pay for me since I was a college student.
cons: After hired I could never receive assistance. I was bounced back and forth between training classes. It got so bad that I was stuck in a limbo, and never started taking calls. Sadly, I had to quit after that.
advice_management: New method of communication, please. The supervisors either never read their emails, or have so much on their plate that sometimes important emails get buried.

summary: "The good and bad after 3 years at AWS as a SA"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
•	Starting pay was decent but low pay increases. Good bonus for first two years. Equity is great because the stock is doing so well. Fun conferences and many learning opportunities
•	The Amazon brand, saying that you worked here (it matters for some people/companies). I got an offer from Microsoft largely due to the rivalry and brand. I turned them down. I got calls from Google too which I didn’t pursue
cons:
•	Scheming culture - There are a lot of smart people, but there are also a lot of untalented schemers who get ahead by sucking up and bad mouthing others behind their back. Culture makes it very difficult to form a network. 
•	Bad middle-management - You’re working with many A-type's especially in the middle management ranks. Middle management is not transparent and always scheming. They will back stab you and throw you under the bus first chance they get, if it means saving their own skin and if you’re not part of the “in” crowd. Zero feedback or appreciation from middle management
•	Non-commission based work - Support multiple commissions based non-technical Account Managers where they make big money (via commissions) and you do the hard work and burn out
•	No teams, just groups - They try to mold you into a technical widget so you can potentially be easily replaced and the culture promotes isolation and lack of synergy, all individual contributor work. They want you to know as little as possible outside of your tunnel vision
•	Just building block services that are costly - Strong IaaS player, but bad when it comes to SaaS or PaaS models. Many new services are MVP and waiting for features of interest can be a long wait. They put a spin with low costs and utility style billing but seeing the bills of many customers are anything but cheap. AWS is always competition with everyone which creates a lack of trust, and the customers don’t always come out on top and the product is not always rock solid
advice_management:
1. Change your culture to focus on employees, don't treat them like widgets
2. Replace your middle management with people who actually like to manage
3. Reduce the levels of middle management, culture of back stabbing

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros: Good pay that's all, nothing else.
cons: Managers show favoritism  Amazon does not care about employees

summary: "Big title company. Good conditions and people."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Tech stack here covers nearly everything, you can always find the thing you like to do.
cons: There are lots of teams here, and different team is like different small company. Your experience here depends a lot on which team you are assigned to.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
I have worked for Amazon for over 4 years now and there are reasons that i have been here that long without getting a thought of leaving even once. 

1) In the first year itself i was awed by the shear intelligence of folks around. Due to the high bar of hiring, Amazon tends to hire smartest workforce and that's why i have always had learning opportunities from 360 degrees. There are people who are much junior to you and yet are smart and there are folks above you who you can learn from. Which is unique to all other employers i have had.

2) As my journey continues with Amazon i started loving the fact that promotions and raises are tightly tied to performance. Promotions are a rigorous process but if you are a good performer then all falls in place for you. Politics does not play in, the processes and mechanisms in place ensure that the deserving folks get to the next level. The icing on the cake in there in no time in role requirement to get to next level. If you can perform at next level, you will get there.

3) Last and most important reason that i have started appreciating in last couple of years is that the yearly planning process in bottoms up. I most companies the goals are decided up top and then they flow down. Not true here ! At Amazon, each teach team decides its own fates and proposes what great things it will do next year and then that planning process flows upwards. Which gives tech teams autonomy to do stuff which makes it super unique.
cons: The first year at Amazon can be difficult sometimes. Mostly with the fact that it has a unique culture of rigor as well as people being brutally honest. If you put together a poor quality doc (no presentations at amazon) for a review, you will be told that in the meeting. If you cant deal with it (which is difficult at start) then you will have issues. The best way to deal with this is to first get a mentor who can help you see through these situations. Next try to imbibe the Amazon leadership principles, they are amazing and if you see things through the lens of these principles then you will understand why people behave in the way they do.

summary: "So many pluses, but one big minus"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: There are many positives about working at Amazon. You can go in many directions once you get into the company. There is a great hiring process, which means that the talent and personality of the average employee is very high.
cons: Management is not a talent or skill that is encouraged or required. It is a job duty assigned to high performers. It makes career development tough, unless you are in a very technical position.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: 100% employee engagement and focused on the associates. Everyone bottom up is 100% customer focused and engaged in continuous improvement to remove waste. Beyond World Class EHS environment. Expanding international presence.
cons: Long Hours, duplicating of reporting, inexperienced manager's that don't understand labor tracking, activity based costing, and encouragement of inflating productivity, then being promoted. Overtime this will become company culture and we all know Enron and the other examples.
advice_management: Continue to develop the younger managers and instill the culture of winning right.

summary: "They're not the biggest company for no reason"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Great benefits packages, base pay and 401K options.
Relaxed environment
cons:
Communication between corporate and retail teams has always needed a saving grace.
Changes done in the middle of the day and expected to be executed with little to no communication of the change.

summary: "HR is unorganised... Take your cases to the higher-ups."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
Cafeteria with food
A lot of people to talk to
Very down to earth
Coaches you, no discipline (only if you screw something royal)
cons:
HR throws you around a lot if you have a medical problem
A lot of people
Food isn’t free
If you
advice_management: If people cannot physically carry out a task, assign them to another place to work at!

summary: "It’s not as cool as it seems DONT WORK HERE"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The pay is decent, you don’t have to worry about hours, and the lack of human contact is a plus for antisocial people
cons:
The routes are the worst. Depending on where you work at, for me they had me going up into the mountains where you would think there are no houses at. 

You’re expected to fit a huge van into many narrow roads

Don’t plan on ending your shift on time. You will most likely always do overtime. 12 hour days are more common than not.

Good luck finding a bathroom near your route. The company urges drivers to find one instead of peeing in a can like I’ve had to do on several occasions. Finding a bathroom will but you so far behind schedule that it’s not worth it.

The device they give you to confirm deliveries always runs out of signal and will put you behind schedule.

Even when you finish your deliveries for the day, prepare to spend another hour debriefing at the warehouse. Whoever is at the desk will most likely be mean and give you a hard time if you have UTA’s 

Mentally prepare yourself when delivering to a business or apartment. It can take an hour sometimes to find the drop off points
advice_management: Don’t force overtime on your employees.

pros:
The pay is good for the work.
Most people will help you if you are visibly struggling.
Most of the supervisors were friendly.
There is always overtime opportunities and sometimes chances to leave early if you want.
They often have prize giveaways and incentives.
cons:
- Working in there with no music feels like absolute DEATH.
-The floor feels awful on your feet - get comfy shoes.
-The break starts from the moment you punch out, and you spend half of the quick breaking walking to and from your station.
Overall, the job is mentally draining for a person that hates silence (except for Machines 247), and doesn't like working independently for too long.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros: The pay is always good and they give out incentives sometimes.
cons: You can work 10-12 hours a day. Sometimes you barely have work to do. They will lay you off unexpectedly after saying they may hire you. Don't look forward to being hired in unless you go directly through the company.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Amazon has a fair compensation policy (expect a a cliff at year 4) and the company culture is treated seriously throughout the company.
cons: The company has become extremely top-down and process heavy across the board. Very hard to get anything done with the amount of red tape and politics in place. Your success largely depends on the impact of the projects you'll be able to deliver, which is good in theory, except that the ability to grab high-impact project is out of your control. Deadlines are top-down and will drive you to the ground.

summary: "Best Job I've ever had / Company I've ever worked for!"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: You constantly push your limits at AWS - Always evolving in your knowledge and skills, everyone is SUPER-SMART and super-intelligent - Very high bar to get hired! But once you are in, you will up-your-game in terms of your skillset, FAST. It's a challenge for sure, but one that offers so many benefits. The corporate culture, driven by our Leadership Principles, is amazing....the LPs may sound silly from an outsider perspective, but once you are in Amazon and see them in practice, they make sense, and they really DO work and provide the principles by-which we all live by @ Amazon.
cons: The amount of work/effort here can be significant; however, it's one's own job to manage their own schedule/workload to maintain work/life balance!  Also there is a significant amount of writing, as we have a very writing-based culture @ Amazon, so if you don't like writing, this can be a perceived con. There is a strong purpose behind the narrative writing; however. Just google it.
advice_management: Keep up the bar raised on hiring Amazonians, as we continue to grow!

cons: As a part-time associate, you do not accrue ATO or PTO. They only give out 20 hours every 3 months which amounts to about 5 shifts. This isn’t flexible if you’re a student. They will not work with you if you’re involved in stuff on campus. HR is terrible.
advice_management: Hire better HR. Implement better flexibilities for students

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year

cons:
* Paid vacation/public holidays aren't great compared to other tech companies
* There seems to be a lack of training with some managers in regards to FMLA and their obligations. Big disparity between teams how they handle this stuff.
advice_management: Better training for managers with regards to their obligations.

summary: "Job experience depends on who you work with"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Pros:  competitive pay, amazing benefits, access to Amazon buildings. (if you're a student great place to study). Good if you like a good stable job that requires absolutely  no critical thinking or creativity (all of that is done for you through standard procedures)
cons: con:  No opportunity for upward mobility, you are being watched constantly,  every mistake you make the managers will know cause you are tracked via the scanners.  You are the Hufflepuff of Amazon divisions.  Repetitive tasks, they time all your breaks, (this is understandable when the store is busy and low staffed, but even if the store is empty as hell and they will still time you lol). If the store is not busy and they don't need you they will offer "voluntary time off" because legally they can't send you home if you are scheduled for a shift. without at least 2 hours of pay. If they offer you "voluntary time off" and you don't take it they will literally try to bore you to death until you want to go home.
advice_management:
Try and be more flexible, as long as your team is meeting the organizational goals be a bit more relaxed and loosen up on your workers. I know the procedures are there for a reason but know when to implement them.  Ever wonder why your employees rarely last more than a year?  It's so much cheaper and more efficient to keep an existing employee than to constantly hire new ones. The value that each employee adds to your store only increases the longer they've been working there.  If this continues, all you'll be left with is the worst of the worst who 

1. Aren't skilled enough to find a better job 
2. Never question anything they're told to do or why they do it ( these workers value increases at extremely low rates)

This will result in employees who lack the following Amazon principles:
Ownership
Invent and Simplify
Are Right, A Lot
Hire and Develop the Best
Think Big
Have Backbone; Disagree and Commit

summary: "Take a close look at the positive reviews."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: benefits are the only good thing.
cons: A large corporation that pretends to care about its employees.   Compensation does not equal amount of work required.  All of the positive reviews are from people who have been there for less than a year. Hang in for two years and then we can talk.
advice_management: Management wouldn’t listen anyway...

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Good pay, ok benefits, paid parental leave, stock which you most likely won't see it all.
cons: Most managers do not last over a year. Rotating door on Management. They are able to recruit because of their high salary and sign on bonus. Its a trap. If you leave before the agreed time you pay it back, if you make it a year and have already reloed it will take two years to pay that back. Rsu's are great if you make it. Its 4 years for full vest. 1st year taxes will eat ur shares. 2nd year if you make it makes it more worth it. If theres a 3rd year you will be on the gravy train for a while. Connections questions where mgmt is rated by Assoc is a joke and quick way to get fired if you don't accommodate you assoc. The senior mgmt does not know what they are doing and reacts to every fire and will take an associates word before a managers. There is no support. If you do work there get your money and get out. You will not have a family life there.
advice_management: Advice to senior mgmt support your managers and treat them well. They are on your team.

job_title: Former Employee - Customer Service Agent (Work From Home)
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros: The hourly wage went up to offset the negative news around the CEO, but before the negative the benefits have and remain to be great.
cons: For IT company, they have the worst search engine. For example, if you try to look up the company's phone number in their KC(internal database of all their policies), logically you would think they would have "company phone number" as a keyword, when you type that, you get no result; instead the keyword is "phase phone".   When you have to resolve a call quickly, and obvious keywords dont help; it is frustrating. If you contact a Supervisor for quick help (because all keywords you type in KC dont help), Amazon counts that against you.  Amazon has so many departments to transfer customers to, but every other week the name of the department changes (of course, the new name of the department may takes weeks or months before it appears in KC, so you have to call around, which prolongs customers' wait time). Their policies on how to resolve a particular problem are deliberately ambiguous so that they can use it against you, when doing performance review. The mainframe you use to resolve customers issues (returns/refund/payments/ a-to-z claims) changes so often without any regards on how it may affect agents efficiency on a call; worst of all no updates to notify you that that something you use to see for many years, now as a different abbreviated name and steps to resolve.  Now that the company raised the minimum wage to 15, they are using all of these ambiguities in their system and policies to get rid of agents (which means the really could not afford to raise wages, but by doing that they win favors with many people and few people will focus on the fact that they only raised the wage to protect the company's image from the divorce and mistress scandal). Oh, I forget, I cant remember the number of software and processes and change in teams I have experiences in one year; every new software has a life span of a few months and then you have to learn new one for reason that should I have been thought out well in advance during the UX development phase.
advice_management: Hire people who have direct experience in the line of work their staff is doing.   Many Managers have the mentality of a brick and mortar Manager; with most issues that need to be managed being technical issues (people with soft skills and little technical skills should be expected to have real technical skills to able to report confidently most of your internal technical issues that agents face a lot while trying to serve customers). It is not sensible for a Manager to write up their staff for technical issues that they could avoid by looking at their data reports  and by doing real data analytical work. Managers with no real technical and direct job related knowledge are obviously forced to blame their employee for problems they cant solve.  Getting rid of an employee for their poor ability to do their end of their job only helps the Manager to keep their job longer at the expense of the employee. If you are going to let Managers be in their position (simply because you like them ) then the data they use to evaluate employees should be made available to the employee so that they can manage or help themselves.  When the technical tools (only they can see and manipulate to their favor) they misinterpret affect the agents, then you are creating a  work culture that values keeping and promoting employees because you like them, not because they are hardworking.

summary: "Adaptability Required! If you can build culture and create"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: You create your own culture with your team, while having the ability to enhance processes that drive your department and building's performance. Compensation from an external hire is enough to take your mind off pay to focus on performing at a high level. Work life balance is great! I work 4 days 12 hours. In previous jobs I worked the same daily hours with a 5th or 6th day and calls after I got off work.
cons: As I have read there are many people with a focus on themselves and their own agenda.  So yes there are issues with the culture as a whole. However, as a leader you can set the culture in your own department and shape how your peers and senior leaders interact with you. Culture is everyone's responsibility. 401k is not good, 1/2% match up to 4% for a max of 2%.
advice_management: With every interaction with senior leadership culture and safety seem to be the priority. Keep pushing and hiring those leaders that care about development and people. The change will happen.

summary: "Would not recommend for anyone outside the Intern program"
job_title: Current Employee - Amazon Finance Rotation Program Financial Analyst
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
-Potential for a lot of learning experiences... but only if you have a good manager
-Ability to create a large network
-There's dogs sometimes
cons:
-Previous interns get a $5k larger bonus than those who are not even if they have way less experience
-No real analytical work in rotations, just a quick burnout session
-Most managers in the rotations are not helpful in developing you
-Only a handful of people who are not previous interns and very few AFRP events throughout the year to get to know people from each class
-Some rotations expect you to work nights and weekends
-No snacks in the shared kitchens (I didn't realize how much I'd miss these)
-Amazon culture is quite an adjustment for anyone coming from an outside company... frugal to a fault
advice_management:
-Consideration for the very few non-returning interns with previous fortune-500 experience
-Try to get managers to give some interesting analytical work rather than having AFRP just automating monotonous processes and writing SQL codes
-More events to meet AFRP from all classes

summary: "Learning and building cool things are part of the job!"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Most companies hire people for what they already know and you need to deliver results quickly. At AWS, they hire you if they believe that you can learn and they give you time to learn and build whatever you like on their platform. When you are ready to work with the customers,  a big part of the job is continue to learn new things.
cons: First couple of months is like drinking from a firehose. But it gets better.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: If you have ownership, bias for action and deliver results - you will find Amazon to be a fast-paced and rewarding place. Read the Leadership principles and see how you hold up. In general, they reward people for their effort and hard work and politics is usually not as toxic as some of the other companies.
cons: The benefits are good but not top of the line as compared to other big companies like Google. Amazon also has bad pockets like any other company. So if you land in a personal situation that requires Work-Life balance for a longer time, sometimes the best option is Leave Of Absence. Empathy is very much team specific and not supported well at the company level. The dreaded stack curve can often trip up people and lead to an unpleasant situation. Also, some groups like Twitch or SFO teams have better benefits like free lunches or breakfast unlike most Seattle teams. People find it easier to jump companies and boomerang rather than being incentivized to stay and get promoted within especially as they get closer to the higher level.
advice_management: Replace Stack Curve with Financial curve and provide better benefits compared to other companies.

pros: 1) Physically demanding job is a good workout and I've lost a pant size in the first few months (while craving & eating carbs and ice cream to boot!) 2) Rules are fairly easy to follow so I feel like I've done a good job most of the time.  3) There are so many people on a shift that I find the hard working people, like me, and ignore the other, lazier, ones. 4) Some managers are really good at telling us we've done a good job, or saying thank you which keeps me motivated.
cons: Management styles vary and some are rather untrained so that it hurts to be in their area for a shift. Some just deliver general yelling of commands like we are a bunch of dumb cattle or bad children who need to be scolded. I don't perform well when being belittled.
advice_management: Think about how you like to be treated and give us your best side. Eye contact is important for good communication. Explanations go a long way - why something should be done a certain way rather than 'just do it'.)

summary: "Senior Leaders Lack Integrity and other Tangibles"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Pay. Company name attracts interest of other  potential employers.
cons: Money not worth the treatment.  Senior level managers make approvals and fire the same people approvals made for. Sounds like a set up. Regional managers clean house to bring in nobodies. Integrity, leadership, honor are laughable at best.  1 for 14 on leadership principles.  Good at telling managers disagree and commit. Concerns never addressed.  First line management (your ASSET MANAGER) turnover is embarrassing and no surprise. It's a joke amongst associates because as soon as they find out their managers name it's already changing.  Onboarding associates is like an assembly line of countless people every week.  Temps not treated with dignity. Considered expendable and not worth investment.
advice_management: Senior leaders need to deep dive definitions of the leadership principles and develop their own IDPs around each one. Be sure to use SMART goals.  This includes ops mgrs, sr ops, multi site leaders, and all support leaders of site and at HQ. Don't just demand obedience and trust.  Earn what you expect and show what good looks like. Senior leaders are out of touch.  You don't know everything in operations anymore.  Stop pretending you do and leverage knowledge from your boots in the ground.  If you make a mistake, take ownership.  Excuses and blame are not ownership.

advice_management: Explain total compensation better. Compensation has changed drastically over 6 years. Whereas I used to expect stock in fair increments, stock compensation has drastically dropped off since the price has increased.

summary: "Interviewing or got an offer? Think through what you truely want before joining"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
- Big name in the industry
- Learning the peculiar Amazon way of execution
cons:
READ the New York Times article before joining, google: "Inside Amazon: Wrestling Big Ideas in a Bruising Workplace"

- Likely to get to work on areas that are 1 inch wide and a mile deep - thinking about your impact on the product and ask yourself, is that the way you'd like to grow in your career?

- Lots of mid-level managers that abuses the power to keep themselves afloat (unfortunately an issue not getting enough attention from the high-level managers and since the turn over rate is so high, there won't be a shortage of applicants, so your feedback are likely to get ignored as a new hire)

- A grinding place: systematic overuse of new hires, it's team dependent, but your likelihood to get burn out is much higher than the other tire one tech companies

- Definitely not a company culture that encourages interpersonal communications (to run the scale Amazon has, the company prioritizes process, guidelines, and documentation over human connections - ask yourself is that the way you like to work?)

- Most people just think about themselves and how to climb up the career ladder, as the turn over rate is so high, no one really cares to have long-term thinking  for your career or the product 

- The review system is corrupted: People learn how to game the system and sometimes even use it to bring down their peers or go up

 - You will get to work on products with lots of traffic, but many of which will have no visibility to end users (if you cares about this)

- If you enjoy working with people that have a true appreciation of user experience and design, this is not the place for you, although you will learn a good deal of business execution
advice_management: Limit the power of mid-level managers, who abuses them for self-interest

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros:
A place to belong,  and be yourself .
The benefits are awesome, for part time, and full time. The best in the country. Eligibility is quick, and very rewarding. 
Leadership is supportive, nurturing, focused, driven,  and intelligent. The Trainers, Learning, Ambassadors,  Ops, HR, Safety, the Yard, Facilities,  Security,  Logistics, all of the departments , are all mentors to us, and we support each other 100%.
Teamwork makes the Dreams work. 
Amazon.com gives you all the tools you need to move up, and elevate. You have to want to, and work hard. It's all right there for us.
Amazon helps pay for our school and training, highest company pay support,  that I have personally ever had. That rocks!
Great friendships, and supportive relationships. Great place to work, and excel.
Team atmosphere, we take ownership.
A place where being different, is 100% accepted, and nurtured, and you can thrive .
The open door policy, is not like anything  that I gave seen in Business. They mean every word. If you have a problem, you can go speak with any leader,  on the floor, or in the offices.  I was impressed by this. 
 They mean what they say.
They take the time to address our issues, mentor us, and support your growth in the company.  

I could go on all day, I  love my job, where I work,  and the people I work with. 
I am an Amazonian.💖
cons:
The only I thing that I see that some people might notice , is when they are new, is the size of the staff , especially at Peak Season. Me personality, I thrive there. Like a flower growing everyday, I found my place.
 I feel at home for the first time in many, years. I was welcomed from day one. Awesome mentors, in every department in the building.
Jeff Basos is a brilliant, CEO.  I love watching his videos online, and reading about him.
My dream is to go to Seattle, and meet him, and see the original place it started. The original building, and the garage, that Mr. Basos started his book delivery. I also want to see the Seattle offices. You can have dogs and cats there. That is so cool!
I aspire to relocate to Seattle, someday, as a  future plan, when I am older. 😁
advice_management:
Keep doing what we are doing at  Amazon.com. I have no complaints. I am loyal to them, and thankful for all of them . That loyalty is reciprocated back to their Associates, and it's real.
Let's keep growing, and making history! 
Boss 5!

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Safety and Work/Home balance is a priority.  Benefits are generous even for PT employees from day one which together with starting pay kept me there until I reached FT promotion.  Getting time off for family reasons and medical is generally easy to get approved. As long as you demand the best from yourself you are treated great and rewarded for such.  Generally, advancements are hired from within so iif you are driven, then the skies the limit for upward mobility.
cons: You don't need to have lazy days.  They are not tolerated so stay home if you can't perform to excellent par which is not so difficult if you have a strong personal work ethic.  Generally you have to learn specifics of how to be successful from other experienced employees as there is a very short learning curve and management themselves don't generally take the time to provide the personal individual training you need at the beginning due to the large number of employees.  So don't be afraid to ask for help from your team coworkers.  They will help you as you depend on each other.
advice_management: Find a way to have time for more personal training at the very start.

pros: Benefits, pay, schedule is good
cons: Not really a challenge for an EHS professional

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
- Huge company with a ton of different opportunities across the world, in any position you are interested in.
- Process Assistant role in particular is an excellent opportunity for building leadership and management experience.
- Very open-ended roles with lots of individual flexibility in driving your own success. Large departments have a variety of processes, goals, and the people to achieve them. As a PA, it's largely up to you to decide how to utilize your resources through your associates to achieve your department's goals.
- Strong employee support from management and HR. Majority of managers are highly skilled, extremely focused on employee support and development, and strongly motivated for the success of the team.
- Constantly exciting and ever changing situations and goals. No end to the creative and organizational potential for those willing to build off of it.
- As a PA, you are the most immediate (indirect) supervisor and face of leadership for the vast majority of employees. Majority of your day is working with associates and solving their problems. Extremely good role for anybody who likes helping people. Many of the tier I associates are unskilled, and it is exciting to develop your associates into their potential.
- Decent pay and benefits for an entry-level leadership role. Lots of potential for overtime if you are physically up for it (see cons).
cons:
- Easy to move up from Tier 1 to Tier III for anyone with professionalism and work ethic. Far more challenging to move from Tier III to Tier IV, requiring years of experience and a proven track record of being above and beyond as a tier III.
- Use of broad "tiers" for a number of different jobs considered on the same level reduces wages and opportunities to move up past tier III.
- Heavily chaotic, not particularly well-organized warehouses. Lack of consistent direction and a lot of wasted effort, resources. Good opportunity to excel and get noticed as a Process Assistant is building processes to make order of the chaos; however, clear organization is not the norm and you may encounter significant pushback.
- Physically demanding - 10-12 hour days on your feet with continuous need to be present across a large department or the entire warehouse.  Occasional mandatory overtime leading to 50-60 hour weeks during peak times.
advice_management: Prioritize the processes needed to achieve clear organization and communication with the team. This is a small investment in time for large rewards in reduced labor and materials costs.

summary: "Great place to learn, churn n burn culture in finance"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
- super smart people, the best of the best from schools
- if you get hired here, you will be hirable anywhere, recruiting process is tough
- the pay is above average, probably 1.5 times elsewhere (but the expected results are 150% of elsewhere too)
- lots of opportunities to work on new, innovative projects
- cool SLU campus, lots of options for food and drinks after work
cons:
- frugality is taken to the extreme, only 2 weeks vacation, parking takes a year or more to get, zero perks (not even free Prime), no fitness allowance, poor 401k
- your peers will stab you in the back, your manager will blame you for their errors, you can't trust anyone
- people who throw others under the bus and take credit for other people's work get promoted
- expectations 60 -70 hours a week, some teams expect Sunday to be an "in the office day", headcount never gets filled, teams are always short a few people but the work keeps piling on.
advice_management: The culture and reputation of amazon will never change unless you want it to and set the tone from the top. Try using some customer obsession with employees- as management, employees are YOUR customers.  Making great products or margins is fine, but if you have a reputation/brand for treating people awful, then are you really a success?  Also, there is visible lack of women or minorities in any leadership role compared to pretty much every other large company in Seattle. Seems like you have to try really hard in a city as diverse as this to be so undiverse.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros: There was always room for advancement if you're a go getter, there was always extra hours to pickup, and I truly enjoyed the people that I worked with.
cons: As a blue badge if you go over the allotted time you're able to miss even if you have a doctor's note it's automatic termination. I lost my job because of this. I took a serious fall outside of work and was seen at the ER, I was told not to return to work before a certain time and I had doctor's notification but Amazon was not hearing that! I was immediately terminated and locked out of the employee portal.
advice_management: I would say that management wasn't the issue. HR was the issue and they need to understand that life happens, there should be some concessions given certain situations.

summary: "Great place to work if your not a minority"

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Pay is good. Fellow Associates are cool. Paid and unpaid time off options
cons: For what we do and how much we do, we are underpaid compared to other warehouses in the area, plus no recognition. Other warehouses start off at 19.50 while amazon starts off at 15.40. There is a lot of mixed signals in the management and everyone is definitely not on the same page. VERY hard to get higher up in the company unless you have a degree, which automatically puts you into salaried pay with CRAZY hours. If youve heard the rumors about people being treated like numbers youve heard right. So much for "Work Hard, Have Fun, Make History".
advice_management: Stop treating people like numbers and start treating the people who make the company work like actual people. PLAIN AND SIMPLE.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
-Part time shifts were only 3- 5 hours long
-health benefits after about 6 months of employment
-lenient attendance policy
-$15/ hr starting pay
-seasonal opportunities for those only interested in a part time job for the holidays 
-safety was emphasized as the number one priority at the facility I worked at, so I felt much more comfortable with the work environment
cons:
-sometimes really stressful when there was a high volume of packages to sort
-sometimes VERY physically demanding (but it's an enjoyable challenge for those who like fitness stuff, i.e. me)
-sometimes the work itself was a bit too repetitive and dull; this made me feel like I was losing brain cells and my sanity.
-if you don't have a bachelor's degree, there isn't much room for advancement, unless you have 2 years of Amazon experience. 
-Having to take the shuttle was definitely a drawback. You had to park at a separate location and take a shuttle bus to the actual facility where you work. If you missed the shuttle to or from the facility, you'd have to wait for another one, and sometimes you could get stuck waiting outside in harsh weather conditions. I got stuck waiting outside in the dark a couple times, and it was windy and cold :/ Definitely remember to keep an umbrella in your car.
advice_management: The whole management team at ACY5 was full of amazing people. A+++

summary: "Now I know: The best man for the job is a woman."
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
Easy hiring process. Almost everything is done online. Admire the women that do the same work as the men. I felt sorry for the Managers, they were nice and only doing what their computer told them to do. They pay you overtime, the time it takes to walk to the time clock from your station at the end of your shift. When you are new they will ask you how you like it, and not get on you about productivity.  Free  coffee and hot chocolate. Unlimited gloves. Free computers to
use at break. Video games in the break room. Free parking. Personal locker with lock. Chairs to sit in during break and lunch. Onsite human resources for any concerns. No need to carry electronics of any kind inside the warehouse. Cool robots working like slaves. Smoking allowed inside the smoke room. Weekly pay at my site. Extra pay for working nights. Get paid to exercise and lose weight.
cons: You will feel like a 2nd class citizen from day 1 because you are a "white" badge. Back breaking work lifting and moving heavy boxes continuously for your whole shift. It was called building pallets. Put boxes on pallets so that they can be shipped to their next destination.  It felt eerily like the book "1984", you are constantly being monitored and surveyed. The scanner would ask "Is your manager focused on safety?" And then you are suppose to pick an answer. It felt like being in a prison. the buzzer tells you when it's time for break or lunch or end of shift. It would take me exactly 7 minutes to walk to the time clock. I would not do this job if it paid $20 per hr. Some coworkers would just do the easy work, scan the smallest boxes, throw boxes onto the pallets, not take time to close out the pallets because they only care about their rate. (No. of boxes scanned per hr). At manual pallets everyone could work at any conveyor so no one had any accountability if the pallets were organized, lopsided or who is scanning the huge boxes. After 2 days of training you are on your own to figure it out. I quit after my 1st real day. I would have quit before then but the women I went through training with had toughed it out. I almost felt guilty until I remembered that I hired on at will which means they can fire me at will, and I can quit at will. I suspect that the ibuprofen in the machines at amazon are just sugar pills.
advice_management: They are already aware of what is going on, constantly get new people in and get out the tired ones. What they might not be aware of is that these workers are also consumers. I have been an amazon customer since 2003. I am canceling amazon prime and will probably never order anything again. Not everyone who gets a job at amazon is desperate and poor. I have been with my government job for 29 yrs. I feel for the poor souls that have no choice and work their fingers to the bone and hope that they will eventually move up to a better job but in the end will probably be fired because they aren't productive enough. Thank you for the cool orange vest and clear lunch bag and the 1 glove that I brought home.

job_title: Current Employee - Part Time Package Handler

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: The job itself is not bad if you're capable of learning and adapting to change. I enjoyed having a team and PA's that respected, supported, and worked hard for me. Definitely an experience to be thrown in the fire by inheriting the worst team in the building and having the privilege of witnessing their growth into one of the best teams. I did everything I could to treat them well despite the work environment and iniquitous culture. In addition, you'll be stepping into a role with tremendous responsibility and actually learn a few things such as your level of patience and the type of person you really are. I had so "many" good things to say about this company that I forgot to mention the decent pay + bonuses and advancement opportunities.
cons:
Let's start off with what I have NEVER experienced with any company. 

- NEVER have I seen a group of AM's that are friends try to tear each other's heads off and point fingers for their team's poor performance with Ops Managers just watching.
- NEVER have I met leaders that deliberately try to humiliate and yell at you in front of everyone just because they can. Seriously, is that your method of teaching and being a role model? 
- NEVER have I been directed by the senior team to write my associates up for random bs just because they're having a bad day performance wise. 
- NEVER have I worked at a place that allows you to chew and spit tobacco while on the floor.
- NEVER have I worked for a company where power is abused and you can literally be blamed for anything and everything that you have no control over. 
- NEVER have I met so many freaking 2 faced individuals. Act like your best friend one minute because they needed help with something and then turn around and throw you under the bus.
- NEVER have I witnessed so much bullying. Racist comments, lets see who's bigger and badder, make girls and even some guys cry because. . . well you ain't ever gonna learn if I don't sh*t on you. 

You get the point. Come work for Amazon! I've never worked somewhere so toxic. You'll work 12-13 hours everyday (more if you're not up to par), not eat or drink anything for 10 hours just to end your day by getting treated like dog sh- feces. I've stayed there for almost a year (only stayed that long because of my team) when the average tenure is about 6 months. The leadership principles, the values, the culture - all of it is a bunch of crap. You can recite the bs but what are they if they're just words and you hire incompetent people that can't comprehend it? 

I'm sure you've already read up on articles about Amazon and everyone already knows the truth. You'd hear the typical excuse, "It'S a PArt Of THe GrOwtH".
advice_management: One word. Integrity. Read it, learn it, live by it.

summary: "Hard work is expected from everyone and is the culture at Amazon."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Benefits.  Culture, Learning, Opportunity is plentiful if you have what it takes.
Others in leadership roles working together to develop and hire the best.

As in any ORG, everyone has a specific skill-set.  Many in the same roles rely on one another to hold the team to the expected standard.  If you are petty, gossip or complain you should work elsewhere.  

In working in several buildings, there is always plenty to improve upon is often welcomed by Sr. Leadership to invoke change.

HR purposely assigns people of different personalities in roles to keep things in check.  This upsets those who like to create "clickish" groups but prevents issues.

Promotions and Inclines are given to those of us who have performed and able to raise the bar.

Buildings are secure and for the most part clean.

I started on the floor as a part time employee and quickly have risen to leadership based on my hard work.  2 years later in my role I am respected by my peers and Sr leadership.
cons:
Constant change due to explosive growth, not a bad thing but you must be prepared to accept the challenges presented.   

Parking at many buildings are a premium.  Be prepared to walk to your assignment.

If you expect to just come in do nothing just to collect your earnings this is not the place.  

Jealousy by those who cannot meet the highest standards and try to inject discord or fabricate and gossip.  Thankfully, in my region It is quickly quashed and uprooted.
advice_management: When rolling out new policy add it to the wiki.  Have process in place and training in the role and re-train.

summary: "Favoritism abounds but hours and chances for advancement are lacking"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: None that I can think of.
cons:
Working at the Chesapeake location was okay during the holidays, since we were able to work any hours needed to get by (what with Peak season); but after the holidays we were constantly flexing down, the amount of routes lessened, and the people starting early everyday cut into the other associates' time/money. Also, a good portion of the remaining associates are still considered seasonal with no benefits, and management continuously dodges our questions about conversion.

Management honestly doesn't care about employees (other than their favorites, who always get put into the more substantial positions in the warehouse); and if any issues come up, they'll just punish without even looking at evidence/one of the many cameras in the warehouse beforehand. BUT when they want to congratulate themselves on jobs well done or promotions, they won't hesitate (there's seriously a row of Hollywood-esque stars on the floor leading towards the stand-up area with all their names and positions).

summary: "Opportunity to have impact; a little loose on structure"
job_title: Current Employee - Principal Technical Product Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Tons of smart people. You'll never be the smartest person in the room.
Company is focused on the long-term, willing to invest strategically.
Company is introspective and always trying to improve the employee experience. There were some changes made to the annual review process after the NYT article, which have mostly been positive. 
Growing fast, and in so many lines of business that there are lots of internal opportunities to move around if you want a change.
cons: Still growing fast, which means growing pains, and frequent reorganizations and changes as old approaches stop scaling. Can be a very ambiguous environment. You must be adaptable and willing to change course frequently to avoid going crazy.
advice_management: Despite efforts to make the promotion process more fair and transparent, it is still pretty heavy-weight in many cases, particularly for the higher levels and for non-tech roles. People still feel it's sometimes easier to leave and come back at a higher level than to get promoted internally. Recommend increased focus on making these processes lighter weight.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: pays well at 15 an hour
cons: working at amazon was literally such a nightmare i hated every second of it. the staff was so rude i could not believe it.. anyone who tells you differently is lying. the only positive is that it is $15/hr but the management expects so much from you and act like they are way above you. i went to the bathroom one time and got docked an entire point for not being at my place of work.. like are we not allowed to have a stomach ache without getting in trouble? i was shocked. also i had a creepy man follow me around every time i was at work and followed me into my car and when i told HR they did nothing about it. the HR is really horrible there and were so behind on emails and didn't ever respond. it was really embarrassing on their part. im not even venting on here i just need people to know that the management is horrible and they expect so much out of you and the BEST you will get is maybe a high five. it's horrible and i was ecstatic to quit. please do not waste your time here. i became so depressed working as an associate. would never recommend this to anyone.
advice_management: be nicer ! waaaay nicer to your employees and look around at who is doing a good job and congratulate them on a job well done.. instead of belitting everyone and acting so entitled. the girls who work there are so mean it makes me really sad.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
I have just finished a year of working at Amazon, and been loving it. I'm constantly motivated being surrounded by smart engineers and managers.
 What i really like is how the leadership principles are applied by teams in design/code reviews. I can see how working here can help driving oneself to become a great leader. 

Learning new skills and technology is up to you. There is lot of resources and materials.

WFH is not questioned thus allowing employee flexibility.
cons: At times, i can sense people tend to align work based on promotion.
advice_management:
Great job on resonating the leadership principles.
Compensation is not bad at all, but they should match the likes of Google/Facebook as it sad to see some peers leave for higher pay.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year

cons: Culture can be better. If you’re liked, you’re “in there”. If you’re hated, you’re better off quitting before they find a reason to fire you.
advice_management: Don’t put numbers above the well-being of your associates.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
-benefits
-pay (to some point)
-opportunities
- some managers are ok
cons:
- hard work
-'f' word - favoritism
- internal promotions are half the pay what external are getting.  

I started work at Amazon because for some reason I thought that it would help me later when I get my MBA. It turned out that, when you already are blue badge employee you can't get an internship (bc you already work for the company) also, when you get promoted to Manager Level 4 as internal you will get at least $30.000 less than external employers and  guess what? you will have to work as hard and sometimes externals people can start as Level 5 or 6. When you are internal employee and you can't skip levels so you have to be 4 then 5 in order to be in few years level 6.
advice_management: People who start as Tier 1 and want to grow with the company should be valued much more than random people who know nothing about work at Amazon. This does not rally show that you care about your employees. Some people quit to be re-hired 3 months later to get external employee money.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
- unique in how they approach technology
- incredibly fast pace
- work with smart and driven people
- a sense of belonging in the "Amazon Culture"
- everyone genuinely follows the leadership principles
cons:
- the chaos can lead to feeling like you work for yourself with little to no support
- they encourage you to put in your all; no one will stop you from burning out
- restructuring can come without warning
- promotion process is doable but hard
- recent "human rights" issues leave a bad taste in my mouth
- revolving door of employees (the Amazon "MBA")
advice_management: Professional Services is currently going through a ton of changes, some good and some bad, especially in management. This can leave the technical consultants feeling unsupported and like the product more than employees.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Really easy to get hired. Instant benefits are amazeballs! There is a lot of incentive to work here in terms of health care benefits, tuition assistance, bonuses after X amount of years, etc... And starting at $15/hr for warehouse work is nice.
cons:
You'll work 10 hour shifts at the same station doing the same thing. You cannot listen to music.  
They allow two 15 minute breaks but the building is so massive it can take you over 5 minutes just to get from your station to your locker/break room. 
My manager was too strict. I was constantly performing 2.5 times better than what was expected of me but if he saw me chatting with the person stationed next to me he'd come tell me that wasn't helping my performance. He even told me I wasn't holding my stretches long enough once ... Gimme a break, dude.
advice_management:
If an employee is exceeding expectations, get off their back. 
Consider training all employees in two fields more consistently and switching the employees work task after lunch to avoid over use injuries and mental fatigue.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros: Finally, make a decent wage $15 / hour is decent! Some of the management is open to feedback.
cons: I started in 2017 as a Flex PT Employee.  My hours change every 3 weeks based on business need.  We average 20-28 hrs/week.  During peak season (Nov - First part of Jan) we work full time or more hours in a week.  July we work 30-40 hrs per week for about 2 weeks for Prime Day.  Because we flex our schedule I thought it was great they gave us medical benefits.  I qualified for Medicaid and stayed on it.  So now it's 2019 and I don't qualify for Medicaid due to the pay increase and now Amazon is not offering us benefits for medical and prescription.  Not sure what I'm going to do.
advice_management: Offer all of your employees benefits.  PT Flex employees change their schedule every 3 weeks to meet BUSINESS NEED and we don't get medical benefits?  That's not right.

summary: "Growing Company. Lots of Opportunity. Won’t “hold your hand”. Not for those who value free time"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Challenging work. Every day you are challenged to do better than the day before. Opportunity for advancement if you are willing to put the work in both on the job and from home. Company is growing at a rapid pace and if you are flexible with relocation, the sky is the limit for how far you can go
cons: Don’t kid yourself. You will do something work related every day to keep up with the pace. Especially if you are an outside hire. Training is all on you. Absolutely no one will hold your hand. If you can’t build relationships, if you are afraid to ask ??s, or if you expect to be given a long learning curve, then this is not the environment for you.
advice_management: Focus on building a development culture now. Development is currently a distant second to meeting productivity goals.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Easy to learn. Decent pay. Very gracious with training. It's even kind of fun to shop for other people. Easy to get time off since it is almost impossible to get on the schedule.
cons: I can't get any hours. You basically go to a website at the same time every day and hit refresh until they post the available time slots. Inevitably, someone is quicker than you and you end up with no available working hours. Also, unless you can work early afternoons, don't plan on getting any evening shifts. It's just disappointing. I was really excited to work and it's been a month since I trained. I haven't worked one shift.
advice_management: I think the orientation folks need to be more up front about the job and the likelihood of not getting scheduled. The HR team that provided the orientation didn't say that employees would have to battle it out with other employees for time. They made it seem like you can pick your own hours and would get shifts based on your availability. Amazon hired like 18 people at the same time, so it's almost impossible to get a shift when you are competing with that many people for hours.

After I explained what took place with my HR, she acknowledged it. Came into work that Monday morning to find out I had no job and that I would need to reapply as a non seasonal worker when shifts are available.  Makes no sense to me!!!
advice_management: Better communication with HRs.

Also, too many ambassadors who do their best to do absolutely nothing, while trying to give orders to everyone else. Pretty stark contrast of what I "envisioned" Amazon to be vs what it really played out to be.
advice_management: Keep up with whats going on in the facilities future and let the workers know what to expect, instead of "I don't know" as an answer to every question raised.

summary: "You are worth more than a warehouse job!!"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
- 401(k)
- Health Benefits (Medical, Dental, Vision)
- Vacation Time
- Paid Time Off
- Holiday Pay
cons:
- You are only give two "15-min" breaks when in reality it's less than that. They give you roughly 2-mins to get to your destination for your break and roughly 2-mins to get back to your station and EXPECT you to scan your first item at the 15th minute (if you are a picker). If you don't scan your first item at the 15th min., you start accumulating TOT (time off task).
- If you get 30-mins or more of TOT, you get a write up.
- If your quality is down one day out of the 4 day shift, you get a write up.
- You are expected to reach squad goal of 380 UPH (units per hours) if you don't they write you up for productivity.
- If you get three write ups, your employment is terminated.
- You are required to stand for the 10-hour duration of your shift without given any opportunity to rest your feet.
- If you take a bathroom break, the pods break down, the totes jam up, or if you are waiting for amnesty to fix a problem, your UPH gets docked and it's affects you and can ultimately lead to a write up, even though it's not your fault.
- AM's (area managers), PA's (Process Assistants), and LA's (Learning Ambassadors) stand around and talk but push you to make squad goal.
- They provide stretching that is irrelevant to your actual movements at your station.
- During the holiday season, you are required to work 60-hours a week.
- If you don't work your mandatory overtime day, you can be terminated from employment.
- Some AM's have bad attitudes and talk to their employees in a condescending tone.
advice_management: Treat your warehouse associates like humans not robots. You fulfillment center isn't a sweatshop. Appreciate your employees because they are the reason why your customers get their packages. Without the hundreds of thousands of warehouse workers, Amazon would be nothing and customers wouldn't receive their packages.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year

Kids need to go to Dr.'s appointments, etc. but always felt like I was being judged if I tried to leave early and by early I mean 5:15PM to attend to baseball, boy scouts etc. I needed to do this once per week. No one I worked with had kids so it was tough to understand. Definitely not a good environment for single working moms. In the 2 months I worked there, paycheck was wrong 3 times.
advice_management: No advice because it is Amazon and it will do what it wants.
