job_title: Current Employee - Principal Technical Program Manager
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Best reasons? it's a challenging environment with many diverse routes to take in your career assuming you perform well at each stage. People are held accountable for the most part (exceptions everywhere in life). The bar is high which makes for teams that do strive to operate at a level that other companies give up on.
cons: Careers are made or broken based on the team you join. do your research. And once your in, listen to your instincts. if you feel that you are performing at a mediocre level (and we all know when we are) - chances are it's not un-noticed. If you are struggling to fit in, chances are it's not a fit. If you had anxiety, depression, insecurity before joining Amazon (or any company), no one can fix that but you. If you find yourself too stretched, get a mentor, regroup, take a step back. self-awareness is a blessing and a curse, but essential here.
advice_management: be honest and stop pretending that Amazon leadership has a clue about what your team does. chances are good that they don't. sort out your value prop, elevator pitch and ensure that every employee does the same. if you are struggling for headcount, it's because no one knows what you do or the value you bring.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Flexible work schedule, extremely friendly work environment, plenty of perks, competitive salary, internal training and learning for new skills that will lead to promotion.  Co-workers actually help each other in a non political work environment. Challenging work loads with plenty of resources to help solve problems.  Thinking out side the box is encouraged and asking "why" is not frowned upon.  No traditional dress code.  Products that one can back.  Truly a team environment.  Dream Job and Work place.  This is the only job that I had where I walk into the building with a smile on my face. I have worked in Transportation, Retail, Military, Access Controls, Government, Big Medical and various technology firms, and cannot imagine a better place to work.
cons: If you are looking for a place to being told "what to do" this may not be the place for you.
advice_management: Keep it up and never change the culture

summary: "Good, Okay, or Terrible Depending on the Team"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Stock value keeps going up and up and up. 
Decent benefits, but not the best. 
Competitive pay.
Employment stability- generally you really have to screw up to get totally fired.
Easy to transfer internally, and an internal transfer is often like an entirely new job. 
Definitely room to grow skills and try any new project you would like to. 
Better than average response to ADA accommodation requests. Not perfect but better than many.
cons:
No one will ever complain if you work too hard, and it's easy for a perfectionist to work into burnout quickly. 

Everyone gets so heads-down on their own thing that you have to engage in internal social networking to get people to help you with things that should be part of their job. 

Required "bell curve" stack ranking means that promotion depends heavily on a boss who knows how to play the game on your behalf and will do so for you.  This stack-ranking was made less visible after the NYT article but it seems like it still happens behind the scenes. 

Golden handcuffs: stocks are awarded as part of your "total compensation" but don't vest until 2 years after they are awarded, so if stocks do not go up as much as previously you actually take a pay cut from the year before. 

High team turnover: I averaged 1.4 bosses per year there.  

A lot of tools are proprietary/in-house so certain specific types of learning is not transferrable outside the company. 

Seattle traffic is absolutely horrific.

You also get 20 hours of Unpaid Time Off every 3 months for a total of 80 a year. As of this year it all transfers over if it isn't used by the end of the year. The benefits they offer are absolutely amazing as well. Plus 3 days off isn't bad either.

advice_management: Spend less time training us on things that are obvious, and spend more quality time on things your employees clearly are confused about or continually ask questions on.

summary: "An inhumane sweatshop that treats its employees like disposable machines"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Great pay and benefits, three day weekend outside of Peak season
cons:
This gigantic building full of people performing physical labor has minimal air conditioning, and most departments don’t even have ceiling fans so there’s even less air flow. It’s always hot and humid, made even worse by such a physically demanding job.

They are obsessed with how quickly you can perform your job. I work in packing, we are expected to pack 227 items per hour (individual items, not complete boxes). That’s approximately 3 items per second. The starting rate was only 150, but they keep pushing it higher and higher and setting their own employees up for failure. And they WILL hold you to that ridiculous standard. I was written up for only being 85% to rate. 85% of 227 is not good enough for these people.

Everything single you do is recorded by your workstation down to the last second. This includes leaving your station for something like using the bathroom. I once had a manager come up to me and complain that I was TWO MINUTES late getting back from lunch. When I told them it was because I use the bathroom after break, they told me not to do that. I’m not exaggerating. This company penalizes its employees for their bodily functions.

We get two 30 minute breaks every day. That may sound fine, but BOTH breaks count for travel time. So in the time it takes to leave my station, go through security, get to my locker, grab my belongs, and then go back to my locker considerably cuts down on my actual break time. Our “thirty minute” break often ends up being half that time, if not less.

Amazon describes itself as being “customer obsessed,” and while they may treat their customers well, they clearly couldn’t care less about their employees.
advice_management: Treat your employees like human beings.

summary: "A company with a lot to offer, but go in with eyes wide open."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Amazon is a company where the diversity of businesses, teams, and roles within those teams allows you to explore opportunities in almost anything you can think up.  You are encouraged to leverage your areas of strength to contribute, and you really have the opportunity to manage your career, but you are responsible for managing your career... nobody is going to do that for you.  Everyone I've engaged with has been great in helping me to ramp, but I'm responsible for doing my homework ahead of time and engaging people to answer questions.  This isn't a company where someone is going to walk up to you and say, how can I help you, but if you initiate, they will be responsive.  My caveat to that is that your manager does have a responsibility to help you to ramp, and I've experienced that to varying degrees in the roles I've taken.  Some managers are much better at the "develop the best" portion of that leadership principle than others.  No matter the level, I've found that you are made to feel like you make a difference... because you do.  It doesn't feel like you're part of a big machine even though you're one of many, many employees.   Often I've been in meetings where the conversation can get heated, very strong points of view are shared, and it's very contained to that meeting or that conversation.  People value differing points of view as long as they're substantive or backed by some rationale, in other words, don't talk just to talk... it won' t win you any points.  The caliber of individuals I've had the opportunity to work with is mind-blowing.  You really do feel like you're working with the best of the best.  I love that the Leadership Principles are things we live and breathe every day at every level and not just some abstract or meaningless charters.  These are principles we are expected to use to measure ourselves and the way we look at the performance of others.  I also believe in the senior leadership of the organization, Jeff and his S-Team.
cons:
Some managers aren't great at developing people, and it is harmful to the individual especially when they're new.  The depth and consistency with which performance feedback is delivered varies dramatically from team to team, and that's something that needs to be worked on.

It varies from team to team, but we talk a lot at the company about work-life harmony, but sometimes I feel like leadership and managers are talking out of both sides of their mouth.  It is expected that you ruthlessly prioritize so this company doesn't eat you alive, and that's with any company that is operating at the scale of Amazon.  There is always more work to do and it's the responsibility of the employee to prioritize and to align on that prioritization with their management.  It's also understandable that there are ebbs and flows, some times you're working all night when it's really busy but that is supposed to be offset with times which are lighter.  I think leadership doesn't do a great job of listening sometimes when an employee says, "stop," it's too much.  I've seen it happen where there's always one more and one more and one more thing to do, and management has said "well it all needs to get done but it will get lighter when...", and that "when" doesn't come.  People, particularly people that are new or more junior, I've seen get worried that a "no" will be viewed as "I will hurt my chances of promotion" or "I will create a negative perception or hurt a relationship with my partners/customers."

Amazon is not a company where the word "promotion" is well-received from my experience.  Advancement can mean increase in scope or a new opportunity, but the "path to promotion" is too abstract in many areas.  We have leveling guidelines to help you measure your performance and what the expectations are at the other levels but I've found that many mangers aren't great about aligning your strengths and areas of opportunity to those in a way that indicates when, if, or how you may be ready for promotion.  It is a flat organization, and everyone I know has leveled down in terms of title to come work here, and that's okay, but promotion should not be made to feel like it's a taboo or bad word.  You don't get promoted into a role here (i.e. if you're a manager, you don't go from Manager to Sr. Manager just by applying to a Sr. Manager role), you do well at your level and either 1.  Get promoted in your role and then are expected to rotate into a role at that new level 2. have a current role that can be scoped at a higher level and then they level you up in your role and you can stay in that role 3.  Apply to a higher level scoped role (1 level higher max) and are expected to perform at that higher level for x months and then get promoted.  The con of that is that it varies from organization to organization within the company and sometimes from team to team on how that works and the transparency around that is not great at all. Sometimes people say you can't get a promotion unless there is a role of that same level open in that organization or the team, in other teams that's not the case.  It's super confusing.  The upside is that once you are up for promotion, the process is really good from  my POV because it's not based on one person's experience.  At a high level the concept is that a document is put together where your manager puts you up for promotion and you also have feedback from your partners supporting that promotion.
advice_management:
Create more transparency around the promotion process and the development of employees to get them ready for promotion.  Don't make them feel like it's a taboo topic.  If a milestone for an individual is to get promoted, we understand promotion is not the only thing, but it is a thing, so have the conversation... help us, and be clear about what it takes to get there with, to whatever degree possible, tactical, tangible achievements that help to support that.

Be better about enforcing work-life harmony.

You work actively on hiring and developing more women and diverse candidates/employees.  You've focused a lot on hiring and retention, but I'm not clear on how we're being helped as existing employees on the promotion portion of that objective and what our KPIs are.  Promote more from within.  You've hired the best... promotion is one of several measures of development, so promote.

summary: "Rewarding to those who put the effort in."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Very Laid back atmosphere.  Very accommodating in terms of schedule, you work a set schedule but if you go to school for anything or have medical issues, or if you have a very ill relative you are able to have them accommodate your schedule if need be. Very easy to meet expectations.  If you are interested in learning more just ask your management team, they are always very happy to help with that.  Management is very approachable never in the 5 years I've worked there have I felt uncomfortable approaching a manager about an issue or even calling them out on something.
cons:
If you have a bad week, you get a write up... It doesn't matter how many weeks of excellent performance you've had in the past. 

Everything you do is virtually tracked.  If you are caught not doing work for up to 30mins a day you get a write up that sticks with you for 365 days. time not working is called Time off Task. or TOT for short.

Bathrooms are very far and few inbetween.   If you really have to go bad enough you need to determine if you have enough TOT to sacrifice to make the journey.  and no using the bathroom is not an excusable reason for having excessive TOT.
advice_management: Get to know the strengths and weaknesses of your workers by examining them physically work, not but just researching their work habits virtually.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: You really build a bond with your associates. Your peers are snakes! And political rule the hiring process. If someone does not like you, you’ll never get promoted. Merit means nothing, only how you’re viewed by the senior team. And the logic is “do more with less”. It’s stressful, your personal life suffers. Waking up at 4AM and getting there at 5 AM only to leave at 6PM. Now, factor in your time to catch your favorite show. Catch up with a friend. Go to a bar with your bestie....... you can’t!!
cons: DO NOT TAKE THIS JOB UNLESS YOU HAVE NO OTHER CHOICE!! Or if you have a crappy GPA and need a top rated company on your resume. They hire anyone because they can’t retain people. My peers had art degrees and language degrees etc etc. you are basically a retail manager in a warehouse. And as much as they pretend, they don’t care about you or the associates.
advice_management: Give your managers perks. They work hard EVERYDAY and you don’t even want to give them free prime accounts. Tragic. I hope they replace you all.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
Pay.
Some slim chances at cross training if you get in good with management.
cons:
You will be randomly pulled to other parts of the warehouse and be berated for not knowing how it runs.
No sick days regardless of how bad the sickness is, if you dont have pto or upt you show up.
LOA is run VERY shady here, personally know of two employees that were fired mid loa.
Don't trust Amcare (amazon in house clinic basically) they will do their best to trick you into signing papers stating that any on job injury is not Amazon related.
Write ups/ Verbal warnings are black and white even if you have an excuse for not hitting rate (i.e. Being extremely sick) it does not matter.
God help you if you have to go to the bathroom, its considered time off task and you can be terminated for it, you stand at your station for 10 hours a day and dont move except on breaks.
Depending on your location you might end up doing busy wok more than your actual job.
advice_management: Realize your employers are human beings not numbers, and stop firing all your good employees.

summary: "The worst company I have worked for"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Some teams are better than other, 50% of co-workers are nice. Free umbrella in the rain which is nice in Seattle weather.
cons:
1. No appreciation of individual: you work here you will never feel appreciated. You can be replaced anytime
2. Overwork: there is no time to ramp up and no useful training/help. You will find yourself under really high pressure and work over weekend. Management does not give you time to ramp up, 3 months is considered very long here.
3. Cheap- cheap-cheap: Amazon, despite being very rich company, does not give you any perk, you do not have free prime, you would pay for your own Wine Wednesday/ Thirsty Thursday which is a social event required for your team (yes, you heard it right, you pay for company's social event). Lowest 401k match. There is only one type of notebook or pen you can use. No color printer. Everything is basic, cheap, and bare minimum.
5. If you go on business trip and spend more than $100 (in Las Vega dinner for example) prepare to pay for part of it.
6. Doesn't pay for your full phone bill (limit to 50) though definitely expect you to check email on phone.
7. If your monitor breaks down, prepare to physically ask for a monitor and screw driver and attach them on your monitor arms yourself. IT department here does not support request as such. It is all self service at Amazon.
8. REPORT REPORT REPORT- it is all about looking good ! Prepare to spend 50% of your time in some teams on reporting, since your managers need to look good in meetings. Very little value added work. 
9. Meetings are not to discuss issue but to show/check your work.
10. Overall, most people work for paycheck, the company is so bad that no one is loyal to it, which is a clear sign.
advice_management:
1. Stop trying to look good through reporting, do some actual work.
2. Invent and simplify ! Where is it?
3. Treat employees like human
4. Have clear direction for the business. Do not hire a whole new team to follow an initiative and spend a year later paying another team go undo it- think twice
5. Less expectation on employee- YES, you heard me, less expectation ! Putting pressure on employees only make thing worse. Ppl can't be creative under pressure for reporting

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
The job itself, no matter where you're stationed is pretty straight forward and easy.
The culture is diverse and interesting.  You work with different people often and management is supportive.  Fun atmosphere.  There are some really great benefits.
cons: The physicality of the work can be pretty brutal, particularly for those with arthritis or other bone and joint issues.  Working on hard concrete for up to 10 hours a day is hard on the body.  Pay attention to how you schedule your shifts, because it's on you if you can't keep up.  Breaks are wasted of time due to building setup.
advice_management: Figure out a solution to the 'jiffy' issue and the 'break time' issue.  If you didn't come up through fulfillment to get your job at Amazon, take the time to shadow a few associates in each position to understand what we do and where are frustration points are better.

summary: "Leadership Principles are observed in action daily"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Live by the LPs, Results Driven & you constantly hear conversations in hallways and elevators related to what people are working on to add value to the company.  Pro and Con - they encourage moving around the orgs as early as six months into the job. It takes more time to get acclimated to a role.
cons: One pagers, 3 pagers, 6 pagers, PRFAQs.. Too much writing which at times gets in the way of Delivering Results. Culture tends to foster silos and people not wanting to help their team is they don't benefit from the work.
advice_management: Foster collaboration and remember that hiring MBA folks does not mean they are ready to have direct reports. They need to master their job and develop that leadership skills prior to facing the need to learn their role, deliver results AND lead teams under them. It will set them up for success.  Finally, look for transferable skills from external applicants too. There is already talent in the company, imagine how much more you can have by looking for those with transferable skills.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Culture, Bonus, Stock Incentives, some of the Benefits
cons: Benefits are not the best, no much room for growth for your associates and leads due to the company attempting to go leaner, only for store manager and higher. I've met leads and associates who were recruited with the intention that they would grow with the company only to still be in the same position after two years. Even with new store openings, there are no positions available for them to apply to.
advice_management:
Stop trying to cut down expenses so much that you overwork your employees, impacting the customer experience,.
Give leaders and associates the capability to move up in the company by removing the tier program. Many of your leads have vast store management experience but cannot apply for a position that matches their experience due to the tier system plus downgrading their levels.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros:

- Company culture is a meritocracy
- Company culture makes sense/is logical (which for engineers is important)
- One of least political places to work
- Engineering teams have lots of ownership...no software architects or 200 page requirement documents. Thin product management layer.
- Managers are good individual contributors, not just people managers
- Peer review culture (of your code/designs/deliverables)
- The feedback produces lots of personal growth, and better engineers
- No-one asks you to do overtime/work weekends/etc. 
- Pretty flexible working for people with kids (as long as prepared to commit to coming into office most of the time)
- The Amazon reading and writing practice is awesome.
- Crappy team mates get encouraged to leave the company quickly. 
- Company promotes women and minorities, educates staff on implicit bias, etc.
- The NYT article was completely inaccurate/trash/rubbish/basura
- I could see myself spending the rest of my career here.
cons:
- There is always too much to do...have to manage your time and avoid over-committing. Have to have discipline over your own time to innovate and stay up to date on things going on outside company.
- It's easy to confuse the wisdom of teams (which is huge) with individual wisdom...yes, the people in the room are as stupid as you are...just collectively they appear smarter. 
- Not a good fit for talented people/geniuses who struggle to pay attention/too laid back/not detail oriented/can't be anything other than a big fish in a small sea/don't realize the company and customer comes first. 
- Lots of meetings (that pro about peer review culture has a counter balance) if you aren't prudent about declining.
- Definitely better benefits in other companies. Amazon's opinion is they'd rather pay you well and you buy your own lunch rather than supply lunch every day, for example.
advice_management: - Can take a long time for people to figure out how to be successful and how that changes as people move up. More time should be spent on educating people on success and value.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: None...Glassdoor informed me I had to write more than five words.
cons:
You will be lied to by the recruiter informing you that you will receive bonuses annually as either a Area manager or Operations manager. Amazon does not pay cash bonuses. Amazon pays RSUs when you sign-on with the company. Each year you would expect to get some type of RSU or bonus compensation and this is not the case. Being with the company for several years I have yet to see an additional share or RSU grant. The company has not paid one dollar in bonus money and if you are considered a highly valued on your evaluation you will only receive a 1% increase to your salary.

This is truly unfortunate as many other companies have great compensation packages. When you sign on with a six-figure RSU package understand that this is considered part of your compensation package. Your RSUs won’t completely vest until four years. At this time you will see managers run for the hills not looking back at such a horrendous company. This is why Amazons turnover will always be high. Like everyone else I am waiting for my 4 year vest. On the day this vesting occurs I will vacate the company and not look back. I have seen managers run for the hills prior to the four year vest leaving over 200k on the table. From speaking with these individuals the theme is common...it’s not worth losing your sanity.

Amazon does not value feedback or want any type of feedback from managers. If you have a backbone and disagree and commit you will have a target on your back.
advice_management: Truly reevaluate your compensation package for managers. Bonuses should be paid in cash and RSU grants should be standard regardless of how well the stock is performing.

summary: "If you're expecting full time, keep looking."
main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Good pay
Even paced work flow
cons:
Favoritism, nepotism, site operations manager was hardly available. Anyone higher up than a shift assistant would look down on associates who seek guidance.
No on-site Human Resources.
No paid vacation.
No benefits.
Very difficult to advance.
advice_management:
Offer full time & benefits to employees in sortation centers. Can't expect to meet service when you deliberately ration manpower and have resources on hand. 

People who incite a toxic work environment and discrimination should be dealt with via corrective action instead of incidents, whether they are isolated or recurring, being swept under the rug.

Leadership principles are not the only thing that should matter. Concerns of your workforce matter just as much. Contradiction is apparent of this.

Those with a high caliber work ethic should be recognized, not chastised. Implore associates to do their best, help them where they falter - fill in the gaps and move forward on a goal as a cohesive unit. 

One site's issues does not speak for an entire company but it gives a bad impression through word of mouth. Micromanagement is a serious issue that needs to be removed from the work environment altogether. The CEO should be fully aware of lowered morale at various sites caused by micromanagement. Intervention of HR when reporting issues is lacking.  All of these elements create a formula to drive one to seek employment elsewhere.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Benefits day 1 and constant work load meaning days dont feel too long
cons: slave like labor with unrealistic standards, you can/will get fired for hitting 99.99999% of your weekly quota once. Phones are banned on the floor and they say "because we sell phones and dont want one to get stolen" but they allow us to have smart watches on the floor so my guess is it makes it hard to file a report about the un safe work conditions but i could be wrong . managers have 0 regard for safety and if you get hurt on the job they will say its your fault and make you go back to work, they say "2, 15 min breaks" but thats not true at all, lets say break is at 12:00-12:15, you're not allowed to leave your station until exactly 12:00, leaving early can get you a write up (they monitor the exact time that you stop working), by the time you get to the break room and past security its 12:05, the bell to go back to work goes off at 12:12 and if youre not back at your station working at exactly 12:15 you can get written up agian, so breaks are really around 7ish min long. During peak time expect to work 6 days a week 10 hours for 5-6 weeks. been here 3 months and am actively looking for new employment
advice_management: start treating your employees as a valued employee, not a number in a system, my manager has said all of 5 words to me in 3 months and that was "Hi my name is _______", pathetic

There is a reason why their average tenure is so low now and why the average age of their employees has dropped.
advice_management: Simply treat your employees better.  Mr Bezos you built your company on our backs but chose to go this direction anyway.  You have lost years of tribal knowledge and hard work in the tenured employees you are moving out of the company.

cons:
•Management will dangle a promotion in front of you and fail to follow through over and over
•Don’t plan on transferring roles before you have been leveled up (which will never happen) because nothing you have done in your last role will count towards your promotion. It’s like hitting the reset button completely.
•If you want a promotion you better start sweet talking at least 6-7 people (all various levels) into writing you a favorable review (essay) when your manager asks. If one person thinks they have not had enough time working with you to write an essay for you, your manager will tell you they are putting the whole thing off for 5 months even though you are one of the highest performing members of the team.
•Current employee making about $50,000 less than my peers for doing the exact same job. 
•Stock compensation is a complete joke when you can go to Microsoft and they will pay you double what you’ll make here
advice_management: Fix you bs promotion system and promote when people have earned it.

summary: "Avoid Amazon and save yourself 12+ hours each day"
job_title: Former Employee - Software Development Engineer II
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
1. Smart people overall
2. Reasonable pay if you ignore the fact that you work 12+ hours a day (sometimes even more than that).
cons:
1. No work-life balance - I've worked 12+ hours each day in Amazon. There were a couple of months that I even worked for 14-16 hours a day + weekends.
2. No growth opportunities.
3. Poor benefits compared to other top tier companies.
4. Managers aren’t in Amazon are not to be trusted – 
Your manager will tell you anything to make you join his team and make you work harder. But from my experience managers in Amazon aren’t on your side. For example: During my 1.5 years in Amazon I had 5 managers (yes, 5!). The first manager was the one that recruited me. Back then Amazon gave me an SDE 2 offer although I was a senior in some other leading company. That manager together with his director, told me not to worry. They told me that Amazon give sde 2 to almost everyone, but then they promote senior people after 6-12 months. Shortly after I joined Amazon I discovered that there was no truth in these claims (even if you ranked high as I did there was absolutely no chance for that to happen). In fact, 3 months after I joined my first manager already left so that promise faded into the air.
5. Unbelievable amount of politics -
As I described managers in Amazon aren’t to be trusted. They are all about slaving their employees so they can move up the ladder faster. After a year in Amazon I came to my 5 (and last manager) and asked him about the promised promotion. My last manager told me that in Amazon, if you want to get promoted, you need to “play the politics”. You need to find ~6 engineers to support you. Later on the same manager told me in one of our 1-1s that in order to get his support for my promotion, I need to kill one of my side project and give it to him so he can present it as his own initiative.
There is also a lot of politics on the peers level (which I won't describe here).
6. Lack of diversity – yes, unfortunately that also exist in Amazon. My division had a clear preference for engineers that came from a certain country. All of the managers and senior engineers in our division came from that country. I personally didn’t think it’s a coincidence.
7. Pay is only reasonable if you ignore the fact that you work 12+ hours a day. In fact, strong engineers can find way better offers at every other leading company pretty much.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Working at Amazon is not for everyone. It is hard work. On average I walk over 20 miles per day at work and climb over 30 flights of stairs. The great part is that I lost a lot of weight since I started with Amazon and I have been much more active. If you have a positive attitude, working at Amazon will be a piece of cake. If you’re the type of person that gets frustrated easily, this probably isn’t the job for you. 99% of my job consists of training people how to figure out things for themselves (autonomy) and holding people accountable for when they do not do their job.
cons:
Long hours. Before you are hired, they will tell you that you will work 4 10hr days but its actually closer to 4 13hr days or sometimes 14hr days... During peak season, you’ll work 6 days (almost 80 hours) I don’t mind working that much, but I wish that they would have been upfront about it during the hiring process. 

Sometimes you will have to have tough conversations with associates that are not meeting performance expectations. You get better at the tough conversations as you go.
advice_management: Don’t forget about the “have fun” in the slogan. Working hard and making history are things that we do everyday, but we tend to forget to have fun on occasion.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
-A lot of smart people
-Every day you are presented with a different problem to pull apart; depending on how you see things it can be a positive or a negative
-You will learn a lot from the people around you
-You will have the opportunity to lead large teams and learn how to drive performance through those teams
-Benefits are great
cons:
-Diversity is a huge miss: Female leaders in Sr roles are practically non-existent and minorities are severely under-represented in those same roles; I would include diversity of thought as well
-Not a ton of investment in developing leaders 
-You will miss the holidays with your family pretty much every year
-The culture can sometimes make you feel like you're expendable: there is always someone right behind you that will do the job regardless of experience
advice_management: Leaders need help establishing a development pipeline to  retain talent and make them better.

summary: "They want the best, not the best of the best"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Amazon has a relatively low bar compared to other companies on this level (Google, Facebook, even Microsoft). They offer decent compensation in recent years considering the rapid growth of their stock price, although that's not lasting anymore. They do cool stuff and they are always looking for new areas to explore.
cons:
1. They offer very little compensation adjustment once you join. Year over year salary growth is less than 2 percent. Good performance is not rewarded whatsoever.
2. Due to the relatively low bar, product quality can be uneven across the company.
3. Their offer will shrink significantly as their stock price stopped growing. They have a low ceiling on base salary too.
4. No lunch, parking has a waitlist of more than 1 year. Not much team building culture.
5. Hard to get other teams to commit to stuff sometimes.
advice_management: Focus more on how to keep your existing employees.

summary: "I wish that I had joined years ago"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
I've been at Amazon Web Services for just over a month now, and I am already certain that this has been my best career move to date. Everyone that I have worked with or spoken to so far is brilliant, wants to succeed personally, as a team, and as a company. The Leadership Principles really are a big part of everyday life & conversation at Amazon, and everything stems from customer obsession. Decisions are data driven, and the writing culture is legit.

Amazon is the dream for self-starters that want to keep growing.
cons:
- You will be "drinking from the fire hose" for a while, as there is so much to learn about the culture, processes & procedures, et cetera, so if you do not have a voracious appetite for learning new things, Amazon isn't for you.
- Also, job descriptions at AWS can change rapidly as new products & services are being developed all of the time, existing products & services are constantly being iterated upon, and new opportunities are popping up. If you prefer to do the same thing day in & day out, Amazon isn't for you.
advice_management: Never compromise on the bar.

summary: "If you want to be treated like a number this is the place to work!!!!"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Access to amazing reports and recruitment data.
cons:
Worked on the Workforce staffing team overseeing staffing for a particular state.  From the day I started I knew I was a number.  My boss called me the Friday before I was going to start to say that I need to travel for two weeks straight for training, would have been great to know during the interview so I could have made arrangements with my family.

Had maybe a handful of 1:1's with my boss in which case I was never asked anything about growth or development.

It is a 7 day a week operation and you are expected to work when they need you with little to no notice.

There are many people in the Senior Regional and Team Lead roles who are very underqualified and they were only placed in those positions to fill the hole which makes it difficult on everyone around them.

Turnover for the department is over 20% yet when I gave my notice I did not hear from a SINGLE person.  If you are trying to fix things maybe try asking your employees why they are deciding to leave.  I was contacted by no one so I just left my computer and badge on my desk.

Work environment is extremely dirty.

Pay - there philosophy is to pay low, give you a fairly decent sign on bonus for year 1 (mine was $25k) and then an additional sign on bonus for year 2 (mine was $20k) as well as some stocks that do not vest for 5 years.  It is the way to try and keep people through at least the 2 year mark.  Merit increases are fairly non existent and if you do get one it is in the range of 1%.  Oh and if you leave before the 1 year mark is up you owe the remaining money back, which makes sense, but no one tells you that while you are still there, they wait a few weeks after your end date and then just send you an email which what you owe and tell you it due in 30 days.  

Career opportunity - everything is by level and if you interview for an internal position that is a level above you they will downgrade that position.  All it means is that you have opportunity to get promoted if they feel down the road you are doing a good job.  I am not sure why anyone would do the work of a level above them but only get paid their same amount.  And even if that is the case they need to be telling  employees that in the interview process not at the time of the offer for the new position.  (Oh by the way it will be a lateral move.)

Restructure -- the workforce staffing team went through 3  restructures in less than a year.  The individuals in Seattle are making the changes but not engaging the staff that are actually doing the tactical work to ensure that it make sense.
All in all I think that they have a lot of work to do when it relates to how they treat their employees, everyone is so focused on the next best thing that they have lost sight of the fact that you can't make it to the next best thing without employees.  They are your biggest investment.
Overall this was by far the worst professional experience I have had at any company!  Would not recommend to anyone.
advice_management: Care about your people!!!

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Amazon is a place to work on building new applications. Unlike a long-established company at steady business model, Amazon is always at Day1. This means the mentality of trying and creating new business model, make-break-test attitude is always present. So one gets to see new products/services in production, also see them getting built from scratch. 
So if you are the kind who loves to learn and work in make-break / try-by-doing and if you can sustain the ambiguity around that, you'll enjoy working at Amazon.
cons:
Its a fast paced environment. At times, you may feel overwhelmed. 
Sometimes, some products / ideas dont work and you got to move on to next idea to try. 
People move from team to team, and there could be some changes in management styles and direction (not very frequent though). One got to work around those. 
A large part of your career building is up-to you - means you got to understand how you move forward with the projects in hand and where could be the next building opportunity.
advice_management: I think they are doing pretty good job in terms of managing such a huge company (which grew so fast recently). From ground up, I think there are some replications in products / services. But that too is natural when the company is growing so fast, building new things at hectic pace.

pros:

summary: "A Supposedly Good Employer I'll Never Work For Again"
main_text: I worked at Amazon  for less than a year
pros:
- Good pay, probably at least the 75th percentile for the industry, probably closer to 85th
- Lots of office locations offers a good chance to work where you want to
- Good resume boost (much greater response rate to job applications after I worked at Amazon)
- Got to work on multiple teams doing entirely different things, meaning I got diversity in office locations, products I worked on, and culture
- Lots of smart co-workers. I learned a ton about how tech is developed at scale. Bezos, of course, is a genius. 
- The smaller offices that are relatively under the radar have much less "Amazonian" culture which, sadly, is a good thing
- Stock price is doing well, meaning RSUs are worth more (although if this means your are above your comp "target" they cut down on bonuses, etc. What a great thanks for all the hard work!)
- Very product oriented, meaning you get to more clearly see the business/product impact and motivations behind tech. 
- Non-technical people are especially impressed when you say you work at Amazon. To a regular, non-tech person, Amazon seems to be more impressive than Google or Facebook, even though in the tech world the latter are considered more impressive.
cons:
- Lack of empathy for employees or sense of mission for doing good for the world. This has been a core cultural value from the start, as I learned from "The Everything Store" and other histories of Amazon (e.g., Steve Yegge's blog posts)
- Lots of small, employee antagonistic policies--non-competes (I've seen INTERNS have to sign 18 month non-competes), clawing back 2/3 of that year's 401K match when you leave (and it's already an industry low 2%), 5-15-40-40 vesting schedule with the 40s vesting as 20 per 6 months...compare this to the standard 25-25-25-25 vesting schedule with monthly vesting after the first year.
- Rather stingy/subpar benefits compared to other big tech companies
- Inadequate investment in onboarding. Google and Facebook have 4-6 week bootcamps for new engineers. Amazon...has either a 1 day orientation in Seattle (which sometimes they'll fly out people from other offices, sometimes not), or a subpar wiki you follow on your own. 
- Lots of janky internal tooling that the company has not invested enough in. Again, I hear about the internal tooling at FB/Google and drool a bit. The downside of a tech company not run by engineers, though the upside is speed and business/product decisions are more emphasized so you can learn more about that.
- Frugality Leadership Principle means inane things like paying interns six figure annualized salaries but not paying $25 for a single checked bag on their flights or Lyfts to the airport, no free food but okay with highly paid engineers spending a long time going out to get lunch, sometimes subpar backpacks, stingy $100 annual employee discount only after you spend $1000 on items shipped and sold from Amazon (which is less than half), no free Prime, etc.
- Warehouse Employees are treated horribly (just Google it), and the little antagonistic policies make it clear they'd treat us engineers like that if they could. Dystopian when Jeff Bezos is the world's richest man
- Corporate and bureaucratic at larger offices
- Kool aid/cult-like obsession with Leadership Principles which end up weaponizing them, since multiple LPs oppose each other ("Dive Deep" vs "Bias for Action") so just about anything can be justified or opposed via the LPs. Not as bad as the cult around, say, consulting companies like McKinsey but still kinda bad. 
- Very inconsistent experiences across teams and orgs. Some teams I was on were absolutely wonderful and amazing, others were miserable. This is true to some extent in all big companies but much more so at Amazon. It really is roulette.
advice_management: Adopt empathy as a core Leadership Principle. Customer Obsession is empathy for your customers, but the lack of empathy means high turnover and people, like me, who only use Amazon as a quick stepping stone to get to a company where they actually feel valued. Stop being stingy (I mean uh..."frugal") because it saves a trivial amount of money relative to the salaries being paid but seriously hurts morale (add free Prime, better employee discounts, more swag and company events, catered lunch). There's a difference between true Frugality and this.

summary: "Not a bad job but its tough on the body"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
-Wages are now decent at $15/hr
-Health benefits
cons:
-95% of your 10-12 shift you'll be standing. Your feet/ankles will definitely hurt and there's no seating anywhere outside of the break room. After 3 months I can safely say your body does not get used to it.

- There's a lot of people, but it's a pretty lonely job. You will be at a station repeating some mundane task for your whole shift. The ambient noise of the machinery and the distance between stations makes it impossible to converse with anyone while you work.

- Not allowed to bring any electronics in, so no music or podcasts to make up for not being able to converse with people around you. Hopefully your imagination is good enough to entertain you for 10 hours a day.

pros: Great pay, good exercise, climate controlled facility, great medical benefits from day 1, I excell when I do not have any time to stand around doing nothing- even the peak season 12+ hour shifts went by very quickly for me, though i was exhausted at the end of each shift, I felt like my efforts were noticed, praised, and rewarded.
cons: The breaks that you do not clock out for can be severely shortened depending on which part of a facility you are working in, when I was stowing on the far end- that was 250 yards or more away from the only exit I was allowed to to leave thru, makes getting a snack and having a smoke in the winter time- nearly impossible.
advice_management: Assign specific HR staff to specific new employees so that when one has an issue and needs support or guidance, you are not telling them something completely different every time while also not taking the time to read all previous email correspondance about the associates issue- just like predicted in my first email asking for assistance in resolving an issue- because some one different helped me at every step, the entire thing got completely messed up as every HR idiot redid everything done by the previous person with taking the time to fully become aware of what had already been said and done- which in the end, was all blamed on me- leading to my termination followed by acknowledgement that it wasn’t ever my fault but it was too late for my job. HR IDIOTS!

summary: "Great People, Toxic and Cut Throat Enviornment"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Some really awesome, smart and ambitious people but unfortuneatly they are not in leadership positions. Remote options for employees is a big perk.
cons: Sweat shop for recruiters, poor hiring on the recruiting side. Sink or swim enviornment, training courses are average at best and then you are expected to hit the ground running. This is a metric driven company even though the leadership team uses the words data driven. They look for agency backgrounds so they can hammer you with numbers, pace and unrealistic goals. Leaders that are not qualified to lead teams but since there is so much turnover, they are tenured and trusted. Recruiters here dont really have a path for career development. Pay structure is confusing, make sure you do the research on the comp package so you really know what the number is at the end of the day.
advice_management: Calibrate your interviewers on the recruiting side so you can hire the right folks and set them up for success. Talk to your teams, recognize wins and focus on the positive impact folks are making.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
You work with very hard working people
You will learn how to deal with tremendous ambiguity 
You will be pushed beyond you limits, which can be amazing for some and horrible for others
If you’re lucky you get a great manager and teammates
cons:
The ambiguity of what you are doing can get just overwhelming. You have no control or any say in any top down decisions. You are WORKED at times to the brink of madness. Multiple days where I didn’t have time to take lunches or breaks. Would go hours on end with out eating because I just had no time between jobs. No company car for a job where you may drive over 100 miles a day. It felt like upper management only pretended to listen. The job went from us being consultants to literally becoming handymen. Had hardly any proper training on how to use drilling equipment, had no space to practice TV Mounting or security camera mounting. It took over a year to get semi professional looking polo shirts. It was simply a disappointing experience at the tail end of my time here. 

In less than 2 years I was absolutely BURNT OUT and dreaded going to work.
advice_management: Please listen to your Field Technicians. Implement their ideas. They are the face of Alexa and your boots on the ground. If you aren’t going to pay them more, give them better and bigger offices and please provide company cars. You’re a tech company, care a little bit more about those that represent your organization.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros: You get paid $15 an hour for walking 12-13 miles a day and  working like a slave .
cons: They need to have realistic expectations.  You're expected to be at a consistent hourly rate but due to the logistic challenges of the warehouse environment it can be challenging.   The industrial sized fans were negative and I felt like I was being sucked into a tornado or whirlwind every time I was in the vicinity of one.    HR needs to familiarize themselves with the CA labor laws because when you're employment is terminated you're supposed be paid all owed wages at that time. It's been 2 days since I received the phone call that I was no longer needed and still  haven't been paid.
advice_management:
The shifts should be 8 hours, not 10.   Ten hours is way too long to be pacing back and forth in that dusty warehouse. 
 Also, quit leading seasonal employees to believe that there is ample opportunity  to convert to full-time employment after peak because there isn't.

Reviews-stack ranking, someone always has to be picked to be in the bottom 10% even if they are good performers and put on a performance improvement plan. Politics. Safety is very important and it gets a lot of attention but safety culture doesnt exist due to no vision or passion for it.  Good Sr leaders are difficult to come by, they lack vision, path directive, passion, people skills. summary: "Outstanding place to be if tech is your passion!"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The company, and how we engage with each other, our customers, and community are all grounded in the leadership principles.  It keeps us focused on the right things.  The culture here is unlike any other.  This company truly accepts people for who they are,  despite your likes/dislikes, beliefs, appearance, etc.  Many companies try to accomplish this, and it becomes a "thing."  Here at Amazon, it's not a "thing", it's just how we operate and grounded in who we are.  Very cool work environment, I find it to be quite inclusive, it enhances my work and personal experience as an employee.  I feel like a contributing member of a great community, and not just an employee with a job to do. The support system and resources to get my job done are greatly optimized (and readily available) in comparison to any other company I have worked for.
cons: Keeping up with the expected pace of growth.  But I am not sure anyone here would see this as a con, just a challenge.  I believe we are all here because we want the company to succeed, and be part of phenomenal growth in our own individual careers.
advice_management: Continued focus on how Amazon will grow/evolve, without losing it's core culture,  and principles from which the company was founded.  Engage all of us on the best ideas you become aware of to keep the culture alive/thriving years into the future.

summary: "Fine as a temporary job, wouldn't work here for more than a few months"
job_title: Former Employee - Part Time Shipping and Receiving Associate
main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: The facility I was at was not nearly as bad as the common horror stories implied.  Work was straight forward and area managers weren't as strict with us as you'd ex[ect, which was nice.  Coworkers were pretty friendly. If you're a student that's bored during the summer and you don't want to work retail, this job will be your best bet.
cons: If you're a remotely fit male or semi-fit female, you are pretty much guaranteed to be loading or unloading trucks for 80-90% of your shifts (which is the hardest work imo). This makes work a drag and makes it easy to burn out. There are days where I pretended to be injured during the pre-shift meeting so that I could have a break and have a slightly less difficult role for the day.
advice_management: Hire more people and try to maintain as many loading-unloading types as possible so that some of us can have a break from it occasionally.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros: Easy money, full time, easy job
cons: Long hours, boring, easy to get fired
advice_management: Better PTO system

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: You develop great relationships with co-workers. The work is very straight forward and easy to learn. Pay was ok given the type of work. You get a good workout as a Delivery Associate.
cons: Corporate ended our program with not much notice. The delivery associate program was new and needed a lot more planning. Constant changes during implementation but is understandable given the new program but ultimately was shut down right when we got a good groove going.
advice_management: The management directly above us was great. Corporate just needs to better assess program implementation and iterate instead of kill.

summary: "Awesome job for people who actually work"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Benefits, managers, HR, Hours, growth & opportunities, you get what you put in!
cons: The pay isn't stellar but that's just me, I personally need more, & whining employees saying it's difficult "work" lol, this generation has no idea of what real work is. Amazon is cake! Stop talking to other employees & maybe you'll make rate!!
advice_management: Collaborate more with fellow managers, get on the same page. Nothing worse than getting conflicting orders from 2 different managers

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Overall compensation is great (salary, signing bonus, stock options, insurance).
cons: If you are a recent college graduate- DO NOT ACCEPT THE OFFER! You are subject to working ANY shift (days or nights, and guaranteed weekends at most sites). Although most buildings only have 4 day long shifts, you work 12 hours a day, so this is more than the average 40 hour work week. Along with that, it is a tough environment. You will not have a desk, and be on your feet most of the day.
advice_management: Ease up on the rigid structure of the position- most people with a 4 year degree expect to be able to leave their place of work for lunch once in a while (at the bare minimum).

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Flexibility with scheduling if you live very close / want to be part time.
cons: The wage is decent, $15/hr but you're only allowed to work a maximum of 29 hours and be scheduled for 6 total shifts. Each shift is only 4 hours so you need to work all of your 6 shifts plus pick up extra on the side to even get close to 29 hour max. Often times when you show up for your 4 hour shift it will be cut to 3 hours and there is nothing you can do, you just lose that extra money. And depending on how busy they anticipate the day being, they will send employees home as soon as you arrive (if you want to leave) which always seems to leave not enough people left and you get absolutely slammed trying to keep up.
advice_management: Better training. Too many people are sent home leaving the remaining workers to be over worked. Management doesn't coordinate well, employees are constantly being rotated around the building to "problem areas" that are backed up but they never address the root issue to resolve the issue. Metrics are provided as standards but most of my fellow employees are unable to meet the minimums yet there seems to be zero consequences, and no incentives for meeting the minimum requirements / working hard.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: This is laughable that you have to include this, but there is somewhat a relaxed atmosphere - so I guess it's a pro.
cons:
Everything.

Hours? Don't count on it. Sure, the pay is$15 an hour but you're lucky if they don't offer you or "force" you by hounding you into VTO (Voluntary Time Off). Then they will eat up the hours by hiring more people, and offer only 25 shifts a week and put the shift responsibility on your shoulders when you're fighting literally 50 other people for work. All the shifts that remain open are shifts that no one wants to work and end up screwing you. 

Want a transfer? Forget about it. Amazon will lure you around for nearly a month only to close the transfers at the first of the month and then the positions were filled by Full-time associates before you could even get a chance to be looked at. 

Want to go to the bathroom? God forbid if you do and don't ask them for permission! 

Want to read something put out from Corporate? Time off task and you get scolded like a child who got a bad grade.

15 minute break? Yeah that isn't the whole story. 

Point is, stay as far away from this company as possible and don't feed their pockets. Sure, use them as a means to get something shipped to you but working for them is completely different.
advice_management: Get a clue. Your turn-over margin is not because the pay is bad, but because you are mismanaging not only your hours but your personnel. You lie to your associates about hours, get onto them about the silliest of things and yet you don't lead by example. In all my years I have never seen a group (Yes, we're talking like 10 Managers for like eight associates working!?) stand around and shoot the crap all day and get paid.

summary: "I sort out packages to specific racks with code numbers and when I’m not sorting packages, I manage bags in aisles."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: There is a $15 hourly wage, overtime pay, and voluntary time off.
cons: I have to drive 16 miles every day and back and it is waste of gas.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Great Company with amazing benefits
cons: Work is difficult at times
advice_management: Great work, and great team

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
- Freedom in picking shift, if attainable, thus flexible hour
- Decent hourly rate
cons:
- Management is a barely existent presence, there are a lot of times no help on that front
- Shifts are gone too fast, merely a few seconds, and any availability will disappear
- Not a secure job
- Low moral (because of above reasons)
advice_management:
Is understandable when company want to keep cost cheap. But when one cannot feel certain if they would see the next meal on the table, because of how much work time fluctuates due to competition in grabbing shifts, it just kills the mood, demeans the effort employee put forth, creating a vicious cycle of people dropping out, more stress on the ones that stayed, lower energy, and further frustrates everyone involved.

Try not to use your employee like robots, be a little more caring, effort is a two way street.

summary: "Not what it seems..dont apply if you have morals"
main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Paid Weekly at 15.00 an hour. Outside benefits were great as well for things like phones and car insurance. They offered to pay for your college as well.
cons: Where do I begin. HR is a joke. No direct contact is provided and you will be lost as a new hire. I worked at the sort center and it was hell. Give young adults some authority and it swells their head up like MegaMind. You constantly have to scan and sort packages just to be told you arent making quota. You basically fighting over packages to keep your numbers up so that you arent sent home. Management does not know how to communicate. They are walking , yelling, time crunched people. Flex time ( you stay or leave a hour early or late) is unpredictable. If you decide to leave , at the end of you shift and not stay for flex, this is counted against you. You can only speak to HR  before or after shift. Imagine a line 20 people long.. Parking is a joke! Better arrive 20 mins before you shift because thats how long you're going to wait for a spot! Dont bother bringing a lunch..because you have 7 mins to eat..no lie. If you email HR at CLE05, you will get a answer 5 days later . My numbers were about average but it was painful to see people gp through this( management pulls you off the line in front of everyone and tells you how  bad or good of a job you're doing)..oh the staff..money is the only motivator. Watch you back.
advice_management: You really need to rethink your whole process at this location.Its messy and the employees do not care about the packages..only the numbers. People shouldn't fear coming to work to be put on blast that your numbers are low.  You should have at least a week of HR and training before actually working. Two 5 hour shifts will not cut it. That is why the pallets fall and mail isnt delivered to the correct location.  Its a mess and nightmare. Invest in speakers or an intercom.. no human should feel like they are working in a sweatshop

summary: "Its a great place to grow, but its not easy"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: The culture is like no other.  Leadership comes from varied backgrounds so you get a good mix of people and learn many new things.  Additionally, there are several programs for which you can expand into.
cons: There is no clear path to promotion.  Each building promotes individually and you arent competing against others in your field.  The path to promotion is also different depending on the politics in your building.  Also, you get salary for 10 hours/ 4 days, but wind up working 12+ hours/ 4 days.  During peak you work 14+/5 days at the same rate.
advice_management: Create a path to promotion that is clear, fair, and can be applied across all Operations.  Having it vary from building to building is not consistent.  Consider having a peak incentive pay or peak performance bonuses.  Too often managers sleep in their cars due to exhaustion and because they want to perform at their very best.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
-Simple job tasks
-Can manage your own time through employee website
-No micromanagement
-$15/hr
-Diverse coworkers (age/gender/race etc) who usually have agreeable personalities
-Many opportunities to leave work early without penalty (but no pay)
cons:
-No notice given when laid off.  You will show up and suddenly have no job
-No predicted end date given for seasonal work
-Extra hours mainly available during overnight shifts. Spots are filled seconds after text notification.
-As a seasonal worker, no opportunities to apply for regular part-time at this facility
-Penalty point system will lead to automatic termination if too many accrue. You are given absence points despite management closing warehouse / sometimes you get them for no reason (glitches) so keep an eye out and ask for fixes
-Overhiring and sending people home early without pay
-General lack of accountability since nearly all workers including management are part-time
advice_management:
Good: Thanks for responding to issues with points, devices, lost packages, etc in a timely matter, and allowing employees to work uninterrupted mostly.

Bad:  
-Please communicate with HR so you can tell your seasonals when their jobs are disappearing.  I expected some kind of notice before the job ended since Amazon is an established company.  

-Someone needs to be assigned to do new hire training, not a random employee walking by the group that may or may not have been trained properly in the first place.

-Make sure your orientation doesn't promise PTO (not available for seasonal) and a lot of extra hours (which only 4-5 people get per week out of  60+ employees).  Control your new hire numbers because some days over 20 people went home

-Your warehouse needs a phone number to call.  General HR numbers do not help when employees need to know if the warehouse is open, or if you want to send workers home (VTO opportunities not always posted in time)

main_text: I have been working at Amazon

job_title: Current Employee - Software Development Engineer II
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Work involves continuous challenges, each pushing you to learn new things and innovate. Any field you have on your mind and want to get into, Amazon has it. The easy to switch work culture makes it easy to explore ample options.
cons: Amazon thrives on being customer centric. Given that customer comes first, if your team provides live support, be ready to be paged off hours for help. As long as you are customer centric too, you wont mind it :)

summary: "Cool stuff going on at Amazon, terrible place to work"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Worked on cool stuff.  Travelled the world.
cons: I had 4 managers in less than 2 years.  One manager was forcibly removed.  Terrible pay.  Weak bonus and stock awards program.  No strategy for the future (my group - not other parts of company).  Failure to identify talent and move up or around.  Packed too tight in open space seating. Terrible work environment (seating, noise, people smells). Very disorganized global organization structure.  Was hard to tell who ran the organization from what part of the world.  I received direction from various folks around the globe.  Terrible training program. Teach yourself for the most part.
advice_management: Increase pay.  Ease up on the Frugality Leadership Principle.  Dig deeper to recognize talent.  Give managers power to make decisions and execute.  All my managers (4 in less than 2 years) were timid and afraid to step out and take risks.  Seems they had to ask for everything.  Get rid of the colored lanyard rank thing you have going on now (blue, orange, red, purple, black).   Higher more women.  Do more of the right thing.  Check your attitude.  Implement Tuition reimbursement program for employees to go to college.  Implement matching program for charitable contributions.

summary: "The Holy Grail of Advancement for Goal Oriented Techs; all others beware"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Great for driven, goal oriented IT guys and gals willing to trade technical sweat equity in exchange for career advancement. If you're hungry, oh you're in the right place.

Room for motivated people to grow into new titles and positions within AWS.
-Come in as Data Center Operations Tech decommissioning  old equipment and leave in a few years as a Hardware Engineer( *given that you have the knowledge).

Try to get a contract position and then flip to perm. This is the easiest way to get hired.

Take a piece of success while making AWS a success ; it's a fair trade.
cons:
When employers promise customers bleeding edge advancement and change it's the employees that get cut. It's true what others have said.  AWS seems to dislike their employees and treat them like a necessary evil. That said, this seems to be status quo across all industries.

Everyday is day one! Which means that they act on impulse and drive their employees crazy. If you can't stand change, beware. 

They don't drink their own Kool-Aid . No one believes in the Leadership Principles, but boy you better know them well to get hired. Then forget them immediately. They're only used by management to manipulate, lie, and chastise employees.

You're never doing well or good no matter how much you do.  
You are only either in trouble or not in trouble.

Anyone looking for easy, fun, nice, long term, intuitive, or stagnation avoid.
advice_management: Stop stack ranking employees against each other for modest raises; We shouldn't have to be doing 120%  just to get a crappy 5% raise.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years

I did not get any raise in last three years. Most worker bees - SA, TAM, SDEs, proserve consultants are nice people. I enjoyed working with such talented people but managers and directors are ruining this company.
cons: I worked here for about three and half years. Company was great when I joined. Now its bad. Many useless managers, play dirty politics to survive. Directors and senior leaders in our org can be replaced by rock and company will still do better.  They have no leadership skills. Andy Jassy, Jeff Bezos are good but theirs values not followed by these managers.  Andy and Jeff have no time to motivate workers anymore. There is push for female equality but that just means promoting non qualified women to leadership positions. Long term this is against cause of equality.  This is not fare to hardworking and qualified men, we have families too. There are good female leaders such as Teresa Carlson,  she is the best, deserves to be the leader, she motivates and takes care of her people.
advice_management: Jeff Bezos and Andy Jassy should review leadership principles,  check its effectiveness, and try to motivate people again. Share your wealth with worker bees. Fire all VPs, Directors, senior managers and ask  them to reapply to their position and see if they can qualify. Please review female equality program, its went too far from its goals. Please help your people manage work life balance.

summary: "Don't Buy-In To The Hype, This Company Is **NOT** Fun To Work For"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Great health coverage; stock options; strong salary; encouraged to think outside the box; always looking to improve
cons: you are literally treated like slave labor.  You're expected to be there 60-90 minutes before shift starts and you are routinely staying after shift for 60-90 minutes to submit numerous reports.  Your work day ends up being an average of 12-14 hours;  you will have numerous unreasonable expectations put on you;  they will force you to "motivate" and "engage" your employees, while senior leadership does NOTHING to motivate you; their motto of "work hard, have fun, make history" is a complete joke.  They suck any fun whatsoever out of the job by always criticizing performance; hourly associates get 3 breaks during the shift, but managers are discouraged from ever taking breaks.  You are expected to be out on the floor the entirety of the shift.  They completely take managers for granted and never encourage them to take a few minutes break.  In general, BEWARE of this company.  Know what you are getting yourself into.  And don't buy-in their BS hype.
advice_management: Stop taking your managers for granted.  Encourage them to take breaks during the shift to refresh and recharge.  Stop micro-managing every single detail.  Motivate and engage your managers before you preach to them to motivate/engage their hourly associates.  Actually hold monthly 1 on 1's with your managers instead of making excuses.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years

-The schedules are set, meaning there are no changes on start time from day to another, it stays the same that you are scheduled to work.

-3 days off

-plenty of time to use to take off from work
cons:
-during peak season (thanksgiving-christmas) expect to work 50-60 hours every week.
which is 5-6 days straight in a row

-Time to take off from work has to be accrued. (example:3.5 hours of vacation per paycheck) which isn't a lot since 1 work day is 10 hours.

-you will work most holidays if it falls on a day you are normally scheduled to work

-some holidays are paid at the same rate as a regular work day and not at an overtime rate

-the 10 hour work days can be pretty long

-its physically demanding
advice_management: Be brave, stay wild, we'll see you on the next adventure.
