summary: "Great if you get a tier 4 position, Not so great if you are a tier 1"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros:
48 hour of PTO for a year as a tier 1 More for tier 3 and above. 
40 hour of vacation time, increased each year. 
New 15$ base pay for tier 1. Mean less chance of getting fired since they got rid of seniority pay and now everyone is a the same level. 
UPT time that you can used at any time. 
After staying for a year you can take certain classes for certain job field that amazon will pay for you. (up to 95%)
cons:
Favoritism (promotion, position transfer, peak prize, "random drawing") 

Safety is preached but it not truly carried out. The warehouse is generally messy and dirty. 
Funny story, tier 1 now only get 2 gloves for a 4 day work week but during peak people worked 5 to 6 day a week. So people had to wash their gloves or waste time asking manager (4) or pa(3) to get a new pair of gloves. 
Funny story 2 Tier 5/6 manager make FSI but they don't actually try to make sure the building is clean, they do it asap so they can go home 

Rate- If you don't make rate you get a write up. Multiple write up mean termination. Plus Amazon goal isn't actually to keep tier 1 associate for long term, thus Manager (4) don't have any ability to incentives (lack of prize, fund, free food)  or motivate associate beside fear of being fired. Plus no one actually follow the amazon way of doing thing  100%  in certain path since you can't make rate if you do.  So when the manager do a audit and see how you are doing everyone has to do the "safe and 100% amazon way" but then go back to the rate way. It a joke how everyone know the process is strange but the manager have to do the audit since it a part of their job and it make no sense rate wise or safety wise.  

Promotion - Even though theoretically it suppose to be 60% promote within and 40% outside hire. The opposite is true hence low morale. If you do well at your job it unlikely you get a promotion or a transfer to a different job path. Even though the GM(8) and the board states if you have a  college degree you can apply for a tier 4 manager position, it very unlikely. Amazon expect if you come into amazon as a tier 1 you have to move up the ladder as a tier 3 then to a tier 4 etc. (they don't tell you on the website or anything, a manager told us that) It more likely for someone to leave amazon get a degree and then come back to get a tier 4 faster then someone to get promote from a tier 1. The fastest from tier 1 to tier 3 then a tier 4 is 2 and half year but you have to know people. Most people who started Miami and Orlando 2018 building were either new college hire or those who worked for amazon for a few month, left and got a degree in whatever and then came back and got hired as a tier 4. PA3 people tend to stay in position for a long time and  tend to teach the new college hire tier 4 how to do their job and for most of the time are actually the one running the team. Few are ever promoted to tier 4 since amazon tend to keep people who do their job well in same position for years instead of promoting them. Hence getting a tier 3 position take time but staying as a tier 3 and waiting for a tier 4 promotion from within the company is even longer. 

Culture- Amazon Organization Behavior  is really strange. Since Manager and above (4-8) stress high productivity but don't have any mean or wiliness to give anything for tier 1 & 3 when team and building performance is reach or goes above quota. Only thing that is given is empty praise. Our team is number 1 or out building is number 1 in the network etc. Plus teamwork is stress but those who go above don't get promoted instead they are usually stuck in position for years.   Indirect role path people  are treated worst incentive wise  even though they are key to success to those in path. Of course amazon consider those people to not actually help amazon making money doesn't help. 

peak- schedule is confusing and can be different from the online schedule and what is stated in the building. Tier 1/& 3 have to be extra careful to follow the exact schedule cause if you miss a day you lose time. If you work an extra day and it add up to more then you are allowed to worked in a week you get a write up 

HR is nice to certain people, but it doesn't always show mercy when some people have a medical issue, and  thus they are fired.  Plus they aren't great at setting up the schedule.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: You get to work a a couple miles from the beach.  That is it. No free lunch, no annual bonus, a 401k you will only see when you have finally finished your 3rd year.   You never even have time to go to the beach at all.
cons:
Amazon Alexa hires engineers fast, work you like a horse and then when you eventually get burntout, and believe me when I say you will, you will either leave to one of the other silicon valley companies (in which Amazon does no vest your stocks, 401k, or relocation package) or you will get fired from the organization for "under performing.

I have seen engineers whom just got out of ivey league schools get fired, I have seen young adults whom just bought a home close to the office get fired, and I have seen father's of multiple children get fired.

Amazon creates a toxic culture where you are just trying your best to out perform the weakest link on your team and so because you don't want to be the weakest, you either keep pushing or you get burntout and go elsewhere.   I have seen women crying at their desks from the stress they are being put on from micromanagement, living in shared housing to afford Bay area cost of living. 

There are daily stand up meetings where you have to announce to the team all the things you are working on, and they vote on how much your workload is truly worth.  It's just another way for management to give you more work without you fighting back.

Company holidays and team building events are very minimal, Amazon is really great at being as frugal and cheap with their employees.

Break room is filled with junk food that you will get hooked the first month and then won't ever eat because you know it's bad for you 

Not a friendly environment, when you get hired you will be in an exciting, ambitious, enthusiastic mood that will give you the motivation to work hard, but a year into it you will see how many people leave and how many people are asked to leave.  Amazon doesn't mind because they get the most amount of value from you for the least amount of money.  This is what the Alexa organization is all about.

I worked an entire year and I didn't even get a salary increase, none. Not even adjusted to inflation, it's really demoralizing and I am at a point where me and others are studying to interview with Google, Facebook, Microsoft, and Apple.
advice_management:
Talk to your team about promotions before they get burntout and are right about to leave.  Too often I see people get promoted and then leave to another company 2 weeks later because you didn't offer I until they told you they got an offer from another company.  Pay your valued employees more, and if that is too difficult, at least have catered food for lunch.  I mean for the cost of like $10 a person in the office, people will give way more of that back during their lunch break at their desk or after they had lunch. If that is too expensive at least have healthier options in the kitchen.  Please show this to executive management to get more funding for this organization.  Alexa is a long term goal, don't take small gain short cuts.

Please show this to Rob Williams.

summary: "Suspended but it took my Upt hours...."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros: I rather rerate after my issue is solved
cons:
Hard to get HR to do anything to help resolve issues
I had problems with the postal office because I didn't receive my SS card in time for my (90 day from hire  i9 document hand in) . Even though I kept putting effort to obtain it . I turned in receipt record from social security administration as proof of applying over n over upon each 14 days no card in mail  senario . What's really upsetting is they suspended me on my first day off of the current work schedule and did not notify me . I had to find out by showing up for my shift 3 days after that , and  my badge not working to get in  . that very same day I had just gotten my ss card I turned it in HR HELPED ME FIX MY BADGE AND took physical copies of my ss card she EXCUSED TWO DAYS BECAUSE she SAID IT WOULD TAKE 48 HOURS TO LIFT MY SUSPENSION. SHE COULDN'T RETURN MY UPT THAT WAS TAKEN OUT SHE SAID SHE WOULD DO IT ONCE THE SUSPENSION WAS LIFTED. suspension SHOULD BE EXCUSED!  I returned to work 2 days later to trying to clock in for my shift and it saying associate inactive
I talked to HR again they said they didn't get my document , what the f....
I returned in my i9 document HR Manager scanned it in and said 24-48 hours  suspension should be lifted


they took all my hours of upt so much so that I was negative in hours.
I can work now but really can't because I don't like confrontation. I have PTSD I shouldn't be stressed out to the point of taken vto to try and reslove the matter of give me my Upt hours back so I am not so stressed out about possible confrontation of your fired conversations in my future stand up meetings.  I feel very discouraged by The lack of human kindness, respect and understanding in this company.
They are all for the customer not the associate teir 1s
It's sad but true 
Anyway still in -s in Upt hours dunno what to do.
advice_management:
Respond to your employees that work hard for you .
And show some respect to all of your employees, but especially those who have mental health problems but still work for you. Don't make associate's mental health deteriorate further because of your HR staff neglect their responsibility to communicate exactly what it is that is going on and help resolve the issues of your employees.

The atmosphere here is pretty light as well. Nerf wars tend to break out every so often. But when there is work to be done, it is eyes forward!

advice_management: Keep going -- it's working and the things that aren't, we'll fix :)  One suggestion: be more flexible about vacation versus salary -- coming from another company where I had more vacation, I'd have taken less compensation to have closer to my previous vacation. And rested employees work harder when they're in the office than tired ones.

A chance to be part of a big change in our society
cons:
The perspective on the company differs with the team and location
Too much change invokes falls sense of progression while never addressing the issues
Basic lack of human respect in the sense that responses are canned, there is no time for genuine engagement, all levels are disposable in the fast-paced environment
Management is more like a supervisor job in the sortation centers.
Core values sound ideal and are poorly manifested in daily life.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time
pros: 4day 10hr work shift  and tuition. reimbursement
cons: hard to meet the percentage required.  after the 3rd write up they let employees go instead of finding a different department that fits better. when an employee gets injure they don't accommodate and if they accommodate they accommodate them in the same department that they got injured .  they don't take in consideration that the employee won't be able to perform their 100% therefore, it makes it hard to meet their percentage quota.  also they lose their stocks if placed on a medical leave or leave for absence.
advice_management: Accommodate employees that get injured at the job in other departments.  Don't take away their stocks. Accommodate those employees that got injure to the 1st half of their shift instead of their last half of their shift

summary: "Easy to get fired , worst healthcare ever"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Chill environment, 3 days off is great I guess ,work life balance was good at least where I was at they gave me a set schedule
cons: The healthcare was horrible, why should I save money on a health savings account, then pay a 1500-3000 dollar deductible just to go into my own savings account to pay for medical bills makes no sense also it's easy to get fired , this job isn't stable at all, yet bills come every month weither your employed or not ,
advice_management: Amazon has the worst job security, increase the job security here, most people been at Amazon for less than 2 years and get fired , I don't know why amazon offers a 401k retirement plan when they don't even give anybody the chance to retire at Amazon  ? Smh, the culture is horrible here ,they even give employees 5,000 dollars to quit, it's like they advertise you to stop working at Amazon eventually, , why can't you be like every other company and hire people to let them stay forever as long as they have a positive attitude

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: The pay is pretty decent and I love the insurance. They will pay for school, they offer vocational classes in CDL. They pay for a lot of different schooling, and vocational classes. They give the employee's a lot of time off.  HR is extremely helpful in almost every aspect. I definitely believe Jeff Bezos is a very smart business man. If you show up for work on scheduled time, make expected rate and not have a lot of time off task,  then you have potential  of opportunity in growing with amazon. Great place! Wish I had began working for Amazon a long time ago. One last thing, veterans are looked upon highly in the company.
cons: The managers change quite often. Everyone is looking for the best idea to get the best outcome and it's encouraged to be the one with the next greatest idea in management.  There is a lot of change in the air all the time, so if you're not flexible, you might not happy there.
advice_management: When an employee is struggling in one area, get in there and get involved. Find out the obstacles for their employee, not just look at numbers, give warning and right ups. That stuff is very important of course, but interaction will go a long way.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Interesting work, everyone has heard of the company and it has a good reputation.   Lots of flexibility to explore  interesting technical solutions.  Coworkers are generally of high caliber and quick to take action.
cons: Difficult to get hired as a technical woman.  Difficult to move up in a technical position if you are not a man.   After watching hundreds of people get hired, the women are universally hired ~1 level lower than men of equal tenure and skill.  On the plus side, there is never a line at the ladies room!
advice_management: Earn Trust!  Share the  measurement of and data related to Leadership Principle "Hire and develop the best".   I wish I had known that my manager had never promoted a woman to a senior manager position.  HR just says "diversity is a problem" but no data.  Twice a year, this problem gets worse when all promoted individuals are men.   Employees have learned that they can get overcome institutionalized barriers by  "boomeranging" -  joining the company, get a good reputation, leave for a year and come back at a higher grade than when they left.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year

cons: Not much room for improvement
advice_management: 10 hours a day for four days straight isn’t that bad at first glance. Let people listen to music while working and have longer breaks like just one hour instead of two 30 minute breaks since it takes a while to walk to the break room. I get the whole no phones on the floor thing but offer some kind of way to let people have some kind of MP3 player to at least get them through the days instead of the sound of conveyer belts and automation.

summary: "They deal with you not as human, they want you to be a robot"

cons: Insane company, associates are getting treated so badly and disrespectfully. They have the high amount of turnover rate, every day there is hiring and firing. They can play easily with anyone's future.  For peak season they hire so many people, as soon as it is over, they put a rough target that no human being can meet it, so they can fire them back, with due respect to all human being, I see that amazon is using people like toilet paper, wipe off and through away, that is all.
advice_management: Amazon has got a big name, I am not sure if anyone has ever did an investigation on what is going on with the associates there?  I would highly recommend an investigation to be done on how staff getting treated in this company.

summary: "A Job, At Least For A While"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Coworkers are generally the best part of Amazon. 

For how easy it is to get in (usually), the pay is rather alright.

The work isn't especially difficult.
cons:
Performance is measured by scan rate, which means people who can't keep up aren't especially likely to get further training or transfers. Indirect work can play a part in your performance, but your supervisors have to take notice.

While the work isn't difficult, if you have wrist/hand problems some if it can definitely get taxing if you try to keep up with rate on certain jobs.

Amazon isn't especially transparent about a lot of the rationale behind policy, and don't always provide truthful answers. Whether or not that is policy or the person being misinformed isn't clear.

While process assistants (essentially your direct supervisors) do help at times with work, they aren't very hands-on with their help a lot of the time. This wouldn't be a problem, but the various floor managers (the level above process assistants) claim that their job is to be hands-on with employees. There's either a disconnect here or "hands-on" is less than you'd think.
advice_management:
Increase transparency with policy decisions
Listen to employee feedback that isn't strictly positive

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: If you convert over as a Amazon worker the benefits are ok. You can work over time if necessary
cons: Long hours. You are on your feet for very very very long. You can walk from 15 to 20 miles per day depending on the amount of people there. If they give VTO out to everyone then you are screwed if you stay. You will be sent all over the warehouse. The pay sucks they take out around 200 dollars from your pay check. Also if you are off task you will be questioned about what you were doing at a certain time of the day. You get 2 write ups and your out. You can be off task for 30 mins per day. Anything over that expect to get questioned about your where about.
advice_management: Try to take the workers feelings into consideration. We are on our feet all day walking 15 plus miles. So when it comes to being off task take into consideration the size of the warehouse. It takes around 5-7 minutes to get to a certain spot on whatever floor the scanner randomly sends you to. Also you should talior everyone's height to what bin they will be picking from. If you are short send them to a floor where they will not have to get a ladder for every pick. This will save time! And the same goes to taller people. Do not have them picking from bin a-c for every pick. Those bins require alot of bending down and its really taxing on your body and back!

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Benefits were great! Associates work really hard to meet customer demands. Customer service is top of the line.
cons: Amazon warehouse in Tampa have a lot of deep-seated issues. Very prejudice and only seek to work with employees if they are favorites. Very distasteful place to work for. I imagine the whole company is not like this; however, leaders above the warehouse level need to investigate and observe management and employee relations on the warehouse level. No work-life balance; they work you until you are sick and unable to work there. No opportunity to grow with fake, non-value added projects.
advice_management: Encourage and develop your employees that work hard instead of target them and put them down.

summary: "If you get hit by a bus they wouldn't know they'd just fire you for not working enough."
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros:
*Flexible Schedule sometimes
*Can cancel 48/24 hours ahead of time.
cons:
You have to get all your hours at selected times like piranhas during dinner time it is a feeding frenzy. 

There isn't enough hours, so you are unintentionally cannibalizing others when you get a good week . 

They want to  utilize a permanent underclass to always be desperate enough to work the mind-numbing, soul deadening job where they will reduce you to metrics that alone get to determine.
advice_management: Please hire competent mangers that actually care about human well being.  This place is a mad house for the underprivileged. Not only do very few white people work here, You have people that are clearly mentally ill. Please tell corporate that exploiting the mentally ill is bad. I get that you hired select groups like deaf people to inoculate you from criticism. All well and good but I have heard people explain their serious problems to managers at full volume that is deflected to please work harder.  Stop exploiting the only class of people that keep showing up to this job. Mackenzie Bezos is my hero, she is actually going to get money out of Jeff which is something his workers could never do.

summary: "A job that expects a lot and also gives a lot"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros:
Pay/benefits are great! Plenty of insurance options and Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) give you plenty of reason to stick around

It's Amazon! Feels good to work for a company that's changing the world.

Amazon isn't afraid to change processes that aren't working. "That's the way we've always done it" is never a valid reason, so we're always trying to change our processes for the better

If you're in management, you'll learn a lot about leadership in a short amount of time
cons:
Definitely high-stress, especially during peak season (Black Friday to Christmas)

Sometimes you'll have to come in for overtime if you're a salaried manager
advice_management: If you're new, try to learn a little about the process each day. Also take time to introduce yourselves to your associates and show them you care about their well-being! If you learn your area and get the trust and buy-in of your workers, you'll go far!

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year

cons: No work life balance. Long hours (12-15) on average 6 days a week. During PEAK (up to 16 hours) preferably 7 days a week. The company retention is horrible. People, health, and safety are put last. Very racist environment, and leaders are extremely unethical. It's all about making numbers, at whatever cost.

pros: They give prizes, shirts, amazon cups. Christmas food was ice
cons: The quota that is required to meet is nearly impossible. Job must be performed with using standards that are difficult and I was written up for making 7 mistakes out of 9000 items. The workroom floor is huge and you barely have enough time to eat lunch or even take breaks. People would literally run to try to get to the microwaves or get to their cars to make phone calls.  They have adolescents as supervisors who don't know how to deal with people of different generations. They treat older people horribly. There were like 5 time clocks and over 60 people trying to clock in. It was like a zoo. I would compare this job to a sweatshop.
advice_management: Get managers that are competent to do their job and allow time to actually get to the breakroom for breaks. There should be more time clocks.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
+ Strongly customer driven
+ Utilize the best in class technology to build solutions, with keeping a keen eye on timelines and agility
+ Work with the best of talent on the planet or increasingly diverse and hard problems
+ High pace of innovation and delivery, so as to meet customer needs the fastest
+ Excellent opportunities to work independently, have huge impact and drive your career growth
+ Good amount of internal mobility
cons: - Amazon deals with a lot of baggage that is mainly driven by external perceptions. Amazon is a large company and therefore not perfect. In fact I do not believe perfect exists. But nevertheless, if you cut through all the noise, we are running a successful business that continuously provides immense customer value. We work hard to attain that trust and it can be hard. But we all share the vision and help each other to get there.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros: Great benefits and office space
cons: If you are planning to work for the Amazon Fashion team specifically in NY...run far away! The people in this part of the organization are the worst senior leadership I've ever seen. Certain people do what they want, show up to work at 11AM, and work from home every week, while others are held to totally different standards. The team also has no idea how to use technical tools and they are seriously lacking more analytical minds. You will also have no job security with the amount of constant restructuring this company does.
advice_management: Set a better example for your team members...if you want your team to work hard you should also show up to work at a reasonable time once in a while. You should also stop gossiping about your team members to other managers as it looks extremely unprofessional and word gets around.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros: Empowered to make decisions. Anyone can have an idea, regardless of level, and work to get it implemented. Things move and change quickly and there is openness to think big. Employees are encouraged to think what is possible vs. what has been possible before.
cons: Little to no career development. Experience depends largely on your specific manager and team, as there is little company culture that is cohesive across the organization. Expectations are often unclear and potentially unrealistic. Employees are incentivized to take credit from others or cut others down in order to make themselves seem more valuable or better than others. This creates a culture that is not conducive to training, sharing experiences or working together to achieve goals.
advice_management: Focus on creating an inclusive culture and valuing employees.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Good pay, smart coworkers, good insurance
cons: HR is out to protect the company and not the employees. Be careful of Restricted Stock Units awarded as a % and not an exact number.
advice_management:
Many of your employment contracts state for Restricted Stock Units “x% vest on the 15th of the month of your 1 year anniversary”. However, what you do not make apparent is that when the % inevitably includes partial shares, those shares round down. For example, if you are awarded 150 RSUs like I was, on year 1, your 5% vested amount is 7.5. This is then rounded down to 7 and then taxes, fees, and commissions are taken from that. I can imagine this has a bigger impact for those new hires who get a lower RSU allocation. For me, at the time of vesting, this 0.5 of a share was valued at $1,100 and was not a minor oversight. The feedback from HR was that “this is how it’s always been done”. There was nothing in the contract allowing for this, and thus my employment contract was breached. I am still working for Amazon, but can say I’m very unhappy with the way it was handled by HR and would expect better from such a large company with many lawyers. It became apparent to me that HR was more concerned about the implications of what correct this for me would be, as they have likely done this to many employees. 

MANAGEMENT: all your new hire contracts should state exact number of vesting shares, and not a percentage. 

NEW HIRES: require that your employment contract lists the exact number of vesting shares and not a %. This will avoid all surprises. I work in the Seattle office, so I can’t guarantee what employee contracts look like in other offices, but all potential new hires should be aware.

advice_management: Gave me no choice but to quit due to illness because HR was unwilling to excuse my sickness. You lost a great employee due to a random uncontrolled sickness. Seems unfair to both sides and management should be more considerate.

They never did, my upt went negative, and when asked when it was going to be taken care of, I was told "Everyone's upt is low, so you'll just have to wait." In general, people don't want to bond and it's a very individualistic culture. Not much diversity. The tools you'll use are all internal tools, so they won't be useful in your next job.
advice_management: Start hiring UX Designers that focus on UX and not UI. Start hiring Visual Designers that focus on UI and not UX.

advice_management: Take more time to prepare for the holiday season 2019 cause you all messed up this year. The load up process every morning is an absolute nightmare and I'm not surprised at the amount of drivers quitting by the week. Despite the pay hike, no one is going to put up with poor working conditions.

summary: "Unorganized, unhelpful, and rude. Do not work here. Do not fall for their “Same Day Hire” offers."
main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Honestly, I’m not even sure if there is a pro. I guess that some of the people were nice at first? And it seemed easy to do. If you don’t have any physical problems, it should be a fine place to work.
cons:
I don’t know where to start. There is the lack of organization, the laziness to fix their problems, favoritism, and the ability to not work with their employees.

My main issue in the warehouse was they (or should I say their “random generator”) would put me in inbound and have me unload the trucks. Now, I have requested to maybe have me go else where to easier sections of the warehouse because I have rheumatoid arthritis and dermatomyositis (which I wasn’t exactly warned what this job entailed until I was actually started working there). But each time I requested, I got some excuse as to why I could not be accommodated- it’s a “random” system that places me there, I need to get papers signed by my doctor (which I get but it takes months to get an appointment where I go), or the “we can’t to anything about it because this is a physical job”. And I’m not stupid. I think I know by day 1 it’s a physical job. But I, a lack of muscle aching small person, was unloading trucks with the muscle men while the middle aged moms and other girls got less heavier things like small sort or sort slide. I never, if not rarely, was ever put into those sections.

Next, I’d like to point out the lack of training + throwing people all over the warehouse doing different jobs. I get it, moving people around makes it so it’s not boring. But put people in places where they were trained to work. We get new confused people in a different sections and then yelled at because everyone is going slow. Yeah, it’s because no one knows what they are doing or they have to fix what someone else messed up

Next, is communication with team members. I’ve been thrown back and forth between Safety and HR and both people have given me different responses to a problem and get mad at me for being confused. 

Then the organization of the ENTIRE company is a joke, you only get health benefits for working full time but they mostly hire part time, they don’t explain any of the rules and when you “break” a rule they rudely scold you, and to try and seem like a “good company” they get stupid stuff like a basket ball game set up in the work area (not the break room) or “treat” people to some food in the break room.  Or have “cool” prizes. Just stop. Help people with important things first like more pay or health coverage. Then you can go and play games. 

Also, I got the job in a separate state. Once I got a notification that a place was opening closer to me, I requested to be transferred or to maybe work on getting me to a closer location. But all I got was “well, you can quit here, do the whole process to get hired again, and reapply there.” Which it shouldn’t be hard to transfer a current employee.

Finally, I had enough and resigned. I thought I was done with amazon, but boy was I wrong. I still, to this day, get annoying spam messages and emails about VET opportunities or how I have unpaid time off used when I literally signed a sheet to resign my position, handed it to HR, and handed in my badge over a month ago. I do not work there anymore. I can’t even get in the building to complain. And I’ve messaged the company a couple days ago, no action was made. I can’t into the A to Z page to stop the messages. So I’m constantly reminded of the annoyance of ever being apart of amazon. 

I really tired to stay there. I tried to work things out with amazon, but they don’t care, they never cared, and they will never care about any of their employees. Not even the packages are cared for. Most of the employees throw the packages on the belts so “we can move faster” in the 3 hour shift they decided to have instead of the normal 4 hour shift. 

I’ve had a HORRIBLE experience working with amazon.
advice_management: Get it together please and actually listen and help your employees. Also, if you don’t want people with disabilities (like myself) working there, actually tell us what the job description is instead of making everything sound nice and fun on your “same day hire” events. And stop pretending to care and actually care! Once I started working at amazon, I realized how fake everyone was when they said amazon was a fun, caring company to its employees.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Large company,  possible room to advance. Management was respectable.  Facility area was Amazon Prime, majority of packages were light and small. Everything under 25 lbs., so not too strenuous. When there's a continuous flow of boxes, the 4 hour shifts seemed to go by quickly.
cons: Facility was a nightmare to park at. Flex drivers would be in a car line that went out onto the main street. Repetitive, boring work. Supervisors desks are placed in front of work space for overview of production making it a bit uncomfortable. Bathrooms are purposely placed way TF on the other side of your workplace. New facility, so workplaces set up weren't as efficient to work in. Shifts, at times can go by slow if you don't have a continuous workflow. Typical large facility where you're easily replaced. Not a challenging position so can be boring. Pay was OK at the time, but I think it's better now.
advice_management: Ensure workplaces are equipped with equipment & supplies for max efficiency.

summary: "AWS: Great place to work, but not for everybody"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
1. Exposure to cutting edge technology
2. Experimenting is encouraged
3. Flexible schedule (work from home) - except when on business trips
cons: For the most part, you do not get specific assignments - it is up to you to find your specialization, technical challenges to work on, solutions that will benefit customers - in short, you have to be a self-starter! If you like a more structured environment when your manager decides what you do and sets the goals - Amazon AWS is not for you. We also do about 20% of travel - if you cannot accommodate travel, position at Amazon AWS might not be for you.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: There are lots of business in Amazon. It is very easy to change team inside Amazon. I like this "available changing team/role" culture inside Amazon. You can always have the chance to try and work on a new business or a new role without leaving the company. Business teams inside Amazon are very independent. There are 4 times a year promotion windows. If you do your job pretty well in your new position, it is also possible you can get your next promotion in 6 months in your new team. And a clear and fair performance evaluation system is also another very important valuable point I find in Amazon.
cons: No free beverage or snakes in the office. No gym benefit. Limitation in teeth insurance coverage. 401K company matching is low.
advice_management:
Increase 401K company matching. 
Add some other retirement benefit choices.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Amazon has provided me a space to grow my skills set; to learn from incredibly smart individuals that love seeing positive change through their work; challenge the status quo in case there may be a better way to accomplish a goal; innovate on behalf of customers.
cons: The pace of work can differ from team to team, but if fast-paced, time critical, environments are not something that interest you, then I would reassess if this company would be the right fit. You also need to be comfortable getting real-time feedback on your work; sometimes that can be uncomfortable but the result is that you can usually find project resolutions more quickly.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: - Competitive compensation package (high base, sign-on bonus, and generous RSUs).
cons:
- Regional Management team misled early hires (e.g., bait and switch regarding role / responsibilities) 

- Mgmt not in touch with customers or customer needs & failed to drive a cohesive strategy 

- Toxic culture driven by fear and self-doubt (perpetuated by mediocre mid-level mgmt). 

- Little or no support for remote offices from Product or Eng (e.g., someone writes a 6-pager and regional teams are made to force fit American way of conducting business abroad)
advice_management:
- Apply much more scrutiny on Managers (e.g., implement truly 360 degree mgmt feedback programs & actually utilize HR to identify bad actors in mid-level layer and hold accountable > more coaching > demotion or manage out)  

- Listen to overwhelming themes shared by employees (e.g., where there is smoke... there’s likely a fire)

- Invest in remote offices.  Allocate Product & Eng resources to customize regional offerings where needed.

main_text: I worked at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros:
Flexible Schedule

Can easily transfer to other locations
cons:
Limited Number of Employees Allowed to Work: While you do get to pick your own schedule, the managers limit the amount of employees allowed to work per shift. So if they decide only three people can work a morning shift, and you want that shift, prepare to compete with everyone else that wants that shift. Also, they drop shifts randomly. So you'll have to keep your phone nearby in case managers decide to release the shift you want. And don't forget that you're required to work a certain amount of hours every month to even keep your job there. Utterly stupid.

Incompetent Management: Besides the scheduling snafu, some of the managers are frankly not qualified for their post. They will often make mistakes you wouldn't expect from someone of management level.

No Promotion Opportunities: They will sweet talk you during your initial job fair, but don't be fooled. People rarely rise above the ranks of associate at that place. And the managers won't inform you of any opportunities because they want those for themselves. There are opportunities to switch locations and maybe get a different job, but you will rarely rise above the level you enter into the company at.
advice_management: I have no advice. Not like you'd listen anyways.

summary: "advice to SDE's from former L7 SDM"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Great place to start your career, if you get an L4 SDE offer out of college take it! you will learn a ton and it will be a great platform to find your next job (ideally 1 year after being promoted to L5)

Principal Engineers - (L7+ SDE's)  are untouchable in the company culture, if you get a Principal offer, take it - $$$$$$$ a year with stock increase is not uncommon after a couple years.

Stock price keeps on going up (even with recent dip)
cons:
Do not take an L5 SDE position, it is a broken level with people from 2-9 years of experience being judged together in reviews. If you were just promoted to L5 and do not get mid-top marks in your next review (or two) - move on. 

Anger and yelling is rewarded  in some groups

As a Sr. Manager, managing someone's career was not rewarded

Amazon is a great company and you'll get LOTS of experience. However, working in management and leadership here can get VERY stressful. It honestly all depends on the Fullfillment center you're working in and how the culture is. 

If you want solid operations experience at the cost of being stressed a lot, then this is for you. If you cannot take stress well, then consider being an Area Manager at Amazon.
advice_management: Try to set standard work on warehouse culture. We care about our associates, but we need to set a standard on making sure our managers are also taken care of. This not only stems from associates, but also to leadership too.

summary: "Extremely Toxic Work Environment; Rank Stacking encourages Dog-eat-dog Culture!!!!"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Discounts on Prime are Ok
cons:
The bottom line to all of this is "BUYER BEWARE!" AWS is not a work environment you want to be a part of if you're looking for career advancement, a positive work environment, or professional recognition (they even have a patent stipulation for systems you may create, that end up being owned by AWS....). 

Last, good luck with your job search, just don't search at AWS.....
advice_management:
If you are a sadomasochist and enjoy being treated like a overused kitchen appliance, AWS will accommodate. 

The recruiters use a major bait and switch tactic, by enticing the applicants with the notion of corporate "ownership." That ownership gets packaged up in an offer of low pay, 4-year stock vestment, vacation that can't be taken right away (it has to accrue first), then presents the offer as a "short term sacrifice," in order to entice the unaware into the most toxic and highest turnover work environment on the planet. With the average tenure at AWS of only 1 year, the applicant will never collect their stock due to lack of vestment time, turning the applicant's offer into one that is "not worth the paper it's written on." 

If you need supporting data you have but to Google it. There are plenty of articles from credible sources out there that back this up. Beware though because the content is alarming. 

If you are an optimist, and are one to venture where the "sane man" does not, then read on. 

Once inside AWS, you will quickly discover management is directed to work you through the performance metrics. A metrics, by the way that is geared to replace 20% of the staff, even if the whole team you are on performs well compared to the competition!! This is what Amazon calls it's "Peculiar" work environment. What is really creates is a very toxic work environment, leaving the remaining staff to adopt a "kill-or-be-killed" culture, managed by leadership not interested in the people, but driven by that metrics. As a result of this "Peculiar" work environment, the #1 question asked by anyone who's been there long is, "...am I on the DEV PLAN?," followed up with, "are you Pivoting me out of the company?" What a horrible why to treat the #1 asset in your business, your human resource!

summary: "Not the Same Company Jeff Bezos Describes"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Amazon.com is a strong business fueled by a virtuous cycle. Sales growth drives increased network density which improves cost per package fueling more sales growth.  AWS is Amazon’s profit engine while growing rapidly and losing leadership to Azure.  Alexa is strong as well although also looking vulnerable to Google.  With growth comes opportunity.

The workforce is young and high energy.  You’ll find sharp folks in all organizations.  Decisions are made quickly especially when reversible.  Jeff is obsessed with delighting customers and long term in his thinking.  Peers tend to be sharp, but a step down from the other tech firms I’ve worked for.

Pay is fine- comparable to other top tech companies but lower after adjusting for cost of living.  Benefits are somewhat typical with the exception of vacation and sick days.  Both lag behind top tech peers.

The Seattle campus is beautiful and modern.  There are plenty of food choices including a good food truck scene.  The buildings are dog friendly which keeps things cheery.
cons:
I joined Amazon because I found that Jeff’s leadership principles and vision resonated with me.  I find those principles poorly lived at Amazon,  My impression is that the company grew too quickly and failed to maintain standards in doing so.  

For some context, I’ve worked in high tech since 2000 and have worked for three tech titans, all number one in their fields.  Amazon has lower standards than all three.  I’ve seen the worst tech of my career at Amazon.  I’ve seen the worst data, data management, and systems at Amazon.  The comparisons are quite stark.  Entire tech teams here would have been summarily fired at prior employers.  At Amazon, they linger despite low standards and repeated failures.

While Jeff is quite long term in focus, business unit heads can be very short term.  Emphasis is placed on the number of projects  completed in a given year.  (Congratulations on busy!). However, very little planning is done beyond the current year and next to nothing is discussed on long term vision.  Tech teams design to the current years’ projects which may not be aligned with the long term.  Much of the tech work is wasted year over year.

Rapid growth has led to a very inconsistent culture.  It’s unusual to work with anyone who has been at Amazon more than a couple of years. What is valued becomes subjective with little in the way of common standards for employee assessment.  Managers have nearly unilateral control over performance reviews which creates a culture of manager pleasing.  This leads to bad decisions as employees do not challenge their hierarchy.

Hubris is the Achilles heel of any successful company.  Amazon is no exception.  Folks expect newcomers to be awed.  I was, but not in a good way.  I find the company does little to study and adopt external best practices.  

The company practice of raising the bar with each external hire can mean you can find less capable folks at more senior grade levels.   Don’t expect your grade level to change as a result.  You can only be promoted within your current role.  If your boss is not interested in having you as a peer, you’ll have to take a lateral and then earn your promo there.

Some managers do consistently push their teams to their physical limits.  Health and marital problems are commonplace as a result. I’m the longest tenured team member at one year due to this.  The following three longest in seniority are all looking for other jobs.

Amazon doesn’t seem to see high turnover as wasteful.  Nothing seems to be done with managers who have 100% turnover every year.  

Low standards leave little to learn from. If you’re driven by intellectual curiosity and personal growth, you may need to look elsewhere.
advice_management:
There are far too many managers that are not capable of getting into the detail of the work (diving deep).  When a manager can’t understand the work being done, they hinder as often as they help.  They struggle to discern good work from bad and often exhibit poor judgment as they lack context.

Amazon should consider collecting feedback from employees on how well their manager understands their work.  A good barometer is whether employees indicate the manager could perform the role if needed.  Managers with a high ratio of “no’s” should be under scrutiny.  Amazon should consider moving them to roles that align with their strengths.

Amazon should ask employees which leadership principles their teams exemplify and which they struggle with.  They should ask the same questions to employees of their managers.  Teams should also be graded by partner groups.  

Managers should be assessed on how much they can teach or help their employees.   A manager who cannot help their employees grow can do little to help Amazon’s growth.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Excellent benefits, expected to meet quota, good exercise, lots of perks and trainings even for outside the company (theyll pay for you to be a phlebotomist is thats what you want) Room to grow (unless you start on the bottom then you're stuck)
cons: No meant for everyone, very demanding.  Very physical even managers walk 25k steps a day.  Get ready to move.
advice_management: SR leaders need to Communicate better to the bottom.  Such as, Don't set a higher  expectation to keep our floors clean while simultaneously taking aways the brooms because they're not esthetically appealing.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time
pros: Good for people who need part time work. (students, transitioning from one job to another)
cons:
It's a warehouse role. The highest non-management position an associate can achieve would probably be the learning ambassador role (training and orienting new hires)

Some associates are offered only seasonal work. Work ends when peak season ends.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Benefits from day one, you can sign up for dental and go to the dentist the following day, 48 hours of personal time and 40 hours of vacation, plus paid holiday!
cons: Be prepared to work your butt off literally, I lost 10 pounds in 3 weeks,  would be good if I had weight to spare! They rob of your breaks!  I don’t understand how this is legal!! You have 2 30 minutes breaks that start from the time you leave your station and you are expected to be back in exactly 30 minutes but it takes 5-8 minutes to get to the break room and even more to get to your car, don’t even think about leaving the parking lot because there is absolutely no time
advice_management: Give employees a 30 minute break and a hour lunch, we are working super hard to get that merchandise where it needs to go!

pros: was fun to work here!

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
- Money.  You can make a lot if you are willing to put the time in and take as much OT as you can handle.

- Good environment to network in.  With the heavy turnover rake, you are very likely to know one, if not multiple people at your next position. Be willing to use this to your advantage when you start looking.

- Looks good on a resume, for now.
cons:
- You aren't going to learn much because it's being taken out of your hands.  With various automation "tools" are taking the actual work out of your hands.

- Don't expect to last too long.  AWS burns people out quickly. 

- With the number of good people leaving Amazon, word is getting out that it's not the best place to farm talent from.
advice_management: Numbers don't show the whole picture.  If you've got to setup special projects to fix issues that could have easily been taken care of years ago before they grew too big, then you've got a problem with how things are managed and not with the people that want to fix them.  Maintenance isn't a dirty word and shouldn't be shunned until it's too late.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: The pay is not bad.
cons: Everything about the culture is straight out of dystopian horror fiction.

advice_management:
Work on the rating system. I get told daily that they appreciate my hardwork and my effort. I got a reward for being a top performer one day last week, but last night I was verbally coached for productivity. I don't feel like things are adding up. 

Inspire employees to work together to meet goals, rather than compete for the best rate. Lift eachother up.

summary: "Warehouse Team Member (Seasonal, Part-Time, Full-Time, Flexible Hours)"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
-You get paid to exercise.
-Great introductory pay for warehouse.
-Strong company with brand recognition.
cons:
-Off-site parking.
-You are just a number or letters in the system.
-May be difficult to move up (I have only been here two weeks and have heard a lot of complaints about how management has been the same.)
-Not always the most logical thinking, a lot of wasted time and energy.
-Poor communication.
-Not easy to call in if unable to make it to work or accidentally schedule a shift at the wrong time.
-Misleading job posts ( I thought I was getting an 11-5:30 shift Wednesday-Friday, but that was only training.  I have to wait until the post their Flex schedule and log in and claim work days before others snatch them all up. I don't mind doing that, but I thought and the other 20 people in new orientation with me thought we were getting a part time shift, 11-5:30.)
Little to no direction for day to day activities.  I understand the business needs change from day to day, but when one manager says to do one thing and another manager tells you to do a totally different thing or they look confused as to why the first manager told you to talk to them about what they needed you to do, it makes me think there is little to no organization or communication involved between managers. 
-Did I mention off-site parking? Taking the bus to get from their off-site parking to work takes extra time out of your day.
advice_management:
-Get better organized.
-Communicate with each other and then the employees.
-Expand your parking!!!
-Have a way for employees to actually call in, the number you provide only tells us to contact the Manager or HR, which is the only one that actually responds and helps.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time

summary: "Work if you’re desperate for a big four title"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Lots of work and smart individuals. Pretty cool projects to work on
cons:
Do not expect anything extra compared to other tech companies. Nothing is free at amazon. No free drinks/snacks. No gyms. Nothing. 

Different teams let alone orgs have very different cultures. It highly depends on your manager how your work/life balance will be handled. 

I only joined for the name but honestly I should’ve just joined a start up or some mid size company in the bay. 

You will honestly have the worst time of your life here... and amazon knows this. Their stock vesting accounts for people leaving the company early. Do not make the same mistakes I did and avoid this company at all cost.
advice_management: Please take care of your employees. We are not a bunch of code monkeys for y’all. Treat us as actual human beings.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: The pay is amazing as long as you get a block. Getting a block is competitive. The app has a good flow.
cons: Use of gas and wear and tear on car.The navigation is pretty bad sometimes. Customer service is hard to understand and not helpful. If something goes wrong they always blame the employee. Trying to explain a situation to support was like talking to a brick wall. Overall though, i enjoy the work.  I think it's fun. And again.. Pay is great.
advice_management: Get customer service folks that can speak better English. For no other reason except they're hard to understand. Be more personalized. Take into account the pay when you work over the block time. Fix the navigation system. It sucks.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: If you meet standard requirements, show some initiative and an eagerness to learn you will be provided  the tools to succeed within the company.  After 30 plus years in  other fields that never required punching a clock, I was hesitant to begin a new career as an associate in the fulfillment center at Amazon. It has been an incredible 4 months in which I've learned 5-6 different specialties within the FC.  I don't know from one shift to the next what I will be assigned to do. It's never boring and the majority of my associates work hard. While having several specialties means nothing in terms of pay,  It does make me a more valued employee if ever there need to be lay-offs.  And it brings me closer to an advance to the next pay tier.
cons: As my Title states, There's the AMAZON in Seattle with free lunch, an arborium lobby, dogs at work etc...Then there's the AMAZON that I know with things like half working scanners and work areas held together by packing tape.  We could use a little more Seattle in New Jersey.
advice_management: We walk out through a metal detector to prevent theft. But anyone with an employee badge can walk right onto the main floor with any weapon they want because there are no metal detectors on the way in. One could perceive that they value the merchandise more than the employees.  Make us feel safer.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: They recently increased the pay to $15/hr, which is really the main reason why and I so many others applied. You don't interview at all. Just pass a drug test and background check and you are hired. You are allowed to pick the schedule that works in your favor and the work is crazy easy. The people are all super friendly and helpful as well. I never once felt intimidated or nervous. You also can have any sort of look there, no restrictions on that. I worked in the sortation warehouse where all we did was take the packages off the line and put them in pallets to match their zip codes. Pretty much mastered it on the first day.
cons: You feel like cattle being herded to slaughter. They ship you all in at once and you clock in and mindlessly stack boxes for hours with a really sad excuse for a break in between. I honestly only worked one full day before getting another job offer. I am about to send in my resignation right now. You just feel like a drone working in a windowless warehouse all day. It may be easy, but it is very draining. I also feel like I am back in high school with how some of the coworkers act. If you are looking for an easy, okay paying gig then this is for you, but expect to get burned out FAST.
advice_management: Management was super nice and helpful. I really liked them tbh. No problems on that end.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year

cons: This same freedom can be a hinderance to some folks. If you are not a self starter, don't know how to manage your own calendar and don't know how to ask for help, you will not do well.

summary: "Corporate Counsel - 2+ years in, and it's hard but fascinating"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
Being an attorney for Amazon always offers opportunities to work on interesting problems.  From day 1, I owned my own matters, made independent decisions, and worked frontline with new clients and customers.  It's a lot more responsibility than my law firm associate role, and has more opportunities to speak up and lead.  The issues we work through might be operationally difficult, involve high dollar value transactions, or have customer-facing implications (or all three) but each attorney works independently and within the team to solve them.

I get excellent mentorship and training benefits.  There are more levels between you and leadership than at a firm, but there are also good opportunities to work with senior leaders on specific deals, project work (for process improvement, scaling etc), and as an escalation point.  My career got a big jump start by being at Amazon, and my manager is actively coaching me to achieve my goals.  I feel that Amazon has invested in me, and that makes me more willing to invest in Amazon.

Everyone I work with is super smart and has high expectations.  They all went to excellent law schools, and worked at top tier law firms and in house roles before joining Amazon.  You get to work with, and be trained by, the best here.

The leadership principles are very real - your hiring, performance, and promotion, are all tracked against them.  Team members and leaders give feedback framed in the leadership principles, and it creates a common language in a huge company, which I've found helpful.
cons:
I generally work law firm hours still.  Some weeks are better than others, but this isn't a normal in house role. 

It takes time to adjust to this work style and approach.  I love it but definitely needed to stick out the first 6-9 months to get into the swing of things.  Amazon attorneys are serious about their jobs and the leadership principles,  and there's a lot of "project work" for business improvement, so you're always balancing your main work (transactional or advisory etc) with projects that fix broader problems.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The benefits are the only good thing about amazon.
cons: Worthless employee discount.  Unrealistic expectations of employees. Long hours, manditory overtime. Constant standing. They enforce rates on job tasks that aren’t fair and write people up constantly. It’s a revolving door, always people getting fired and hired, like daily.  Your 30 min break isn’t really 30 because it takes 5 mins to walk to a clock to punch out snd in. Sane with breaks. They’re talking about the many ways to be fired all the time, from day one. No ways to request or call off work, not even if you’re sick, no doctors excuse nothing. You get 10 paid and unpaid hours to start and if they’re gone then too bad, you get fired. No discussion. They add hours but not in fast enough increments or amounts to make a difference. There’s so many more cons honestly. But i digress.
advice_management: Learn to manage. The management is a joke, bad attitudes, unfriendly, unhelpful. People arent cattle. Treat people like people.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros: Amazon only hires Type A players and thus the reliability of team work is at its maximum potential.  The results are proof.
cons: Not a good place to work if one does not believe in joint/individual contribution and associated rewards.  Not a place for people without any drive or conviction.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Amazon is definitely the fastest growing billion dollars company. The business is always changes and this gives employees always new ways of improving and challenging themselves either via new technologies, new teams or new locations. The company still works as a startup where everybody is enabled to create and propose innovative ideas, as we always say: Invent and Simplify.
cons: The company still has the characteristic of a startup in terms of un-mature and un-consolidated processes. There are a lot of improvement areas still to work on. The frugality approach sometimes wins over less affordable but more efficient solutions.
advice_management: Management should invest more on growing internal candidates for higher roles since they have a better understanding of the business. This requires more soft skills trainings

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years

Not cut management team so thin that there is essentially no time to develop skills, instead only enough time to focus on overbearing daily scope.

summary: "Great company, but don't expect to slack off"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: There is plenty of good things to say about Amazon. Plenty of workers would be happy with the insurance alone. The lowest end of payscale is $15/hour. As IT Support Engineer I am getting $21.15/hour, above expectations for the area.  Amazon does really value their leadership principles and it shows in their management.
cons: There is something called "Amazon pace." No matter what role you are at Amazon, you won't be lacking on finding something to do! Not a bad thing for those on the move, but if you expect things to be easy, not the place for you!
advice_management: From what I read, Amazon, like most companies doesn't reward loyalty when it comes to promotions, lucky, it seems some management fights for their workers.

summary: "An innovative, exciting company with an amazing culture"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Amazon is really an exciting place to work, you should never have a shortage of engaging work here. I expect that almost every possible type of job can be found here; if it isn't, it could be created. At Amazon Web Services (AWS), where I work, you would be hard-pressed to find more interesting, challenging, and future-thinking technology. One of my favorite things about working at Amazon in general is the inclusion--Amazon proudly employs, and vocally supports, minorities, LGBTQ+ individuals (including transgender persons), veterans, and people with disabilities. My entire management hierarchy, including myself, is made up of women (until reaching the CEO, Andy Jassy, who is male). As a young employee, I feel like my opinions are valued, and that I'm not looked down on due to my age or tenure. If you're hard-working, tenacious, and incredulous, you can find a place at Amazon.
cons: Amazon is an extremely fast-moving workplace, which is exciting, but it can also be exhausting if you don't know how to manage the pace. It is critical to set a work/life balance for yourself (or as Jeff Bezos says, work/life harmony). Management also plays a huge part in how much people enjoy working at Amazon. I have heard of people having night and day experiences on two similar teams, or even the same team, due to a change in management. The process to be promoted can also extremely vary across organizations, and there is a lack of inconsistency in who is promoted, after what time period. You need to be an advocate for yourself when you work at Amazon (but I've found many mentors who helped me grow this skill, personally and professionally, during my time here).

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good salary, good benefits. Management culture for lower-level managers seems pretty focused on making sure the team can get their work done without distraction.
cons:
* "Work hard / play hard" culture usually just means work hard / work hard. 
* Oncall rotations for most developers
* Often multiple vacancies on a team, so teams are constantly understaffed.
* The above two points combine to mean there are going to be long periods of crunch, in addition to round-the-clock oncall schedules.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year

Increase in both hourly pay and night shift differential. 4 day work week. Holiday pay (6). Swagbucks, gets you free items just for working. Advancement opportunities. Career path stock option. Great employee discounts. Many different shifts. So much more...
cons: Nothing just do your job and work when you suppose too. It's not hard, yes it's physical. Yes you leave tired. But it's what you make of it. Only hard thing is is getting use to a two week check. Lol after that minor adjustment, SMOOTH SAILING....
advice_management: Keep it up

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: -Ability to work on projects that impact a lot of customers.
cons:
-Extremely toxic work environment where managers don't care about advancement of employees.
-You are usually referred to as what level you are, not your name.
-Managers often have zero real "management" experience and have no idea what they are doing.
-People will take credit for your work and you can't do a single thing about it.
-No opportunities for upward feedback.
-Politics control everything. People will smile in front of your face then backstab you when they aren't.
-The infamous NY Times article is still spot on with how awful the company culture is.
advice_management:
-Show that you actually care about employees - don't just state it. Your words are vapid, actions are all that matter.
-Show that you care about more than just the top line. You have no idea how much your direct reports get away with when you aren't looking.

summary: "High paced, challenging, meaningful career as an Area Manager"
main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
Great pay for entry level manager.
Ability to start projects that influence your department/team or facility.
Open door policy with top management means that managers are always in check.
Comprehensive daily grading system for all managers that get rated by their direct reports which ensures that all managers are always trying to improve and learn. 
Able to drive meaningful results.
Management really does try improving the experience for area managers.
cons:
Job is very high paced and very demanding which may lead to managers freaking out and quitting; understandable but one should push themselves to take on this huge challenge instead of running from it.

Depending on how well your site runs you should be regularly NOT doing overtime (except for 1 week and 1 month in a year (prime day, Peak season)). Expect 40-45 hour work weeks with up to 60 hours during peak and prime. This will be different for launch buildings
advice_management: Keep on maintaining the mindset that you are not the perfect employer, keep on trying to improve, this will lead to bettering the experiences for all of your new hires.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros:
Pay
Benefits
Experience
Repetitive task oriented work
Easy if you pay attention
cons:
•Supervisors/ambassadors (young, inexperienced in management, condescending, argumentative)
•Scheduling-hard to get a good schedule if you start seasonally
•Differentiating training on daily tasks regardless of how the full group is instructed by upper management.
•cut hours frequently 
•poor training if trained at all
advice_management:
***I’m working PT as a second income and I have management and HR experience. I’m going to be as objective as Possible but this is also based on my experience at one warehouse, others could be run differently.***

Be aware of your team and train your ambassadors so they are able to properly train the team to do things consistently, accurately and with minimal downtime. Be mindful of unproductive people and address the issues. I’m in a warehouse that ships around 30,000 packages a night but if people were trained when hired and things were done productively, it could be accomplished with a third less staff in the same time. There’s 2 hours minimum on-boarding training videos you have to do before you start (Unpaid) that could EASILY include training on how to pick, pack, stow and load a van so people could be ready on day one and already know the basics. That is, if they didn’t give a completely different training on how to do things based on who’s there. (Very frustrating for someone who’s been a trainer). They could EASILY create an interactive training course on familiarizing yourself with how to read the labels etc, the post office does this before you’re even hired to be sure you understand what you’ll need to be able to do. Be mindful that “ambassador” is a supervisory role, and should be earned by people who are at minimum knowledgeable and experienced in the work and managing people. 

All that being said, having an HR background I’ve seen enough to qualify for a hostile work environment case before I hit a month in. (Again, this is one location) Some management figures can be great and some seem to be too immature for the position (argumentative, bad mouthing corporate on day 1, unwilling to conform to upper management training procedures). Others have a lot of unnecessary back and forth with employees ultimately running them off for no reason. 

Overall it’s an “easy” job (you can work up a sweat) that pays good money for what it is. Just block out the nonsense and get your work done. I gave it 3 stars because of the pay and benefits and ease of the job, it’s the same everyday. But those 2 stars down are based on management and lack of proper training.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
You get to work with some of the smartest in the industry. 
Also, pay is fantastic and mobility within the organization is encouraged. 
Fantastic people, great work culture, and a truly inspiring place to work.  This is the first place I have worked where I see myself growing a true career for years to come.
cons:
A lot of people are not always held to their metrics like they should be.  Also, a lot of bizarre hires that do not fit company standards.  

People need to be held more accountable, particularly in a sales organization.
advice_management: When you have several roles to fill, do not lower standards to fill them.

main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
1. You get ample joining bonus in shares.
2. You get to see bureaucrats and then you know how to avoid them in next job search.
3. No dress code
cons:
1. Specially the retail software division are highly engaged in politics. If you want to join then only join aws, kindle, fire tv. 
2. The management in retail is highly political. The high bar set upon them makes them compete between orgs and you may be dragged into it.
3. low salary
4. The management in retail has a target to put certain % of people on pip. They always choose SDE-2's for this. You would be surprised at the feedbacks in pips. Your manager will say it's not in their control, its company policy of rank and yank, etc etc.
5. Lots of micromanagement. In fact the manager keeps on documenting your daily activities. They do not know who will be put on PIP the next year, so they are always ready with the proofs.
advice_management: Actually other companies should stop hiring managers from Amazon. They bring their toxic culture every where.

summary: "Unprofessional environment, managers are not trained well, very dirty building"
main_text: I worked at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Easy job to get, they hire anyone
cons: Unsafe environment to work, very ghetto atmosphere.
advice_management: Drug test everyone again, and start inforcing the rules better.

main_text: I have been working at Amazon  for more than a year
pros: None really, but this is only on FBA org. There are plenty of teams that are amazing, this is not one of them.
cons:
Micromanagement - This was huge, if i was a min late from my break or to work i had to explain why, yes not exaggeration one minute 

Management in general - The left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing. If I would put in a request for time off, which was sent to the entire team some multiple would email me several times to confirm. Moral is super low, and we're expected to hit our numbers 100% everyday. I get that numbers need to be hit, but even a 99% was considered bad. 

Career opportunists - Next to zero, you can become an AA or a Sr. investigation specialist but it really is the same job
advice_management: Trust your employees, and tone down the micromanagement. You might actually get people to stay more than 2 years.
